headline: What Happened at the Trump Trial on Tuesday
abstract: Donald Trump was fined and warned of jail time after he violated a gag order in his criminal trial. Prosecutors have argued that his statements threaten the trial. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump was fined and warned of jail time after he violated a gag order in his criminal trial. Prosecutors have argued that his statements threaten the trial. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.

headline: Even Celebrities Don’t Know How to Ask Their Friends About Ozempic
abstract: When Barbra Streisand posted a comment on social media about the actress Melissa McCarthy, it prompted a public conversation.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the actress Melissa McCarthy posted a photo to Instagram in which she was wearing a tiered, sea-foam-green gown at a gala she had attended alongside the director Adam Shankman. Though the photo itself didn’t cause much of a stir, one comment — which happened to be from the entertainer Barbra Streisand — did. It read, in part, “Did you take Ozempic?”

headline: Law Firm Defending Trump Seeks to Withdraw From a Long-Running Case
abstract: The firm, LaRocca Hornik, has represented Donald Trump’s political operation in numerous suits dating to his first presidential run, including a pregnancy discrimination case in New York.
lead_paragraph: A law firm that has long defended Donald J. Trump’s campaign and businesses from employment lawsuits has abruptly asked to withdraw from a yearslong case over what it calls an “irreparable breakdown in the attorney-client relationship.”

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Hannah Ritchie
abstract: The April 30, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Hannah Ritchie. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Albuquerque School’s Staff on Leave After Drag Show at Prom
abstract: Albuquerque Public Schools in New Mexico also installed an acting principal as it investigates a high school prom.
lead_paragraph: A school district in Albuquerque, N.M., has placed employees at a high school on leave and installed a new acting principal as it investigates a performance by a drag queen at the prom this month.

headline: Democrats Win New York Special House Election, Narrowing G.O.P. Majority
abstract: The victory by Timothy Kennedy, a Democratic state senator, was not a surprise. But it will make Republicans’ lives more difficult in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Timothy M. Kennedy, a Democratic New York State senator, easily won a special House election on Tuesday to replace a retiring congressman in western New York, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Bit in a Bar
abstract: Juliana Tringali Golden nips our worries in the bud.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Federal Judges Block Newly Drawn Louisiana Congressional Map
abstract: In a 2-to-1 decision, the panel sided with challengers who argued that the map that created a second Black majority district was an “impermissible racial gerrymander.”
lead_paragraph: A newly drawn congressional map in Louisiana was struck down on Tuesday by a panel of federal judges who found that the new boundaries, which form a second majority Black district in the state, amounted to an “impermissible racial gerrymander” that violated the Equal Protection Clause of the U.S. Constitution.

headline: Tornado Destroys Homes, Kills at Least One in Kansas
abstract: A powerful tornado ripped through a community in northeastern Kansas on Tuesday afternoon, destroying dozens of homes and structures and killing at least one person, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A powerful tornado shredded homes and killed at least one person in a small Kansas town on Tuesday, as severe weather threatened millions of people across the region.

headline: Columbia Asks N.Y.P.D. to Stay on Campus Through Middle of May
abstract: The university released the letter after police entered Hamilton Hall, a building that was occupied by dozens of demonstrators. Columbia’s commencement is currently scheduled for May 15.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University asked the New York Police Department in a letter on Tuesday to clear a building occupied by pro-Palestinian protesters and encampments, and asked that the police remain on campus until at least May 17, after commencement.

headline: Text of April 30 Letter From Columbia’s President to N.Y.P.D.
abstract: Dozens of pro-Palestinian demonstrators at Columbia University in Manhattan were arrested Tuesday night by hundreds of police officers in riot gear after Columbia’s president, Nemat Shafik, requested police intervention.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of pro-Palestinian demonstrators at Columbia University in Manhattan were arrested Tuesday night by hundreds of police officers in riot gear.

headline: Paul Auster, the Patron Saint of Literary Brooklyn, Dies at 77
abstract: With critically lauded works like “The New York Trilogy,” the charismatic author drew inspiration from his adopted borough and won worldwide acclaim.
lead_paragraph: Paul Auster, the prolific novelist, memoirist and screenwriter who rose to fame in the 1980s with his postmodern reanimation of the noir novel and who endured to become one of the signature New York writers of his generation, died on Tuesday evening at his home in Brooklyn. He was 77.

headline: Paul Auster’s New York Tragedy
abstract: A complicated, generous life yielded a body of work of staggering scope and variety.
lead_paragraph: I first became aware of Paul Auster, who died on April 30, from reading old issues of The Columbia Review when I was a student at the university. He translated French Surrealist poetry and wrote prose fiction, set in a sort of silent-movie cityscape that anticipated his novels and films.

headline: China’s Electric Cars Keep Improving, a Worry for Rivals Elsewhere
abstract: More capable autonomous driving is just one way Chinese automakers are threatening to pull ahead — their E.V.s are also becoming bigger and roomier.
lead_paragraph: Automakers in China are building a new generation of bigger, more technologically advanced and competitive electric cars, threatening to leap further ahead of their global rivals as they step up exports around the world.

headline: He Won by a Landslide. Why Is He Fighting for His Political Life?
abstract: Ben Houchen, a regional mayor in the north of England, faces a close re-election race, partly thanks to the broader troubles of Britain’s Conservative Party.
lead_paragraph: The last time Ben Houchen ran to be mayor of Tees Valley, a struggling, deindustrialized region in northeastern England, he stormed to victory with almost 73 percent of the vote.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Demonstrations disrupt U.S. colleges.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators on college campuses across the U.S. clashed with police officers yesterday and drew crackdowns from administrators.

headline: Swimming Beneath Sand, It’s ‘the Hardest of All Animals to Find’
abstract: Indigenous rangers in Australia’s Western Desert got a rare close-up with the northern marsupial mole, which is tiny, light-colored and blind, and almost never comes to the surface.
lead_paragraph: If you saw a northern marsupial mole, you might be surprised. Known to the First Nations peoples in the Western Desert of Australia as the kakarratul, it is eyeless and has shaggy golden fur. Just four inches from nose to tail, the animal would fit in the palm of your hand. And unlike the mole species of North America, it is a marsupial.

headline: Police Arrest Protesters at City College in Harlem
abstract: The arrests came after pro-Palestinian protesters tried to take over an administrative building at City College. Earlier, the police cleared a building that had been occupied at nearby Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: Police officers arrested dozens of pro-Palestinian demonstrators at City College of New York in Harlem late Tuesday night, as clashes over the war in Gaza continued to escalate on campuses across the country.

headline: Read the Federal Judges’ Ruling
abstract: A newly drawn congressional map in Louisiana was struck down on Tuesday by a panel of federal judges who found that the new boundaries, which form a second majority Black district in the state, amounted to an “impermissible racial gerrymander” that violated the Equal Protection Clause of the U.S. Constitution.
lead_paragraph: A newly drawn congressional map in Louisiana was struck down on Tuesday by a panel of federal judges who found that the new boundaries, which form a second majority Black district in the state, amounted to an “impermissible racial gerrymander” that violated the Equal Protection Clause of the U.S. Constitution.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Delicious Wherever You Are
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It is basically just a standard, not-so-interesting cake. It has a different standing outside Germany as something special.”

headline: Corrections: May 1, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the tactics universities are using to handle pro-Palestinian campus protests misidentified the group organizing the encampment in Harvard Yard. It is the Harvard Out of Occupied Palestine Coalition, not the Harvard Undergraduate Palestine Solidarity Committee, the group suspended by the university.

headline: Drought That Snarled Panama Canal Was Linked to El Niño, Study Finds
abstract: The low water levels that choked cargo traffic were more closely tied to the natural climate cycle than to human-caused warming, a team of scientists has concluded.
lead_paragraph: The recent drought in the Panama Canal was driven not by global warming but by below-normal rainfall linked to the natural climate cycle El Niño, an international team of scientists has concluded.

headline: Blinken meets with Netanyahu, hoping to stave off an Israeli assault on Rafah.
abstract: President Biden is pushing Hamas to release some hostages for a six-week cease-fire, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says he will do a major assault in Rafah “with or without” a deal.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel on Wednesday, his latest stop on a Middle East tour as President Biden tries to stop Israel from invading Rafah, the city in southern Gaza where Palestinians have sought shelter during the war.

headline: Word of the Day: pigeonhole
abstract: This word has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word pigeonhole has appeared in 15 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 18 in “Hollywood Actors Are Leaping Into Video Games” by Just Lunning:

headline: Frustrated South Koreans Blame President in Standoff With Doctors
abstract: A walkout by physicians has dragged on for weeks, as they protest a plan by President Yoon Suk Yeol’s government to increase medical school enrollment.
lead_paragraph: Eun Sung injured her right thumb in a fall in March and needed surgery to fix a torn ligament. But scheduling one has been difficult even though she lives in one of the most developed nations in the world, South Korea.

headline: Late Night Weighs In on Donald Trump’s $9,000 Fine
abstract: “I know $9,000 might not seem like a lot to a successful businessman, but what about to Trump?” Colbert said of the court-imposed penalty for violating a gag order.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,047
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 325
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Prosecutors Say They Plan to Retry Harvey Weinstein as Soon as the Fall
abstract: Mr. Weinstein, the disgraced former Hollywood producer, was in a Manhattan court Wednesday as prosecutors sought to retry him on sex crimes charges.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors on Wednesday said they planned to retry Harvey Weinstein on sex crimes charges after his recently overturned conviction and could be ready to do so as soon as this fall.

headline: The Most Decorated Battleship in U.S. History Gets an Overdue Face-Lift
abstract: It has been 34 years since the Battleship New Jersey was last pulled out of the water for maintenance.
lead_paragraph: The most decorated battleship in the history of the United States is done with war.

headline: Student Orchestra
abstract: A youth ensemble in New York City had an extraordinary opportunity. Would you want to be a part of a school orchestra or band?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever played in a school orchestra or band? If so, what was the experience like?

headline: Police Arrest Columbia Protesters Occupying Hamilton Hall
abstract: Officers entered the building through a second-floor window using a bridge on top of an emergency service vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Officers entered the building through a second-floor window using a bridge on top of an emergency service vehicle.

headline: Columbia Said It Had ‘No Choice’ but to Call the Police
abstract: Columbia’s president expressed regret about calling in the police to clear a previous protest. On Tuesday, she said she had “no choice” after protesters occupied a building on campus.
lead_paragraph: Exactly 56 years to the day after the 1968 student occupation at Columbia University was violently cleared by the New York Police Department, hundreds of police officers moved into the Manhattan campus on Tuesday night to quell a different kind of antiwar protest.

headline: India’s Master of Nostalgia Takes His Sweeping Vision to Netflix
abstract: Sanjay Leela Bhansali’s films are known for splendor, grandiosity and obsessive attention to light and detail. Will that translate to smaller screens?
lead_paragraph: In the small Bombay theater that showed big films, his father brought him — over and over again — to see the biggest of them all.

headline: Police Officers Respond as Clashes Erupt at U.C.L.A. Encampment
abstract: The university called in law enforcement officers to help after “horrific acts of violence” occurred on campus Tuesday night, an official said.
lead_paragraph: Administrators at the University of California, Los Angeles, called in law enforcement officers on Wednesday after violent clashes broke out at a pro-Palestinian protest encampment, a university official said.

headline: Glamping With the Stars
abstract: Would cloudy weather ruin a visit to the first-ever resort to receive certification from DarkSky International? A stargazer in Utah holds on to her optimism.
lead_paragraph: As I exited Harry Reid International Airport on a bright March afternoon, my hand flew up to protect my eyes, which had grown accustomed to the dull light of a long, gray Tennessee winter. I’d headed west for the sun, but even more so for the night sky, so I was hoping for clear weather ahead. I climbed aboard a shuttle bus that would take me two hours east to Utah, where I planned to spend a starry night at Under Canvas Lake Powell-Grand Staircase.

headline: 2 Books Go Behind Bars With Palestinians
abstract: These authors investigate the interior lives of Palestinians charged with violence and probe the confines of Israeli prisons.
lead_paragraph: “The story of Palestine cannot be told smoothly,” the critic Edward Said observes in “After the Last Sky,” a meditation on the complexities of being Palestinian. “Palestinian life is scattered, discontinuous, marked by the artificial and imposed arrangements of interrupted or confined space,” he writes. “No straight line leads from home to birthplace to school to maturity, all events are accidents, all progress is a digression, all residence is exile.”

headline: The Artist Who Burned the U.S. Flag Raises a New One in Venice
abstract: Dread Scott’s unabashedly activist art once led to a Supreme Court ruling on free speech. Now during the Biennale, he tackles racist immigration policies.
lead_paragraph: Nobody would accuse the activist-artist Dread Scott of being a diplomat. He would rather dismantle power structures than sustain them. But the “All African People’s Consulate,” he has created as a conceptual artwork along the Grand Canal during the 60th Venice Biennale has quickly become a solid gathering place for the Black community in a city that hasn’t always been hospitable to people of color.

headline: Beyoncé’s Last Fashion Frontier
abstract: It’s now impossible to see a cowboy hat or pair of cowboy boots and not think of her.
lead_paragraph: Has there ever been an artist who owned fashion — and owned as much fashion — as Beyoncé Knowles Carter? Though chances are slim that she will attend the Met Gala on Monday (she hasn’t graced the party since 2016), she is practically a Met Gala unto herself.

headline: Bulgarian Distrust of Russia Simmers Over a Black Sea Oil Terminal
abstract: Russia has been losing its grip on the Rosenets Oil Terminal, near the port city of Burgas, as Bulgarian authorities seek to assert greater control over the Russian-run facility.
lead_paragraph: The oil terminal’s piers stretch just a few score yards into the Black Sea from the Bulgarian coast. For 25 years, the Russian crude they received fed a sprawling network of economic and political influence that helped keep Bulgaria tethered tightly to the Kremlin.

headline: Rare Editions of Pushkin Are Vanishing From Libraries Around Europe
abstract: Dozens of books have disappeared from Warsaw to Paris. The police are looking into who is taking them, and why — a tale of money, geopolitics, crafty forgers and lackluster library security.
lead_paragraph: In April 2022, soon after Russia invaded Ukraine, two men arrived at the library of the University of Tartu, Estonia’s second-largest city. They told the librarians they were Ukrainians fleeing war and asked to consult 19th-century first editions of works by Alexander Pushkin, Russia’s national poet, and Nikolai Gogol. Speaking Russian, they said they were an uncle and nephew researching censorship in czarist Russia so the nephew could apply for a scholarship to the United States. Eager to help, the librarians obliged. The men spent 10 days studying the books.

headline: I’ll Sign Your Baseball if You Sign Mine
abstract: As fans and collectors clamor for autographs, Major League Baseball players have built a network — and an etiquette — for signing things for each other.
lead_paragraph: One recent morning in Phoenix, Juan Soto, a star outfielder for the New York Yankees, was watching TV in the visiting clubhouse when an attendant approached him to ask a favor.

headline: $2.1 Million Homes in Massachusetts, Texas and South Carolina
abstract: An early 19th-century Cape Cod-style home with a writing studio in Provincetown, a 1939 cottage in Austin and an 1840 house in Charleston.
lead_paragraph: The owner of this house spent several decades restoring it, focusing on retaining its historic character while adding modern amenities like a gym with a sauna in the basement. It is a few blocks from the Provincetown Theater and from a public beach popular for dog walking in the quieter spring and fall months. Commercial Street, one of the town’s main thoroughfares, is also nearby. A Stop & Shop supermarket is about five minutes away.

headline: She Wrote ‘The History of White People.’ She Has a Lot More to Say.
abstract: “I Just Keep Talking,” a collection of essays and artwork by the historian Nell Irvin Painter, captures her wide-ranging interests and original mind.
lead_paragraph: As the historian Nell Irvin Painter has learned over the course of her eight decades on this earth, inspiration can come from some unlikely places.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Jazz Bass
abstract: Writers, scholars, radio hosts and musicians, including the bassist Ron Carter, share songs that shine a light on an instrument that lays the foundation of jazz.
lead_paragraph: There’s a clip circulating on social media where Charles Mingus, arguably the most famous jazz bassist of all time, is asked what he’s saying through his instrument on the bandstand. His answer, profane and hilarious, isn’t fit to print here, but it’s fitting for the so-called “Angry Man of Jazz.” I’ve often wondered if Mingus’s attitude was just his way, or if he felt somewhat underrated compared with others from his era. By and large back then, bassists weren’t bandleaders; Mingus was an anomaly. And that had me thinking about jazz bass overall: While it might be the most unheralded of all the instruments, no composition resonates without it.

headline: Trump’s Trial Can Right a Wrong From 50 Years Ago
abstract: Here we are, watching the narrow, tawdry version of the trial the nation ought to have had 50 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Of the four criminal cases that Donald Trump is facing, the one unfolding in Manhattan is generally considered the weakest. Its legal foundation is complex. Its key witness is a felon. Its details are the sort of stuff that the tabloids splash across their front pages.

headline: Emily Ratajkowski Can Take Care of Herself, but a Little Help Would Be Nice
abstract: Why the model and writer wants to blow up gender roles in dating, without chivalry having to die.
lead_paragraph: Emily Ratajkowski is doing a balancing act many famously beautiful women have to perform. In her 2021 book “My Body,” she reflects on what it’s been like to build a career based on her public image, and her struggle to control that image in an industry largely run by men. Since getting divorced a few years ago, she’s been thinking a lot about gender dynamics and the type of agency she wants to have in dating, too.

headline: Federal Money Is All Over Milwaukee. Biden Hopes Voters Will Notice.
abstract: White House officials have barnstormed Wisconsin to make the connection between big changes and their signature laws.
lead_paragraph: Across Milwaukee, residents can see evidence of federal money from laws passed under the Biden administration, if they know where to look.

headline: Why Are Movies so Bad at Making Civil War Look Scary?
abstract: The filmmaker has made it clear that “Civil War” is a warning. Instead, the ugliness of war comes across as comforting thrills.
lead_paragraph: Early in “Civil War,” the writer-director Alex Garland’s dystopian blockbuster, a plucky young journalist named Jessie recalls an event called the Antifa Massacre. You can picture the eeriness that Garland must have assumed that phrase would conjure: familiar words, filtered through his apocalyptic vision, projecting today’s ideological rancor into the future. His film is an invitation to imagine what might emerge from America’s political divisions if we don’t back away from the fractious disaffection that has characterized most of the 21st century. But it is also vague about what the Antifa Massacre, or any of the war, actually is. Who was massacred? Who did the massacring? What were the stakes?

headline: This Is Peak College Admissions Insanity
abstract: Getting into a selective college has always been a source of anxiety and stress for students, but this year seemed like academic Hunger Games.
lead_paragraph: Selective college admissions have been a vortex of anxiety and stress for what seems like forever, inducing panic in more top high school seniors each year. But the 2023-24 admissions season was not just an incremental increase in the frantic posturing and high-pressure guesswork that make this annual ritual seem like academic Hunger Games. This year was different. A number of factors — some widely discussed, some little noticed — combined to push the process into a new realm in which the old rules didn’t apply and even the gatekeepers seemed not to know what the new rules were.

headline: Florida’s Six-Week Abortion Ban Is Now Law, With Political Implications
abstract: The ban, which took effect on Wednesday, was part of Gov. Ron DeSantis’s push into cultural conservatism. But Florida politics is rarely that simple.
lead_paragraph: As Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida prepared to run for president last spring, he gathered anti-abortion activists in his Capitol office for an unusual bill signing, held late at night and behind closed doors.

headline: When My Mom Got Sick, This TV Show Kept Us Going
abstract: “Indian Idol,” the Hindi version of “American Idol,” is a pleasant distraction from life’s more trying predicaments.
lead_paragraph: Every family has its archetypes, so here’s mine: My dad and my brother and I are all miserable. None of us are quick to experience joy, and all for different reasons — my dad is irritable, my brother is anxious and I’m bitter. The three of us combined could make one moderately unwell person. Instead, we are planets that orbit a sun more optimistic than we could ever be, and we hope that some of that shine rubs off on us periodically.

headline: Bird Flu Is Spreading. Did We Learn Nothing From Covid?
abstract: Zeynep Tufekci studied the U.S. response to Covid. Now she’s concerned about the nation’s response to bird flu.
lead_paragraph: American dairy cows have been contracting avian flu, and inactive traces of the virus have been found in milk supplies across the country. The spread to humans has been very limited, but the Times Opinion columnist Zeynep Tufekci argues that hoping for good luck is not a strategy for responding to potential pandemics and that government agencies need to do a better job of coordinating, testing and reporting their findings quickly.

headline: ‘Where Is the Palestinian Gandhi?’
abstract: Issa Amro, who has been arrested and beaten for simple acts of defiance, is trying to pursue nonviolent resistance in the West Bank at a time when violence has become inescapable.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7, as the Israeli military deployed across the country to combat Hamas, a group of soldiers waited on an ancient hill called Tel Rumeida in Hebron, a city in the West Bank. Their target was a burly Palestinian man, then 43, named Issa Amro. As Amro approached the soldiers through an olive grove, they moved in and struck him with their rifles, he later recalled. Amro put up little defense; he was handcuffed and taken to a military base. There he was tied to the back of a chair with zip ties. He was first blindfolded, then gagged. Then a beating began, Amro says. The ordeal lasted more than 10 hours.

headline: Model-Boat Sailing Returns to Central Park
abstract: I tried operating a boat on Conservatory Water, the pond famous for model boating. It’s harder than it looks.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at the return of model boating in Central Park for the first time since the pandemic. We’ll also get details of the penalty that Donald Trump was ordered to pay for breaking the gag order in his criminal trial.

headline: Fed Holds Rates Steady, Noting Lack of Progress on Inflation
abstract: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged for a sixth straight meeting and suggested that rates would stay high for longer.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged and signaled that they were wary about how stubborn inflation was proving, paving the way for a longer period of high borrowing costs.

headline: Who Could Catch Bird Flu First? These Experts Have an Idea, and a Way to Help.
abstract: We need to start aggressively testing dairy workers for bird flu to safeguard their health as well as ours — now.
lead_paragraph: H5N1 is in a better position than ever to move between species and spill over aggressively into humans: This bird flu virus is now thought to have been spreading among dairy cows for many months, and federal regulators have found viral fragments circulating widely in the commercial milk supply chain across the United States (though live virus has not been found).

headline: Who Are the Hosts of the Met Gala?
abstract: Which brother is Chris Hemsworth, again? Meet the co-chairs of the party of the year.
lead_paragraph: Each spring a handful of attractive celebrities who do not seem as if they would hang out in any other situation are selected as co-chairs of the Met Gala, the black-tie blowout that is essentially the X Games of fashion (subtract motorcycles, add tulle).

headline: The Fed Tries to Steer Clear of Politics, but an Election Year Is Making It Tough
abstract: Economists are wondering whether political developments could play into both the Fed’s near-term decisions and its long-term independence.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are fiercely protective of their separation from politics, but the presidential election is putting the institution on a crash course with partisan wrangling.

headline: Biden Is Not Winning. His Campaign Should Stop Acting Like It Is.
abstract: It’s good to have a reality check every few months.
lead_paragraph: In February there was a flurry of discussion about whether President Biden’s advancing age and seeming weakness in a matchup with Donald Trump meant that he should step aside. I wrote a column on that theme, but the more notable (that is, nonconservative) voices arguing that Biden should consider withdrawing from the race included the polling maven Nate Silver and my colleague Ezra Klein. The report from the special counsel Robert Hur, which indicated memory problems for the president, was also part of the discussion — or, if you prefer the terms favored by the president’s allies, part of the unnecessary freakout.

headline: What Small Wins Have You Had Recently?
abstract: Experts say that keeping track of your tiny victories can boost your motivation and morale. What have you succeeded in lately?
lead_paragraph: What small wins have you had recently?

headline: In Children’s TV, Dads Get to Have All the Fun
abstract: Our critic on the paternal fantasy of “Bluey” and more.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Hess, a critic at large for The Times, has been watching a lot of children’s television since becoming a parent. But when she started watching “Bluey,” the wildly popular cartoon about a family of Australian dogs, she found herself thinking: What’s up with the dad in this show? And what can be learned from looking closely at the vision of fatherhood provided by this show, and others like it?

headline: Hey, A.I. Let’s Talk
abstract: Meta, Google and others are driving a renaissance for voice assistants, but people have found the technology uncool for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: A pair of glasses from Meta shoots a picture when you say, “Hey, Meta, take a photo.” A miniature computer that clips to your shirt, the Ai Pin, translates foreign languages into your native tongue. An artificially intelligent screen features a virtual assistant that you talk to through a microphone.

headline: A Huge Gender Gap Is Emerging Among Young Voters
abstract: The oldest president is in big trouble with the youngest voters, especially men.
lead_paragraph: It has become clear that one constituency — young voters, 18 to 29 years old — will play a key, if not pivotal, role in determining who will win the Biden-Trump rematch.

headline: Arizona Lawmakers Repeal 1864 Abortion Ban, Creating Rift on the Right
abstract: Two Republican state senators broke with their party to ensure final passage of the repeal. Gov. Katie Hobbs, a Democrat, is expected to sign it on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Arizona lawmakers voted on Wednesday to repeal an abortion ban that first became law when Abraham Lincoln was president and a half-century before women won the right to vote.

headline: Florida’s Abortion Ban Will Reach Well Beyond Florida
abstract: Seven hundred miles to the nearest clinic: how one ban will reshape access in the South.
lead_paragraph: Seven hundred miles to the nearest clinic: how one ban will reshape access in the South.

headline: The New Abortion Fight Before the Supreme Court
abstract: The Biden administration is arguing that Idaho’s near-total abortion ban violates a federal law on emergency treatment.
lead_paragraph: As the presidential race moves into high gear, abortion is at the center of it. Republican-controlled states continue to impose new bans, including just this week in Florida.

headline: Florida Abortion Ban Takes Effect, and U.C.L.A. Calls in Police
abstract: Plus, a possible shift on marijuana policy.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Expressway Collapses in Southern China Amid Heavy Rains, Killing 36
abstract: The road gave way Wednesday morning in an apparent landslide. At least 30 other people were injured, many of them seriously.
lead_paragraph: A nearly 60-foot segment of an expressway in a rural area of southeastern China collapsed before dawn on Wednesday after days of heavy rain, killing 36 people and injuring 30 others.

headline: Chinese Scientist Who Shared Covid Sequence Protests Lab Closure
abstract: Professor Zhang Yongzhen had flouted a government ban by disclosing the genome of the Covid virus soon after it emerged in Wuhan in 2020.
lead_paragraph: A well-known Chinese scientist who defied a Chinese government gag order by being the first to disclose the genome of the Covid virus to a global database four years ago held a rare protest this week in Shanghai after being locked out of his lab.

headline: Will Hamas Say No?
abstract: We explain why a cease-fire hasn’t happened.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Hamas have been talking for months about a deal to release the hostages held in Gaza and to halt the war there. Today, I’ll explain why they haven’t agreed on a renewed cease-fire — and what will determine whether they do.

headline: The Cannabis Industry Hopes for New Highs
abstract: The Justice Department’s recommendation that restrictions on marijuana be lifted have revived expectations for a business that has waited years for such a change.
lead_paragraph: For years, the dreams of the cannabis industry looked like they might go up in smoke, with the U.S. government classifying marijuana as a drug as dangerous as heroin. But the multibillion-dollar industry now has some hope that could change.

headline: Why Does My Husband Exclude Me From Dinners With His Siblings?
abstract: A reader has been feeling left out by her husband’s siblings-only dinners — and never more so than when her brother-in-law crashed a recent get-together.
lead_paragraph: My husband meets his two sisters once a month for dinner. I think it’s great they can spend time together. Recently, I mentioned it would be nice if spouses were invited occasionally. Tonight, when my husband came home from a sibling dinner that doubled as a birthday celebration for his sister, he told me that his brother-in-law was there. I was extremely hurt not to be included! (It didn’t help that they met at an expensive restaurant and my husband probably paid.) My husband said I was being ridiculous. He claims he had no idea his brother-in-law would be there. But I think it was a major faux pas not to invite me and an apology is in order. Your perspective?

headline: The ‘Impossible Life’ of Equal Devotion to Art and Mothering
abstract: So much has changed for moms since the 1960s, and so much hasn’t.
lead_paragraph: “Too much life enters this house,” Tillie Olsen, the writer, labor activist and mother of four girls, wrote in a letter to the poet Anne Sexton. “Up at 6, breakfast in shifts, lunch packing — then, if no one ill, or it isn’t a holiday, or any of the other ORs, the day for work until 4, sometimes longer or an evening — depending on housework load, shopping, errands, people, current family or friend crisis.” This description of artistic and familial tumult was written in 1961, but it could have been an email from one mother to another in 2024.

headline: What Is the American Independent Party, Anyway?
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will be on the November ballot in California after securing a presidential nomination from the American Independent Party.
lead_paragraph: There’s little mystery about which two political parties dominate in California. About 47 percent of California’s 22 million voters are registered as Democrats, and 24 percent as Republicans.

headline: In a Portland Library, Activists Fortify for a Standoff
abstract: With wood pallets piled at the entrance, dozens of pro-Palestinian activists are holed up in the Portland State University library. Here’s a look inside the makeshift fortress.
lead_paragraph: At Portland State University’s crescent-shaped library, students can normally peer through floor-to-ceiling windows at the leafy green spaces below. But the library, under occupation since Monday by pro-Palestinian protesters, now has been turned into a makeshift fortress.

headline: Paul Auster’s Best Books: A Guide
abstract: The novelist played with reality and chance in tales of solitary narrators and mutable identities. Here’s an overview of his work.
lead_paragraph: Paul Auster, who died on April 30 at the age of 77, was an atmospheric author whose scalpel-sharp prose examined the fluidity of identity and the absurdity of the writer’s life. An occasional memoirist, essayist, translator, poet and screenwriter, Auster was best known for his metafiction — books that were characterized by their elusive narrators, chance encounters and labyrinthine narratives.

headline: Some Gazans Say U.S. Campus Protests Give Them ‘Hope’
abstract: The protests have come at a fearful time for Palestinians in Rafah, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowing to launch a ground invasion of the city.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of miles away from the campus protests that have divided Americans, some displaced Palestinians are expressing solidarity with the antiwar demonstrators and gratitude for their efforts.

headline: Greene Says She Will Demand Vote Next Week on Removing Johnson
abstract: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, the right-wing Republican from Georgia, excoriated the House speaker for working with Democrats to push through major bills. She said she would move ahead despite all but certain defeat.
lead_paragraph: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia said on Wednesday that she would demand a vote next week on a motion to remove Speaker Mike Johnson, moving forward in the face of all but certain defeat with a second attempt during this Congress to depose a Republican speaker.

headline: Biden Cancels $6.1 Billion in Debt for Former Art Institute Students
abstract: The announcement covers 317,000 former students and marks another step in the administration’s student loan relief efforts.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Wednesday canceled more than $6 billion in student debt for 317,000 people who attended the Art Institutes, a now-defunct network of for-profit colleges that President Biden said “knowingly misled” students.

headline: The Treadmill Desk Might Really Be Worth It
abstract: Research shows they can indeed deliver fitness benefits while you work — but only if you use them wisely.
lead_paragraph: Experts have long known that extended inactivity can be bad for your body, increasing your risk for heart disease, Type 2 diabetes and other illnesses. As the saying goes, “sitting is the new smoking.” At the same time, decades of studies have shown that walking — even just 4,000 steps a day — is good for the mind and body.

headline: 14 Protesters Are Arrested at Tulane After Police Clear Encampment
abstract: Two students were among those arrested early Wednesday, the university said. Officers from three law enforcement agencies moved in after ordering the group to disperse.
lead_paragraph: An encampment of protesters at Tulane University in New Orleans was cleared and at least 14 people were arrested early on Wednesday, the university said, after officers from three law enforcement agencies ordered the group to disperse.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, Disney+, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in May
abstract: “The Idea of You,” “Scrublands,” “The Big Cigar” and “Hacks” are streaming.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of May’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: New Progressive PAC Targets 8 Key House Races in California
abstract: The super PAC, Battleground California, said it would drive turnout among voters of color to try to flip seats that are seen as crucial to winning control of the House this fall.
lead_paragraph: Democrats nearly pulled off the impossible in the 2022 midterms.

headline: What Makes a Society More Resilient? Frequent Hardship.
abstract: Comparing 30,000 years of human history, researchers found that surviving famine, war or climate change helps groups recover more quickly from future shocks.
lead_paragraph: From the Roman Empire to the Maya civilization, history is filled with social collapses. Traditionally, historians have studied these downturns qualitatively, by diving into the twists and turns of individual societies.

headline: Chicken katsu, weeknight rescue
abstract: Kay Chun’s recipe cleverly shallow-fries the cutlets so they emerge golden and crispy, ready for rice, tonkatsu sauce and a shaggy mound of shredded cabbage.
lead_paragraph: Of all the crispy fried cutlet variations that have tantalized me over the years, Kay Chun’s chicken katsu might be the most weeknight friendly. Instead of turning to the usual messy deep-fry, Kay shallow-fries the cutlets by using just enough oil to submerge them halfway. The thin disks of meat emerge golden, crunchy and juicy inside, ready for their customary accompaniments of steamed white rice and a shaggy mound of shredded green cabbage. Kay provides a recipe for tonkatsu sauce (a tangy Japanese barbecue condiment with Worcestershire and ginger), but it’s easy to buy a bottle if you want to save a step.

headline: Eric Adams Seizes Role as Face of the Crackdown on Student Protests
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams of New York defended the arrests of nearly 300 protesters and said he would not allow the protests to disrupt the city.
lead_paragraph: Less than 18 hours after protesters at Columbia University took over Hamilton Hall, Mayor Eric Adams convened reporters at Police Headquarters to deliver a warning. The situation on campus, he said, would not be allowed to keep escalating.

headline: His Book Was Repeatedly Banned. Fighting For It Shaped His Life.
abstract: “The Chocolate War,” published 50 years ago, became one of the country’s most challenged books. Its author, Robert Cormier, spent years fighting attempts to ban it — like many authors today.
lead_paragraph: In the 50 years since it came out, “The Chocolate War” has become one of the country’s most challenged books. But the tensest battle over the novel may have been fought in Panama City, Fla., in the mid-1980s. That’s when an attempt to ban “The Chocolate War” divided the town, leading to arson and death threats against middle-school teachers.

headline: Job Openings and Hiring Are at a 3-Year Ebb
abstract: March data showed a cooling labor market, but layoffs remain low. The overall trend is likely to be welcomed by Federal Reserve policymakers.
lead_paragraph: The red-hot labor market cooled somewhat in March, government data showed on Wednesday.

headline: Aspirin Can Prevent a Deadly Pregnancy Complication. Why Aren’t Women Told?
abstract: Women at risk for extreme high blood pressure should take a daily baby aspirin. But their doctors don’t always tell them.
lead_paragraph: Baby aspirin is routinely prescribed to people who survive heart attacks. But there’s another vulnerable group who benefit from daily low-dose aspirin: pregnant women at risk of developing pre-eclampsia, life-threatening high blood pressure.

headline: Counterprotesters Storm U.C.L.A. Pro-Palestinian Encampment
abstract: Violence broke out as counterprotesters attempted to pull down barricades at a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Violence broke out as counterprotesters attempted to pull down barricades at a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, Los Angeles.

headline: Should I Lie So That My Cousin Can Have a Catholic Wedding?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to fib for a relative, especially when you don’t think the ends justify the means.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, my cousin became single after an end to a decades-long marriage. Both he and I are Catholic, and the rules on divorce aren’t as clean-cut as they are under the law. Because my cousin and his ex-wife were married in a Catholic wedding, it means that, as far as the Catholic Church is concerned, my cousin and his ex are still married in the eyes of God.

headline: Unruly Passenger Must Pay United Airlines $20,638 for Disrupting Flight
abstract: The man had been “verbally and physically aggressive” on a United flight from London to Newark, prompting the plane to land in Bangor, Maine, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A passenger who was yelling and became physically aggressive on a United Airlines flight from London to Newark in March, prompting the crew to divert the plane to Bangor, Maine, has been ordered to pay the airline $20,638 in restitution, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Record Number of Writers Were Jailed Globally in 2023, PEN America Says
abstract: For the first time, China has more than 100 incarcerated writers, and Israel and Russia entered the list of the 10 countries with the most imprisoned writers.
lead_paragraph: The number of jailed writers in China surpassed 100 for the first time as the country continued to be the biggest jailer of writers, according to PEN America, a free expression group, which released its annual Freedom to Write Index on Wednesday.

headline: Zwirner Anchors Los Angeles Art Neighborhood With New Gallery
abstract: Its flagship will open with a 30th-anniversary exhibition featuring works by all of the gallery’s 80 artists.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — David Zwirner will open its new flagship Los Angeles gallery on May 23 with a 30th-anniversary exhibition featuring works by all of the gallery’s 80 artists. Zwirner’s decision to plant a flag in a third new space on North Western Avenue represents a powerful vote of confidence in the West Coast art market as well as in the Melrose Hill neighborhood, which has recently exploded with galleries.

headline: Senators Slam UnitedHealth’s C.E.O. Over Cyberattack
abstract: Several lawmakers questioned whether the company had become so large — with tentacles in every aspect of the nation’s medical care — that the effects of the hack were outsize.
lead_paragraph: In a tense Senate hearing on Wednesday, lawmakers sharply criticized UnitedHealth Group’s handling of the cyberattack that paralyzed the U.S. health care system, citing the failure of its security systems and the potential disclosure of sensitive medical information of millions of Americans.

headline: What to See in New York During a Month-Long Celebration of Design
abstract: These are the highlights of what to do and where to go in May if you’re interested in design topics.
lead_paragraph: The annual NYCxDesign festival gives space to artisans, manufacturers and students showing off their latest inventions in architecture and design. The 12th edition is scheduled to run May 16-23, but the exhibitions, product introductions and panel discussions revolving around buildings, furnishings, fashion and graphics start as early as May Day and continue through the month. Here are some highlights.

headline: What the Fed’s Moves Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
abstract: Higher rates benefit those who can save, but for borrowers falling rates would reduce bills on credit cards, home equity loans and other forms of debt.
lead_paragraph: American households who were hoping interest rates would soon decline will have to wait a bit longer.

headline: United Methodist Church Reverses Ban on Practicing Gay Clergy
abstract: In a meeting on Wednesday, church leaders also voted to allow L.G.B.T.Q. weddings.
lead_paragraph: The United Methodist Church removed on Wednesday its longstanding ban on ordaining gay clergy, formalizing a shift in policy that had already begun in practice and that had prompted the departure of a quarter of its U.S. congregations in recent years.

headline: What the First Amendment Means for Campus Protests
abstract: Encampments? Occupying buildings? Demonstrators cite their right to free expression, but the issues are thorny.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the college protests at U.C.L.A. and other universities.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Proposes $6.5 Billion in New Talc Settlement Offer
abstract: The offer is the company’s third attempt to resolve tens of thousands of claims that its baby powder caused ovarian cancer and mesothelioma.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson said on Wednesday that it would ask tens of thousands of people suing the company over claims that its talcum powder products caused their cancer to approve a new $6.5 billion settlement, its third attempt to resolve the lawsuits.

headline: NASCAR and Its Race Teams Fight Over the Sport’s Future
abstract: Team owners said they needed to share in racing’s financial success, putting them at odds with the privately held business that runs the sport.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Jordan and his right-hand man, Curtis Polk, bought a NASCAR team in 2020 with the driver Denny Hamlin, they were prepared to endure short-term losses. Drivers, mechanics and a sales staff had to be hired. The Next Generation cars that were introduced in 2022 would cost top teams about $18 million a year to run before paying a driver, and their team, 23XI, had two. Paying for a new building to house the cars would cost tens of millions of dollars more.

headline: Pet Alligator Is Mistakenly Released Into the Wild, Owner Says
abstract: Wally, an emotional support alligator that was denied entrance to a Phillies game last year, was apparently kidnapped, found and dropped in a swamp.
lead_paragraph: WallyGator, the emotional support alligator who enjoyed a moment of fame last year when he was denied admittance to a Major League Baseball game, is back in the news.

headline: Judging the Justices on the Presidential Immunity Case
abstract: Responses to articles about the case before the Supreme Court. Also: Perspectives on the campus protests; how children value trees as homes for animals.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Flooding in a Kenyan Natural Reserve Forces Tourist Evacuation
abstract: The heavy rains that pounded East Africa for weeks, killing hundreds, have spilled into the Masai Mara, one of Africa’s greatest wildlife national reserves.
lead_paragraph: Devastating floods that have killed hundreds of people and displaced tens of thousands more in East Africa are now inundating parts of the Masai Mara, one of Africa’s greatest wildlife national reserves.

headline: Share Your Experiences With Virginia’s Judicial Appointment System
abstract: Times journalists writing about the state’s judicial system would like to hear from lawyers about their experiences with the appointment process.
lead_paragraph: Virginia is one of two states in which the legislature selects all judges.

headline: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, April 22, 2024
abstract: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Why Is ‘Baby Reindeer’ Such a Hit? It’s All in the Ending.
abstract: The Netflix stalker series combines the appeal of a twisty thriller with a deep sense of empathy. The conclusion illustrates why it’s become one of the most-discussed shows of the year.
lead_paragraph: This article includes spoilers for all of “Baby Reindeer.”

headline: Bird Flu Highlights Concerns Around Raw Milk
abstract: Testing suggests that pasteurization inactivates the virus. But what about raw milk and cheese?
lead_paragraph: While maintaining that avian influenza poses a low risk to the general public, health officials again warned on Wednesday about the potential risk of unpasteurized milk.

headline: From Florida to Arizona, Abortion Politics Dominate the 2024 Race
abstract: As a six-week ban takes effect in Florida, and Arizona legislators repealed their 1864 law restricting the procedure, Democrats hope the issue will help carry them through a tough political environment.
lead_paragraph: In Florida, a ban on most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy took effect.

headline: Truth Social Co-Founder Says Trump Nearly Derailed Deal That Led to Market Windfall
abstract: Andy Litinsky, who helped start the former president’s social media company, revealed Mr. Trump’s last-minute doubts about an agreement that made them all very wealthy.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company is currently worth over $6 billion. But the agreement that set the stage for its stock market debut in March was nearly derailed years earlier by Mr. Trump, who is now the biggest beneficiary of its richly valued stock, one of the firm’s co-founders said on Wednesday.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in May
abstract: Highlights this month include an adaptation of Tom Wolfe’s “A Man in Full” and Jerry Seinfeld’s directorial debut.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of May’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, April 23, 2024
abstract: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Chinese Companies for Aiding Russia’s War Effort
abstract: The penalties came after top Biden administration officials warned China not to help Moscow restock its arsenal to attack Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Wednesday announced nearly 300 new sanctions on international suppliers of military equipment technology that the administration said have been helping Russia restock its arsenal as it carries out the war in Ukraine.

headline: Collusion in Health Care Pricing? Regulators Are Asked to Investigate
abstract: A data analytics firm has helped big health insurers cut payments to doctors, raising concerns about possible price fixing.
lead_paragraph: Recent revelations about a data analytics firm’s role in determining medical payments have heightened concerns about possible price fixing in health care and led to a call for a federal investigation.

headline: Met Museum Reaches Fund-Raising Goal for New Modern Wing
abstract: The museum achieves a milestone, but still faces a complex public approval process for its Tang Wing, which is on city land.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday announced that it has raised $550 million in private donations for its new modern and contemporary wing, named after Oscar L. Tang and Agnes Hsu-Tang in honor of the couple’s $125 million lead gift in 2021.

headline: Are Smartphones Driving Our Teens to Depression?
abstract: The evidence reveals a more complicated reality than the conventional wisdom would have you believe.
lead_paragraph: Here is a story. In 2007, Apple released the iPhone, initiating the smartphone revolution that would quickly transform the world. In 2010, it added a front-facing camera, helping shift the social-media landscape toward images, especially selfies. Partly as a result, in the five years that followed, the nature of childhood and especially adolescence was fundamentally changed — a “great rewiring,” in the words of the social psychologist Jonathan Haidt — such that between 2010 and 2015 mental health and well-being plummeted and suffering and despair exploded, particularly among teenage girls.

headline: How to Make an Easy Picnic That Transports You to France
abstract: A pepper-crusted flank steak and French potato salad anchor this summery menu from David Tanis.
lead_paragraph: With fair weather settling in and summer on the horizon, what I want to serve friends is a bright, sort-of-French pique-nique spread. In France, with cheese shops, bakeries and fine prepared foods available in every neighborhood, it’s easy to have an impromptu picnic — at a park, in the woods or on a river bank — at the drop of a (straw) hat.

headline: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, April 25, 2024
abstract: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Before the Violence, U.C.L.A. Thought a Tolerant Approach Would Work
abstract: The school was ill prepared when protesters blocked students from accessing parts of campus and counterprotesters violently attacked the pro-Palestinian encampment.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the campus protests.

headline: 125 Picture Prompts for Creative and Narrative Writing
abstract: What story can these images tell?
lead_paragraph: For eight years, we at The Learning Network have been publishing short, accessible, image-driven prompts that invite students to do a variety of kinds of writing via our Picture Prompts column.

headline: Handcuffs and Barricades at Columbia, but No Reporters
abstract: By restricting media access, the N.Y.P.D. prevented the public from knowing the full details of its campus raid.
lead_paragraph: Whatever one’s views on the pro-Palestinian demonstrations sweeping the nation’s colleges, the decision by the New York Police Department on Tuesday to block journalists from witnessing its raid on Columbia University was a clear infringement of the First Amendment.

headline: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, April 26, 2024
abstract: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: The 63-Year-Old Career Activist Among the Protesters at Columbia
abstract: Videos show Lisa Fithian, whom the police called a “professional agitator,” working alongside protesters who stormed Hamilton Hall.
lead_paragraph: Among the throng of Columbia University student protesters gathered outside Hamilton Hall on campus early Tuesday morning was a gray-haired woman in her 60s.

headline: It’s Not Just Gaza: Student Protesters See Links to a Global Struggle
abstract: In many students’ eyes, the war in Gaza is linked to other issues, such as policing, mistreatment of Indigenous people, racism and the impact of climate change.
lead_paragraph: Talk to student protesters across the country, and their outrage is clear: They have been galvanized by the scale of death and destruction in Gaza, and will risk arrest to fight for the Palestinian cause.

headline: In Latest Stunt, Airbnb Lists the ‘Up’ House. It Floats.
abstract: The company announced a new category of outlandish stays in partnership with brands and celebrities, building on the success of gimmicks like the Barbie Malibu DreamHouse.
lead_paragraph: The sleek mansion in the hills overlooking Las Vegas could have been featured on MTV’s “Cribs.” But the highlight of Aubrey Garza’s weekend stay there wasn’t the palatial rooms or the marble fireplace. It was meeting her Airbnb host: Christina Aguilera.

headline: Giuliani’s Spending: $43,000 a Month and a Lot of Credit Card Bills
abstract: Rudy Giuliani promised a bankruptcy court that he would limit his spending, but it didn’t take long before he broke that pledge, and by a lot.
lead_paragraph: Besieged by creditors and with his income drying up, Rudolph W. Giuliani laid out an austerity program of sorts in January for a federal bankruptcy court.

headline: Tell Us What You Think About New York City’s Streets
abstract: We want to know more about your neighborhood — and how you get around the city.
lead_paragraph: Do the streets and sidewalks of New York feel crowded to you? Does it seem like there are too many people? Too many bicycles? Too many cars?

headline: 11 Spring Art Fairs Kick Off for Buyers and Browsers Alike
abstract: With Frieze comes a buffet of art in New York City over two weeks, whether you’re looking for blue-chip galleries or emerging talents.
lead_paragraph: Frieze New York is upon us, which means an explosion of art fairs over two weeks, most but not all of them in Manhattan. These fairs are where dozens of leading galleries and dealers from around the world exhibit their best, and sometimes, the best of art history. Here are our picks for a crawl around the city, based on what your art heart desires (or wallet and weekend time allow). And be sure to ask dealers for prices; often they are not conveniently posted.

headline: The Latest Campus Battleground Is the Flagpole
abstract: Demonstrators have raised Palestinian flags in place of American flags on several campuses, and drawn an angry response.
lead_paragraph: As students continue to protest Israel’s assault on Gaza, the flagpoles at universities have become the latest point of conflict.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Atomic Blonde’ and More
abstract: I report on Hollywood for the Business and Culture desks. Here are five I’ve watched recently.
lead_paragraph: I report on Hollywood for the Business and Culture desks. Here are five I’ve watched recently.

headline: As Protests Grow, Universities Choose Different Ways to End Unrest
abstract: Columbia has taken the spotlight after twice asking the police to quell pro-Palestinian demonstrations on campus. Brown University chose a different path.
lead_paragraph: The first time Columbia University tried to shut down the pro-Palestinian encampment on its campus, two weeks ago, it called in the New York Police Department. That backfired. Students who were not arrested reestablished a larger encampment on the next lawn over and drew hundreds of protesters from across the city and beyond who rallied at the campus’s gates.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Sabrina Carpenter, Chappell Roan + Editing Taylor Swift
abstract: Picking the best songs from “The Tortured Poets Department” one week later. Plus: the rise of a pair of pop’s middle-class stars.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Duane Eddy, Whose Twang Changed Rock ’n’ Roll, Dies at 86
abstract: A self-taught electric guitar virtuoso, he influenced a generation of musicians. One of them, John Fogerty, called him rock’s first guitar god.
lead_paragraph: Duane Eddy, who broke new ground in pop music in the 1950s with a reverberant, staccato style of guitar playing that became known as twang, died on Tuesday in Franklin, Tenn. He was 86.

headline: When Banks Fail, Why Do We Keep Bailing Out Uninsured Depositors?
abstract: In routinely making the uninsured whole, the F.D.I.C. isn’t doing its job, an N.Y.U. professor argues.
lead_paragraph: Michael Ohlrogge has a theory about the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the agency that makes sure ordinary depositors don’t lose their money when their bank goes bust.

headline: The Words That Have Defined This Week in Donald J. Trump’s Trial
abstract: Witnesses discussed the salacious and the banal, and the judge warned the defendant he could go to jail.
lead_paragraph: During the past week in Donald Trump’s criminal trial, there has been talk of trysts and the trade in the secrets of the rich and famous.

headline: Walnuts Recalled From Natural Food Stores After E. Coli Outbreak
abstract: The outbreak linked to shelled organic walnuts distributed by Gibson Farms has sickened 12 people and hospitalized seven in California and Washington State, federal officials said.
lead_paragraph: A California company is recalling organic walnuts that were sold at natural food stores and coop retailers in 19 states because of an E. coli outbreak that has sickened 12 people and hospitalized seven, federal officials said.

headline: Kim Noltemy, Orchestra Veteran, Is Tapped to Lead L.A. Philharmonic
abstract: Noltemy, the Dallas Symphony Orchestra’s chief executive, will take the helm of the Philharmonic as it searches for its next music director.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Philharmonic’s history of inventive programming and strong finances has made it the envy of orchestras around the United States.

headline: Colombia to Sever Ties With Israel Over Gaza War
abstract: Gustavo Petro, Colombia’s first leftist president, made the announcement in front of cheering crowds in the capital that had gathered for International Workers’ Day.
lead_paragraph: Colombia will sever diplomatic ties with Israel over its prosecution of the war in Gaza, President Gustavo Petro announced in Bogotá on Wednesday, describing the Israeli government as “genocidal.”

headline: Thursday Briefing: Police Deployed at U.S. Campuses
abstract: Also, China’s surging electric car market and a new Netflix series from India.
lead_paragraph: Police officers across the U.S. entered campuses where pro-Palestinian protesters have erected encampments and seized academic buildings. Students at several universities remained entrenched, indicating no intention to back down.

headline: Olga Fikotova Connolly, Olympian in a Cold War Romance, Dies at 91
abstract: She was from Czechoslovakia. He was from the U.S. And after meeting at the 1956 Games and winning gold medals, they married. Love had breached the iron curtain.
lead_paragraph: Olga Fikotova Connolly, who won a gold medal in track and field for Czechoslovakia in the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, watched Harold Connolly of the United States win one the next day, and, in March 1957, married him as the highlight of a storybook Cold War romance, died on April 12 in Costa Mesa, Calif. She was 91.

headline: Harris Blasts Trump Over Florida Abortion Ban
abstract: On the day that Florida began to enforce its six-week abortion ban, Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a searing attack on former President Donald J. Trump in Jacksonville, Fla., calling the measure “another Trump abortion ban.”
lead_paragraph: On the day that Florida began to enforce its six-week abortion ban, Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a searing attack on former President Donald J. Trump in Jacksonville, Fla., calling the measure “another Trump abortion ban.”

headline: In Bid to Oust Johnson, Greene Tries to Reclaim a Powerful Perch on the Fringe
abstract: The Georgia Republican’s doomed push to remove the speaker has placed her at odds with most in her party, but it has brought her back to her roots as a norm-busting provocateur.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, first dangled the threat of ousting Speaker Mike Johnson, she received a call from a longtime ally and fellow hard-right Republican who urged her not to follow through.

headline: Police Enter Fordham’s Manhattan Campus and Arrest Protesters
abstract: Some Fordham students said they had been inspired by the protests at Columbia and City College, where there had been nearly 300 arrests combined the night before.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the college protests across the U.S.

headline: In Florida, Harris Looks to Make Trump the Face of the State’s Abortion Ban
abstract: The vice president sought to tie former President Donald J. Trump to the state’s six-week abortion ban, which took effect on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: On the day that Florida began to enforce its six-week abortion ban, Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a searing attack on former President Donald J. Trump in Jacksonville, calling the measure “another Trump abortion ban” and saying he was forcing women to live a “horrific reality” without access to essential medical care.

headline: ‘Lack of Further Progress’ on Inflation Keeps Interest Rates High
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said that the central bank needed “greater confidence” that inflation was coming down before it decided to cut interest rates, which are at a two-decade high.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said that the central bank needed “greater confidence” that inflation was coming down before it decided to cut interest rates, which are at a two-decade high.

headline: Veteran Collected Benefits After Lying About Purple Heart, U.S. Says
abstract: Sharon Toney-Finch, who served in Iraq, was charged with fraudulently claiming to have a Purple Heart and with defrauding the Department of Veterans Affairs.
lead_paragraph: A woman in upstate New York was arrested on Wednesday and charged with fraudulently claiming to be a Purple Heart recipient, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Giant Pandas Are Returning to San Diego, China Announces
abstract: “Panda diplomacy” has represented an area of cooperation between the United States and China despite tension over weighty issues of trade and national security.
lead_paragraph: The United States and China may be at odds these days over Russia’s war in Ukraine, cheap Chinese exports, tensions with Taiwan and matters of human rights.

headline: Arizona Voted to Repeal Its Abortion Ban
abstract: Also, the Fed eyes a longer period of high rates. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Arizona lawmakers today repealed an abortion ban that first became law in 1864, when Abraham Lincoln was president and a half-century before women won the right to vote.

headline: Mountain Goats Are Not Avalanche-Proof
abstract: The scene ends badly, as you might imagine.
lead_paragraph: Mountain goats are high-elevation daredevils, learning to balance upon the steepest of rocky edifices soon after they are born. Nannies lead their kids up gnarly slopes, seeking places that predators fear to tread. While the precarious perches help goats avoid being eaten, there is an obvious downside to these sanctuaries: avalanches.

headline: Biden to Speak on Antisemitism at a Holocaust Remembrance Next Week
abstract: President Biden has made little effort to personally address the anti-Israel protests, frustrating some Democrats who want him to show more public leadership.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, who has personally stayed relatively quiet during college campus protests in recent days, plans to speak out against antisemitism next week at a ceremony hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum’s annual “days of remembrance” commemoration, the White House announced on Wednesday.

headline: Trump Praises Police Crackdowns on Campus Protests
abstract: The former president called protesters “raging lunatics” and suggested, without evidence, that they were hired to draw attention away from border crossings.
lead_paragraph: Holding his first campaign rallies since his criminal trial in Manhattan began, former President Donald J. Trump on Wednesday urged college presidents to take a tougher approach to protests over the war in Gaza that have swept across campuses and praised police action at the demonstrations.

headline: Blinken Turns Up Pressure on Hamas to Accept Gaza Cease-Fire Deal
abstract: “The time is now,” Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken declared, urging Hamas to accept the terms of a proposed truce. He also made clear that he expected more from Israel.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken delivered twin messages to Hamas and Israel on Wednesday, pressing Hamas to accept a cease-fire proposal while at the same time urging Israeli leaders to put off a major ground invasion into the thickly populated southern Gaza city of Rafah.

headline: Read Transcripts From Trump’s Manhattan Criminal Trial
abstract: The New York Times published the court system’s transcripts from the Manhattan criminal trial of Donald J. Trump, who is charged with 34 felonies in the case.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court system released transcripts from the Manhattan criminal trial against former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on May 30 on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: How Six-Week Abortion Bans Went From Fringe to Reality
abstract: Even opponents of abortion saw such curbs as too controversial just over a decade ago. Times have changed.
lead_paragraph: Just over a decade ago, six-week abortion bans were seen as too radical even by many members of the anti-abortion movement, who worried they carried too much political and legal risk.

headline: Armed Student Is Killed Near Wisconsin Middle School, Officials Say
abstract: School officials in Mount Horeb, Wis., southwest of Madison, said that no one else was harmed and that schools were placed on lockdown.
lead_paragraph: The police killed an armed student after an active shooter had been reported near a middle school in Mount Horeb, Wis., on Wednesday, the authorities said.

headline: Pasteurized Dairy Foods Free of Live Bird Flu, Federal Tests Confirm
abstract: But the scope of the outbreak among cattle remains uncertain, and little human testing has been done.
lead_paragraph: Additional testing of retail dairy products from across the country has turned up no signs of live bird flu virus, strengthening the consensus that pasteurization is protecting consumers from the threat, federal health and agriculture officials said at a news briefing on Wednesday.

headline: Sept. 11 Trial Plea Negotiations Still Underway at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: The lead prosecutor briefed the judge on the talks in an effort to fend off a claim that members of Congress had unlawfully meddled in the negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors and defense lawyers are still negotiating toward a plea agreement for the men accused of plotting the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks despite the Biden administration’s refusal to endorse certain proposed conditions, the lead prosecutor said in court on Wednesday at Guantánamo Bay.

headline: Dan Schneider Sues ‘Quiet on Set’ Creators, Saying Series Defamed Him
abstract: In the suit, lawyers for the former Nickelodeon producer called the documentary a “hit job” that had falsely painted him as a “child sexual abuser.”
lead_paragraph: The television producer Dan Schneider filed a defamation lawsuit on Wednesday against the creators of the documentary series “Quiet on Set,” which aired accounts of sexual abuse and other inappropriate behavior on sets at Nickelodeon, where Schneider was once a star creator of content.

headline: Republicans Call on NPR’s C.E.O. to Testify About Political Bias Accusations
abstract: Katherine Maher, the radio network’s new chief executive, has been in the spotlight since an editor published an essay accusing the organization of leftward-leaning bias.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans on Wednesday said they had asked NPR’s new chief executive, Katherine Maher, to address accusations of political bias in the radio network’s journalism during a hearing next week.

headline: Senate Democrats Reintroduce Legislation to Legalize Marijuana
abstract: The bill, which reflects growing support for legalization, would end the federal prohibition on cannabis. But it is unlikely to pass in an election year and a divided government.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats reintroduced broad legislation on Wednesday to legalize cannabis on the federal level, a major policy shift with wide public support, but it is unlikely to be enacted this year ahead of November’s elections and in a divided government.

headline: Republicans Step Up Attacks on Scientist at Heart of Lab Leak Theory
abstract: A heated hearing produced no new evidence that Peter Daszak or his nonprofit, EcoHealth Alliance, were implicated in the Covid outbreak.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans demanded on Wednesday that the president of a virus-hunting nonprofit group be criminally investigated and barred from federal research funds, a sharp escalation in their campaign against scientists in the United States who Republicans have suggested either had links to the origin of the Covid-19 pandemic or obscured its true beginnings.

headline: How Protesters Can Actually Help Palestinians
abstract: I worry that the more aggressive demonstrators may be hurting the Gazans they’re trying to support.
lead_paragraph: Student protesters: I admire your empathy for Gazans, your concern for the world, your moral ambition to make a difference.
