lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia and Israel are America’s two most important Middle East allies, and the Biden administration is deeply involved with both today, trying to forge a mutual defense treaty with Saudi Arabia and help Israel in its conflicts with Hamas and Iran. But the Biden team has run into an unprecedented situation with these two longtime partners that is creating a huge opportunity and a huge danger for America. It derives from the contrast in their internal politics.

headline: University of California Workers May Strike After UCLA Raid
abstract: A union representing academic workers said it would file unfair labor charges against the University of California, Los Angeles, and potentially walk out over the handling of protests this week.
lead_paragraph: The largest employee union in the University of California system said on Thursday that it was preparing to ask some or all of its members to authorize a strike over the treatment of pro-Palestinian protesters at the University of California, Los Angeles.

headline: Jill Biden Hosts Gala, With Teachers as the Honored Dignitaries
abstract: The first lady commended the winner of the National Teacher of the Year award during an event evoking formal state dinners.
lead_paragraph: The hallmarks of a state dinner were there: lavish floral displays festooning the White House, the first lady arriving in a floor-length sequined gown, and members of Congress and cabinet secretaries mingling with attendees. But the honored guest was not the president of France or the prime minister of Japan.

headline: ‘Unfrosted’ Review: What’s the Deal With Pop-Tarts?
abstract: Starring Jerry Seinfeld in his feature directing debut, “Unfrosted: The Pop-Tarts Story” is the only corporate saga whose main ingredient is high-fructose sarcasm.
lead_paragraph: Pop-Tarts were invented over four hectic months in 1964. Jerry Seinfeld has been developing jokes about them for over 10 years, first in his stand-up act, and now as a full-fledged, fully ridiculous feature comedy targeted to the audience’s sweet-and-salty dopamine receptors. “Unfrosted,” directed by Seinfeld with a script by him and longtime collaborators Spike Feresten, Andy Robin and Barry Marder, gives the comic his first-ever live action leading film role as Bob Cabana, a fictional cereal flack who revolutionizes the breakfast industry. (William Post, the real-life person who helped create Pop-Tarts, died in February at the age of 96.) Cinema has endured branded biopics on everything from Air Jordans to the BlackBerry to Flamin’ Hot Cheetos. This is the only corporate saga whose main ingredient is high-fructose sarcasm.

headline: Cool-Down Stretches
abstract: Eli Cotham makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Jury Hears Tape of Trump and Cohen Discussing Hush-Money Deal
abstract: The tape, played at the former president’s criminal trial, captured Michael Cohen, the former fixer of Donald Trump, telling him about a payment to a former Playboy model. Jonah Bromwich, who covers criminal justice for The New York Times, gives a summary.
lead_paragraph: The tape, played at the former president’s criminal trial, captured Michael Cohen, the former fixer of Donald Trump, telling him about a payment to a former Playboy model. Jonah Bromwich, who covers criminal justice for The New York Times, gives a summary.

headline: We Didn’t Know It Was the Last Time
abstract: My daughter and I looked at a book together, posed for a picture, and then she left. Forever.
lead_paragraph: Last December, a couple of weeks before Christmas, I left my water bottle at the gym. As we drove home, my husband said, “Do you want to go back?”

headline: Mapping a Life Together Through Movies
abstract: Maddie Whittle and Charles Bramesco met through the New York film scene, connecting over a shared sensibility (and an affinity for the horror genre).
lead_paragraph: Madeline Claire Whittle and Charles Norton Bramesco first hit it off over a horror movie — not as theatergoers, but as judges serving on a panel at the Brooklyn Horror Film Festival in October 2019.

headline: The Two-Week Sublet That Led to Love
abstract: Wiktor Freifeld lived in Tusia Dabrowska’s apartment when she left Warsaw for New York. A deep friendship soon followed.
lead_paragraph: While living in Warsaw in 2009, Tusia Dabrowska was always on the hunt for potential creative collaborators. Friends suggested that she meet Wiktor Maria Freifeld, who, like her, was Polish and Jewish, and making art.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Tale of Geopolitics, Forgery, and Vanishing Russian Literature
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Libraries are in the business of providing access to scholars and the public, and when a breach of trust like this occurs, necessary changes in security can curtail that access.”

headline: How a One-Month Fitness Pass Turned Into a Lifetime Commitment
abstract: Andrew Matt met Kayla Dye six years ago at an indoor cycling studio in Dallas after signing up for a class she was teaching. Both instructor and student were immediately smitten.
lead_paragraph: In January 2018, Andrew Stephen Matt said he spent the best $20.18 he’d ever spend: He bought a one-month, unlimited class pass to Lync Cycling in Dallas.

headline: An Online Radio Station Where Everything Is Eclectic
abstract: Music played by D.J.s like Flo Dill on NTS encompasses obscure ambient tracks and timeworn dad rock. The approach has won it fans far beyond its London home.
lead_paragraph: On a gloomy Tuesday this past March, a cohort of trendy young Britons was waking up to the sounds of underground ’80s R&B. And Swedish space disco. And the folk singer John Martyn.

headline: China Launches Spacecraft to the Far Side of the Moon
abstract: If successful, the Chang’e-6 mission will be the first in history to return a sample from a part of the moon that we never get to see from Earth.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, China launched a second lander to the lunar far side. If the mission is successful, it will be the first in history to bring back a sample from the part of the moon that Earth never sees.

headline: No Corrections: May 3, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, May 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: corrections here.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Hamas considers a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: A Hamas leader said yesterday that the group was studying Israel’s latest cease-fire proposal with a “positive spirit,” raising hopes of progress in the stalled efforts for a truce.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Says Police Officer Accidentally Fired Gun Inside Columbia Building
abstract: Footage of the shooting was captured on the officer’s body camera and provided to the Manhattan district attorney. The officer was on the first floor of Hamilton Hall when his gun went off.
lead_paragraph: A police sergeant’s gun “accidentally” fired inside a Columbia University building where officers were removing pro-Palestinian protesters from the campus this week, the New York Police Department said on Friday.

headline: Tanker Fire Shuts Down I-95
abstract: Traffic stopped on the highway as firefighters worked to extinguish the flames in Norwalk, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Traffic stopped on the highway as firefighters worked to extinguish the flames in Norwalk, Conn.

headline: I-95 in Connecticut Will Be Closed for Days After Fiery Crash
abstract: A gasoline tanker crashed on Thursday, causing a fire that damaged a bridge in Norwalk, Conn. Early Friday morning, commuters were facing clogged roadways, and one school district canceled classes.
lead_paragraph: Update: Interstate 95 was reopened on Sunday. Read our coverage here.

headline: Word of the Day: rueful
abstract: This word has appeared in 34 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word rueful has appeared in 34 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 6 in “For Megan Rapinoe, an Ending Not Even She Could Have Imagined” by Jeré Longman:

headline: ‘Dead Poets Society’ Has Some Distinctly Australian Relevance
abstract: Brought to life by the Australian director Peter Weir, the movie’s conflict reflects a collective cultural trait his fellow citizens can relate to.
lead_paragraph: With my 13-year-old daughter home for a break from her one-year adventure at a boarding school in the Australian bush, we put on an old movie the other night that she had asked to see: “Dead Poets Society.”

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Wants to Testify at Donald Trump’s Criminal Trial
abstract: “I think I can keep Trump awake during the trial,” Kimmel said after learning that text messages about his talk show were entered as evidence in the case.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,049
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 327
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: How a ‘Hidden’ $1.4 Billion Tax Will Make N.Y.C. Water Bills Rise
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams is resurrecting a budget gimmick and charging rent to the city’s Water Board, which will pass on the costs to ratepayers.
lead_paragraph: It is a problem bedeviling local governments nationwide: How can they pay for city services at a time of limited funds and rising costs?

headline: Shadowy Figures
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or write about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: U.K. Conservatives Suffer Sharp Setbacks in Local Elections
abstract: The scale of the losses suffered by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s party sent an ominous message about its chances in an upcoming general election.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Conservative Party suffered sweeping setbacks on Friday in local elections that are viewed as a barometer for how the party will perform in a coming general election and a key test for the embattled prime minister, Rishi Sunak.

headline: A Race the Whole World Is Watching
abstract: A three-team race is deciding this year’s Premier League champion. The competition’s global reach means a significant portion of the world’s population is following along.
lead_paragraph: The teams might bear the names of English towns, the stadiums might sit on English soil and the stands might still be primarily filled with English fans, but the Premier League slipped its borders long ago. The world’s most popular sports league has, for some time, been a global soccer competition that just happens to be staged in England.

headline: At Venice Biennale, Artists Make a Case for Returning Looted Artifacts
abstract: For years, activists and politicians have led discussions about whether disputed museum objects should go back to their countries of origin. At this year’s Biennale, artists are entering the fray.
lead_paragraph: When Glicéria Tupinambá, an Indigenous Brazilian artist, first visited the Quai Branly Museum in Paris, she had an encounter that would change her life.

headline: Eurovision Fans Are Hungry for News. These Superfans Are Here to Help.
abstract: A cottage industry of blogs and social media accounts, run by Eurovision obsessives in their spare time, satisfies a seemingly endless demand.
lead_paragraph: Magnus Bormark, a longtime rock guitarist in Norway, said his band had gotten used to releasing music with little publicity. So nothing prepared him for the onslaught of attention since the band, Gåte, was selected to represent Norway at this year’s Eurovision Song Contest.

headline: Planning Their Proposals, Together
abstract: Some couples choose to turn away from traditional engagements and opt for joint proposals, no surprise needed.
lead_paragraph: For many couples, a wedding proposal suggests an element of surprise. One partner typically chooses the location and the activity, sometimes even inviting family and friends to join in the celebration. The other partner is often left initially stunned.

headline: Thousands Believe Covid Vaccines Harmed Them. Is Anyone Listening?
abstract: All vaccines have at least occasional side effects. But people who say they were injured by Covid vaccines believe their cases have been ignored.
lead_paragraph: Within minutes of getting the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine, Michelle Zimmerman felt pain racing from her left arm up to her ear and down to her fingertips. Within days, she was unbearably sensitive to light and struggled to remember simple facts.

headline: Oil Companies Expand Offshore Drilling, Pointing to Energy Needs
abstract: Shell and others say they plan to drill for oil and gas in the Gulf of Mexico in part because doing so releases fewer greenhouse gases than drilling on land.
lead_paragraph: About 80 miles southeast of Louisiana’s coast, 100,000 metric tons of steel floats in the Gulf of Mexico, an emblem of the hopes of oil and gas companies.

headline: Chacarita Is Buenos Aires’s Quirkiest Neighborhood. Get There Soon.
abstract: Strolling through this once-traditional nook of the Argentine capital, the author found Art Deco houses on cobblestone streets, decadent churros and pizza slices, and whimsy around every corner.
lead_paragraph: To become a city’s coolest new neighborhood, there are certain prerequisites: a crop of cafes that toe the line between cozy and snobbish, chefs combining the innovative with the Instagrammable, and shops so sincere that they are doomed to close when rents rise, which they inevitably will.

headline: Initial Necklaces Worth Treasuring
abstract: A roundup of precious letters, from gothic characters to minimalist medallions.
lead_paragraph: Anne Boleyn, the queen of England from 1533 until her execution in 1536, was famously depicted wearing a gold “B” on a strand of pearls around her neck, and the mystery of its disappearance has led to centuries of speculation. (Was it, as some have suggested, given to her daughter, the future Queen Elizabeth I?) In recent decades, the piece has inspired brands, including Balenciaga and the London-based line Dilara Findikoglu, to create versions of their own, continuing a long tradition of adorning ourselves with our initials and those of our loved ones — a trend that seems especially prevalent now.

headline: Wanted: The Good Old Days When Kid-Lit Criminals Were Bad
abstract: Even for the youngest readers, attempted piggy-bank robbery may not cut it.
lead_paragraph: A good heist makes for a great story. There’s danger, action and the satisfaction of a daring plan that outsmarts the cops. But should responsible, grown-up writers expose such unlawful activities to an audience of innocent, impressionable children? Three new titles say yes. And I, for one, was excited to see the morality patrol flustered.

headline: It Was the Biggest Job of His Life. Was He On Target, or Off by Half?
abstract: An antiques shop owner in Maine was hired by a friend to value the collection of the artist Robert Indiana. His verdict was $85 million. A second appraisal says that’s way too much.
lead_paragraph: Whenever a worthy cause needs help in Rockland, Maine, this town of 7,000 overlooking Penobscot Bay, people reach out to Bruce Gamage Jr., an auctioneer who runs an antiques shop downtown.

headline: Noisy, Gaudy and Spiritual: Young Pilgrims Embrace an Ancient Goddess
abstract: On an island whose religious diversity is part of its democratic identity, many of the faithful participating in a pilgrimage for Mazu, Goddess of the Sea, were in their 20s and teens.
lead_paragraph: In a din of firecrackers, cymbals and horns, a team of devotees carried the shrouded wooden statue of a serene-faced woman, holding her aloft on a brightly decorated litter as they navigated through tens of thousands of onlookers.

headline: A 1970s Office Building’s New Life as a Rental
abstract: Pearl House, at 160 Water Street, is designed to bring personality to its neighborhood — whether you think that’s FiDi or the Seaport.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, 160 Water Street looks like one of the many office buildings packed close together on the border of the financial district and the Seaport neighborhood of Manhattan.

headline: Covid Vaccine Side Effects: 4 Takeaways From Our Investigation
abstract: Thousands of Americans believe they experienced rare but serious side effects. But confirming a link is a difficult task.
lead_paragraph: Soon after their arrival in late December 2020, the Covid-19 vaccines turned the pandemic around and opened a path back to normalcy. They prevented about 14.4 million deaths worldwide, according to one estimate.

headline: They Found a Rare Species in the Wild: An Original Bolt-Together House
abstract: The tiny cabin, one of the few extant examples of a popular 1970s design, had no heat or toilet. But it was theirs for $85,000.
lead_paragraph: One weekend in 2021, Gemma Warren was doing what she did every weekend: sitting over coffee in her home in Tulum, Mexico, combing through the real estate listings for cabins in the Catskill Mountains of New York.

headline: On Dua Lipa’s ‘Radical Optimism,’ Romance Is Everything
abstract: The English singer and songwriter’s third album, featuring production from Danny L Harle and Tame Impala’s Kevin Parker, is nonstop ear candy.
lead_paragraph: Romance is a blast on Dua Lipa’s third album, “Radical Optimism.” It’s a thumping, reverberating, woofer-rattling, arena-scale sensation, something to exult in even when it doesn’t always go right.

headline: Haiti’s Police Are ‘Begging for Help’ in Battle Against Ruthless Gangs
abstract: The United States is rushing support to Haiti’s depleted police force, which is awaiting international help as it tries to restore order and quell violence.
lead_paragraph: Gangs stormed the neighborhood of Haiti’s police chief, Frantz Elbé, in March, broke into his house, set it afire and killed his dog.

headline: $850,000 Homes in Lisbon, Portugal
abstract: A townhouse in Belém, an apartment with a balcony in Santos and an apartment on a plaza in Alfama.
lead_paragraph: This two-story townhouse, or “mini villa,” is in Belém, a neighborhood on the Tagus River that is famously marked by its eponymous 16th-century waterfront tower, and by the Monument of the Discoveries, which commemorates Portugal’s legacy of sea exploration. The farthest west of Lisbon’s civil parishes, with a 2011 population of 16,528, Belém is about four miles from the city center. The neighborhood is famous for its brightly colored houses, seafood restaurants and Pastel de Nata custard tarts from Pastéis de Belém, the legendary pastry shop. It is also near the Gothic Jerónimos Monastery and is a 30-minute train ride from Praça do Comércio, Lisbon’s main town square.

headline: Sofia Coppola’s Latest Release? A Lip Balm.
abstract: The tinted balm was inspired by products that the filmmaker confected as a girl to achieve the “berry-stained lips” of a character in a Roman Polanski movie.
lead_paragraph: As a girl, Sofia Coppola liked to melt down her lipsticks, mixing colors and consistencies to make a tint that conformed to her aesthetic ideal.

headline: A Duplex on Central Park Is Listed for $8.75 Million
abstract: The apartment, at 101 Central Park West, was bought in 1976 by Irwin Segelstein of Columbia Records and is on the market for the first time in nearly half a century.
lead_paragraph: The stately brick-and-limestone apartment house at 101 Central Park West has been home to many high-profile residents over the years, including the actors Harrison Ford and Rick Moranis and the equestrian Georgina Bloomberg.

headline: Lavender Is the Springtime Answer to Pumpkin Spice
abstract: Coffee shops, restaurants, retailers and bars are capitalizing on demand for the herby, purple flower with lattes, cocktails and chocolates.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Jonathan Grahm, a chocolatier, visited Paris and noticed the ubiquity of lavender in French soaps and lotions. He wanted to add a floral-leaning chocolate to his lineup at Compartés, a confectionery shop in Los Angeles established in 1950, and figured that lavender was his way in.

headline: What to Know About ‘Unfrosted’ and the Real History of Pop-Tarts
abstract: In his directorial debut, Jerry Seinfeld tackles the history of the fruit-filled pastries … kind of. Here’s the real origin story, along with a bonus quiz.
lead_paragraph: First, there was the Flamin’ Hot Cheetos biopic (complete with an Oscar-nominated song). Then came “Tetris”; “Air,” about Nike Air Jordan sneakers; “BlackBerry”; and “Barbie.”

headline: The 5 Boro Bike Tour: Tough to Arrange, Tough to Finish
abstract: The organizer of the event, which takes place on Sunday, says it’s harder to stage than the New York City Marathon.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at what it takes to stage the Five Boro Bike Tour, scheduled for Sunday. We’ll also get details about an appellate decision in a case that could force changes in policies at public schools with selective admissions policies.

headline: ‘The Contestant’ and the Reality-Show Ethics We Should Be Weighing
abstract: The documentary tells the strange story of a groundbreaking 1998 Japanese TV show but doesn’t go far enough in its examination.
lead_paragraph: So imagine this. It’s 1998. You want to be a comedian, and you’re desperate for work. You strike out for the big city and start going to auditions. Then, to your utter joy, you’re cast on a reality show.

headline: The ‘Fall Guy’ Filmmakers Have a Cause: Give Stunts an Oscar
abstract: The academy is keeping mum about the prospect, but the movie is part of a renewed push for a new Academy Award first considered more than 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The life of stuntmen and women is never glamorous. The job is to take the fall, endure the pain, break the bone, then walk away — unsung, battered and bruised. They usually move on to the next gig without ever seeing the finished product. They rarely get invited to the movie premiere. Oscars? Forget about it.

headline: Untangling the Mess of Campus Protests
abstract: And the role politicians play in all of it.
lead_paragraph: On this episode of “Matter of Opinion,” the hosts get heated about the political divisions and contradictions revealed by the recent campus protests and ask why some in Washington seem so invested in perpetuating the demonstrations.

headline: It’s Time to Tax the Billionaires
abstract: Billionaires are experts at avoiding taxes. By banding together, countries can make them pay up.
lead_paragraph: Billionaires are experts at avoiding taxes. By banding together, countries can make them pay up.

headline: What Does African Rejection Mean for the U.S.?
abstract: The U.S. is losing its terror-fighting presence in Africa. That’s not a bad thing if Washington uses the development to help African governments deliver more to their citizens.
lead_paragraph: The forced withdrawal, announced last month, of more than 1,000 U.S. Special Operations troops and drone operators in Niger and Chad should raise the alarm for Washington. In Africa, our policy of strengthening security partnerships rather than supporting democracy has not worked. The United States needs a new approach.

headline: In His New Song, Johnny Cash Goes to the Laundromat
abstract: … and more new music for your weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The New York Times, picks a playlist of five recently released songs to listen to this weekend:

headline: On the Road for a Modern Pilgrimage
abstract: In Taiwan, it has been the season for Mazu, the most widely venerated of folk deities that many people here turn to for solace, guidance and good fortune. This year, the country’s two major pilgrimages for Mazu attracted record numbers of participants. Many of them are younger Taiwanese who are drawn to keeping alive the old traditions.
lead_paragraph: In Taiwan, it has been the season for Mazu, the most widely venerated of folk deities that many people here turn to for solace, guidance and good fortune. This year, the country’s two major pilgrimages for Mazu attracted record numbers of participants. Many of them are younger Taiwanese who are drawn to keeping alive the old traditions.

headline: Maps of Two Cicada Broods, Reunited After 221 Years
abstract: Brood XIII and Brood XIX are making their first dual appearance since 1803.
lead_paragraph: Brood XIII and Brood XIX are making their first dual appearance since 1803.

headline: Would You Ever Want to Be a Politician?
abstract: Twelve lawmakers told The Times what Congress was really like. Do their answers make a life in public office more admirable and attractive to you? Or is it something you would rather avoid?
lead_paragraph: Would you ever want to hold or seek an elected office in the government? Why or why not? What do you think would be the most rewarding or challenging aspects of holding political office? Do you consider being a politician an important or honorable job?

headline: Israeli Officials Weigh Sharing Power With Arab States in Postwar Gaza
abstract: Israeli officials say they are discussing inviting Arab states to help oversee Gaza after the war. Arab officials rejected the idea because it doesn’t ensure Palestinian statehood.
lead_paragraph: For months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has avoided detailed public discussion about Gaza’s postwar future. Trying to placate both his far-right allies, who seek to rebuild Israeli settlements in Gaza, and Israel’s foreign partners, who want Gaza returned to Palestinian governance, Mr. Netanyahu has stopped short of any specific declaration.

headline: Zendaya Is No Stranger to the Met Gala Red Carpet. But It’s Been a While.
abstract: The actress will return to the event for the first time in five years, this time as a host. Take a look at all her previous Met Gala looks.
lead_paragraph: “The designers must fight to the death to dress you,” Kelly Ripa told Zendaya, the 27-year-old actress, as they discussed her preparation for this year’s Met Gala on a recent episode of “Live With Kelly and Mark.”

headline: U.S. Approved More Weapons for Ukraine. Now It’s a Race Against Time.
abstract: President Biden and Ukraine’s allies have invoked a sense of urgency over weapon deliveries. But there are logistical hurdles, and Ukraine has little time to lose.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday, as Russia put pressure on Ukrainian forces across a 600-mile front line, Ukraine received a shipment of anti-armor rockets, missiles and badly needed 155-millimeter artillery shells. It was the first installment from the $61 billion in military aid that President Biden approved just four days earlier.

headline: Google Employees Tune Out Antitrust Threat as Trial Comes to a Head
abstract: They shrugged off concerns about the company’s fate ahead of closing arguments in the Justice Department’s lawsuit this week.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Google’s employees gathered for an all-hands meeting named T.G.I.F. These companywide meetings are rarely held on Fridays these days, but the name has stuck.

headline: What Happens When NASA Loses Eyes on Earth? We’re About to Find Out.
abstract: Three long-running satellites will soon be switched off, forcing scientists to figure out how to adjust their views of our changing planet.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the next few years — no one knows exactly when — three NASA satellites, each one as heavy as an elephant, will go dark.

headline: Attack on U.C.L.A. Encampment Stirs Fears of Clashes Elsewhere
abstract: The first big pro-Israel counter demonstration was on Sunday in Los Angeles, home to large Israeli and Jewish populations. More are planned in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: At a rally at the University of California, Los Angeles, last Sunday, Elan Carr, the leader of an Israeli diaspora group, told more than 1,000 demonstrators that Jewish mobilization at universities was beginning.

headline: A New Wave of Appreciation for the Man Who Drew New York
abstract: Jason Polan chronicled city life in thousands of sketches before he died at 37 in 2020. What happens to his legacy now?
lead_paragraph: A somber gathering of artists and illustrators took place at a gallery in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan on a recent Friday evening. They were there for a Wright auction preview of the drawings and personal belongings of Jason Polan, the celebrated New York street artist who died of cancer at 37 in 2020.

headline: Calls to Divest From Israel Put Students and Donors on Collision Course
abstract: To get protesters off campus lawns, Brown University and others have agreed to consider ending investments linked to Israel. But how?
lead_paragraph: Desperate to stem protests that have convulsed campuses across the country, a small number of universities have agreed to reconsider their investments in companies that do business with Israel.

headline: Big Ticket: N.Y.’s Top Sales and Listings in April
abstract: April's top sales include a $22 million row house bought by the founder of the beauty brand Glossier.
lead_paragraph: April's top sales include a $22 million row house bought by the founder of the beauty brand Glossier.

headline: A New Issue Flares in the 2024 Race: Campus Protests
abstract: With tensions escalating and Republicans pouncing, President Biden finally weighed in and sought to increase the distance between himself and some of the more radical activism on colleges.
lead_paragraph: Protests and arrests on college campuses exploded into the forefront of the presidential race this week, opening up a new line of attack for Republicans and forcing President Biden to directly address an issue that has divided the liberal wing of his party.

headline: U.S. Antitrust Case Against Google Is Just the Start
abstract: As the Justice Department’s case against Google nears an end, the federal government has more suits in the pipeline trying to rein in Big Tech.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government’s landmark antitrust trial against Google’s search business is nearing its conclusion. But the parade of major federal cases challenging Big Tech’s power is just getting going.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, May 3, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: MAGA Is Demoting the Anti-Abortion Forces It Once Coddled
abstract: Swing-state Republicans are running from the anti-abortion movement.
lead_paragraph: Kari Lake’s appearance at Arizona State University last week was billed as a town hall, but it wasn’t really, because only representatives of young conservative groups were permitted to ask her anything.

headline: Protect Journalists, Everywhere
abstract: On World Press Freedom Day, a reminder of how many journalists are not free to do their vital work.
lead_paragraph: Friday is World Press Freedom Day, and The Times is lending its pages to amplifying the cause of bringing home the hundreds of missing or jailed journalists across the globe.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Jane Schoenbrun’s “I Saw the TV Glow.”
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Jane Schoenbrun’s “I Saw the TV Glow.”

headline: How to Survive Your High School Reunion
abstract: Step one: Manage your expectations.
lead_paragraph: The first high school reunion I attended was held in a basement reached by a rickety elevator. After I got there, I hung out nearby to see the other arrivals. This turned out to be a mistake.

headline: Immigrants With DACA Protections Will Be Eligible for Obamacare
abstract: Thousands of immigrants in the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program could obtain federal health coverage this year under a new rule.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people who were brought to the United States illegally as children will be able to obtain health care through the Affordable Care Act under a new federal rule, U.S. officials said on Friday.

headline: A.I. at Your Jobs + Hank Green Talks TikTok + Deepfake High School
abstract: A synthetic chief executive, a bot trained on employees’ personalities, and a regular duel with ChatGPT — our listeners brought us their stories.
lead_paragraph: We asked listeners to tell us about the wildest ways they have been using artificial intelligence at work. This week, we bring you their stories. Then, Hank Green, a legendary YouTuber, stops by to talk about how creators are reacting to the prospect of a ban on TikTok, and about how he’s navigating an increasingly fragmented online environment. And finally, deep fakes are coming to Main Street: We’ll tell you the story of how they caused turmoil in a Maryland high school and what, if anything, can be done to fight them.

headline: The Protesters and the President
abstract: Over the past week, thousands of students protesting the war in Gaza have been arrested.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language.

headline: The Secret Recording Played at Trump’s Trial, and the Latest Cease-Fire Negotiations
abstract: Plus, the shadow over the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: What Happened When the Skating Coaches Wanted a Union
abstract: A group of figure skating coaches at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan, many of whom earn less than $40,000 a year, sought to bargain their contracts collectively. Two were fired.
lead_paragraph: A simmering labor dispute involving figure skating coaches at Sky Rink in Manhattan ramped up in recent days after two leaders of a fledgling union were fired as part-time employees.

headline: U.S. Job Market Eases, but Hiring Remains Firm
abstract: Employers added 175,000 jobs in April, a milder pace than in the winter months, though layoffs have remained low and most sectors appear stable.
lead_paragraph: The American job market may be shifting into a lower gear this spring, a turn that economists have expected for months after a vigorous rebound from the pandemic shock.

headline: The Side Effects of Covid Vaccines
abstract: Thousands of Americans have filed vaccine-injury claims with the federal government.
lead_paragraph: Let me start with a disclaimer: The subject of today’s newsletter will make some readers uncomfortable. It makes me a little uncomfortable.

headline: Iran Says It Released Crew of Israel-Linked Ship It Detained
abstract: Iranian forces seized the Portuguese-flagged ship, the MSC Aries, as tensions between Iran and Israel were rising.
lead_paragraph: Iran has released the crew of a container ship with links to Israel that it had detained last month, but is continuing to hold the vessel, the country’s foreign minister has said, according to Iranian media.

headline: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a nature documentary filmed in the Indian wilderness and an animated family adventure from the studio behind “Despicable Me.”
lead_paragraph: Cuddly Daniel Tiger would definitely not feel at ease in the real-world forests of India, which are home to about 70 percent of the planet’s tigers. In this Disneynature documentary, filmed over the course of 1,500 days and narrated by Priyanka Chopra Jonas, we get to know one of these creatures: a tigress named Ambar, who protects her cubs from pythons, prowls the forest for food and survives brutal monsoon seasons to roam another day.

headline: ‘The Contestant’: Traumatic Isolation Played for Laughs
abstract: A new Hulu documentary looks back on a Japanese reality show starring a man, Nasubi, who didn’t know he was on TV. In an interview, he discusses why he’s sharing his story.
lead_paragraph: Naked, alone in a tiny room in Japan, Nasubi had one way to survive: submit entries for sweepstakes.

headline: What Will Warren Buffett Bet on Next?
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway shareholders will gather in Omaha for the conglomerate’s annual meeting on Saturday, with questions about the company’s future.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of investors are flocking to Omaha this weekend, which can mean only one thing: It’s time for Berkshire Hathaway’s annual shareholder meeting, dubbed the “Woodstock for capitalists.”

headline: Biden Honors Prominent Democrats With Presidential Medal of Freedom
abstract: Six months before the election, the president selected a list of awardees heavy with political allies like Nancy Pelosi, James E. Clyburn and John F. Kerry.
lead_paragraph: President Biden awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom on Friday to a host of prominent Americans, including several of his most important political allies like former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, former Secretary of State John F. Kerry and Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina.

headline: Crosstown Rivals Publicly Criticized Over Campus Protests
abstract: As U.S.C. and U.C.L.A. pick up the pieces, the two universities present dueling case studies in crisis management.
lead_paragraph: They are crosstown rivals and civic landmarks. One is public, one private. One is surrounded by some of the priciest real estate in the nation; the other’s neighborhood is decidedly more working-class.

headline: The Perils of the Fed’s Vast Bond Holdings
abstract: The Federal Reserve is shedding assets at a glacial pace, exposing the financial system to continuing risks, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is engaged in a colossal transformation of the financial economy. Yet scarcely anyone is noticing.

headline: Medical Debt Shows Up Less Often on Credit Reports
abstract: But the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said 15 million people still had medical bills in their files, which can make it hard to qualify for loans.
lead_paragraph: The share of Americans with unpaid medical bills tainting their credit files has fallen in the two years since the major credit reporting agencies — Equifax, Experian and TransUnion — changed how that debt was reported, a federal watchdog agency said this week.

headline: 8 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: After the lead of a blockbuster action movie goes missing, his stunt double, Colt Seavers (Ryan Gosling), must try to find him. This action romp includes an impressive array of stunts.

headline: The Fed Just Got the Job Market Cooling It Has Been Waiting For
abstract: Wage growth and hiring slowed in April, prodding investors to slightly increase their bets on rate cuts this year.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are keeping a close eye on the job market as they contemplate when and whether they can cut interest rates this year. Friday's jobs report offered early evidence of the type of moderation that they have been hoping to see.

headline: Still No Stag and Not Much Flation
abstract: Most of the bad news about the economy is just noise.
lead_paragraph: The economic news continues to be pretty good, especially compared with the dire forecasts many were making in late 2022. But you might not have gotten that message if you watch financial TV: It’s hard to spend 24/7 talking about the economy while saying “not much happened this week.” So commentators — and partisan media — seize on every hint of bad news.

headline: Pro-Palestinian Encampments Spread to Campuses in Other Countries
abstract: Student activists in Australia, Britain, France and elsewhere are challenging their universities’ stances on the war in Gaza and ties to Israel.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Palestinian students at one of France’s most elite universities, Sciences Po, occupied a campus building overnight. Like-minded demonstrators at University College London set up an encampment. And tents with Palestinian flags stretched out this week across university campuses in Australia.

headline: Horse Racing’s Loudest Critic Is Favored in Its Biggest Race
abstract: The brash owner Mike Repole will take a break from tweaking horse racing’s powers when his colt Fierceness runs in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: In the world according to Mike Repole, everyone involved in horse racing is a dummy. Except him, Mike from Queens or the Commish, as some of his followers on X call him.

headline: The Death of a Treaty Could Be a Lifesaver for Taiwan
abstract: Since pulling out of an arms-limitation agreement with Russia in 2019, the U.S. has quickly developed new weapons that could be used to stop a Chinese invasion force.
lead_paragraph: During a military exercise with the Philippines that began last month, the U.S. Army deployed a new type of covert weapon that is designed to be hidden in plain sight.

headline: Missouri and South Dakota Move Toward Abortion Rights Ballot Questions
abstract: Both states are reliably Republican and have abortion bans that are among the strictest in the nation.
lead_paragraph: Two more states with near-total abortion bans are poised to have citizen-sponsored measures on the ballot this year that would allow voters to reverse those bans by establishing a right to abortion in their state constitutions.

headline: Sexually Transmitted Infections Have Surged, and Age Is No Barrier
abstract: Older daters are not getting adequate screening and protection from S.T.I.s. Here’s how to be a safer sexually active senior.
lead_paragraph: Since her marriage of more than 20 years ended in divorce, Amy, a 62-year-old Texan, has had a couple of committed relationships and a handful of sexual partners.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a Mexican family drama, a Palestinian coming-of-age tale, a high-school movie from Ukraine and more.
lead_paragraph: There is a beautifully elastic quality to Rodrigo García’s “Familia,” which follows the myriad members of a Mexican family across a day spent together at their house in the countryside. The story is nothing new. The patriarch, Leo (Daniel Giménez Cacho), wants to sell the estate and retire from the job he has held for most of his life. The proposition unleashes currents of raw emotion at the dinner table, as his children (three daughters and one son) and grandchildren, not to mention their various partners and spouses, reckon with their family home and with each other.

headline: Punchy, Potent Tuna Puttanesca
abstract: Don’t stint on the anchovies.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The Kentucky Derby is on Saturday, the first since last season’s spectacularly sad and difficult outing. I’m about as good of a handicapper as I am a heart surgeon, but here’s my bet: Fierceness, trained by the horseman Todd Pletcher and ridden by the four-time Derby winner John Velazquez. I’ll tip my mint julep to that team at the start of the race and, if I’m not celebrating a couple of minutes later, I’ll still be eating maple-pecan bourbon balls for the win.

headline: At Frieze, Photographer of Gay Life Seeks ‘a Place in the Sunshine’
abstract: Stanley Stellar  has documented gay New York, on the streets and in his studio, for decades. Now he steps onto his biggest stage.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Stellar was on Canal Street one Sunday morning in 1976 when a young man with a killer body passed by. Like many New York street photographers, Stellar is curious, bordering on nosy, and he can, when necessary, be a whiz at masking flirtation as flattery to put straight guys at ease.

headline: An Opaque Philip Johnson House Reopens After 15 Years
abstract: Following an extensive restoration, the Brick House, the other half of the architect’s famous Glass House, is once again receiving visitors.
lead_paragraph: The architect Philip Johnson’s Glass House, a rectangular glass-and-steel residence set on a grassy shelf above a wooded bluff in New Canaan, Conn., has epitomized a certain East Coast ideal of midcentury elegance since its completion in 1949. Before becoming an architect at age 37, Johnson ran the architecture department at MoMA, and the spare, luminous building, which he inhabited for over half a century, embodies the Modernist International Style that he helped define in a landmark exhibition at the museum in 1932. The home also established Johnson himself as the paragon of a specific type of New York architect: erudite, absolutist in his refinement and formidable in his influence wielding, shaping careers, institutions and public opinion like few others in his field.

headline: ‘The Fall Guy’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director David Leitch narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ryan Gosling and Emily Blunt.
lead_paragraph: The director David Leitch narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ryan Gosling and Emily Blunt.

headline: Watch Ryan Gosling Perform His Own Stunt in ‘The Fall Guy’
abstract: The director David Leitch narrates a sequence from the film featuring Gosling and Emily Blunt.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Dortmund, Bayern Munich and the Siren Song of Yesterday
abstract: Change comes neither easily nor naturally at Germany’s two most successful clubs. Will success in the Champions League delay it again?
lead_paragraph: In those few minutes after Niclas Füllkrug had scored, as the Yellow Wall swayed and roared, Borussia Dortmund must have felt the stirring of some distant memory. Waves of attacks pounded down on Paris St.-Germain, now dizzied and wearied. The world shimmered with possibility. A place in the Champions League final felt, for a moment, close enough to touch.

headline: ‘The Cherry Orchard’ Review: Chekhov in the Fun Zone
abstract: Benedict Andrews’s production in London offers perfectly pitched comedy where other directors find somber tragedy.
lead_paragraph: When Anton Chekhov wrote “The Cherry Orchard,” his 1904 play about a financially beleaguered aristocratic household in turn-of-the-century Russia, he thought of it as a comedy. Generations of theater directors — starting with Konstantin Stanislavsky in its original Moscow run — had other ideas, preferring to render it as a somber tragedy. In London, a new production sets out to do justice to the playwright’s vision by leaning in to the play’s comedic elements.

headline: TikTok Tells Advertisers: ‘We Are Not Backing Down’
abstract: Hundreds of marketers and ad agency types flocked to TikTok’s annual sales presentation after a new law put its future in question.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of advertisers, including major brands like L’Oreal and Victoria’s Secret, flocked to the Lower East Side on Thursday night for TikTok’s annual spring pitch to marketers. It had been about a week since President Biden signed a law that says TikTok must be sold from its Chinese parent company or face a potential ban, and marketers were champing at the bit to hear TikTok’s thoughts.

headline: Who Is Hope Hicks, Once One of Trump’s Most Trusted Advisers?
abstract: Ms. Hicks, testifying in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, is expected to be asked about the hush money payment at the center of the case against him.
lead_paragraph: Hope Hicks was 26 years old and had no political experience when Donald J. Trump plucked her from a job at his daughter Ivanka’s clothing business and hired her for his presidential campaign in 2015.

headline: Winners and Losers of the Columbia Protests? History Will Tell.
abstract: Activism often lands on the right side of history. But history also shows that tactical mistakes — and smashing windows — can weaken protests’ effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: Fifty-six years to the day after police in riot gear first swept through the campus of Columbia University to clear buildings that had been taken over by protesters, hundreds of officers stormed into Hamilton Hall and put an end to the occupation over the war in Gaza. Of the 109 people arrested this time, most were students, though Mayor Eric Adams claimed others were “outside agitators” who he believed were dangerously “radicalizing our children,” a characterization that fell awkwardly between forgiveness and condescension.

headline: Police Clear Tents and Arrest N.Y.U. and New School Protesters
abstract: Protesters had been camped out for days, demanding that their schools end financial ties with Israel.
lead_paragraph: Police officers cleared two pro-Palestinian encampments and arrested student demonstrators at New York University and the New School early Friday morning after officials at the universities asked for their assistance, New York Police Department officials said.

headline: Auditor That Works for Trump Media Is Charged With Fraud
abstract: Regulators said BF Borgers failed to abide by accounting rules that its public company clients are required to follow.
lead_paragraph: An accounting firm that audits the financial statements of hundreds of public companies including former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company can no longer do so, U.S. securities regulators said on Friday.

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Violence and its impact on writers anchor three of our recommended books this week: Michael Korda offers a group biography of the soldier-poets of World War I, while Kristine Ervin writes about her mother’s murder and Salman Rushdie relives the knife attack that almost took his life two years ago.

headline: Liberia Moves to Create War Crimes Court, Decades After Civil Wars Ended
abstract: Until now, key players had blocked the establishment of a court that could hold them accountable for atrocities like murder, rape and torture.
lead_paragraph: Liberia’s president has signed an executive order establishing a war crimes court, the culmination of a decades-long effort to bring justice to victims of the country’s two civil wars, which killed an estimated 250,000 people from 1989 to 2003.

headline: 15-Year-Old Girl Charged With Murder in Stabbing Death of Bronx Teenager
abstract: The victim, identified by the police as Emery Mizell, 17, was attacked at an apartment building in the Soundview neighborhood of the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old girl was arrested on Thursday and charged with murder in the stabbing death of another teenager in the Bronx earlier that day, the police said.

headline: ‘Access Hollywood’ Tape Rattled Trump’s Campaign, Hicks Recalls in Testimony
abstract: Hope Hicks, Donald J. Trump’s campaign press secretary in 2016, testified about the infamous recording, which captured him bragging about grabbing women’s genitals. It was revealed by The Washington Post a month before the election.
lead_paragraph: Hope Hicks, a former spokeswoman for Donald J. Trump, described during testimony in his criminal trial on Friday that the release of the so-called “Access Hollywood” tape shook his campaign in 2016.

headline: Nuclear Power as a Clean Energy Tool?
abstract: Readers discuss an Opinion guest essay calling that a fantasy. Also: Quality at Boeing; a toilet sign; running, fast and slow.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: At New York City Ballet’s Gala, the Usual With a Twist
abstract: The two premieres — one by Justin Peck, one by Amy Hall Garner — were gala-style pieces that felt more fresh than rote.
lead_paragraph: Ballet galas are a special species of performance, as much about schmoozing and speeches and gowns as about the dancing. Ballets made for such occasions tend to fall into certain patterns and formulas: usually upbeat and often emphasizing opportunities for dancers to show off. As with any genre, a gala-style piece can be done in a rote or fresh manner, and at New York City Ballet’s spring gala on Thursday, the two premieres were fresh enough.

headline: Ballot-Access Consultant for R.F.K. Jr. Was Arrested on Assault Charges
abstract: The consultant, Trent Pool, was arrested at a Manhattan hotel last weekend after a woman said he had assaulted her, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: A top ballot-access consultant for Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s independent presidential campaign was arrested on assault charges at a luxury Manhattan hotel early last Saturday morning, the New York Police Department said.

headline: Kendrick Lamar Gets Inspired (by Drake), and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Miranda Lambert, Illuminati Hotties, Mabe Fratti and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Furor Over U.S. Steel Bid Puts Secretive Government Panel In Spotlight
abstract: Backlash over the deal has echoes of the 1980s when Nippon Steel tried and failed to buy another American metal company.
lead_paragraph: At a campaign event last month in Pennsylvania, the heartland of American steel manufacturing, President Biden made clear that he does not want the proposed takeover of U.S. Steel by Japan’s Nippon Steel to happen.

headline: How I Reported on the Columbia Student Protests … in 1996
abstract: Nearly three decades ago, a young reporter slept on the floor of Columbia’s Hamilton Hall for several nights to file an article for The Village Voice.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 students were slumped around the oak-and-marble lobby of Hamilton Hall, the main hub of Columbia College, fighting off sleep.

headline: TikTok’s Boss Goes From Reserved Tech Exec to Met Gala Chair
abstract: With the company facing a ban in the U.S., Shou Chew is expected to join Zendaya, Bad Bunny and Anna Wintour on the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: Although the Met Gala serves as a branding event for Vogue, it has long accepted sponsorships from the tech giants that have threatened the very survival of legacy media publications.

headline: When Failure Is the Only Senate Option
abstract: Members of the upper chamber are regularly holding votes on amendments that, by design, have no chance whatsoever of passage.
lead_paragraph: Senator Eric Schmitt, a freshman Republican from Missouri, is new to the Senate but has already figured out that the so-called upper chamber is not always on the up and up.

headline: The Actor Who Played Jar Jar Binks Is Proud of His ‘Star Wars’ Legacy
abstract: Ahmed Best recalls the painful backlash to the “Phantom Menace” character that was considered a racial stereotype at the time, but is now embraced by fans.
lead_paragraph: Ahmed Best is a futurist, an educator, a martial artist, a writer-director and the actor behind Jar Jar Binks, the most hated character in the “Star Wars” universe.

headline: Voters Swing to Labour in English Local Elections: Key Takeaways
abstract: While the ballots were still being counted on Friday, big losses for the Conservative Party could signal a difficult general election later this year.
lead_paragraph: While the votes in local elections in England and Wales were still being counted on Friday, a picture has begun to emerge of significant losses for the governing Conservative Party.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: This week, the hosts discussed a revelation from the South Dakota governor, Kristi Noem, as well as former President Trump’s apparent inability to stay awake in his Manhattan criminal trial. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: This week, the hosts discussed a revelation from the South Dakota governor, Kristi Noem, as well as former President Trump’s apparent inability to stay awake in his Manhattan criminal trial. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: University of Chicago President Says ‘Encampment Cannot Continue’
abstract: The university is home to the Chicago statement, a framework for free expression that has been embraced by other colleges.
lead_paragraph: The president of the University of Chicago said on Friday that the pro-Palestinian encampment on his campus’s quad “cannot continue,” a position that was being closely watched in higher education because the university has long held itself up as a national model for free expression.

headline: Gas Stove Pollution Risk Is Greatest in Smaller Homes, Study Finds
abstract: Gas-burning ranges, a significant contributor to indoor pollution, can produce and spread particularly high levels of some pollutants in smaller spaces.
lead_paragraph: For decades, scientists have worked to clean up air pollution from factories, cars and power plants. But researchers are increasingly turning their attention to the air that people breathe indoors. And one appliance has come to the fore as a source of pollutants harmful to human health: the humble gas stove.

headline: The Music of Luca Guadagnino’s Cinematic Universe
abstract: Hear songs from “Challengers,” “Call Me by Your Name” and more.
lead_paragraph: This week I saw Luca Guadagnino’s much-hyped tennis love-triangle movie “Challengers” — like a lot of people, it seems. And also like a lot of people, including The Times’s chief film critic, Manohla Dargis, I had a good time at the movies. This film “isn’t trying to say anything important, which is a relief,” Dargis writes in her astute review. “It wants to engage and entertain you, and it does that very nicely.” She also characterizes Guadagnino, correctly I think, as a filmmaker adept at “blissfully gliding along the surfaces of life.”

headline: A Gaza Doctor Has Died in Israeli Custody, Palestinian Groups Say
abstract: Israel has not offered an explanation for the death of Dr. Adnan Ahmad Albursh, chief of orthopedics at Al-Shifa hospital, four months after he was first detained.
lead_paragraph: A Palestinian doctor from the Gaza Strip, detained by Israeli forces and held for four months, has died in detention, Palestinian officials and detainee rights groups say.

headline: As Rains Lash Southeast Texas, Residents Brace for More Flooding
abstract: Several counties were under flood warnings in the Houston area and other parts of Southeast Texas on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Schools were closed, roads were flooded and residents were told to evacuate as heavy rain continued to lash the Houston area and other parts of Southeast Texas on Friday, placing thousands of people under flood warnings.

headline: Henry Cuellar Indicted Over Bribery Scheme
abstract: Mr. Cuellar and his wife are accused of accepting bribes from a bank in Mexico City and an oil and gas company owned by Azerbaijan. He has maintained they are innocent.
lead_paragraph: Representative Henry Cuellar, a Texas Democrat in a crucial swing district, and his wife were charged with participating in a yearslong $600,000 bribery scheme involving Azerbaijan and a Mexican bank, according to a federal indictment unsealed in Houston on Friday.

headline: How Rebel ‘Star Wars’ Fans Saved the Original Movies
abstract: George Lucas wants them to fade into oblivion. But some fans spent more than a decade digitally restoring the original “Star Wars” trilogy, preserving the movies as they were shown in theaters.
lead_paragraph: Han shot first.

headline: What I’d Assign to Today’s College Students
abstract: A reading list outside the progressive box.
lead_paragraph: My weekend column used this season of campus protest as an opportunity to discuss the evolution of Columbia’s core curriculum, whose readings on contemporary politics, I argued, usefully distill the core of contemporary progressivism while leaving a great deal else by the wayside.

headline: Nancy Schuster, Crossword Champion, Creator and Editor, Dies at 90
abstract: A dedicated cruciverbalist, she won the first American Crossword Puzzle Tournament in 1978. She went on to test and proofread puzzles for The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Schuster, who began crafting crossword puzzles for a P.T.A. newspaper when her children were young and who went on to make puzzles her career — constructing them, competing in tournaments and editing them for magazines — died on April 26 in Newburgh, N.Y., in Orange County. She was 90.

headline: Joel Conarroe, ‘Hub of the New York Literary Wheel,’ Dies at 89
abstract: An influential arts administrator and educator, he was a trusted confidant to countless writers, notably Philip Roth.
lead_paragraph: Joel Conarroe, a celebrated arts administrator and professor who headed the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation for nearly two decades and served as a friend and confidant to a pride of literary lions, including his close friend Philip Roth, died on Sunday in the Bronx. He was 89.

headline: The Columbia Protests Made the Same Mistake the Civil Rights Movement Did
abstract: Passion counts for a lot, but the bottom line should be results. The protests seem to be headed in a different direction.
lead_paragraph: Last week I wrote about the protests that had come to dominate my professional home, Columbia University, and make headlines across the country. I said that though I did not believe the participants were motivated by antisemitism, the volume, fury and duration of their protest left many Jewish students feeling under siege for their Jewishness. That assessment has turned out to be one of the more polarizing things I have ever written, in part because some readers interpreted my position as opposing student protest overall.

headline: What Would Happen if the U.S. Suddenly Seemed Like a Risky Investment?
abstract: The American economy has long been a safe haven, but it might not be forever.
lead_paragraph: Financially speaking, the United States has been a Teflon nation. Bad things happen — near defaults, giant budget deficits, a Capitol invasion — but nothing sticks for long. The world’s investors keep pumping money into the country, which keeps interest rates low and stock prices high.

headline: Latino Advocacy Groups Call Trump’s Deportation Plans a Danger to Democracy
abstract: The political arms of five organizations are coordinating their efforts to mobilize Hispanic Democrats, saying that defeating the former president is their top goal.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of five Latino and immigrant rights’ organizations on Friday denounced former President Donald J. Trump’s immigration proposals, saying his plans would amount to constitutional overreach, lead to mass racial profiling against Latinos and pose a threat to democracy.

headline: Mississippi’s First Serious Bid to Expand Medicaid Collapses
abstract: State lawmakers failed to reach a compromise, dashing hopes of extending largely free health care to most low-income residents and supporting struggling rural hospitals.
lead_paragraph: Mississippi’s first serious attempt to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act collapsed Thursday night, after an agreement reached by state lawmakers earlier in the week disintegrated and last-minute scrambling for a compromise failed.

headline: U.S.C. Announces New Commencement Plans After Canceling its Main Ceremony
abstract: The university said it would hold a celebration at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. More than 100 school-specific graduations and smaller receptions will also take place with tighter security.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of tumult at the University of Southern California, administrators have announced updated commencement plans, with increased security and modified festivities. The plans are in lieu of the university’s main graduation ceremony, which the school had canceled, citing security concerns.

headline: Overlooked No More: Min Matheson, Labor Leader Who Faced Down Mobsters
abstract: As director of the International Ladies’ Garment Workers’ Union, she fought for better working wages and conditions while wresting control from the mob.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: New Mutations Identified in Bird Flu Virus
abstract: A genetic analysis sheds light on when the outbreak began, how the virus spread and where it may be going.
lead_paragraph: The bird flu virus sweeping across dairy farms in multiple states has acquired dozens of new mutations, including some that may make it more adept at spreading between species and less susceptible to antiviral drugs, according to a new study.

headline: A Conversation With Colm Tóibín
abstract: The Irish author discusses “Long Island,” the sequel to his 2009 novel “Brooklyn.”
lead_paragraph: Colm Tóibín’s 2009 novel “Brooklyn” told the story of a meek young Irishwoman, Eilis Lacey, who emigrates to New York in the 1950s out of a sense of familial obligation and slowly, diligently begins building a new life for herself. A New York Times best seller, the book was also adapted into an Oscar-nominated movie starring Saoirse Ronan — and now, 15 years after its publication, Tóibín has surprised himself by writing a sequel.

headline: Police Arrest 3 in Slaying of Sikh Leader That Shocked Canada
abstract: The killing of Hardeep Singh Nijjar, a Sikh nationalist who had sought a separate state in India and was viewed as a terrorist by New Delhi, set off diplomatic tensions between Canada and India.
lead_paragraph: Three Indian men were charged in the brazen slaying of a Sikh separatist on Canadian soil, the police said on Friday, a killing that set off a diplomatic clash with New Delhi after Prime Minister Justin Trudeau blamed “agents of the government of India” for orchestrating the shooting.

headline: Small Bedroom Ideas: The Best Ways to Maximize Your Tiny Space
abstract: How to store and decorate in a modest room.
lead_paragraph: How to store and decorate in a modest room.

headline: Jobs Data Revives Wall Street’s Hopes for a Rate Cut
abstract: A cooler-than-expected jobs report for April shifted the tone on Wall Street, rekindling investors’ expectations that the Federal Reserve may cut rates soon.
lead_paragraph: Just as Wall Street appeared to come to terms with the idea of high interest rates sticking around for longer, a cooler-than-expected jobs report on Friday brought the idea of rate cuts back into the conversation.

headline: ‘We Will Save Our Beef’: Florida Bans Lab-Grown Meat
abstract: Other states have also considered restrictions, citing concerns about farmers’ livelihoods and food safety, though the product isn’t expected to be widely available for years.
lead_paragraph: Florida has banned making and selling meat that is grown in a laboratory, a move several other states have considered amid worries about consumer safety and concerns that the technique could hurt the beef and poultry industries.

headline: Campus Protests Over Gaza Spotlight the Work of Student Journalists
abstract: Columbia University’s radio station and other student-led news outlets have provided some of the most detailed coverage of the turmoil engulfing university campuses.
lead_paragraph: Their updates come in harried bursts. Real-time narrations of the scene at Columbia University’s protest encampment in Manhattan, interspersed with the calmer voice of a host in the studio, directing live on air the dozen or so student journalists covering the moment police officers in riot gear moved in to clear an occupied university building Tuesday night.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, May 4, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Police Treatment of a Dartmouth Professor Stirs Anger and Debate
abstract: A video showing Annelise Orleck, 65, being taken to the ground intensified criticism of the decision by the college’s president to call in officers.
lead_paragraph: The video is jarring: A gray-haired woman tumbles, gets up to reach for her phone, held by police officers, and is yanked and taken to the ground. “Are you kidding me?” a bystander asks.

headline: Trump and His Onetime Confidante Meet Again, This Time in a Courtroom
abstract: Hope Hicks, once a spokeswoman for Donald J. Trump, broke down in tears on the witness stand as she talked about their time together.
lead_paragraph: Her voice low, her posture tense, the woman who spent years steering Donald J. Trump through strife and scandal stepped to the witness stand on Friday carrying a different burden. She was there under the fluorescent lights of a dreary Manhattan courtroom, seated 15 feet from the former president she once fiercely defended, to testify at his criminal trial.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Social Media Attacks Prompt City Council to Seek Investigation
abstract: The Council speaker requested an investigation of police officials’ use of social media to attack critics. The mayor’s office asked for an inquiry into a councilman’s behavior.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of top New York Police Department officials unleashing stinging attacks against their critics, the City Council speaker has asked a city watchdog agency to “urgently conduct” an official investigation into the department’s use of social media.

headline: The Job Market Shifted Into Lower Gear
abstract: Also, a congressman from Texas was indicted. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: After a winter of rapid growth in the American labor market, April’s jobs numbers delivered a more mixed picture. Employers added 175,000 positions, less than economists had expected and well below the average over the last year; and the unemployment rate climbed to 3.9 percent.

headline: From Hope Hicks, the Tears of Truth
abstract: It sunk in that her testimony was hurting the man she still admires.
lead_paragraph: Of all the senior aides who have worked for Donald Trump in recent years, it’s fair to say Hope Hicks was the most popular. As Trump’s surprisingly young communication director during the 2016 campaign and inside the White House, she was — by many accounts — unfailingly professional, polite and composed.

headline: Hope Hicks Takes the Stand: 5 Takeaways From Trump’s Criminal Trial
abstract: In a riveted courtroom, Ms. Hicks, the former spokeswoman for Donald J. Trump, testified how she and her former boss managed one scandal after another.
lead_paragraph: Gasps were heard in the overflow courtroom when Hope Hicks was called as a witness on Friday in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan, an audible sign of the anticipation as Mr. Trump’s former press secretary and White House communications director took the stand. Her testimony ended the trial’s third week in dramatic fashion.

headline: As Turkey Cuts Trade Ties, Israel’s Isolation Grows
abstract: Turkey said it would not resume trade with Israel until a “permanent cease-fire” in Gaza. The move came after a number of countries cut diplomatic ties with Israel.
lead_paragraph: Turkey said on Friday that it would suspend all trade with Israel until there was a “permanent cease-fire” in the Gaza Strip, the latest international sanction against Israel and one that underscores the mounting global pressure to end the war in the territory.

headline: Kristi Noem’s New Book Falsely Says She Met Kim Jong-un
abstract: “I’m sure he underestimated me,” Ms. Noem writes of the North Korean leader in her forthcoming book. A spokesman said the error would be corrected.
lead_paragraph: The new book by Gov. Kristi Noem of South Dakota, a biography that will be released on Tuesday, will be corrected to remove a false anecdote about her meeting Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, a spokesman for Ms. Noem said on Friday.

headline: Paramount Will Let Exclusive Talks With Skydance Lapse, Imperiling Deal
abstract: Negotiations are now likely to focus on another suitor, Sony, which has teamed up with the private equity giant Apollo on a $26 billion bid.
lead_paragraph: Paramount told Skydance that it would not extend the Hollywood studio’s exclusive window to negotiate a merger, two people with knowledge of the decisions said Friday, imperiling the deal but opening the door to other suitors for the owner of MTV and Nickelodeon.

headline: Cheers, Fears and ‘Le Wokisme’: How the World Sees U.S. Campus Protests
abstract: Abroad, some have praised the demonstrations. Others call the crackdowns evidence of American hypocrisy, or of a nation coming apart.
lead_paragraph: The world is watching what is happening on American campuses with shock, pride, relish and alarm. Scenes from the protests — and of the arrests of protesters — have been top news around the world from Bogotá to Berlin, Tehran to Paris.

headline: Evangelical Latinos Shift Toward the Republican Party
abstract: Republicans are attempting to seize an opportunity to gain votes within swing states from Hispanic evangelicals, who find more common ground socially and spiritually with the party.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are attempting to seize an opportunity to gain votes within swing states from Hispanic evangelicals, who find more common ground socially and spiritually with the party.

headline: Final Arguments in Google Antitrust Trial Conclude, Setting Up Landmark Ruling
abstract: Judge Amit P. Mehta must now decide whether Google violated the law, potentially setting a precedent for a series of tech monopoly cases.
lead_paragraph: A landmark antitrust trial against Google concluded on Friday after a federal judge heard final arguments, setting the stage for a ruling that could fundamentally shift the tech industry’s power.

headline: University of Chicago President Says Pro-Palestinian Encampment ‘Cannot Continue’
abstract: The president of the University of Chicago said on Friday that the pro-Palestinian encampment on his campus’s quad “cannot continue,” a position that was being closely watched in higher education because the university has long held itself up as a national model for free expression.
lead_paragraph: The president of the University of Chicago said on Friday that the pro-Palestinian encampment on his campus’s quad “cannot continue,” a position that was being closely watched in higher education because the university has long held itself up as a national model for free expression.

headline: Sam Ash Music Stores to Close After 100 Years in Business
abstract: The chain, which started with a single shop in Brooklyn in 1924, said it would close all 42 of its locations by the end of July, citing competition from online retailers.
lead_paragraph: Sam Ash, the family-owned chain of music stores that supplied countless beginners and working musicians with guitars, drums and other instruments, is closing all of its locations after 100 years in business, it announced this week.

headline: How Counterprotesters at U.C.L.A. Provoked Violence, Unchecked for Hours
abstract: The New York Times used videos filmed by journalists, witnesses and protesters to analyze hours of clashes — and a delayed police response — at a pro-Palestinian encampment on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times used videos filmed by journalists, witnesses and protesters to analyze hours of clashes — and a delayed police response — at a pro-Palestinian encampment on Tuesday.

headline: Hope Hicks Reluctantly Confronts the Man She ‘Totally Understands’ in Court
abstract: The dramatic appearance of Ms. Hicks, once one of Donald J. Trump’s closest aides, riveted the audience. During her testimony, she blinked back tears.
lead_paragraph: In the unceasing reality show that is Donald J. Trump’s life, his Manhattan criminal trial has functioned as something of a reunion episode, where supporting players return to confront the protagonist and relive memorable moments from seasons past. On Friday, the audience in the courtroom tensed when prosecutors announced the next person to testify on their behalf: Hope Hicks.

headline: C.J. Sansom, Mystery Novelist Drawn to Tudor England, Dies at 71
abstract: He wrote a popular series of books revolving around a hunchbacked detective, Shardlake, whose troubles echo the author’s experiences of childhood bullying.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, goody! An 800-page novel about the peasant uprisings of 1549!” Marilyn Stasio, the longtime mystery and crime reviewer for The New York Times Book Review, began a column in 2019.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Build World Pressure on Russia Over Space Nuclear Weapon
abstract: An American official said the United States had information undermining Russia’s claim that a device it is developing is for peaceful scientific research.
lead_paragraph: American officials are trying to increase international pressure on Russia not to deploy an antisatellite nuclear weapon in space, and have obtained information that undermines Moscow’s explanation that the device it is developing is for peaceful scientific purposes, a senior State Department official said on Friday.

headline: Billionaire Donor Assails Brown’s ‘Unconscionable’ Deal With Protesters
abstract: The real estate mogul Barry Sternlicht’s scathing criticism of his alma mater is the most immediate blowback against the school’s deal to end protests on campus.
lead_paragraph: One of Brown University’s major donors, the billionaire real estate mogul Barry Sternlicht, on Friday sharply criticized the school’s agreement to hold a board vote on cutting investments tied to Israel, calling it “unconscionable” and saying he had “paused” donations to the school.

headline: Joe Biden, Pot President?
abstract: The president’s allies say the Justice Department’s chill take on marijuana has a political upside.
lead_paragraph: On Labor Day in 2022, John Fetterman found himself in a room in Pittsburgh with President Biden.

headline: ‘The Miser’ Review: Updating Molière, but Missing a Key Ingredient
abstract: This Molière in the Park production doesn’t have the sharp satirical bite of the original.
lead_paragraph: The support beam of theater in France, Molière is nowhere near as famous in the United States. Yet the comic high jinks, star-crossed lovers and long-lost relatives that pop up in his play “The Miser,” first produced in 1668, will be instantly familiar to anybody who has ever seen a Shakespeare comedy.

headline: Columbia’s President Urges University to ‘Rebuild Community’ in Video
abstract: After President Nemat Shafik called the police to arrest protesters on campus earlier this week, she asked the school community to “show empathy and compassion for one another.”
