lead_paragraph: Columbia University’s president, Nemat Shafik, released a video message late on Friday, following several weeks of tension over Gaza war protests on campus that have spawned a wave of antiwar activism at universities across the country.

headline: After 3 Tourists Go Missing, Bodies Are Found in Baja California
abstract: Mexican authorities recovered the three bodies as a search went on for two Australian tourists and a U.S. citizen who disappeared while on vacation.
lead_paragraph: A dayslong search for three missing tourists who disappeared near a surfing town close to the U.S.-Mexico border ended tragically on Friday as the authorities said that they had located three bodies in a water hole.

headline: Hotfooted It
abstract: Jacob McDermott goes for it with a fast-paced Saturday debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Jacob McDermott’s first Saturday grid after having three Fridays published since last May. I am here for it, clapping and waving my hands, because nearly every long entry is a phrase that springs to mind with a dramatic flourish. An eye roll, a puff of dust denoting speed, a door flung open: These are kinetic touches, and they make for a fun solve. His puzzle will probably be most challenging for solvers who prefer trivia to idioms. Even though I picked up on the vernacular clues quickly, I was still boggled by a few terrific bits of wordplay.

headline: Trump and Hope Hicks Meet Again as She Testifies in Hush-Money Trial
abstract: Hope Hicks, the former spokeswoman for Donald Trump, testified about how she and Trump managed one scandal after another in the 2016 campaign. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
lead_paragraph: Hope Hicks, the former spokeswoman for Donald Trump, testified about how she and Trump managed one scandal after another in the 2016 campaign. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.

headline: Body Cameras Show Police Fatally Shooting Queens Man Holding Scissors
abstract: The man, Win Rozario, 19, had called 911 and seemed to be in mental distress, officials and his family said. The police appeared to shoot him at least four times.
lead_paragraph: Body camera footage of the police fatally shooting a 19-year-old Queens man in his kitchen in March shows what the police had described as a “chaotic” situation. But the video, released Friday, also renewed criticism of the decision to open fire on the man, who was holding scissors and seemed to be in mental distress.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Mortar Crews Reporting Signs of Brain Injuries
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Heads pounding, not being able to think straight or walk straight. You go to the medic. They say you are just dehydrated, drink water.”

headline: Israel, Gaza and the Law on Starvation in War
abstract: A complex legal question became more pressing after a statement from the U.N. human rights chief.
lead_paragraph: On March 19, Volker Türk, the United Nations’ human rights chief, said in an official statement that Israel’s policies regarding aid in Gaza might amount to a war crime.

headline: Drones Changed This Civil War, and Linked Rebels to the World
abstract: Consumer technologies are altering the course of the battle in Myanmar, and rebel drone units are taking notes on Ukraine and other conflicts.
lead_paragraph: In flip-flops and shorts, one of the finest soldiers in a resistance force battling the military junta in Myanmar showed off his weaponry. It was, he apologized, mostly in pieces.

headline: When a Bunch of Bloody Yanks Came for English Soccer
abstract: American investors are gobbling up the storied teams of the English Premier League — and changing the stadium experience in ways that soccer fans resent.
lead_paragraph: In the first half of a January game at Stamford Bridge, the London stadium where the Chelsea Football Club has played since its founding in 1905, seven well-groomed spectators in green velvet jackets stood up together from their seats behind the substitutes’ bench as players raced up and down the field in front of them. They pulled out books and began to read. Then they all brushed their teeth.

headline: How Dylan Lauren, Founder of Dylan’s Candy Bar, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Lauren hangs out with bunnies, grabs some ice cream and makes time for a workout — all while scouting new ideas for her candy business.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, Dylan Lauren has reigned as the candy queen of New York City thanks to her boutique candy store chain, Dylan’s Candy Bar.

headline: He Went From Prison to Politics. Now He Helps Others Get a Second Act.
abstract: Assemblyman Eddie Gibbs of East Harlem has used his experience to help people reinvent themselves, including a high-flying 1990s rapper who went to prison for murder.
lead_paragraph: While he was locked away in New York’s most dangerous prisons, Eddie Gibbs never imagined that he would share a stage with the governor. Now, as he walked to the dais, his hands were shaking and his mouth was dry.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,050
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 335
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Was the Stone Age Actually the Wood Age?
abstract: Neanderthals were even better craftsmen than thought, a new analysis of 300,000-year-old wooden tools has revealed.
lead_paragraph: In 1836, Christian Jürgensen Thomsen, a Danish antiquarian, brought the first semblance of order to prehistory, suggesting that the early hominids of Europe had gone through three stages of technological development that were reflected in the production of tools. The basic chronology — Stone Age to Bronze Age to Iron Age — now underpins the archaeology of most of the Old World (and cartoons like “The Flintstones” and “The Croods”).

headline: City College, Against Its Nature, Asks Police to End Campus Protest
abstract: The public college based in Harlem has a long history of radical politics and activism.
lead_paragraph: It was after 10 p.m. on Tuesday, and the administration building of a college in Upper Manhattan had been ransacked. Protesters were wielding lit flares, the campus was descending into chaos, and the college’s security guards were outnumbered and exhausted.

headline: Trump’s Scandals Captivate the Courtroom, but Case Hangs on Dry Details
abstract: Prosecutors started their criminal case against Donald J. Trump with eye-catching and lurid stories, but the heart of the matter is invoices and ledger entries.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is on trial for 34 felony counts of what could be the dullest sounding crime in New York’s penal code: falsifying business records.

headline: Family Values or Fighting Valor? Russia Grapples With Women’s Wartime Role.
abstract: Russian military efforts to recruit women from prisons and civilian life have clashed with President Vladimir V. Putin’s conservative agenda.
lead_paragraph: The Russian Army is gradually expanding the role of women as it seeks to balance President Vladimir V. Putin’s promotion of traditional family roles with the need for new recruits for the war in Ukraine.

headline: Got an Idea for a Toy? Toymakers Want to Hear From You.
abstract: Companies like Lego and Mattel have divisions that seek out design concepts directly from collectors and other highly dedicated fan bases.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of 2022, Lucas Bolt, an environmental artist and Lego enthusiast in Amsterdam, was working on a design for a Lego set the company had crowdsourced to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Dungeons & Dragons, the tabletop role-playing game.

headline: Growing Up Is Hard. ‘The Skunks’ Is Here to Help You Through the Chaos.
abstract: In Fiona Warnick’s cozy coming-of-age novel, an aimless college graduate finds an unconventional way to process her difficult transition into adulthood.
lead_paragraph: In Fiona Warnick’s quiet, thoughtful debut novel, “The Skunks,” a young woman named Isabel navigates the gloopy period of growing up that takes place after college ends and before real life begins.

headline: Nigel Sylvester Is a Different Kind of Superstar
abstract: One of the world’s most famous BMX riders has used social media and collaborations to become one of his sport's most recognizable figures.
lead_paragraph: At first, the children zipping around on bikes, roller skates and skateboards took little notice of the world famous athlete riding among them. Lot 11, tucked underneath a bustling Interstate I-95, is a haven for all things wheels. That’s where Nigel Sylvester perched on a ramp and surveyed the concrete slabs covering the skatepark’s landscape.

headline: The Romance Novelist, His Muse and a ‘Healing’ Plot Twist
abstract: After their 2021 wedding, John Murray and Kimberlee Stevenson experienced much heartbreak. Now comes joy.
lead_paragraph: When Kimberlee Stevenson married John Murray on April 30, 2021, “we thought the worst was behind us,” Mr. Murray said. “We were ready to start our lives together.”

headline: This Family Story Is Told Backward. It’s All the More Beautiful For It.
abstract: Juli Min’s “Shanghailanders” runs from 2040 to 2014, showing how a cast of unsettled characters arrived at their current predicament.
lead_paragraph: When I first realized that “Shanghailanders,” Juli Min’s remarkable debut novel, was told in reverse, moving backward from 2040 to 2014, the main question on my mind was, why? There is a reason we usually tell stories in chronological order, although as a novelist myself, I understand that authors are always playing with two timelines: the true progression of a story’s events and the order we decide to reveal them. I wondered, are the rewards of Min’s unusual structure worth the increased intellectual effort it requires of the reader?

headline: Three Friends, a Reunion and a Pandemic
abstract: Elise Juska takes readers back to the summer of 2021. The question is, do we want to go there?
lead_paragraph: As the premise for a novel, a class reunion offers fertile literary ground. Characters consumed with memories of youth while reckoning with what they thought they’d become versus where they actually ended up are prime for development and growth. The complexities of spouses, children and careers (or lack thereof) accumulated since graduation are further sources of narrative conflict. Add a plot point or two, ramp up the tension and you have all the ingredients for drama.

headline: The Girl and the Fire
abstract: On knowing when it’s time to get out of the house.
lead_paragraph: When I was 22 years old, I went into a smoke-filled house and persuaded a girl to leave with me. I wanted to save her from pointless bravery; I’d begun to learn what that cost.

headline: Role-Play With Your Friends as Influencers Dying to Go Viral
abstract: The horror video game Content Warning, a surprise hit, lets players microdose as momentary celebrities on the fictional website SpookTube.
lead_paragraph: The list of things that influencers have done for attention is terrifying. Creators have eaten 10,000 calories in one sitting, glued their lips together and smashed gallons of milk on the floor in public. When Logan Paul recorded himself finding a dead body in a Japanese forest known for suicides, it caused a backlash across the internet.

headline: The Bleak Life of a Deposed President and His Wife, Held Captive
abstract: Nine months after a coup in Niger, Mohamed Bazoum, an ally of France and the U.S., remains locked in the presidential residence, cut off from contact with anyone but his doctor.
lead_paragraph: Held captive by his former security guards in an isolated wing of his house, the deposed president of Niger paces a bedroom with no direct daylight, cut off from the world and unable to talk to his lawyers, according to people with direct knowledge of the conditions of his detention.

headline: Here Come a Trillion Cicadas. The Midwest Is Abuzz.
abstract: Illinois is the center of the cicada emergence that is on the way. Two groups of cicadas are expected at once, leaving some people queasy, others thrilled.
lead_paragraph: As the third graders of Cumberland Elementary in the Chicago suburbs colored, clipped and glued paper to make cicadas with filmy wings, they confided their fears about what is about to happen in Illinois.

headline: When Is the Best Time to Work Out?
abstract: It’s an age-old question. But a few recent studies have brought us closer to an answer.
lead_paragraph: What is the best time of day to exercise?

headline: A Battle Over Beer Split a Texas Town’s Biggest Party
abstract: Muenster, Texas, has hosted a German-heritage festival for nearly 50 years. But then some locals rebelled.
lead_paragraph: Social media attacks. Intransigent factions. An anonymous letter complaining about the harm done by some neighbors to the harmony of a bucolic Texas town.

headline: As Biden Makes His Case for Re-Election, the Cost of Insulin Takes Center Stage
abstract: President Biden says lowering the cost of insulin for seniors is among his proudest domestic policy achievements. He now faces the challenge of selling it to Americans of all ages.
lead_paragraph: Kaye Peterson, a 66-year-old retired librarian, is a direct beneficiary of one of President Biden’s proudest domestic policy achievements: lowering the cost of insulin for seniors.

headline: Come on, Kids. Let’s Grab Drinks.
abstract: The many nonalcoholic beverages on the market have attracted a new kind of customer: the (way) under-21 set.
lead_paragraph: The first time Tom Mathe, head bartender at L’Avenue in Manhattan, saw a child order a mocktail, he didn’t know what to think.

headline: ‘The Keep Going Songs’ Review: Vexed by Grief and Worried About the Planet
abstract: Abigail and Shaun Bengson muse on death in their latest work, but its looseness makes it hard to get a handle on.
lead_paragraph: Not a lot of Lincoln Center Theater shows call for setting the preperformance mood with the Grateful Dead, but when “Uncle John’s Band” came over the speakers the other evening before the Bengsons took the stage, it was such an ideal match for their crunchy, mellow, kindhearted, folk-rock vibe that I had to smile.

headline: ‘Dark Matter’ Uses Science to Explore Regret and Desire
abstract: In this new Apple TV+ techno-thriller, a portal to parallel realities allows people to visit new worlds and revisit their own past decisions.
lead_paragraph: In the new series “Dark Matter,” a physics professor (Joel Edgerton) is abducted off the streets of Chicago and replaced by an alternative version of himself. This version, instead of toiling away teaching distracted undergrads, is a prize-winning scientist who, among his various accomplishments, has invented a box that can superposition people into parallel worlds.

headline: How Scammers Are Stealing Food Stamps From Struggling Americans
abstract: Thieves are using skimmers to drain millions in food stamps and other public benefits from the neediest Americans.
lead_paragraph: Something was very wrong with Jackie Kirks’s food stamp card.

headline: Grief Broke Marlon Wayans. Comedy Put Him Back Together.
abstract: The comedian talks to David Marchese on becoming a different person after the death of his parents.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to build a long and lucrative career by making comedy that some people might be tempted to call silly or sophomoric. If it were, more comedians would be as successful as Marlon Wayans. Wayans, the youngest sibling in a family dynasty that also includes his brothers Damon, Shawn and Keenen Ivory Wayans and his sister Kim Wayans, has over the course of his 30-plus-year career scored in nearly every format. He has starred in broad sitcoms (the WB’s “The Wayans Bros.”), irreverent sketch comedy (“In Living Color”) and slapstick movies (“White Chicks”; the first two installments in the “Scary Movie” franchise), and released three, let’s say, Rabelaisian standup specials. His newest effort in that realm, “Good Grief,” will premiere on Amazon Prime Video on June 4.

headline: Laura Linney on the Singer Who Reminds Her of Beginnings
abstract: “The sound of his voice reminds me of the beginnings of things,” the actress said. “The first time you fell in love, the first time you went away.”
lead_paragraph: “One of the great things about getting older is that if you’re lucky enough, you get to work with some of the same people over and over again,” the actress Laura Linney said. “It’s my favorite, favorite thing to do.”

headline: Politics Without Trump? His Youngest Fans Barely Remember It.
abstract: Democrats call Donald J. Trump dangerous. Republicans see him as revolutionary. For young Trump voters, he is just normal.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump held a rally in Rome, Ga., in March, his audience included a second-generation supporter and first-time rallygoer named Luke Harris.

headline: Is ‘The Idea of You’ Harry Styles Fan Fiction? The Answer Is Complicated
abstract: The filmmakers do more to align star and character than the novel did. But somehow that doesn’t make the movie indebted to the musician.
lead_paragraph: Hayes Campbell, the dreamy protagonist of the new rom-com “The Idea of You,” has a bit in common with the mega pop star Harry Styles:

headline: Our Reporter on the Cicada Lifecycle
abstract: Two periodical cicada broods are appearing in a 16-state area in the Midwest and Southeast for the first time in centuries.
lead_paragraph: Two periodical cicada broods are appearing in a 16-state area in the Midwest and Southeast for the first time in centuries.

headline: As States Resist Federal Gender Rules, Schools Are Caught in the Middle
abstract: Conservative state governments are forbidding school districts from doing what the Department of Education says they must, under new Title IX regulations on students’ gender identity.
lead_paragraph: New civil rights regulations released last month by the Biden administration presented school districts across the nation with a clear choice: Either adopt policies that allow transgender students to use the bathrooms, wear the uniforms and be called by the pronouns that correspond with their gender identity, or risk losing federal funding.

headline: Dozens Arrested at U.Va. as Other Protests Disrupt Graduations
abstract: Police officers in riot gear cleared an encampment in Virginia, and protesters walked out of a commencement at Indiana University.
lead_paragraph: At least 25 people were arrested on Saturday at the University of Virginia, as protests over the war in Gaza continued to disrupt university campuses and puncture the celebratory atmosphere around graduation ceremonies across the country.

headline: From Free Speech to Free Palestine: Six Decades of Student Protest
abstract: The protests against Israel’s war in Gaza are merely the latest in a tradition of student-led, left-leaning activism dating back at least to the civil rights and anti-Vietnam War protests of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: An American college student looked out at a sea of protesters and spoke of a machine that had grown so “odious” that it had left people of good will little choice. There must be protest.

headline: Outsiders Were Among Columbia Protesters, but They Dispute Instigating Clashes
abstract: City officials have blamed “external actors” for escalating demonstrations at Columbia University and elsewhere, but student protesters reject the claim.
lead_paragraph: One of the people arrested at Columbia University this week was a middle-aged saxophonist who headed up to the campus from his Hell’s Kitchen apartment after learning about the protests on social media.

headline: The Colorful Anticipation of Hearing 3 Short Words: ‘And They’re Off’
abstract: Photos of the Kentucky Derby, which is marking its 150th running.
lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Derby, the oldest continuously held major sporting event in the United States, celebrated its 150th anniversary on Saturday with a new $200 million paddock and a host of safety initiatives meant to curb the horse deaths that marred last year’s event.

headline: Tesla Pullback Puts Onus on Others to Build Electric Vehicle Chargers
abstract: The automaker led by Elon Musk is no longer planning to take the lead in expanding the number of places to fuel electric vehicles. It’s not clear how quickly other companies will fill the gap.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, blindsided competitors, suppliers and his own employees this week by reversing course on his aggressive push to build electric vehicle chargers in the United States, a major priority of the Biden administration.

headline: Fashion’s Biggest Night: Your Guide to This Year’s Met Gala
abstract: Our Styles editor and our chief fashion critic on everything you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The first Monday of May is nearly here and The New York Times Styles desk is ready to cover fashion’s biggest night: the Met Gala. In addition to being a multimillion dollar fund-raiser, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute benefit is an elaborate costume party and according to our fashion critic, the “ultimate cocktail of power,” attracting notable figures from Hollywood, politics, sports and beyond.

headline: Our Reporter on Safety at the Kentucky Derby
abstract: At the 150th Kentucky Derby, the sport is grappling with how to ensure the safety of racehorses.
lead_paragraph: At the 150th Kentucky Derby, the sport is grappling with how to ensure the safety of racehorses.

headline: Jerry Seinfeld Can No Longer Be About Nothing
abstract: The comedian, long beloved for his apolitical riffs, has been wrestling with what it means to be Jewish amid the Israel-Hamas war. Not everyone is pleased.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Seinfeld became a mic-cradling, cereal-eating, “did-you-ever-notice”-ing avatar of American Jewish life with a brazenly shrugging persona: a merry indifference to weighty material as a comedian and in his megahit TV show about nothing, as petty and apolitical as he seemed to be.

headline: Just What Kind of a Third-Party Candidate Is R.F.K. Jr.?
abstract: Categorizing previous third-party bids helps us understand where he fits in and where he might wind up.
lead_paragraph: With six months to go until the election, it’s still too early to judge whether Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the Democrat-turned-independent candidate for president, will prove to be more than a mere spoiler.

headline: Kate Moss Turns Out for King Charles, and Pharrell Shuts Down a City Street
abstract: This week, after the British monarch returned to official duties, celebrities helped raise money for the trust he founded, and Pharrell hosted a car auction.
lead_paragraph: It was still early on Thursday evening at Casa Cipriani in downtown Manhattan, but Lionel Richie thought he knew how his night would end: “Buckingham Palace is going to call us and ask, ‘How did it go?’”

headline: Lessons From the Front Lines of Canada’s Fentanyl Crisis
abstract: In a visit supported by the U.S. government, a group of Mexican experts came to British Columbia to discuss ways of responding to rampant opioid deaths.
lead_paragraph: A machine used for chemical analysis, with a slight resemblance to a printer, thrummed repeatedly as technicians at a drug testing site in Victoria, British Columbia, prepared to open its doors to local drug users.

headline: Moving Target
abstract: A recent study offers some suggestions on the best time of day to exercise. But optimizing a routine requires having a routine to begin with.
lead_paragraph: Back in the years 2020 and 2021, years that are increasingly easy to categorize as “the past” rather than the ongoing present, I worked from home every day, and on most of those days I exercised from home, too. In the late morning between meetings, or around lunchtime, I rode a stationary bike or lifted weights or danced to Rihanna with a choreographer who broadcast a daily live class from an enviable house in Joshua Tree.

headline: The Realities of Family Separation, Told in Surreal Terms
abstract: The novel “American Abductions” captures the effects of U.S. immigration policy with the expansive reach of art.
lead_paragraph: In this brief, intricate novel on deportations of Latin Americans during the regime of a U.S. president called Racist in Chief, Mauro Javier Cárdenas creates what I’ll call an art-polemic — a melding of play with political purpose. From it, the cruelty of American immigration policy emerges: How else to capture such surreal inhumanity other than with the intractable capacities of art?

headline: The Deep, Tangled Roots of American Illiberalism
abstract: Our biggest mistake would be to believe that Trumpism is a historical exception.
lead_paragraph: In a recent interview with Time, Donald Trump promised a second term of authoritarian power grabs, administrative cronyism, mass deportations of the undocumented, harassment of women over abortion, trade wars and vengeance brought upon his rivals and enemies, including President Biden. “If they said that a president doesn’t get immunity,” Mr. Trump told Time, “then Biden, I am sure, will be prosecuted for all of his crimes.”

headline: The Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez You Don’t Know
abstract: Three terms in, she’s exiting her political adolescence and coming into her own as a veteran operator.
lead_paragraph: Six days after winning election to Congress, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez did what so many young progressives do while visiting the nation’s capital: She went to a rally. It was 2018, and Democratic dissatisfaction with President Donald Trump was a constant in Washington — but Ms. Ocasio-Cortez wasn’t protesting a Republican policy. She was at a sit-in at Representative Nancy Pelosi’s office organized by a group dedicated to pushing Democrats to the left on climate issues. Ms. Pelosi said she welcomed the protest, but behind closed doors, top Democrats soon became exasperated with their new colleague.

headline: The Food and Life Choices of a ‘Fat Activist’
abstract: Readers discuss the “freedom to be fat” and related health and parenting issues.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Medical Stories Do We Trust?
abstract: How vaccine injuries and long Covid test our partisan beliefs.
lead_paragraph: Let me tell you a medical story; you decide what you make of it. A person has a routine medical experience, the kind that all the person’s neighbors have had as well. But afterward the person has weird symptoms, odd forms of pain, fatigue that just goes on and on and on.

headline: One Photo That Captures the Loss in Gaza
abstract: Every death of a child from the war in Gaza is a preventable tragedy.
lead_paragraph: An American surgeon who volunteered in Gaza sent me a photo that sears me with its glimpse of overwhelming grief: A woman mourns her young son.

headline: The Three Faces of Don
abstract: Looking at who Trump was, is and would be.
lead_paragraph: When I worked at Time magazine in the early ’80s, I bought a frame at the company gift shop that was a mock-up of the Time Man of the Year cover, but it was Mother of the Year. I put in a picture of my mom, looking chic in a suit, holding me as a baby.

headline: Prom
abstract: Tornadoes, parades, speeches and more stories from high school’s big night.
lead_paragraph: While the seniors danced at the 2001 prom in Hoisington, Kan., a town of about 3,000, a tornado hit the town and destroyed about a third of it. When the students emerged from the dance, they discovered what had happened, and in the weeks that followed, they tried to make sense of why the tornado hit where it did.

headline: Parts of Gaza Are in Famine, World Food Program Chief Says
abstract: The remarks by Cindy McCain do not constitute an official declaration of famine, but she said the assessment was based on “what we have seen” on the ground.
lead_paragraph: The director of the World Food Program, Cindy McCain, says that parts of the Gaza Strip are experiencing a “full-blown famine” that is rapidly spreading throughout the territory after almost seven months of war.

headline: 2 Books for Rebels
abstract: A maid resists her employers; citizens resist their country.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Is It Good to Go Exclusive?
abstract: The exclusive period for Paramount’s potential merger with Skydance expired without a deal, highlighting the long-debated question of whether exclusivity is a waste of time.
lead_paragraph: Paramount’s proposed merger with Skydance has been the most tumultuous media deal in years. Now it has taken yet another turn after the exclusivity period for negotiations expired without an agreement in hand.

headline: Rishi Sunak’s Dismal Task: Leading U.K. Conservatives to Likely Defeat
abstract: After 14 years of Conservative government, Britain’s voters appear hungry for change. And Prime Minister Rishi Sunak seems unable to persuade them otherwise.
lead_paragraph: A few days before Britain’s Conservative Party suffered a stinging setback in local elections on Thursday, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak recorded a short video to promote some good news from his government. In the eight-second clip, Mr. Sunak poured milk from a pint bottle into a tall glass, filled with a steaming dark beverage and bearing the scribbled figure of 900 pounds on the side.

headline: Berkshire Reports Strong Earnings and Formidable Cash Stockpile
abstract: The company also disclosed in its first-quarter earnings that it had trimmed its stake in Apple, but Warren Buffett, its C.E.O., said he remained a fan of Apple.
lead_paragraph: Berkshire Hathaway on Saturday reported strong operating earnings, which track the actual profit that its array of businesses produce, and a record pile of cash in the first quarter, underscoring the health of the conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Sadiq Khan Re-elected Mayor of London in Latest Win for Labour Party
abstract: Mr. Khan defeated a right-wing rival who focused on crime and cars, his victory another ominous sign for Britain’s ruling Conservatives ahead of a general election.
lead_paragraph: Sadiq Khan, the two-term center-left mayor of London, on Saturday became the first three-time winner of the job by a comfortable margin delivering a new setback to Britain’s governing Conservative Party ahead of a looming general election.

headline: Pimento Cheese and Glazed Meatballs, Roasted Green Vegetables and No-Bake Cheesecake
abstract: Spring is a time for superb snacking and cheerful meals.
lead_paragraph: Spring is for snacking superbly. It’s the season of radishes dragged through butter, potato-pea samosas eaten on a park bench, a wedge of almond cake with a 3 p.m. iced (!) coffee. The days are longer, the sun is sunnier and the trees are flowerier, setting the scene for meandering, grazing and cheerful little meals to match the mood.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses Everton Bidder 777 Partners of $600 Million Fraud
abstract: In a suit filed in federal court in New York, a firm that provided hundreds of millions of dollars to 777 accused the company of double-pledging its collateral to other investors.
lead_paragraph: The American investment firm 777 Partners, whose bid to buy the English Premier League soccer team Everton has been on hold for months amid doubts about the company’s finances, was accused by one of its lenders on Friday of running a yearslong fraud scheme worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Do You Know the Origin of the Word ‘Quiz’?
abstract: OK, so this is actually a trick question …
lead_paragraph: Christie’s International Ltd., based in London, is about to start operations in New York. Christie’s is:

headline: Southeast Texas Expects More Rain After Days of Flooding
abstract: Several rivers north of Houston were forecast to reach or exceed their floods of record, the authorities said. Evacuation orders were in place for some areas.
lead_paragraph: Swollen rivers continued rising in Southeast Texas on Saturday after a night of evacuations and rescues from floodwaters that swamped roads, stranded cars and inundated homes in the region.

headline: Hats on and Off at the 150th Kentucky Derby
abstract: America’s most famous horse race may be celebrating a milestone this year, but the hats are the real stars of the show.
lead_paragraph: There are many associations that come to mind with the Kentucky Derby. Horses, naturally. Mint juleps too. But to be a true participant in the Derby spectacle, one needs a proper Derby hat.

headline: At Donor Retreat, Trump Calls Biden Administration the ‘Gestapo’
abstract: The speech by Donald J. Trump at a Republican National Committee fund-raising retreat came during his criminal trial in New York. He faces a total of 88 criminal charges across four indictments.
lead_paragraph: Fresh from his criminal trial in New York, Donald J. Trump delivered a frustrated and often obscene speech, lasting roughly 75 minutes, at a Republican National Committee donor retreat in Florida on Saturday, attacking one of the prosecutors pursuing him and comparing President Biden’s administration to the Nazis.

headline: Widening Racial Disparities Underlie Rise in Child Deaths in the U.S.
abstract: New research finds that the death rate among Black youths soared by 37 percent, and among Native American youths by 22 percent, between 2014 and 2020, compared with less than 5 percent for white youths.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to advancements in medicine and insurance, mortality rates for children in the United States had been shrinking for decades. But last year, researchers uncovered a worrisome reversal: The child death rate was rising.

headline: Last of Escaped Zebras Captured With White Bread, Oats and ‘Positivity’
abstract: A zebra named Sugar was captured on Friday after being on the loose in Washington State for nearly a week.
lead_paragraph: The last of four zebras that escaped from a trailer in North Bend, Wash., was safely corralled on Friday with the help of a former rodeo bullfighter, a lookout on a mountain bike and a package of white bread.

headline: Frank Stella, Towering Artist and Master of Reinvention, Dies at 87
abstract: He moved American art away from Abstract Expressionism toward cool minimalism. His explorations of color and form were endlessly discussed and constantly on exhibit.
lead_paragraph: Frank Stella, whose laconic pinstripe “black paintings” of the late 1950s closed the door on Abstract Expressionism and pointed the way to an era of cool minimalism, died on Saturday at his home in the West Village of Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, May 2, 2024
abstract: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Canadian Arrests Highlight Alleged Gang Role in India’s Intelligence Operations
abstract: India’s external spy agency, the Research and Analysis Wing, has long been accused of tapping into criminal networks to carry out operations in South Asia. Is the agency now doing similar operations in the West?
lead_paragraph: Months after Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada accused India’s government of plotting a murder on Canadian soil — plunging diplomatic relations between the two countries to their lowest level ever — the first arrests in the killing, which came on Friday, did little to demystify the basis of his claim.

headline: Parts of Gaza in ‘Full-Blown Famine,’ U.N. Aid Official Says
abstract: Cindy McCain, the director of the World Food Program, said starvation is entrenched in northern Gaza and is “moving its way south.”
lead_paragraph: The leader of the World Food Program said that parts of the Gaza Strip are experiencing a “full-blown famine” that is spreading across the territory after almost seven months of war that have made delivering aid extremely challenging.

headline: Charges Against a Congressman Lay Bare Foreign Government Influence Attempts
abstract: Federal prosecutors say Representative Henry Cuellar tried to shape policy for Azerbaijan in exchange for bribes. The country has spent millions in the past decade lobbying Washington.
lead_paragraph: As tensions flared over disputed territory in the Caucasus region in the summer of 2020, Azerbaijan’s squadron of high-priced Washington lobbyists scrambled to pin the blame on neighboring Armenia and highlight its connections to Russia.

headline: Barbara O. Jones, Actress Who Brought Black Cinema to Life, Dies at 82
abstract: Her arresting roles in movies like “Bush Mama” and “Daughters of the Dust” helped shape a generation of independent filmmakers.
lead_paragraph: Barbara O. Jones, an actress whose captivating work in films like “Bush Mama” and “Daughters of the Dust” helped define the cerebral, experimental and highly influential Black cinema movement that emerged in Los Angeles in the 1970s, died on April 8 at her home in Dayton, Ohio. She was 82.

headline: From the Astronaut’s Logbook
abstract: Daniel Bodily’s Sunday puzzle is out of this world.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Police Push Protesters Off a U.Va. Lawn and Arrest 25
abstract: Some protesters questioned the magnitude of the police response, compared with the school’s response in 2017 to white nationalists marching on campus with torches.
lead_paragraph: The police arrested at least 25 pro-Palestinian protesters on Saturday at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville after aggressively clearing demonstrators off a university lawn and at one point using chemical irritants on dozens of people.

headline: Kent State Protesters Call for University to Divest, Echoing Vietnam War Protests
abstract: Hundreds of demonstrators gathered on Saturday, the anniversary of the 1970 shooting by the National Guard that killed four students.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of pro-Palestinian demonstrators gathered at Kent State University in Ohio on Saturday to protest the war in Gaza, exactly 54 years after a similar campus demonstration ended in four student deaths.

headline: China Is Buying Gold Like There’s No Tomorrow
abstract: The global price of gold has reached its highest levels as Chinese investors and consumers, wary of real estate and stocks, buy the metal at a record pace.
lead_paragraph: As gold surged this year to its highest price ever, Xena Lin joined the frenzy by making monthly purchases of gold “beans,” pebble-like morsels of the precious metal.

headline: His Skull Was Taken From Congo as a War Trophy. Will Belgium Finally Return It?
abstract: For decades, Belgium failed to return the remains of hundreds of people taken by force from former colonies. A draft law could change that, but critics say it is not going far enough.
lead_paragraph: Once a powerful local Congolese leader, Lusinga Iwa Ng’ombe fought back against Belgian colonial invaders in the late 19th century.

headline: Just How Dangerous Is Europe’s Rising Far Right?
abstract: Anti-immigration parties with fascist roots — and an uncertain commitment to democracy — are now mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Bardella, 28, is the new face of the far right in France. Measured, clean-cut and raised in the hardscrabble northern suburbs of Paris, he laces his speeches with references to Victor Hugo and believes that “no country succeeds by denying or being ashamed of itself.”

headline: Xi Visits Europe, Seeking Strategic Opportunity
abstract: The Chinese leader has carefully chosen three countries — France, Serbia and Hungary — that to varying degrees embrace Beijing’s push for a new global order.
lead_paragraph: On his first visit to Europe in five years, the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, appears intent on seizing opportunities to loosen the continent’s bonds with the United States and forge a world freed of American dominance.

headline: Chief Counsel at R.N.C. Pushed Out After Two Months on the Job
abstract: Charlie Spies, a veteran election-law lawyer, had been under attack since soon after he joined the Republican National Committee in March.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Spies, the Republican National Committee’s chief counsel, was pushed out of his new role just two months after taking the job, amid a storm of controversy over conflicts involving other clients at the firm where he still works, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Welcomes Dua Lipa and Jerry Seinfeld
abstract: The pop star hosted and performed as the musical guest. The comedian poked fun at the abundant promotion he has been doing for his Netflix movie.
lead_paragraph: A fake commercial from this weekend’s broadcast of “Saturday Night Live” offered these tepid endorsements for “a bigass aluminum tray of penne alla vodka”: “Loved by none, but tolerated by all. Because it’s not that good. But it’s not that bad either.”

headline: Teenager Fatally Shot by Australian Police After He Stabs a Man
abstract: The episode occurred just weeks after two major stabbing attacks in the country. The youth had been under monitoring for having extremist tendencies.
lead_paragraph: The police in Perth, Australia, fatally shot a 16-year-old who had stabbed a man in a parking lot and who officials said had been on their radar for suspicion of having extremist tendencies.

headline: ‘Horrified, I Watched the Beads Come Off and Bounce Onto the Asphalt’
abstract: A beloved necklace breaks in Midtown, an overheard snippet and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: On Queens Soccer Fields, Immigrants Find Each Other and a Sense of Home
abstract: For generations of immigrants, Sunday soccer at Flushing Meadows Corona Park is more than a game.
lead_paragraph: Ender Mora arrived at the soccer field in Flushing Meadows Corona Park one Sunday afternoon with a couple of new Venezuelan friends who had gotten off a bus at Port Authority four hours earlier, after a journey from the Texas border.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,051
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 329
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: She Wrote the First Great Perimenopause Novel
abstract: Miranda July is experimenting again — on the page and in her life.
lead_paragraph: It was not exactly urgent to get the rug, but the larger question the rug had to answer was urgent enough. That’s why, on a bright afternoon at the end of March, Miranda July and I were driving toward Irvine, Calif., where she planned to meet a man about a listing on Facebook Marketplace.

headline: In the Comments Section, Writerly Discourse Awaits
abstract: A critic for the Book Review finds joy — and inspiration — in engaging with readers via the comments forums on his articles.
lead_paragraph: I’ve worked at The New York Times long enough to remember when reader comments arrived in envelopes, often addressed by hand. Even when they were critical — which was most of the time — I was grateful for these letters. They meant that someone was sufficiently engaged (or enraged) by an article I had written to sit down and write something themselves.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As 2 Cicada Broods Emerge at Once, Illinois Prepares to Hear the Loudest Roar
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “They don’t bite, they don’t sting, they’re not poisonous or venomous. They’re just these sweet little guys who hang out and suck tree sap.”

headline: Corrections: May 5, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A review of the NADA New York art fair on page C10 this weekend misstates the cause of death for the artist Jova Lynne’s mother. She died in 2020, during the Covid-19 pandemic, but she did not die of Covid.

headline: Frank Stella Went From Bauhaus to Fun House
abstract: He was consumed with abstract painting and determined to keep it alive even when it became an unpopular cause among younger artists.
lead_paragraph: Frank Stella, who died on Saturday at age 87, once joked that he harbored only one regret. We were sitting in his scruffy studio in the East Village, and he said he was sorry that he had failed to take legal action when the men's wear store bearing his name opened in New York in the mid-70s. “People call here all the time asking for cashmere coats,” he said.

headline: When Prison and Mental Illness Amount to a Death Sentence
abstract: The downward spiral of one inmate, Markus Johnson, shows the larger failures of the nation’s prisons to care for the mentally ill.
lead_paragraph: Markus Johnson slumped naked against the wall of his cell, skin flecked with pepper spray, his face a mask of puzzlement, exhaustion and resignation. Four men in black tactical gear pinned him, his face to the concrete, to cuff his hands behind his back.

headline: Three Lives Entwined by Tragedy — and a Love of Literature
abstract: In Monica Wood’s rich new novel, “How to Read a Book,” death, prison and poetry become the catalyst for new beginnings.
lead_paragraph: ”How to Read a Book” might be the perfect pick to really light a fire under my book club, and yours. It’s a charming, openhearted novel, deceptively easy to read but layered with sharp observations, hard truths and rich ideas.

headline: DNA Tests and Stranded Bodies: Ukraine’s Struggle to Name Its Dead
abstract: Families of some soldiers say they have spent months trying to get official confirmation of their loved ones’ deaths, adding to their anguish.
lead_paragraph: The bodies of the two Ukrainian soldiers lay motionless in a field for months. Around them were bloodstains and their rifles.

headline: A FAFSA Fiasco Has Students Still Asking: Which College Can They Afford?
abstract: The new application for federal tuition aid was meant to be simpler. High school seniors say it has been anything but, and some are still unsure of their plans after graduation.
lead_paragraph: By this time of year, college-bound high school seniors are usually celebrating their choices, researching dorms and even thinking of their majors. This year, that’s not necessarily the case.

headline: A Small Island, a Big Mammal and One Girl’s Awakening
abstract: Set in a remote Welsh enclave on the cusp of World War II, Elizabeth O’Connor’s “Whale Fall” finds fresh resonance for a coming-of-age debut.
lead_paragraph: Can a novel be both blunt and exquisite? I’m not sure I would have known how to imagine such a work before reading “Whale Fall,” Elizabeth O’Connor’s excellent debut. Brief but complete, the book is an example of precisely observed writing that makes a character’s specific existence glimmer with verisimilitude.

headline: Organizers Hope Music Puts the Miami in the Miami Grand Prix
abstract: The entertainment lineup for this weekend’s Formula 1 race has been infused with Latin music and nightclub-like electronic beats.
lead_paragraph: Organizers at Hard Rock Stadium near Miami have hosted some of the biggest spectacles in American sports in the past five years, including the Super Bowl and college football’s national championship game.

headline: Hundreds of Bahraini Political Prisoners Freed in ‘Bittersweet’ Royal Pardon
abstract: Amid deepening tensions in the Middle East, Bahraini activists said that the mass pardon, while welcome, was incomplete, and called for the release of several jailed opposition leaders.
lead_paragraph: When Naji Fateel was arrested in the aftermath of Bahrain’s Arab Spring uprising, his youngest son, Nidal, was a toddler.

headline: How One Latino Pastor Became a Foot Soldier for Trump
abstract: Republicans have spent years drawing Latino evangelicals into their fold. At one growing church in the Las Vegas suburbs, Donald J. Trump is reaping the benefits.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday evening, two teenage boys approached their pastor, Camilo Perez, before Bible study. They wanted his take on a debate that had been gnawing at them. Their friends from a local public high school had been talking about discrimination against Latinos. Did the pastor agree? Does the government give white people more power?

headline: Does a Small Cough Make You Think the Worst? Here’s a Book for You.
abstract: Caroline Crampton shares her own worries in “A Body Made of Glass,” a history of hypochondria that wonders whether newfangled technology drives us crazier.
lead_paragraph: British national identity is built on the stiff upper lip, but the author Caroline Crampton, who lives in Merseyside, has allowed hers to quaver and curl, and it’s a relief.

headline: Steve Gleason’s Unflinching Memoir of Living With A.L.S.
abstract: In “A Life Impossible,” the former N.F.L. player opens up about outliving his life expectancy — the challenges, loneliness and moments of joy.
lead_paragraph: After you turn 70, as I will this year, any celebration will be muted by an ever-increasing awareness of mortality. I fear death, but what I fear even more is the way in which I’ll die. I hope it’s a heart attack in the dark of night — quick and painless, here today, gone tomorrow.

headline: The Sprinter Van’s Glamorous Turn
abstract: Famous actors, singers, athletes and housewives are fans of the Mercedes-Benz van, which has become a staple in streets outside events like the Met Gala.
lead_paragraph: When Kendall Jenner attended the 2022 Met Gala in a Prada gown with an enormous flowing skirt, getting her to the Metropolitan Museum of Art required special transportation. A limousine would not do, nor would an SUV — walking in the dress was a challenge; sitting, impossible. The solution: Ms. Jenner would be driven, standing, in a Mercedes-Benz Sprinter van.

headline: Gallows Humor and Talk of Escape: Trump’s Possible Return Rattles Capital
abstract: At Washington dinner parties, dark jokes abound about where to go into exile if the former president reclaims the White House.
lead_paragraph: It has become the topic of the season at Washington dinner parties and receptions. Where would you go if it really happens?

headline: These Couples Survived a Lot. Then Came Retirement.
abstract: For many relationships, life after work brings an unexpected set of challenges.
lead_paragraph: This spring, Barbara and Joe, a retired couple in their 60s, sat down with me at a bistro in suburban Connecticut to talk about their relationship. That they were sitting there together at all was something of a triumph. In the past few days, they had hurled at each other the kinds of accusations that couples make when they are on the brink of mutual destruction. They were bruised from the words that had been exchanged, and although they sat close to each other, their energy was quiet and heavy.

headline: Front-Runner, José Raúl Mulino, Is Elected President of Panama
abstract: Mr. Mulino, a former security minister, gained support in the chaotic campaign from an ex-president whose bid had been disqualified.
lead_paragraph: Panamanians on Sunday elected José Raúl Mulino, a former public security minister, as their next president, in the culmination of an election cycle that was embroiled in political turmoil.

headline: I Love Facebook. That’s Why I’m Suing Meta.
abstract: We must be able to create a more civic-minded internet, with tools that would empower users to better control what they see.
lead_paragraph: While it’s become fashionable to dump on the aging social media platform Facebook, I quite enjoy using it. Many of my high school and college friends use it to celebrate birthdays and share news of their children and their travels. Eight years ago, I reconnected with a college housemate on the platform, and last year we got married. Thanks, Facebook.

headline: The Best College Is One Where You Don’t Fit In
abstract: Have you heard the advice to go where you can see yourself? Ignore it.
lead_paragraph: This time of year, college campuses like the one where I live fill up with high school seniors preparing to make what feels like a momentous choice. The first imperative is to find a school that they can afford, but beyond that, many students have been advised to find one where they can see themselves. Too often, they take this to mean finding a place with students like them, even students who look like them — a place where they will feel comfortable. I can’t tell you how many families have described driving many hours to a campus somewhere and having their daughter or son say something like: “We don’t need to get out. I can tell already this isn’t for me.”

headline: Marjorie Taylor Greene Is Not as Powerful as She Thinks She Is
abstract: The uproars that don’t seem to touch Trump at all can still bring down other Republicans.
lead_paragraph: In an interview last week, NewsNation’s Blake Burman asked Speaker Mike Johnson about Marjorie Taylor Greene, and before Burman could finish his question, Johnson responded with classic Southern scorn. “Bless her heart,” he said, and then he told Burman that Greene wasn’t proving to be a serious lawmaker and that he didn’t spend a lot of time thinking about her.

headline: How Humans Failed Racehorses
abstract: An exploration of the troubled state of horse racing in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: It was a thrilling finish: A long-shot named Mystik Dan held off a late charge by Sierra Leone and a colt from Japan named Forever Young on Saturday to win the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby, America’s oldest major continuing sporting event, bringing to a close a much-needed casualty-free week of thoroughbred racing.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 6, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Dozens Are Arrested in Pro-Palestinian Protest at Art Institute of Chicago
abstract: The Chicago police said that 68 people had been arrested and charged with trespassing.
lead_paragraph: The police forcibly dismantled a pro-Palestinian encampment at the Art Institute of Chicago museum on Saturday and arrested dozens of protesters, hours after demonstrators had gathered in a garden at the institute and set up tents.

headline: Three Israeli Soldiers Killed in Rocket Attack Claimed by Hamas
abstract: The Israeli military said that about 14 rockets and mortars were fired toward Kerem Shalom, a conduit for aid into Gaza. Three other soldiers were badly wounded.
lead_paragraph: Hamas said on Sunday that its armed wing had fired rockets at Israeli forces near the Kerem Shalom border crossing between Gaza and Israel, in an attack that the Israeli military said killed three soldiers and left three more soldiers critically wounded.

headline: Police Again Clear Pro-Palestinian Encampment at U.S.C.
abstract: The university has been in turmoil following the decision not to allow its valedictorian to speak at graduation.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Police Department and campus police removed a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of Southern California early Sunday morning, pushing several dozen people out of the campus gates in the latest crackdown on student protesters there.

headline: Driver Dies After Crashing Into Barrier Near the White House
abstract: The Secret Service said the incident posed no threat to the public, and President Biden was in Delaware at the time of the crash.
lead_paragraph: A driver died after crashing into a security barrier near the White House on Saturday night around 10:30, prompting an investigation by the Washington police department, the Secret Service said in a statement.

headline: Sweet Tea-Brined Roast Chicken for Sunday Supper
abstract: With horseradish-Cheddar tuna melts and vegan tantanmen for the coming week.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It was peak cherry blossoms last week where I stay, the flowers almost ready to spring off their branches to blanket the curbs like drifts of snow. There was a deep humidity in the air and it made me think of summer down south, the way the atmosphere can seem almost liquid under the sun, everything ripe, everything slow. I made sweet tea and drank it over an enormous amount of ice, on the stoop, marveling at how sometimes sweet tea is the best tea, even if you usually drink tea straight, no sugar, with not even a lemon to counter the tannins.

headline: Are E.V.s Too Quiet and ‘Boring’?
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay that argued they are both. Also: College roommates; tech in school; truths about Russia; water and politics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Madonna Brings Massive Free Concert to Rio, Capping Celebration Tour
abstract: The pop superstar performed a final date on her global trek marking four decades of hits: a set on Copacabana Beach before the largest live crowd of her career.
lead_paragraph: When Madonna stepped out onto the mammoth stage constructed on Rio de Janeiro’s Copacabana Beach on Saturday night in a gleaming halo headpiece and black kimono, she was greeted by the largest live crowd of her four-decade career.

headline: Interstate 95 Reopens After Damaged Bridge Is Demolished
abstract: A section of the highway, a crucial link between Connecticut and New York City, had closed on Thursday when fuel from a burning tanker ignited an overpass.
lead_paragraph: A section of Interstate 95 in Connecticut reopened on Sunday morning after a fiery accident last week damaged an overpass and shut down the highway, a major artery along the East Coast.

headline: Peter Oosterhuis, British Golfer Turned Broadcaster, Dies at 75
abstract: For a time he was one of Europe’s best golfers, winning 20 tournaments, before moving into TV, offering commentary for the Golf Channel and CBS Sports.
lead_paragraph: Peter Oosterhuis, a British golfer who won 20 tournaments around the world, played in the Ryder Cup six times and later distinguished himself as a commentator for CBS Sports and Golf Channel, died on Thursday in Charlotte, N.C. He was 75.

headline: Kristi Noem Suggests Biden’s Dog Should Have Been Killed, Too
abstract: The South Dakota governor, defending her tale of shooting and killing her family’s dog, suggested that President Biden’s German shepherd, Commander, had merited a similar fate.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kristi Noem of South Dakota, already under fire for killing her family’s 14-month-old dog and boasting about it, on Sunday took aim at another family’s pet: Commander, President Biden’s bite-prone German shepherd.

headline: One Dead in Texas as Rain Pummels Parts of the State
abstract: A 4-year-old boy died on Sunday in Johnson County, Texas, after being swept away by floodwaters, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A 4-year-old boy died on Sunday in Johnson County, Texas, the authorities said, after being swept away by floodwaters caused by heavy rains that have pounded parts of the state over the past few days.

headline: Sony and Apollo in Talks to Acquire Paramount
abstract: After letting exclusive talks with the movie studio Skydance lapse, Paramount’s directors met over the weekend and decided to negotiate with all the suitors.
lead_paragraph: Paramount has decided to formally open negotiations with a bidding group led by Sony Pictures Entertainment and the private equity giant Apollo, according to three people familiar with the matter. The move comes after a period of exclusive talks with the Hollywood studio Skydance lapsed on Friday night.

headline: ‘The Fall Guy’ Fizzles With $28 Million in Ticket Sales
abstract: While enough for No. 1, the big-budget original movie gave Hollywood its lowest start to its summer box office season since 1995.
lead_paragraph: “The Fall Guy” seemed to have everything.

headline: Jerome Rothenberg, Who Heard Poetry Beyond the West, Dies at 92
abstract: His anthology “Technicians of the Sacred” included a range of non-Western work and was beloved by, among others, rock stars like Jim Morrison and Nick Cave.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Rothenberg, a poet, translator and anthologist whose efforts to bring English-language readers into contact with creative traditions far outside the Western establishment — a field he called ethnopoetics — had an enormous impact on world literature and made him a hero to rock musicians like Nick Cave, Jim Morrison and Warren Zevon, died on April 21 at his home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 92.

headline: Cease-Fire Talks Between Israel and Hamas Again at an Impasse
abstract: There had been signs the two sides were inching closer to an agreement, but talks in Cairo stalled and a Hamas delegation left the city.
lead_paragraph: The latest round of negotiations between Israel and Hamas hit an impasse on Sunday as mediators struggled to bridge remaining gaps and a Hamas delegation departed the talks in Cairo, according to two senior Hamas officials and two other officials familiar with the talks. An Israeli official also confirmed the negotiations had stalled and described them as being in “crisis.”

headline: Laurent Cantet Is Dead at 63: His Films Explored France’s Undersides
abstract: His acclaimed “The Class” walked a provocative line between documentary and fiction. In that film and others, he explored the inescapable traps of late-stage capitalism.
lead_paragraph: Laurent Cantet, an eminent director who made penetrating films about the prickly undersides of French life and society, died on April 25 in Paris. He was 63.

headline: Monday Briefing: Xi Jinping Visits Europe
abstract: Also, Israel cracks down on Al Jazeera and Myanmar’s rebels get creative with drones.
lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, arrived in France yesterday on his first trip to Europe in five years. He will also visit Serbia and Hungary.

headline: Candidates for Federal Office Can Raise Unlimited Funds for Ballot Measures
abstract: A decision by the Federal Election Commission would allow the Biden and Trump campaigns to raise money for outside groups pushing ballot measures.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Election Commission quietly issued an advisory opinion last week allowing candidates to raise unlimited money for issue-advocacy groups working on ballot measures in elections in which those candidates are on the ballot.

headline: Flies High
abstract: Malaika Handa takes her turn.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: 4 Children From Gaza Arrive in U.S. for Medical Treatment
abstract: The children, who were injured or suffered malnutrition, were greeted at Kennedy Airport with toys and balloons. “These are their first memories here,” one supporter said.
lead_paragraph: The four children had survived horrors in Gaza.

headline: Bernard Hill, Actor in ‘Titanic’ and ‘Lord of the Rings,’ Dies at 79
abstract: With a stout frame, bushy whiskers and a weathered visage, he embodied men of authority facing down danger with weary stoicism.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Hill, a British actor who incarnated a humble style of masculine leadership in three hugely successful Hollywood movies, “Titanic” and two films in the “Lord of the Rings” franchise, died on Sunday. He was 79.

headline: How to Know When a Good Dog Has Gone Bad
abstract: Gov. Kristi Noem suggested that President Biden should have euthanized the family dog, as she did. Animal experts said that such an option should be a last resort.
lead_paragraph: Since late last month, Gov. Kristi Noem of South Dakota has been the subject of fierce bipartisan attacks for her decision to shoot and kill her family dog, a 14-month-old German wirehaired pointer named Cricket. Ms. Noem has repeatedly defended her actions, which are detailed in her forthcoming memoir, in which she says the dog was “aggressive,” “untrainable” and “dangerous to anyone she came in contact with.”

headline: R.F.K. Jr. Claims Censorship After Facebook and Instagram Briefly Block New Ad
abstract: The ad, a sleek 30-minute production, was blocked for several hours on Friday and Saturday. Meta, which owns both platforms, said the link had been incorrectly flagged as spam.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has made censorship — specifically, claims that the government, news media and tech platforms have tried to stifle his message — a cornerstone of his independent presidential campaign.

headline: ABC News’s President, Kim Godwin, to Step Down
abstract: The first Black woman to run a broadcast news division, Ms. Godwin had a rocky tenure defined by infighting and damaging leaks.
lead_paragraph: Kim Godwin, the president of ABC News, told employees on Sunday night that she was leaving the network, capping a tumultuous three-year tenure.

headline: 3 Bodies Found in Baja California Are Identified as Missing Tourists
abstract: Mexican officials said the identities of two Australians and an American had been confirmed by relatives. The men went missing during a surfing and camping trip.
lead_paragraph: Three bodies that were found in the Mexican state of Baja California last week have been identified as those of three tourists from Australia and the United States who had disappeared days earlier, the Mexican authorities said on Sunday.

headline: In China, Ruled by Men, Women Quietly Find a Powerful Voice
abstract: Women in Shanghai gather in bars, salons and bookstores to reclaim their identities as the country’s leader calls for China to adopt a “childbearing culture.”
lead_paragraph: In bars tucked away in alleys and at salons and bookstores around Shanghai, women are debating their place in a country where men make the laws.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Cease-fire talks stall.
lead_paragraph: Negotiations between Israel and Hamas stalled again, meaning more uncertainty for the families of Israeli hostages and no quick reprieve for Palestinians in Gaza. Mediators struggled to bridge the remaining gaps, and a Hamas delegation left the talks, officials said.

headline: Let’s All Take a Deep Breath About China
abstract: Anxiety about China is making American policymakers react in paranoid, repressive ways.
lead_paragraph: The amygdala is a pair of neural clusters near the base of the brain that assesses danger and can help prompt a fight-or-flight response. A prolonged stress response may contribute to anxiety, which can cause people to perceive danger where there is none and obsess about worst-case scenarios.

headline: Daniel Barenboim: What Beethoven’s Ninth Teaches Us
abstract: The conductor Daniel Barenboim explores the political and spiritual power of what many consider the greatest symphony.
lead_paragraph: Ludwig van Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony was first performed exactly 200 years ago Tuesday and has since become probably the work most likely to be embraced for political purposes.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: Met Gala and ‘Wedding Crashers’
abstract: E! covers all the looks of the first Monday in May. And Paramount airs the classic buddy movie.
lead_paragraph: For those who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, May 6-12. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Quotation of the Day: She’ll Have an Orange Juice on the Rocks. Hold the Sippy Cup.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This is a generation that likes to ‘adult’ quicker. The kid who is sitting down to an avocado toast for lunch is ordering a strawberry ginger lemonade mocktail.”

headline: No Corrections: May 6, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Word of the Day: etymology
abstract: This word has appeared in 31 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word etymology has appeared in 31 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 3 in “Is It a Blizzard? A Nor’easter? And What’s the Difference?” by Camille Baker:

headline: Airline Agrees to Pay $79 Million After Selling Tickets for Canceled Flights
abstract: Qantas, Australia’s national carrier, apologized and said it would pay a fine and compensation to settle a suit brought by a consumer watchdog.
lead_paragraph: Qantas, Australia’s national airline, said on Monday that it had reached a deal with the country’s consumer watchdog to pay the equivalent of $79 million for selling thousands of tickets to flights that it had already canceled.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 330
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Congestion Pricing’s Billions to Pay for Nuts and Bolts of Subway System
abstract: The $15 billion expected from new traffic tolls is earmarked for modernizing old infrastructure but is threatened by a raft of lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s congestion pricing program is scheduled to begin charging tolls to drive into the busiest parts of Manhattan next month, with the aim of generating a $15 billion windfall for the mass transit system.

headline: Netanyahu Asserts Israel’s Right to Fight Its Enemies in Defiant Speech
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been steadfast in his goal of destroying Hamas. On Sunday, he defended Israel’s right to defend itself at a Holocaust remembrance event.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Sunday rejected international pressure to rein in its military campaign in Gaza and, speaking at a Holocaust memorial, asserted Israel’s right to fight its “genocidal enemies.”

headline: ‘Tits Up’ Aims to Show Breasts a Respect Long Overdue
abstract: The sociologist Sarah Thornton visits strip clubs, milk banks and cosmetic surgeons with the goal of shoring up appreciation for women’s breasts.
lead_paragraph: It’s a testament to the sociologist Sarah Thornton’s central thesis — women’s breasts are unjustly sexualized, trivialized and condescended to — that I expected her new book, “Tits Up,” to be a light read. In fact, her impassioned polemic makes a convincing case that the derogatory way Western culture views tits (Thornton contrasts her chosen slang with the relatively “silly” and “foolish” boobs) helps perpetuate the patriarchy.

headline: Are We Talking Too Much About Mental Health?
abstract: Recent studies cast doubt on whether large-scale mental health interventions are making young people better. Some even suggest they can have a negative effect.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, mental health has become a central subject in childhood and adolescence. Teenagers narrate their psychiatric diagnosis and treatment on TikTok and Instagram. School systems, alarmed by rising levels of distress and self-harm, are introducing preventive coursework in emotional self-regulation and mindfulness.

headline: The Thrills and Chills of Staying Sober
abstract: Michael Deagler’s first novel follows a young man who is piecing his life back together and trying very hard not to drink.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a pitch for a novel, maybe one you’d like to read. It’s a tale of “utter shock and tragedy, a kneecapped bildungsroman: A bright-eyed young man from the suburbs goes down to Philadelphia and drinks himself into a series of increasingly dire circumstances until he is forced by a deficiency of skills and wits and second chances back to the Bucks County subdivision of his youth.”

headline: How Bad Are Ultraprocessed Foods, Really?
abstract: They’re clearly linked to poor health. But scientists are only beginning to understand why.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1990s, Carlos Monteiro, a nutritional epidemiologist in Brazil, noticed something alarming: Obesity rates among children in his country were rising rapidly.

headline: A Modern Mom Finds an Ancient Outlet for Feminist Rage
abstract: In Alexis Landau’s ambitious new novel, “The Mother of All Things,” the frustrations of modern parenting echo through the ages.
lead_paragraph: What is the source of maternal rage? The answer is as infinite as it is ancient. In 1965, the poet and essayist Adrienne Rich, with small children underfoot, captured a possible explanation for this abyss in her journal when she described it as “a sense of insufficiency to the moment and to eternity.”

headline: Paris Promised the Olympics Would Be Accessible. The Clock Is Ticking.
abstract: The city, which put inclusivity at the center of its bid, has improved access for people with disabilities, but with the opening ceremony about 12 weeks away, obstacles remain.
lead_paragraph: During a trip to Paris last November, Samantha Renke just couldn’t seem to find a taxi that could accommodate her motorized wheelchair.

headline: With Schools in Ruins, Education in Gaza Will Be Hobbled for Years
abstract: Most of Gaza’s schools, including all of its universities, have severe damage that makes them unusable, which could harm an entire generation, the United Nations and others say.
lead_paragraph: Amjad Abu Daqqa was among the top students at his school in Khan Younis, excelling in math and English, and he was applying for a scholarship to study in the United States when war erupted in the Gaza Strip last October.

headline: The National Urban League Comes Home
abstract: The civil rights organization will anchor a sprawling mixed-use development in Harlem that will include a new museum focused on the American civil rights struggle in the North.
lead_paragraph: The National Urban League is moving its headquarters to Harlem, the neighborhood where it was founded in 1910, and will open New York City’s first museum devoted to the American civil rights movement and one of few in the nation to focus on the struggles in the North.

headline: $3.2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A renovated midcentury home in Los Angeles, a hillside house in Sausalito and a 2020 retreat in Santa Paula.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Studio City, about a mile from the intersection of Ventura and Laurel Canyon Boulevards, putting it within a five-minute drive of a bookstore, a Vons grocery store and various dining options. Fryman Canyon, a popular dog-friendly hiking spot and Carpenter Community Charter School, a public elementary school, are also about five minutes away. Radford Studio Center at CBS is about 15 minutes by car.

headline: When Buying a Home Is Treated as a National Security Threat
abstract: A new Florida law prohibits many Chinese citizens from buying homes because of national security concerns. Critics say it has fueled discrimination and chilled the local property market.
lead_paragraph: After years of living in dorms and subpar apartments, Lisa Li could not wait to close on her new home.

headline: Are Flight Offsets Worth It?
abstract: A lot of them don’t work and some might even be harmful. But there are things you can do if you really have to fly.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, research has shown that many offset projects are ineffective or worse. But last we checked, people are still flying. A lot. And the planet is still warming. A lot.

headline: Meet the Candidate Challenging Venezuela’s Authoritarian President
abstract: Edmundo González, a former diplomat, is unknown to many Venezuelans. But some experts say that could work in his favor as he runs against President Nicolás Maduro in national elections.
lead_paragraph: The day Edmundo González was plucked from obscurity and chosen to take on South America’s longest ruling authoritarian leader, technicians were busy making sure his home was not wiretapped.

headline: Tensions Rise in Silicon Valley Over Sales of Start-Up Stocks
abstract: The market for shares of hot start-ups like SpaceX and Stripe is projected to reach a record $64 billion this year.
lead_paragraph: Sohail Prasad, an entrepreneur, launched a fund in March called the Destiny Tech100. The fund owns shares in hot tech start-ups like the payments firm Stripe, the rocket maker SpaceX and the artificial intelligence company OpenAI.

headline: Should Schools Serve Healthier Meals if It Changes Students’ Favorite Foods?
abstract: New federal rules will require school cafeterias to reduce the amount of salt and sugar in the foods they serve. Do you think students will embrace the changes?
lead_paragraph: Do you eat breakfast, lunch or snacks from your school’s cafeteria? If so, what do you eat? What are your favorite foods? How nutritious do you think your choices are?

headline: Celebrity. Money. Fashion. It’s Met Gala Night.
abstract: The annual extravaganza raises money for the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute. The guest list is top-secret.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. The Met Gala, where money and power intersect, is tonight. We’ll look at why the event is important.

headline: ‘The Sympathizer’ Opens a Counteroffensive on Vietnam War Movies
abstract: HBO’s series is not just a good story. It’s a sharp piece of film criticism.
