lead_paragraph: Tornadoes ripped through Michigan on Tuesday evening, injuring residents, damaging nearly 200 mobile homes and lifting some off the ground, and trapping dozens of FedEx workers inside a building, officials said.

headline: OpenAI Releases ‘Deepfake’ Detector to Disinformation Researchers
abstract: The prominent A.I. start-up is also joining an industrywide effort to spot content made with artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: As experts warn that images, audio and video generated by artificial intelligence could influence the fall elections, OpenAI is releasing a tool designed to detect content created by its own popular image generator, DALL-E. But the prominent A.I. start-up acknowledges that this tool is only a small part of what will be needed to fight so-called deepfakes in the months and years to come.

headline: How Changing Ocean Temperatures Could Upend Life on Earth
abstract: Is the world’s climate close to a tipping point?
lead_paragraph: While many of the effects of climate change, including heat waves, droughts and wildfires, are already with us, some of the most alarming consequences are hiding beneath the surface of the ocean.

headline: The Scramble to Broker a Gaza Deal, and More Questions for Boeing
abstract: Plus, Trump is threatened with jail.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Isolated From West, Putin Projects Domestic Power at Inauguration
abstract: The event for the Russian president, who claimed his fifth term in a rubber-stamp election, included a church service that underscored efforts to give a religious sheen to his rule.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir V. Putin was inaugurated for a fifth term as president on Tuesday in a ceremony filled with pageantry and a televised church service, as the Russian leader tried once more to depict his invasion of Ukraine as a religiously righteous mission that is part of “our 1,000-year history.”

headline: U.S. Soldier Is Detained in Russia and Accused of Theft, Officials Say
abstract: The American soldier was detained last week. He was traveling home after being stationed in South Korea, according to the U.S. authorities.
lead_paragraph: A man who has been identified by American officials as an Army sergeant was detained in Russia last week after a local woman reported him on allegations of theft, the Russian authorities said on Tuesday. He will remain in jail until at least July, they said.

headline: On European Tour, Xi Jinping Heads to Friendly Territory in the East
abstract: After leaving France later Tuesday, the Chinese leader landed in Serbia and will visit Hungary, two countries whose authoritarian leaders offer a haven for China as tensions grow over the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: When China’s leader, Xi Jinping, last visited Europe’s formerly Communist east in 2016, the president of the Czech Republic hosted him for a flag-bedecked, three-day state visit and offered his country as an “unsinkable aircraft carrier” for Chinese investment.

headline: Disney Reports Strong Earnings but Warns of Bumps Ahead
abstract: In a surprise, Disney+ made money for the first time in the latest quarter, but the company said it expected a slowdown in its parks division.
lead_paragraph: Disney reported strong earnings on Tuesday, driven in part by a surprise profit at its flagship streaming service — a first. But investors responded nervously to a coming slowdown at Disney theme parks, which have recently been the company’s primary growth engine.

headline: Israel’s Closures of 2 Gaza Border Crossings Prompt Alarm Over Humanitarian Aid
abstract: International agencies and officials said Israel’s moves could exacerbate an already dire humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: With its seizure of the Gaza side of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt on Tuesday, Israel has now closed two key crossings for aid into Gaza, drawing sharp warnings from international agencies and officials who said the moves could exacerbate an already dire humanitarian crisis in the enclave.

headline: The Met Gala, in Photos
abstract: Times critic Vanessa Friedman on the biggest night in fashion.

headline: The Big Questions Hanging Over a Blackstone Fund
abstract: Wall Street has been debating how the investment giant’s $59 billion real estate fund has managed to outperform virtually all its rivals.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, one mystery has been whispered about for months: How accurate is the valuation of Blackstone’s flagship real estate fund?

headline: U.S. Repatriates 11 American Citizens From ISIS War Camps in Syria
abstract: The group — the largest set of Americans retrieved from the war zone — was joined by a 9-year-old noncitizen whose brother is an American.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has repatriated a family of 10 American citizens who had been stranded for years in desert camps and detention centers in Syria run by a Kurdish-led militia that battled the Islamic State, according to officials.

headline: U.K. Armed Forces’ Data Is Exposed in Hostile Cyberattack
abstract: A payroll system used by Britain’s Ministry of Defense was targeted in a cyberattack that some lawmakers alleged was orchestrated by China.
lead_paragraph: The personal information of British army, navy and air force members has been hacked in a significant data breach, raising alarm over a growing threat from cyberattacks by hostile states, Britain’s defense secretary said on Tuesday.

headline: Met Gala
abstract: What were your favorite and least favorite looks at this year’s show?
lead_paragraph: Last night in New York City, the annual Met Gala attracted celebrities, executives, musicians, politicians and more, writes the Times Styles section.

headline: Sweetgreen Is Introducing Steak. What About Its Climate Goals?
abstract: The fast-casual chain aims to be climate neutral by 2027, but beef is a big contributor to climate change.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two decades after the fast-casual salad chain Sweetgreen was founded, the company announced on Tuesday that it would introduce beef to its menu.

headline: Weekly Student New Quiz: Myanmar, Campus Protests, 'Hell's Kitchen'
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: California Is Rebranding
abstract: Why the state’s tourism agency ditched its “Dream Big” slogan after more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you remember the commercials: images of the glittering blue Pacific, the majestic peaks of Yosemite, storybook vineyards and ancient redwoods stretching toward the sky.

headline: Is the Met Gala Protest-Proof?
abstract: Despite a rich, class-based theme and calls to disrupt the fashion extravaganza of the year, politics proved no match for the power of the spectacle.
lead_paragraph: If ever a Met Gala seemed primed to clash with its political moment, it was the 2024 Met.

headline: Don’t Be Fooled by A.I. Katy Perry Didn’t Attend the Met.
abstract: Images of the pop star were convincing enough to trick plenty of people on social media, including Ms. Perry’s own mother.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, a gaggle of celebrities attended the annual Met Gala. As they entered, throngs of photographers and reporters captured the arrival and ascent of guests up the Met’s famed stairs. Bad Bunny! Chris Hemsworth! J-Lo! Zendaya! Zendaya, again, but in a different dress!

headline: Two Dozen Bodies Brought to Rafah Hospital, Doctor Says
abstract: The head of Kuwait Hospital in Rafah said the situation at the facility amid the Israeli military incursion was “catastrophic in every sense of the word.”
lead_paragraph: A Palestinian doctor at a medical center in Rafah said on Tuesday that 27 bodies had been brought there since the start of Israel’s incursion, in which ground troops entered the southeast corner of Gaza and took control of the Gazan side of a border crossing with Egypt.

headline: Ukraine Says It Foiled Russian Plot to Kill Zelensky
abstract: The Ukrainian security services arrested two Ukrainian colonels and accused them of spying for Russia. They said the plot also targeted top Ukrainian intelligence officials.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s security services said on Tuesday that they had foiled a Russian plot to assassinate President Volodymyr Zelensky and other top military and political figures. Two Ukrainian colonels accused of participating in the plot have been arrested on suspicion of treason.

headline: Preparations Ramp Up for Global Security Force to Quell Haitian Violence
abstract: More than half a dozen nations have pledged personnel to a multinational effort to stabilize Haiti, where gangs have taken over much of the capital, setting off a major humanitarian crisis.
lead_paragraph: U.S. military planes filled with civilian contractors and supplies have begun landing in Haiti, paving the way for a seven-nation security mission, led by Kenya, to deploy to the troubled Caribbean nation in the coming weeks, American officials say.

headline: Stormy Daniels, Porn Star Who Says She Had Sex With Trump, Testifies at Trial
abstract: She says she met the former president at a golf tournament and they wound up in his suite. He denies the encounter.
lead_paragraph: For three weeks, witness after witness in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial has spoken the name of Stormy Daniels, the porn star whose claim of a sexual encounter with the former president is at the center of the case. On Tuesday, jurors heard her tell the story herself, and Mr. Trump silently looked on.

headline: ‘Every Dollar Counts’: Prosecutors Use Quotes From Trump’s Books Against Him
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s books provided prosecutors with passages they believe can help their case, as they argue that he knew that his company falsified business records to cover up a hush-money payment to Stormy Daniels.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors cannot force Donald J. Trump to testify at his criminal trial in Manhattan, but that does not mean they can’t use his words against him.

headline: Tadhana Showcases Filipino Cuisine With a 16-Course Tasting Menu
abstract: Inday serves fast-casual Indian American fare, Summer at the Rink Rock Center provides al fresco dining and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: With no shortage of ambition, Frances Tariga, 42, who came to New York from the Philippines in 2011 as the chef for a diplomat, is opening her first restaurant. Dinner, a 16-course tasting divided in seven categories, is $185. Intended to showcase her native cuisine, it progresses from a special mountain bread to vegetable preparations, including a spring roll, then several ceviches, street food items like okra tempura and, with a touch of gastronomic luxury, a traditional duck egg custard topped with caviar. There is soup followed by salo-salo, an array of grilled and steamed items, then dessert. With the chef Mark Nobello at her side in the kitchen and a staff that’s entirely Filipino, she’s running a tight, 24-seat ship in a mere 700 square feet. (Friday)

headline: From a Dead Dog to a Made-Up Meeting: Takeaways From Kristi Noem’s Book
abstract: After a rough start to the rollout of her memoir, the South Dakota governor has continued to defend shooting her dog and to deflect on a false story about meeting Kim Jong-un.
lead_paragraph: In one sense, Kristi Noem has had a wildly successful rollout of her new book: America can’t stop talking about it.

headline: Creamy Noodles Drizzled With Chile Crisp, Chicken Fajitas in Soft Flour Tortillas
abstract: This week’s round of fast, easy dinners leans into cravings.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Mia here, filling in for Emily Weinstein today. I’m delighted to be here in Five Weeknight Dishesland — I’m usually hanging out in the Cooking newsletter with Melissa Clark and Sam Sifton — to talk about my new favorite thing.

headline: Scientists Find an ‘Alphabet’ in Whale Songs
abstract: Sperm whales rattle off pulses of clicks while swimming together, raising the possibility that they’re communicating in a complex language.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the discovery of whale songs almost 60 years ago, scientists have been trying to decipher their lyrics. Are the animals producing complex messages akin to human language? Or sharing simpler pieces of information, like dancing bees do? Or are they communicating something else we don’t yet understand?

headline: E. Coli Has Been Found in Ground Beef and Walnuts. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: The bacteria sickens an estimated 265,000 Americans each year.
lead_paragraph: Last week, federal officials announced recalls of ground beef and organic walnuts because they were potentially contaminated with E. coli bacteria that can make people sick.

headline: In Europe, Police Arrest Protesters and Clear Encampments at Universities
abstract: Many European students’ demands parallel those of U.S. students, including for universities to disclose their investment streams and divest from those supporting Israel in the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: In countries across Europe, students have staged their own pro-Palestinian sit-ins and protests on the lawns of their universities. And in several instances, the authorities are taking a similar approach to their U.S. counterparts: shutting them down.

headline: After the Met Gala, the Parties Lasted All Night
abstract: Usher, Jeff Bezos, Serena Williams, Erykah Badu, Janelle Monáe and other celebrities kept going into the wee hours.
lead_paragraph: One reason the Met Gala after-parties are nearly as famous as the Met Gala itself has to do with an incident that took place 10 years ago at the Standard Hotel in the West Village of Manhattan.

headline: Stormy Daniels Testifies About Her Encounter With Trump in Lake Tahoe
abstract: The porn star met the future president at a golf tournament, and she said she was invited to his suite. Her account of what happened next eventually resulted in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial.
lead_paragraph: Stormy Daniels on Tuesday told jurors her account of a sexual encounter with Donald J. Trump in 2006, an episode that ultimately resulted in the former president’s criminal trial.

headline: These Are Your New Breakfast Favorites
abstract: Variations have been around since bread was invented, but these new takes on French toast show it off simply and stunningly.
lead_paragraph: Humans have been rehabilitating rock-hard, stale loaves into edible food since bread was first invented. But the recipe that has become irrevocably rooted in American breakfast culture is French toast.

headline: Blinken Holds Regional Talks on Migration in Latin America
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s trip to Guatemala comes as the United States tries to get countries in the region to ramp up enforcement of their borders.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with senior Latin American officials in Guatemala on Tuesday as part of the Biden administration’s push to get countries in the region to ramp up enforcement of their borders and expand legal ways to migrate.

headline: Security Guard Injured in Shooting Outside Drake’s Home in Toronto
abstract: The police said that they did not know whether the shooting was related to the recent exchange of increasingly personal diss tracks traded between Drake and Kendrick Lamar.
lead_paragraph: A man identified as a security guard for Drake was wounded in a shooting outside of the rapper’s Toronto mansion around 2 a.m. on Tuesday, the police said.

headline: U.S. Tightens Rules on Risky Virus Research
abstract: A long-awaited new policy broadens the type of regulated viruses, bacteria, fungi and toxins, including those that could threaten crops and livestock.
lead_paragraph: The White House has unveiled tighter rules for research on potentially dangerous microbes and toxins, in an effort to stave off laboratory accidents that could unleash a pandemic.

headline: Shots, Shots, Shots! Why Tiny Drinks Are on the Rise.
abstract: Bartenders are shrinking their pours with variety and festivity in mind.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of the night at Theodora, an elegant Mediterranean restaurant that opened in Brooklyn’s Fort Greene neighborhood in February, diners at the polished concrete chef’s counter are often treated to the last thing they might expect in such a setting: a shot. It’s a ritual, explains Maggie Dahill, 27, Theodora’s beverage director, designed to encourage guests to feel part of a community. The shots, which the staff also partake in, change nightly and reflect the global inspirations of Theodora’s chef, Tomer Blechman, 46. Some are a perennial presence on the drinks menu, like a diminutive pour of Tubi, a citrus-based Israeli liqueur, or an ice-cold dose of vodka served with a skewered pickled mushroom in homage to the chef’s Latvian family. There’s a nonalcoholic option, as well. (On a recent night, it was a homemade fermented kumquat and rose soda.) “To some degree it’s less about the actual beverage and more about that moment of ‘cheers’ with somebody — that sense of connection,” Dahill says.

headline: TikTok Sues U.S. Government Over Law Forcing Sale or Ban
abstract: The social media company and its Chinese parent, ByteDance, sued to challenge the new law, saying it violated users’ First Amendment rights.
lead_paragraph: TikTok sued the federal government on Tuesday over a new law that would force its Chinese owner, ByteDance, to sell the popular social media app or face a ban in the United States, stoking a battle over national security and free speech that is likely to end up in the Supreme Court.

headline: Robert Downey Jr. to Make Broadway Debut in Ayad Akhtar Play
abstract: The Oscar-winning actor will star as an A.I.-curious author in “McNeal,” starting performances in September at Lincoln Center Theater.
lead_paragraph: Robert Downey Jr., who earlier this year won an Academy Award, will make his Broadway debut this fall in “McNeal,” a new drama by the Pulitzer-winning playwright Ayad Akhtar.

headline: Miss USA Resigns From Title, Citing Mental Health
abstract: Noelia Voigt, who represented Utah as she won the 2023 competition, said in a statement that relinquishing her title was a “tough decision.”
lead_paragraph: Noelia Voigt, who was crowned Miss USA in September, said on Monday that she was stepping down from the role to prioritize her mental health.

headline: Indiana Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Indiana primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Indiana primary elections.

headline: ‘Challengers’ and That Ending: Our Critics Have Thoughts
abstract: The tennis movie comes to an abrupt stop midmatch, so we don’t know who won. Does that matter?
lead_paragraph: The relationships in “Challengers” are complicated. Patrick (Josh O’Connor) and Art (Mike Faist) were close pals on the juniors tennis circuit when they met Tashi (Zendaya), a phenom. As the years pass and they become entangled in on-court rivalry and off-court sexual tensions, the film builds to a vicious challenger-circuit match between Art, now a top-ranked pro with a confidence problem, and Patrick, sleeping in his car between tournaments. In the stands is Art’s wife and Patrick’s ex, Tashi, who turned to coaching after an injury cut short her career. The film ends abruptly, the outcome of the match unclear — and that has been the subject of much discussion online. So we asked our critic at large Wesley Morris and our movie critic Alissa Wilkinson to weigh in. Caution: Spoilers ahead.

headline: They Put a 65-Foot Hot Dog in Times Square, and It’s a Blast
abstract: With “Hot Dog in the City,” the artists Jen Catron and Paul Outlaw question the lore and lure of American culture (and condiments).
lead_paragraph: As the sun set on a cloudy evening in Times Square on Friday, a 65-foot-long frankfurter cantilevered into the sky and spewed out a blast of rainbow confetti.

headline: The U.S. Must Keep the Rafah Invasion From Turning Into a Starvation Crisis
abstract: Israel’s latest move aggravates a desperate situation.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces have entered Rafah, near the Egyptian border of the Gaza Strip, but we don’t yet fully understand whether this is the beginning of a full-scale ground invasion of the city or something more modest. What we do know is that the flow of desperately needed food aid into a territory that is already starving is severely impeded.

headline: I Didn’t Truly Know My Mother Until I Cooked With Her
abstract: To connect with a parent who awes (and occasionally intimidates) everyone around her, the Times reporter Priya Krishna spends time with her in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: My mother and I were not the “Gilmore Girls.”

headline: Wearing Masks During the Gaza Protests
abstract: Readers criticize protesters who try to maintain their anonymity. Also: Money and politics; protecting oceans; possible exiles if Donald Trump wins.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Senators Seek to Curb Facial Recognition at Airports, Citing Privacy Concerns
abstract: A bipartisan group of lawmakers is pushing to add language to the reauthorization of the Federal Aviation Administration that would halt expansion of the technology.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of senators is pushing to halt the expansion of facial recognition technology at airports in the United States and restrict its use as part of the Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization bill that is making its way through Congress.

headline: What Does ‘Post-Emerging’ Look Like in Today’s Dance Landscape?
abstract: Fresh Tracks, at New York Live Arts, showcases early-career dance makers. This year’s talented crop wonders about next steps.
lead_paragraph: Bill T. Jones still remembers warming up backstage for one of his first New York City performances, in 1977: a solo at Dance Theater Workshop in Chelsea, as part of a series for up-and-coming experimentalists.

headline: Gaza War Puts New Pressures on U.S. Arms Transfer Policies
abstract: The Biden administration is due to release a report this week on whether it believes assurances from Israel on its use of U.S. arms and protection of civilians.
lead_paragraph: In February of last year, President Biden changed the U.S. standard for cutting off weapons deliveries to foreign militaries that harm civilians during wartime.

headline: Speaker Mike Johnson Says U.S. Universities Are ‘Hostile’ to Jews
abstract: At a Holocaust Remembrance Ceremony, the Louisiana Republican compared the protests on U.S. campuses to what happened at institutions of higher learning in Germany before World War II.
lead_paragraph: House Speaker Mike Johnson on Tuesday compared the protests unfolding on American university campuses to what happened at institutions of higher learning in Germany before World War II.

headline: Stormy Daniels and Trump Have Met in Court Before, to Her Detriment
abstract: Stormy Daniels sued Donald J. Trump for defamation and lost. Her lawyer wound up in prison for stealing from her.
lead_paragraph: Stormy Daniels’s testimony on Tuesday against Donald J. Trump at his criminal trial in Manhattan was not the first time that the porn star and the former president have clashed in court.

headline: The Dangers in Putting Stormy Daniels on the Stand
abstract: She can confirm the tryst happened, but has changed her story over the years.
lead_paragraph: As a purely legal matter, Donald Trump’s hush-money/election interference trial is not about the sex, but a single sexual encounter is at the heart of it. The prosecution made an important decision on Tuesday to highlight that in the most graphic way for the jury.

headline: Could Equinox’s New $40,000 Membership Really Help You Live Longer?
abstract: Blood tests and “biodata” have entered the fitness space.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the high-end gym chain Equinox introduced a longevity program with a $40,000 annual membership fee.

headline: Madonna’s Hits-Filled Celebration Tour, Dissected
abstract: Hear five standouts from the set, and six we wish she’d played.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay is desperately seeking some time off this week, so I am the first of your guest playlisters: Caryn, the pop music editor. I’m going to tell you a secret — you could consider it one of my confessions on a dance floor. I saw Madonna’s Celebration Tour seven times; eight if you include the livestream from Rio de Janeiro on Saturday night, where the Queen of Pop wrapped her first-ever retrospective with a free show before an estimated 1.6 million people on Copacabana Beach.

headline: Transcript: Read Biden’s Remarks at a Holocaust Remembrance Ceremony
abstract: Here is the president’s complete speech, which lasted about 16 minutes.
lead_paragraph: President Biden delivered these remarks on Tuesday at the Capitol for the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum’s Days of Remembrance.

headline: Read TikTok’s legal challenge
abstract: TikTok filed a challenge to a law forcing its parent company, ByteDance, to sell the app or face its ban in the United States.
lead_paragraph: TikTok filed a challenge to a law forcing its parent company, ByteDance, to sell the app or face its ban in the United States.

headline: Panera Will Discontinue Charged Lemonade Drinks
abstract: The highly caffeinated line of Charged drinks at Panera Bread was the subject of two wrongful-death lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: Panera Bread will stop selling its highly caffeinated fruit-flavored drinks, which were the subject of lawsuits by people who said the drinks had caused health problems, including two deaths.

headline: Adams Says Rikers, Staffed by ‘Professionals,’ Is Ready for Trump
abstract: The judge in Donald J. Trump’s criminal case has threatened him with jail if he continues violating the terms of a gag order.
lead_paragraph: A day after the judge presiding over Donald J. Trump’s trial said he would consider jailing the former president should he continue to violate court orders, Mayor Eric Adams said the city’s lockups stand ready.

headline: Man Says He Killed His Wife Because He Couldn’t Pay Her Medical Bills
abstract: Ronnie Wiggs, of Independence, Mo., was charged with second-degree murder in the strangling death of his wife, who was in the hospital for dialysis treatment, records show.
lead_paragraph: A Missouri man charged with strangling his wife told the police that he had killed her while she was lying in a hospital bed because he could not take care of her or pay her medical bills, prosecutors said.

headline: The New Players in Brazilian Politics? Elon Musk and Republicans.
abstract: The billionaire businessman and House Republicans have given new life to former President Jair Bolsonaro by attacking Brazil’s Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Just a few months ago, the political movement behind Brazil’s far-right former president, Jair Bolsonaro, was sputtering. Mr. Bolsonaro had been voted out of office, ruled ineligible to run in the next election and was in the cross hairs of deepening criminal investigations.

headline: If It Bleeds It Leads, Inflation Edition
abstract: How negativity bias affects economic perceptions.
lead_paragraph: By normal standards, the U.S. economy continues to look very good. Unemployment has now been below 4 percent for 27 months, and inflation remains fairly low, albeit somewhat higher than the Federal Reserve’s target of 2 percent. But if you say that, you get a lot of pushback; some get angry.

headline: ‘Maybe the Best Breakfast I’ve Ever Made’
abstract: Huevos rancheros, coffee cake and more reader-favorite recipes for Mother’s Day. (Which, by the way, is this Sunday.)
lead_paragraph: Mother’s Day is this Sunday, and while moms everywhere insist they “don’t want anything,” they would almost certainly appreciate a good breakfast. (She might also like a stripy tote bag or an ikebana kit, but since we’re New York Times Cooking, we’re going to stick to food.)

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Rarity in Paris’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: I was 41, single and no longer looking. Rushing back to work from lunch, I was climbing the Metro stairs when a briefcase brushed against my leg. A tall man in a Barbour jacket excused himself — a rarity in Paris — and smiled, revealing his dimples. We entered the same Metro car, and five stops later, both exited. “Madame, if you do not stop following me, I will call the police,” he said, as we waited to cross the street. His dimples reappeared, and soon after, I was no longer single. — Rebecca Gaghen Veron

headline: With or Without Tesla, More E.V. Chargers Are Coming
abstract: Experts say that a new wave of electric vehicle charging stations are coming soon, even after Tesla gutted its charger team.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Tesla laid off most of its electric car charging team, raising doubts about the feasibility of the Biden administration’s ambitious E.V. expansion plans.

headline: Police Tackle and Arrest Anti-Trump Protester Outside Courthouse
abstract: Officers have enforced a ban on amplification and on Tuesday grappled with a man who had been chanting into a microphone.
lead_paragraph: Several police officers forcibly arrested an anti-Trump demonstrator on Tuesday in a park outside the Lower Manhattan courthouse where Donald J. Trump is on trial.

headline: The Darker Side of Stormy Daniels’s Testimony
abstract: She has never accused Donald Trump of anything but a payoff, but their encounter sounds a lot murkier than before.
lead_paragraph: He promised her dinner … but they didn’t have dinner. He told her she reminded him of his daughter … then stripped down to his boxers and a T-shirt while she was in the bathroom. He said he could help her career with a spot on his TV show … then scolded her, “I thought you were serious,” when she tried to leave.

headline: Macron Adds a Personal Touch to His Diplomacy With China
abstract: The French president took Xi Jinping to his childhood haunts high in the Pyrenees, hoping to forge a bond. If only the weather had cooperated.
lead_paragraph: The French president, Emmanuel Macron, who believes that a personal touch is the key to diplomacy, lured President Xi Jinping of China to a 7,000-foot pass in the Pyrenees on Tuesday, expecting to show off the sweeping views that had stamped his childhood, but instead finding dense fog and wild snow flurries.

headline: A Thank-You Note to the Campus Protesters
abstract: You are my daily reminder of what my Zionism is for, about and against.
lead_paragraph: Dear anti-Israel campus protesters:

headline: Stormy Daniels Was Entertaining, but Did She Make a Real Impact?
abstract: Jurors may believe she and Trump had a tryst, but not necessarily her entire testimony.
lead_paragraph: The court transcript and eyewitness accounts cannot do justice to the entertainment value of Stormy Daniels’s testimony in Donald Trump’s felony trial on Tuesday.

headline: A Romantic New Clothing Line With Hidden Quirks
abstract: The designer Meruert Tolegen started out making children’s wear. Her pieces for adults combine precise construction with a playful spirit.
lead_paragraph: In February, the designer Meruert Tolegen made her New York Fashion Week debut in the midst of a winter storm. As snow fell outside the windows of her chosen venue, a former shopping arcade in Chinatown, models walked in fittingly romantic clothes, including a Pierrot-inspired black silk dress with beaded flowers; an ivory smocked, embroidered-lace dress with panniers; and an enveloping white satin puffer coat with a dainty floral print. Emphasizing the moment’s synergy were the show notes, which included a passage from the Belgian writer Paul Willems’s 1983 story collection, “The Cathedral of Mist.” An excerpt: “The sound of our voices changed and bent, too, beneath the whiteness, while the flakes piled on our clothes and hats.”

headline: A Timeline of the History Between Stormy Daniels and Donald Trump
abstract: Nearly two decades after they met in Nevada, Daniels and Trump met face to face again in a Lower Manhattan courtroom in the first criminal trial against a former United States president.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two decades after Stormy Daniels and Donald J. Trump met in Nevada, they came face to face again in a Lower Manhattan courtroom, where the first criminal trial against a former United States president is taking place.

headline: Garrick Club of London Votes to Accept Female Members for First Time
abstract: The move ended a decades-long dispute that had divided the opulent private club and generated multiple conflicting legal arguments.
lead_paragraph: One of London’s oldest, most celebrated men’s clubs, the Garrick, voted on Tuesday to admit women as members, according to two members. The vote ended a decades-long dispute that had divided the club, generated multiple conflicting legal arguments and made life acutely awkward for some of its most prominent members.

headline: Reddit Posts $575 Million Loss Tied to I.P.O. but Also Strong Growth
abstract: Reddit’s first earnings report as a public company showed leaps in users and advertising revenue, along with expenses related to its initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: Reddit on Tuesday posted a more than $500 million quarterly loss in its first earnings report as a public company, largely due to stock-based compensation expenses incurred during its initial public offering in March.

headline: Redfin Agrees to Share Data and Pay $9.25 Million to Settle Lawsuit
abstract: In addition to paying the fine, the online brokerage would give a group of home sellers access to a nationwide database of commissions paid to real estate agents, pending court approval.
lead_paragraph: Redfin will give home sellers who say they were forced to pay inflated commissions access to its vast, nationwide trove of data on payments made to real estate agents, under a proposed settlement in an ongoing legal fight that has shaken the real estate industry.

headline: Stormy Daniels, Who Testified About Sex With Trump, Will Return to Stand
abstract: The porn star at the center of the ex-president’s criminal trial, who will testify again on Thursday, spoke under oath about their encounter at a golf tournament in 2006, a meeting that could shape American history.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump met Stormy Daniels, their flirtation seemed fleeting: He was a 60-year-old married mogul at the peak of reality television fame, and she was 27, a Louisiana native raised in poverty and headed to porn-film stardom.

headline: Boy Scouts of America to Change Its Name to Scouting America
abstract: The organization, which is battling bankruptcy and sexual abuse claims, said the rebrand was part of an effort to be more inclusive and welcome all members of America’s youth.
lead_paragraph: The Boy Scouts of America, grappling with a bankruptcy and widespread accusations of sexual abuse, will change its name to Scouting America in an effort to become more inclusive, the organization announced on Tuesday.

headline: R.F.K. Jr., Invited to Libertarian Convention, Seeks Trump Debate
abstract: Both presidential candidates are scheduled to address a Libertarian gathering this month in Washington.
lead_paragraph: The independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. challenged former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday to debate him this month during the Libertarian Party’s national convention in Washington, where both men are set to deliver remarks.

headline: What to Know About the Gaps Between Israel and Hamas on the Cease-Fire Proposal
abstract: Hamas said it had accepted the terms of a cease-fire proposed by Arab mediators, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said it was “very far from Israel’s core demands.”
lead_paragraph: Israeli officials said on Tuesday that major gaps remained with Hamas over the latest proposal for a cease-fire in Gaza, as delegations from both sides arrived in Cairo to resume talks.

headline: Lesley Hazleton, Writer Who Tackled Religion and Fast Cars, Dies at 78
abstract: Born in England and raised Jewish, she became agnostic, writing books about her own lack of faith, the prophet Muhammad and her time as a car columnist.
lead_paragraph: Lesley Hazleton, a British-born, secular Jewish psychologist turned journalist and author, whose curiosity about faith and religion led her to write biographies of Muhammad, Mary and Jezebel and examine her own passions in books about agnosticism and automobiles, died on April 29 at her home, a houseboat in Seattle. She was 78.

headline: At the Met Gala, Celebrities Are Nearly Nude. Are We Not Aroused?
abstract: In an era of sexual decline, celebrities are dressing up in outfits that are barely there. But no one seems to be enjoying it much.
lead_paragraph: Watching the red carpet at Monday night’s Met Gala, I couldn’t help but recall a prediction I’d heard from Emily Kirkpatrick, who writes the Substack newsletter “I <3 Mess.” She’d told me recently that, before the end of 2024, it’s possible that “someone is going to show up fully nude on a red carpet.”

headline: How Parents of College Seniors Are Reacting to Campus Disruptions
abstract: No matter their opinions on pro-Palestinian demonstrations on campus, many parents are angry that final semesters and graduations have been upended.
lead_paragraph: The college experience for many of the parents of the Class of 2024 did not begin with the quintessential moment of loading up the car to drive to campus. Instead, parents wished their freshly minted college students luck as they logged on to classes online.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ari Shavit
abstract: The May 7, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ari Shavit. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Inquiry Finds a Toxic Culture at the F.D.I.C., and Takes Aim at Its Leader
abstract: Bad workplace behavior was pervasive at the bank regulator, according to an investigation that questioned whether things can improve without a change in leadership.
lead_paragraph: A report on workplace culture at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation released on Tuesday revealed a broad, yearslong pattern of sexual harassment, discrimination and abuse of mostly women and members of minority groups by senior officials. The findings are likely to lead to another potentially bruising round of questions for the agency’s chair, Martin Gruenberg, who is scheduled to testify in Congress later this month.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Israel in Rafah; Negotiators in Cairo
abstract: Also, Stormy Daniels testified in Donald Trump’s trial.
lead_paragraph: Israel sent tanks into Rafah yesterday and seized control of the border crossing with Egypt, halting the flow of aid. Delegations from Israel and Hamas also arrived in Cairo to resume talks on a proposed deal for a cease-fire.

headline: How Much Money Did This Year’s Met Gala Raise?
abstract: Ticket prices to the event have sharply risen, making it a fund-raising bonanza for the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute.
lead_paragraph: At the Met Gala on Monday, a throng of photographers fought to capture Zendaya and Kim Kardashian parading couture gowns down the red (technically, mouthwash-green) carpet.

headline: Stormy Daniels, Unfiltered, Takes the Stand
abstract: The porn star at the center of Donald Trump’s criminal trial testified, at times in graphic detail, about the sexual encounter she said she had with Trump in 2006.
lead_paragraph: The woman who walked into Donald Trump’s Manhattan courtroom today was a sharp departure from many of the week’s earlier witnesses, who testified on such procedural topics as ledgers, invoices and common accounting practices.

headline: Consultants to Examine Police Response to Attack at U.C.L.A.
abstract: The University of California system said it would bring in a police consulting firm to investigate why the attack on pro-Palestinian demonstrators was allowed to continue for hours.
lead_paragraph: A police consulting firm will review a violent confrontation at the University of California, Los Angeles a week ago, in which a group of counterprotesters attacked demonstrators at a pro-Palestinian encampment while security guards and police officers failed for several hours to intervene, and made no arrests.

headline: Trump, Biden and a Split Screen Made for This Moment
abstract: President Biden gave a speech on Holocaust remembrance. Former President Trump was in court with Stormy Daniels. The day captured the sometimes unreal reality of a presidential race like none before it.
lead_paragraph: These were the images Americans were presented on Tuesday about their two choices for president: One taking his grandchildren to Dachau to bear witness to the horrors of Nazi death camps, the other sitting on a hotel bed in his boxer shorts waiting for sex with a porn star.

headline: White House Condemns Taunting of a Black Student at Ole Miss
abstract: In a widely shared video, one white male student at the University of Mississippi appeared to make monkey gestures at a Black pro-Palestinian protester, as others jeered.
lead_paragraph: The White House on Tuesday condemned the actions of counterprotesters at the University of Mississippi, after videos captured last week showed a crowd of white male students taunting and jeering at a female Black student at a pro-Palestinian protest.

headline: Stormy Daniels Testified About Core Details in Trump’s Trial
abstract: Also, TikTok sued the U.S. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: There is probably no one, other than Donald Trump, more central to his New York trial — the first criminal trial of an American president — than Stormy Daniels. Trump is charged with falsifying business records to cover up a $130,000 payment to Daniels during his 2016 campaign, when she was planning to go public with a lurid story about a sexual encounter with Trump a decade prior.

headline: Judge Postpones Start of Trump Documents Trial Without New Date
abstract: Judge Aileen Cannon had previously made clear that the trial would not start as scheduled this month but she declined to set a new timetable, saying many pretrial issues still have to be resolved.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case formally scrapped her own May 20 start date for the trial on Tuesday but declined to set a new one, saying there was much more work to be done before a jury could hear the charges.

headline: Outage at U.K. Airports’ Immigration Checkpoints Fixed After Several Hours
abstract: Airport officials said Tuesday that a system outage affecting the Border Force’s immigration gates had caused long waits for passengers arriving in Britain. The issue was resolved early Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: International airline passengers arriving at British airports, including Heathrow Airport near London, faced long lines at immigration checkpoints for several hours on Tuesday evening before the British Border Force announced that a nationwide computer outage that caused the delays had ended.

headline: Stormy Daniels Stood Up Well to the Taunts of Trump’s Lawyer
abstract: She had explanations — some more convincing than others — for zig-zagging in interviews.
lead_paragraph: So far, Susan Necheles’s cross-examination of Stormy Daniels feels a little star-crossed, and not just because the jury in the Trump hush-money trial surely noticed when the lawyer accidentally called the CNN legal analyst Jeffrey Toobin “Jeff Daniels” and twice referred to Gina Rodriguez, Stormy Daniels’s talent agent, as “Geena Davis.”

headline: Sanitation Company Fined $649,000 for Hiring Children in Slaughterhouses
abstract: Fayette Janitorial Service was also ordered to change practices that the Labor Department said had led to the hiring of at least two dozen children in dangerous slaughterhouses and meatpacking facilities.
lead_paragraph: A Tennessee-based sanitation company has been fined more than $649,000 after an investigation revealed that it had illegally employed at least two dozen children at slaughterhouses and meatpacking facilities, the Labor Department said this week.

headline: Israeli Tanks Enter Rafah as Cease-Fire Talks Resume in Cairo
abstract: An Israeli incursion into the southern Gaza city did not appear to be the long-anticipated, full-scale invasion of the city, home to about a million displaced Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Tuesday that its tanks had entered Rafah in southern Gaza and had seized control of the city’s critical border crossing with Egypt in what it called a limited operation to eliminate Hamas fighters and infrastructure that had been used to attack and kill four Israeli soldiers on Sunday.

headline: Stormy Daniels Delivers Intense Testimony in Trump’s Trial: 6 Takeaways
abstract: A long day on the stand put Ms. Daniels’s credibility to the test as defense lawyers challenged her motives.
lead_paragraph: “The people call Stormy Daniels.”

headline: When These Snakes Play Dead, Soiling Themselves Is Part of the Act
abstract: Dice snakes found on an island in southeastern Europe fully commit themselves to the role of ex-reptile.
lead_paragraph: Most snakes flee or fight when attacked. Then there are the dice snakes of Golem Grad, an island on a lake in North Macedonia. Grabbed by a predator, they writhe theatrically, soiling themselves with a pungent cocktail of musk and feces. Eventually they go limp, mouth gaping, tongue protruding. To really sell the part of playing dead, some even bleed from their mouths.

headline: Senator Mike Braun Clinches G.O.P. Nomination for Indiana Governor
abstract: Mr. Braun, a first-term senator, will enter the general election as the strong favorite in his reliably conservative state.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mike Braun of Indiana won the Republican nomination for governor of his solidly conservative state, The Associated Press said on Tuesday, positioning him as the strong favorite in this fall’s general election.

headline: A Land Artist’s Work Evades Demolition
abstract: A federal judge granted a preliminary injunction protecting a work by Mary Miss. A Des Moines museum wanted to destroy it, citing safety concerns.
lead_paragraph: A work of environmental art by Mary Miss has evaded demolition — for now. A judge in the U.S. District Court in Des Moines on Friday granted her request for a preliminary injunction that would bar the Des Moines Art Center, the museum that commissioned the land art installation, from dismantling it. The museum maintains it has become a safety hazard and that the resources to repair it are not available.

headline: Body of Final Victim in Baltimore Bridge Collapse Is Found
abstract: The victim, José Mynor López, was a member of a work crew that had been filling potholes on the bridge when it was struck in March by a container ship.
lead_paragraph: The body of the sixth and final victim who died in the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore was found on Tuesday, officials said, bringing to a close a difficult salvage mission after the country’s deadliest bridge collapse in more than a decade.

headline: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, May 6, 2024
abstract: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Canada Re-Criminalizes Public Drug Use in British Columbia
abstract: A province that was a global pioneer in harm reduction took a step back after a political backlash.
lead_paragraph: The government of Canada on Tuesday walked back part of a program allowing people in British Columbia to possess small amounts of drugs, including heroin and cocaine, without fear of criminal charges. At the request of the province and after a public backlash, people in British Columbia are no longer permitted to use drugs in public places.

headline: Stormy Daniels Tells Her Story of Sex With Trump
abstract: Stormy Daniels, the porn star at the center of former President Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, testified about their encounter at a celebrity golf tournament in 2006.
lead_paragraph: Stormy Daniels, the porn star at the center of former President Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, testified about their encounter at a celebrity golf tournament in 2006.

headline: Kai Cenat Resolves Union Square Melee Charges With Apology, Officials Say
abstract: The social media superstar known for marathon streaming sessions was charged with inciting a riot after a video game console giveaway erupted in mayhem last summer.
lead_paragraph: The social media star Kai Cenat will not be prosecuted on charges of inciting a riot in Manhattan after agreeing to post a public apology and paying for the damage caused when thousands of his fans erupted in a chaotic melee in Union Square last summer, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: For American Jews, Biden’s Speech on Antisemitism Offers Recognition and Healing
abstract: While his message resonated with many Jewish leaders, the president’s remarks drew criticism from Republicans and supporters of Palestinians on the left.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, standing in front of six candles symbolizing the six million Jews killed during the Holocaust, delivered on Tuesday the strongest condemnation of antisemitism by any sitting American president.

headline: Cartoon Frames
abstract: Michael Schlossberg sugarcoats the truth.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Former Soldier Convicted in Killing of Pregnant Army Private Two Decades Ago
abstract: A federal jury found the former soldier, Shannon L. Wilkerson, 43, guilty of second-degree murder in the death of Pvt. Amanda Gonzales on Nov. 3, 2001.
lead_paragraph: A former U.S. Army soldier has been convicted of murdering a pregnant 19-year-old fellow soldier on a U.S. base in Germany more than two decades ago, the Justice Department said Tuesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day:Facing Labor Shortages, Japan Moves to Advance Working Women
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You can rely on the day-care center or your parents or friends. Or even your husband.”

headline: Biden Puts Arms Shipment to Israel on Hold Amid Dispute Over Rafah Attack
abstract: The United States withheld 3,500 bombs last week out of concern that they might be used in a major assault against the southern Gaza city, officials said.
lead_paragraph: President Biden paused an arms shipment to Israel last week to prevent the U.S.-made weapons from being used in a long-threatened assault on the city of Rafah, administration officials said on Tuesday night, a sign of the growing rift between the United States and Israel over the conduct of the war.

headline: With a Gaza Cease-Fire in the Balance, Netanyahu Maneuvers to Keep Power
abstract: The Israeli prime minister, under pressure from all sides, is trying to reassure his many domestic, military and diplomatic critics. Here’s a look at what he is confronting.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, is known as a man who likes to play for time and postpone big decisions. But he may not be able to do that much longer.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Israel’s incursion into Rafah.
lead_paragraph: Delegations from Israel and Hamas arrived in Cairo yesterday to resume talks on a proposed cease-fire deal. Hours earlier, Israeli tanks and troops entered the southern Gaza city of Rafah and seized control of the border crossing with Egypt, halting the flow of aid into the enclave. U.N. officials warned that the humanitarian crisis in the besieged territory would worsen. Here’s the latest.

headline: Using Cartoonish Accents, J.F.K.’s Grandson Insults and Mocks Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
abstract: In an escalation of the family feud, the son of Caroline Kennedy portrayed heavily accented characters who suggested that his cousin, the presidential candidate, was on steroids, not too smart and a liar.
lead_paragraph: The grandson of President John F. Kennedy this week savaged his presidential-candidate cousin, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., in a series of mocking, meant-to-be-funny videos that were, inarguably, uncharacteristically un-Kennedyesque, escalating a civil war within America’s most storied political dynasty.

headline: Ian Gelder, ‘Game of Thrones’ Actor, Dies at 74
abstract: He played Kevan Lannister, the brother of the feared patriarch Tywin, capping a television and stage career spanning a half century.
lead_paragraph: Ian Gelder, the British actor who capped his half-century career by appearing in the hit series “Game of Thrones” as Kevan Lannister, brother of the feared patriarch Tywin Lannister, died on Monday. He was 74.

headline: How Iran and Israel Are Unnatural Adversaries
abstract: As long as Iran is ruled by a government that puts ideology before its national interest, the Middle East will never know meaningful stability.
lead_paragraph: “History is littered,” the British writer and politician Enoch Powell said, “with the wars which everybody knew would never happen.”

headline: Corrections: May 8, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about Qantas’s deal with a consumer watchdog commission to pay $79 million for selling tickets to canceled flights misspelled the name of Qantas’s chief executive. It is Vanessa Hudson, not Husdon.

headline: FTX Customers Poised to Recover All Funds Lost in Collapse
abstract: Bankruptcy lawyers for FTX said customers of the cryptocurrency exchange were set to get all their money back, plus interest.
lead_paragraph: Customers of the failed cryptocurrency exchange FTX are poised to recover all of the money they lost when the firm collapsed in 2022 and receive interest on top of it, the company’s bankruptcy lawyers said on Tuesday.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Wants the Dirty Details From Stormy Daniels
abstract: The host disagreed with a judge who said Daniels could skip some of the specifics of her encounter with Donald Trump. “Some of us are trying to host a show here, OK?”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: accolade
abstract: This word has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word accolade has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 4 in “Chemistry Nobel Prize Revealed in Media Hours Early” by Aaron Boxerman and Emma Bubola:

headline: The Connections Companion No. 332
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: N.Y. Prisons Holding Mentally Ill People in Solitary, Lawsuit Says
abstract: A complaint filed by the Legal Aid Society and others accuses the state prison system of holding mentally ill and disabled people in isolation despite a law against the practice.
lead_paragraph: Each time Stephanie Peña was placed alone in a prison cell the length and width of a parking spot, she could feel herself losing it.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,054
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Cicadas for Dinner
abstract: Would you eat a cicada — or any other type of bug? If so, how would you like it cooked?
lead_paragraph: Over the next six weeks or so, a trillion cicadas will emerge across the Midwest and Southeast for a brief, raucous, once-in-a-lifetime bender.

headline: The Knicks Are Finally Good Again. And New York City Loves Them for It.
abstract: Fifty years since the Knicks last won a championship, a freshly promising team led by star point guard Jalen Brunson has captivated their hometown.
lead_paragraph: They poured out of Madison Square Garden and the surrounding bars, draped in Jalen Brunson jerseys and other Knicks paraphernalia, chanting and yelling and exulting as they clogged Seventh Avenue and brought traffic to a halt.

headline: Rolling Blackouts Hit Several Cities as Heat Wave Scorches Mexico
abstract: Cities were plunged into darkness as scorching temperatures strained the national energy grid.
lead_paragraph: There were rolling blackouts in multiple cities across Mexico on Tuesday, as people in several states reeled from soaring temperatures and the national energy authority briefly declared a state of emergency.

headline: Israel Reopens a Gaza Crossing Critical for Humanitarian Aid
abstract: The crossing at Kerem Shalom had been closed since a Hamas rocket attack from Gaza on Sunday killed four soldiers in the area.
lead_paragraph: Israel said on Wednesday that it had reopened the Kerem Shalom crossing into the Gaza Strip after closing it days earlier because of an attack by Hamas. But the United Nations said it was too soon to tell how quickly the humanitarian aid that is critical to stemming a hunger crisis in Gaza would begin to flow again.

headline: Hong Kong Court Bans Democracy Song, Calling It a ‘Weapon’
abstract: The decision could give the government power to force Google and other tech companies to limit access to “Glory to Hong Kong,” an anthem of 2019 protests.
lead_paragraph: A Hong Kong court on Wednesday granted a government request to ban a popular pro-democracy anthem, raising further concerns about free speech in the city.

headline: France Says It Built the Olympics Safely. Migrant Workers Don’t Count.
abstract: Undocumented workers played a larger and more dangerous role in delivering the Games than the Macron administration acknowledges.
lead_paragraph: France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, promised to build the Summer Olympics safely, free of the construction hazards and migrant worker abuses that tarnished soccer’s 2022 World Cup in Qatar.

headline: Close Friends, Competing for Coveted Olympic Spots. Who Would Make It?
abstract: Conner Mantz and Clayton Young had run side by side for more than 10,000 miles. Both vied for a place in the marathon at the Paris Games.
lead_paragraph: Conner Mantz’s arms were shaking as he warmed up for the Olympic marathon trials in Orlando in February.

headline: A Star Is Born. She Looks a Bit Like Amy Winehouse.
abstract: Marisa Abela was not widely known before being cast as the troubled singer-songwriter in “Back to Black.” That’s over now.
lead_paragraph: On the third floor of the Edition hotel in West Hollywood, three chairs were pushed against a wall in a hallway, supporting a rotating cast of entertainment journalists.

headline: A Serene Oasis for Making Music
abstract: Aaron Dessner’s Long Pond recording studio breaks a lot of design rules. It’s why musicians like Taylor Swift have put it on the map.
lead_paragraph: The first things you notice upon entering Long Pond Studio are the glass windows and doors. They’re huge — the doors are eight-feet square — and frame pastoral scenes of grass, trees and water. Picture windows looking onto a pond would be merely pretty in a house. But in this setting — a recording studio in the countryside near Hudson, N.Y. — they’re startling.

headline: A Piano From the Titanic’s Sister Ship Awaits Its Next Audience
abstract: A gilt-trimmed upright Steinway piano commissioned in 1912 for the ocean liner Olympic is on dry land and ready to be heard again.
lead_paragraph: During the Titanic’s maiden voyage, musicians played pianos from Steinway & Sons to entertain passengers with waltzes and opera overtures. A twin of one of the ship’s Steinway instruments has been found in northern England, and a new nonprofit organization is gearing up to return it to the limelight.

headline: Billions in Chips Grants Are Expected to Fuel Industry Growth, Report Finds
abstract: The United States will triple its domestic chip manufacturing capacity by 2032, the largest increase in the world, according to a report from the Semiconductor Industry Association.
lead_paragraph: Billions in federal subsidies for semiconductor manufacturers are expected to help reverse a decades-long decline in America’s share of global chip manufacturing.

headline: The Teenage Witches Are Growing Up
abstract: New books by H.A. Clarke, Robert Jackson Bennett and Micaiah Johnson.
lead_paragraph: THE FEAST MAKERS (Erewhon, 412 pp., $18.95), by H.A. Clarke, concludes a trilogy that began with “The Scapegracers,” a brutal and vivid evocation of the bonds between queer teenagers and the magic they can make together.

headline: The Constant Work to Keep a Family Connected Has a Name
abstract: “Kinkeeping” plays a crucial role in a family’s health and well-being, and it’s still predominantly done by women.
lead_paragraph: Every December when Erienne Fawcett was growing up, her rural Minnesota home transformed into a showcase of snowy miniature villages, complete with tiny reindeer and carolers.

headline: For Her Broadway Debut, She Sings Alicia Keys’s Story
abstract: Maleah Joi Moon almost gave up on theater. Now, in her first professional role, the “Hell’s Kitchen” star is a Tony nominee.
lead_paragraph: Maleah Joi Moon has come a long way in a short time.

headline: Chicago Would Like Everyone to Stop Talking About 1968
abstract: As the city prepares to host the Democratic National Convention, it wants to shed memories of chaos from half a century ago even as protests are growing.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Brandon Johnson of Chicago understands the comparison to 1968. Once again, the city is gearing up to host a late-summer Democratic National Convention against a backdrop of fury and antiwar campus protests from the party’s younger, leftist flank.

headline: For Bulgarian Voters, It’s Groundhog Day, Again
abstract: The nation faces its sixth general election in three years. “I’ve done this so many times people have started to feel pity for me,” one legislator said about campaigning.
lead_paragraph: For citizens of the United States, Britain, India and dozens of other countries around the world, 2024 is a big, high-stakes election year.

headline: How 360,000 Haitians Wound Up Living in Empty Lots and Crowded Schools
abstract: In a worsening humanitarian crisis, Haitians have been forced to flee their homes in the face of gang onslaughts, but the international response has failed to keep up.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of people in Haiti are on the run from rampant gang violence and have abandoned their homes, a worsening humanitarian crisis that the United Nations describes as “cataclysmic.”

headline: George Takei Keeps Faith With Democracy
abstract: At 87, the actor and writer says performing and activism remain his driving forces.
lead_paragraph: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, George Takei explains, in his own words, what continues to motivate him.

headline: ¡Hola Papi!, Does My Grandmother Need to Know I’m Gay?
abstract: Ahead of Mother’s Day, the advice columnist John Paul Brammer (a.k.a. ¡Hola Papi!) has a reminder: Loving your abuela doesn’t have to mean telling her everything.
lead_paragraph: John Paul Brammer writes the “¡Hola Papi!” advice column for The Cut at New York magazine, answering questions like, “Why am I dreaming about sex with a man when I’m a lesbian?” Or, “What if my partner judges me for writing smut?” This candor has given John Paul an intimate connection with his readers. However, as today’s episode reveals, he doesn’t think we necessarily need that level of openness with all of our loved ones.

headline: Amy Poehler Wants Her True-Crime Podcast to Make You Laugh
abstract: “Women Talkin’ ’Bout Murder,” a loving sendup of the podcast genre, is the latest satirical show from Poehler and her improv friends.
lead_paragraph: It was a Friday morning in December, and Amy Poehler was talking about murder. More specifically, she was directing a pair of comic actors over Zoom as they talked about murder in their guise as hosts of a fictional true-crime podcast titled — yes — “Women Talkin’ ’Bout Murder.” Today’s victim: Mary Benson, who went on a yoga retreat and plunged to an untimely demise at the bottom of a ravine.

headline: We Have a Housing Crisis. This New Jersey Town Has a Solution.
abstract: Palisades Park is ending the tyranny of single-family homes.
lead_paragraph: New York City is home to the country’s largest economy, but its suburbs are almost all zoned for single-family homes. That lack of development has resulted in a severe housing shortage in and around the city. But Palisades Park, N.J., is forging a different path.

headline: A Waterfront House with the Message ‘All or Nothing at All’
abstract: The Long Island abode of a couple of musical standards fans takes maximalism to a new level.
lead_paragraph: Consider the 21 gilded mirrors lining the music room, each more extravagant than the last. Or the Italian monastery table that seats 24, never mind the tapestries, peacock feathers, brass candlesticks and Persian rugs seemingly everywhere.

headline: Looking for the Missing People of Mexico
abstract: After surviving an abduction in June 2020, one photographer set out to document how decades of violence have ripped apart families, lives and a country.
lead_paragraph: After surviving an abduction in June 2020, one photographer set out to document how decades of violence have ripped apart families, lives and a country.

headline: Democrats, Sensing Shift on Abortion Rights Among Latinas, Push for More Gains
abstract: Hispanic views on the issue vary widely, and Democrats face hurdles, but opportunities, too. As one House candidate said: “I go to Mass, but I also support a woman’s right to choose.”
lead_paragraph: Hours before Arizona state legislators voted to repeal an 1864 abortion ban last month, a group of mostly Latina Democrats huddled at a nearby Mexican restaurant for a strategy session on galvanizing Latina voters over abortion rights.

headline: Why One Man Runs a Tree Service That Won’t Cut Down Dead Trees
abstract: Basil Camu is on a mission to save trees, even the dying ones. His unconventional approach: Let it be.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the costliest actions we take in managing our landscapes — in terms of dollars and environmental damage — and yet we keep cutting down and carting away the remains of trees. Even those that pose no danger to people or property.

headline: Watery, Peaceful, Wild: The Call of the Mangroves
abstract: On Curaçao, visitors can explore the trees’ habitat, where colorful birds roost on tangled branches and trunks, and small paths through the greenery beckon.
lead_paragraph: It was a sunny afternoon in February at the height of the high season on the Caribbean island of Curaçao, but my partner, Aaren, and I were far from lounging on a white-sand beach, snorkeling over a coral reef or strolling among the Easter-egg-colored buildings of Willemstad, Curaçao’s capital and a UNESCO World Heritage site — typical activities for travelers to this former Dutch colony.

headline: LaToya Ruby Frazier Is Paying It Forward
abstract: She may be America’s foremost social documentary photographer, now with a survey at the Museum of Modern Art. “All I’m doing is showing up as a vessel.”
lead_paragraph: A continuous high-pitched din — a bit whirring, a bit crunching — echoed over the Bottom, the residential sliver of Braddock, Pa., nearest to the industrial plants and the Monongahela River. It rose, indistinguishably, from the steel mill — the Edgar Thomson Steel Works, opened by Andrew Carnegie in 1875 and still operating — and the adjacent air separation plant, where gasses are piped into the mill or liquefied for shipment.

headline: Artificially Intelligent Help for Planning Your Summer Vacation
abstract: Travel-focused A.I. bots and more eco-friendly transportation options in online maps and search tools can help you quickly organize your seasonal getaway.
lead_paragraph: The summer travel season starts in just a few weeks, but if you are looking for software that goes beyond simply booking flights and hotels, you’re in luck. Search engines enhanced by artificial intelligence can help with your research and outline full itineraries. Certain older apps have recently been updated to suggest more eco-friendly travel options. And keeping it all organized on your phone is easier than ever. Here’s an overview.

headline: ‘Time of the Heathen’: Postwar Life and Death, an American Tale
abstract: Newly excavated and restored, Peter Kass’s 1961 movie, full of trippy distortions and grim associations, gets its first New York run at Film at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Peter Kass’s “Time of the Heathen” is as much artifact as artwork. Symptomatizing both Cold War angst and the birth pangs of the New American Cinema, the movie premiered in late 1961 at the influential film society Cinema 16, where it received mixed reviews and dropped from sight.

headline: A NY1 Anchorman Bows Out
abstract: Lewis Dodley said he had decided to retire from the local TV station while “I still have tread on my tires.” He has been there nearly 32 years.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out what the longtime NY1 anchor Lewis Dodley plans to do when he retires at the end of the month.

headline: Dan Stevens and the Allure of Kooky Characters
abstract: Despite his “Downton Abbey” roots, the co-star of “Godzilla x Kong” and “Abigail” likes the kind of role “that makes the filmmaker smile.”
lead_paragraph: The kookiest characters onscreen this season may be the ones played by Dan Stevens.

headline: Stinky Feet? Here’s How to Quell the Smell.
abstract: A mix of bacteria and sweat are likely to blame, experts say. But small changes can go a long way in reducing odors.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live with someone who has really smelly feet. Why does this happen and what can they do about it?

headline: Afraid of Cicadas? This Entomologist Wants to Change That.
abstract: Sammy Ramsey casts the mass emergence of the big, red-eyed bugs as a love story, not an insect apocalypse.
lead_paragraph: Spring has sprung, and coming with it is a mass emergence of two broods of cicadas. After more than a decade underground, they will tunnel through the soil and up to the treetops to spend the remainder of their lives loudly buzzing for a mate.

headline: Uncovering What Audubon Missed, and What He Made Up
abstract: In “The Birds That Audubon Missed,” Kenn Kaufman delves into the fierce, at times unethical, competition among early American ornithologists.
lead_paragraph: By the time Kenn Kaufman finished the research for his upcoming book on early North American ornithology, his view of John James Audubon, history’s most famous birder and the central figure in his new work, had changed entirely — starting with whether Audubon was a fraud.

headline: Can a 50-Year-Old Idea Save Democracy?
abstract: The economist and philosopher Daniel Chandler thinks so. In “Free and Equal,” he makes a vigorous case for adopting the liberal political framework laid out by John Rawls in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: The American political theorist John Rawls may be known for abstractions like “the original position” and “the difference principle,” but any mention of his name puts me in mind of something decidedly more tangible: cake. Consider the potentially combustible situation of two children who have been given a cake to share between them. How do you ensure that the division of the cake is fair and will elicit the least complaint?

headline: R.F.K. Jr. Says Doctors Found a Dead Worm in His Brain
abstract: The presidential candidate has faced previously undisclosed health issues, including a parasite that he said ate part of his brain.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was experiencing memory loss and mental fogginess so severe that a friend grew concerned he might have a brain tumor. Mr. Kennedy said he consulted several of the country’s top neurologists, many of whom had either treated or spoken to his uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, before his death the previous year of brain cancer.

headline: He Knows It’s Important to Admit Mistakes. He’s Made Many.
abstract: In an age of judgmentalism, Glenn Loury holds himself to account.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Loury thought maybe the world — maybe he — had been wrong about Derek Chauvin, the police officer convicted of murdering George Floyd in 2020. Loury had watched a documentary, “The Fall of Minneapolis,” that had circulated largely on right-wing social media, arguing that Chauvin had been wrongly convicted, and found himself persuaded. Was it possible, he wondered, that Floyd had actually died of a drug overdose?

headline: An Abandoned School Becomes a Canvas for Art Galleries
abstract: Six galleries bought a 22-acre property in upstate New York that they are calling the Campus. Its first exhibition begins June 29.
lead_paragraph: In a spirit of cooperation, six midsize art galleries are extending their reach beyond Manhattan with the purchase of a sprawling abandoned school in Columbia County, N.Y., that will be inaugurated as a new exhibition platform called the Campus on June 29.

headline: $900,000 Homes in Illinois, North Carolina and Arizona
abstract: A Frank Lloyd Wright house in Wilmette, an 1897 Italianate home in Wilmington and a renovated midcentury house in Scottsdale.
lead_paragraph: This house is one of Wright’s American System-Built Homes, his effort at affordable housing using precut pieces assembled inexpensively on site. It is a few blocks from a section of Leahy Park with a playground and a municipal golf course. The center of Wilmette and Gillson Beach, on Lake Michigan, are about a mile away.

headline: Second Democrat Emerges to Challenge Mayor Adams’s Path to Re-election
abstract: Zellnor Myrie, a left-leaning state senator from Brooklyn, is moving to run against Mayor Eric Adams in the Democratic primary next June.
lead_paragraph: Zellnor Myrie, an Afro-Latino state senator from Brooklyn known for backing progressive causes, announced on Wednesday that he is moving to challenge Mayor Eric Adams in next year’s Democratic primary in New York City.

headline: Up, Up and Not OK: Letting Go of Balloons Could Soon Be Illegal in Florida
abstract: In an effort to curb microplastics and marine pollution, state lawmakers voted to ban intentional releases.
lead_paragraph: Balloons released in the sky don’t go to heaven. They often end up in oceans and waterways, where they’re 32 times more likely to kill seabirds than other types of plastic debris. Despite this, humans like to release them en masse, be it to celebrate a loved one’s life or a wedding, or to reveal the gender of a baby.

headline: 4 Takeaways as School Leaders Battle Charges of Tolerating Antisemitism
abstract: At a hearing in Congress, public school leaders from New York, California and Maryland forcefully buffed Republican attacks, drawing a contrast with university presidents.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans largely failed to land damaging blows on Wednesday as they questioned public school leaders from three politically liberal parts of the country, accusing them of “turning a blind eye” to an alarming rise in antisemitism in classrooms since the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel.

headline: Can Conservative and Liberal Catholics Coexist?
abstract: A more traditionalist future for the church won’t do away with liberal impulses.
lead_paragraph: Before Pope Francis was elected, conservative Catholics had fallen into a habit of dismissing the more liberal form of Catholicism as an old and faded thing, a vision of the future that belonged to the church’s past, a relic of the 1970s that had little purchase among younger Catholics seriously practicing their faith.

headline: Dua Lipa’s New Album Is Nonstop Ear Candy
abstract: Our music critic reviews “Radical Optimism.”
lead_paragraph: Dua Lipa just released her third studio album, “Radical Optimism.” While Lipa’s earlier releases sometimes tackled powerlessness and sexism, this one sticks entirely to romance.

headline: Why Biden and Harris Are So Busy on Wednesdays, When Trump Isn’t in Court
abstract: The president and vice president have been keeping up a busy schedule in the middle of each week, just as Donald Trump takes a break from his trial in New York.
lead_paragraph: It’s Wednesday, so President Biden will be on the road.

headline: Why Having Kennedy on the Ballot in Texas May Worry Ted Cruz
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who expects to be on the ballot in Texas, could prove to be a wild card in the U.S. Senate race, which Ted Cruz had appeared likely to win.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the independent presidential candidate, is on track to submit enough signatures to get on the ballot in Texas, potentially setting the stage for a three-way contest in the nation’s second most populous state.

headline: What Amazes You Most About Animals?
abstract: Cheetahs can reach speeds of 58 m.p.h. or more. Bats use echolocation to fly in the dark. What do you find extraordinary about animals?
lead_paragraph: Cheetahs are the fastest animals on land; they can also stop and start with extraordinary agility. Dogs are really good at reading our emotions, and they have a keen sense of smell. Bats can produce echolocation calls at a rapid rate — up to 190 calls per second — to help them fly in the dark. And whales can communicate over thousands of miles using complex vocalizations.

headline: Why the Campus Protests Are So Troubling
abstract: I don’t think the protests are antisemitic. But they undercut the only fair and just solution to the war.
lead_paragraph: Readers have been asking me, and I have been asking myself of late, how I feel about the campus demonstrations to stop the war in Gaza. Anyone reading this column since Oct. 7 knows that my focus has been on events on the ground in the Middle East, but this phenomenon has become too big to ignore. In short: I find the whole thing very troubling, because the dominant messages from the loudest voices and many placards reject important truths about how this latest Gaza war started and what will be required to bring it to a fair and sustainable conclusion.
