abstract: Shrimp pasta and dumpling salad for warm evenings; potato soup and sheet-pan sausages for gray days.
lead_paragraph: Here in the northeast, the weather has been all over the place: sunny and summery one day, chilly and bleak the next. This makes a couple of things difficult. First, convincing my tween that she needs a jacket on a 50-degree day when she wore shorts the day before, and second, planning meals in advance.

headline: Podcasters as TV Heroes? We’re All Ears
abstract: Why have podcasters emerged as the rumpled protagonists of numerous television shows? We’ll discuss after the break.
lead_paragraph: Gilbert Power, a public radio veteran and the host of the podcast “On Record,” went to a small town in Ireland to make a show about a 20-year-old missing-persons case. The podcast, he explained, was meant to be “a bit of fun, something to listen to on your drive home. I didn’t understand then how much power a story actually has. But stories can change us.”

headline: Summer 2023 Was the Northern Hemisphere’s Hottest in 2,000 Years, Study Finds
abstract: Scientists used tree rings to compare last year’s extreme heat with temperatures over the past two millenniums.
lead_paragraph: The summer of 2023 was exceptionally hot. Scientists have already established that it was the warmest Northern Hemisphere summer since around 1850, when people started systematically measuring and recording temperatures.

headline: Trump Prosecutors Have Leaned In to Questions on Cohen’s Credibility
abstract: Witnesses called by the prosecution in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial have given their unvarnished views on Michael D. Cohen, the case’s star witness.
lead_paragraph: In the first few weeks of the criminal trial of Donald J. Trump, witnesses have cast Michael D. Cohen as a bully, a nervous wreck and, as one witness put it, a “jerk.”

headline: Pickup Driver Arrested After Crash With Migrant Worker Bus in Florida Kills 8
abstract: The driver of the pickup truck was charged with D.U.I. manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: At least eight people were killed and dozens of others were injured on Tuesday after a bus carrying migrant farm workers in Central Florida collided with a pickup truck driven by a man under the influence, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Pressure’: The ‘Mean Streets’ of Brixton
abstract: Newly restored, Horace Ové’s film about a Trinidadian family in London makes a triumphant return to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: The title “Pressure” suggests the force with which this first feature by the Trinidadian British director Horace Ové struck the conscience of a country. The movie, which premiered at the 1975 London Film Festival, was praised by critics and then shelved for three years. Apparently, its producer, the British Film Institute, deemed the public unready for Ové’s blunt depiction of the police violence and racial animus directed at London’s West Indian residents in Brixton.

headline: Zendaya for $200? ‘Jeopardy!’ Plans to Stream a Pop Culture Spinoff
abstract: Sony Pictures Television said that “Pop Culture Jeopardy!” — which will pit teams of three against one another — would be streamed on Prime Video.
lead_paragraph: “Jeopardy!” has long been ruled primarily by broadcast TV. As a staid, reliable quiz show that had the same host for 36 years, viewers have grown to depend on it at a certain time, on a certain channel.

headline: A Top Chef Winner Finds a New Italian Perch
abstract: Harold Dieterle, the winner of the first season of “Top Chef,” is opening Il Totano in the West Village, Marsanne NYC serves Mediterranean food in a 150-seat space and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: With Harold Dieterle as the executive chef and a partner, Alexandra Shapiro, and her parents, Laura and Robert, have transformed their former Flex Mussels in the West Village into this Italian spot. They had reopened Hoexter’s on the Upper East Side late last year. Mr. Dieterle — formerly of Kin Shop and Perilla, and the winner of the first season of “Top Chef” — has southern Italian roots, as does his chef de cuisine, Steven Lopin. Il Totano will serve crudos, grilled shrimp with pepperoncini butter, bucatini con le Sarde, pork cotaletta, roast chicken Marsala and a baby calamari salad. The room — done in blues, mustard and rust — has seaside touches. (Friday)

headline: Fed Chair’s Confidence in Slowing Inflation Is ‘Not as High’ as Before
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said the central bank was poised to leave interest rates on hold after surprisingly stubborn inflation.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, reiterated Tuesday that policymakers were poised to hold interest rates steady at a high level as they waited for evidence that inflation is slowing further.

headline: A.I.’s ‘Her’ Era Has Arrived
abstract: New chatbot technology can talk, laugh and sing like a human. What comes next is anyone’s guess.
lead_paragraph: A lifelike artificial intelligence with a smooth, alluring voice enchants and impresses its human users — flirting, telling jokes, fulfilling their desires and eventually winning them over.

headline: After Living Much of Life at Sea, Captain Sandy Finds Love on Land
abstract: Sandy Yawn of “Below Deck Mediterranean” married Leah Shafer on — what else? — a superyacht in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Sandra Dolores Yawn has been locked up, left for dead on a Florida highway and chased through the Red Sea by pirates.

headline: Ethical Lapses in the Medical Profession
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay by a doctor calling for changes in the medical culture. Also: Columbia donors; a Florida bookstore; a balloon release ban.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Alice Munro, Nobel Laureate and Master of the Short Story, Dies at 92
abstract: Her stories were widely considered to be without equal, a mixture of ordinary people and extraordinary themes.
lead_paragraph: Alice Munro, the revered Canadian author who started writing short stories because she did not think she had the time or the talent to master novels, then stubbornly dedicated her long career to churning out psychologically dense stories that dazzled the literary world and earned her the Nobel Prize in Literature, died on Monday night in Port Hope, Ontario, east of Toronto. She was 92.

headline: Alice Munro, a Literary Alchemist Who Made Great Fiction From Humble Lives
abstract: The Nobel Prize-winning author specialized in exacting short stories that were novelistic in scope, spanning decades with intimacy and precision.
lead_paragraph: The first story in her first book evoked her father’s life. The last story in her last book evoked her mother’s death. In between, across 14 collections and more than 40 years, Alice Munro showed us in one dazzling short story after another that the humble facts of a single person’s experience, subjected to the alchemy of language and imagination and psychological insight, could provide the raw material for great literature.

headline: Betty Buckley Is Not Wedded to the Same Old Songs
abstract: The actress is back in concert mode at 76, and doing new material. She’s also looking forward to a bold new take on “Sunset Boulevard.”
lead_paragraph: On her 35-acre ranch in Texas, the actor-singer Betty Buckley has been dreaming of playing a Western heroine at last — ideally in something by Taylor Sheridan, the “Yellowstone” creator, who shoots nearby.

headline: U.S. to Stop Buying Russian Uranium, Cutting Cash to Moscow
abstract: A new law accelerates the weaning of U.S. electric utilities from using Russian enriched uranium to power America’s nuclear plants.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed a bill into law on Monday night banning the import of uranium enriched in Russia. Russia controls nearly half the world’s enrichment capacity, and American electric utilities have been spending around $1 billion per year on the fuel to run their reactors.

headline: Orcas Sink Another Boat Near Iberia, Worrying Sailors Before Summer
abstract: Two people were rescued on Sunday after orcas damaged their boat near the Strait of Gibraltar, where the animals have caused havoc in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Summer is on the way, meaning that the orcas are out to play near the Strait of Gibraltar — which is bad news for sailors.

headline: Cannes: Greta Gerwig, Lily Gladstone and the Weight of Politics at the Fest
abstract: The festival opened with questions for the jury about Indigenous representation, #MeToo rumors and other timely topics.
lead_paragraph: Early on in the meta French comedy “The Second Act,” which was opening the 77th edition of the Cannes Film Festival on Tuesday night, a father (Vincent Lindon) and daughter (Léa Seydoux) are sitting in his car and chatting about her boyfriend. But just a few lines into the scene, Lindon cracks and refuses to perform it.

headline: New York Announces $95 Million Revitalization of Port in Red Hook
abstract: New York City plans to rebuild three piers and add a new cargo crane after taking control of more than 100 acres of the Brooklyn waterfront.
lead_paragraph: The Red Hook section of Brooklyn was once home to one of the busiest ports in the United States. But over the years, it was eclipsed by the container terminals that sprouted on the New Jersey side of the harbor.

headline: House Speaker Joins Republicans Visiting Trial to Say What Trump Can’t
abstract: Outside the Manhattan courthouse where Donald J. Trump is being tried on criminal charges, Mike Johnson attacked a key witness who linked the former president to a plan to cover up hush money paid to a porn star.
lead_paragraph: As a key witness testified inside the Manhattan criminal courthouse on Tuesday morning, an increasingly familiar scene unfolded outside, as another in a parade of well-known visitors — this time Mike Johnson, the speaker of the House — stepped up to a microphone.

headline: How Many of Gaza’s Dead Are Women and Children? For 10,000, the Data Is Incomplete.
abstract: The U.N. has begun citing a much lower death toll for women and children in Israel’s military offensive, acknowledging that it has incomplete information about many of those killed.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations has begun citing a much lower death toll for women and children in Gaza, acknowledging that it has incomplete information about many of the people killed during Israel’s military offensive in the territory.

headline: After Ill-Advised Shortcut, 2 Horses Are Rescued in a 5-Hour Mission
abstract: Nearly 50 people were needed to get the horses, Damascus and Beau, out of a swampy area and over a makeshift bridge during the rescue in Lebanon, Conn.
lead_paragraph: It took five hours, nearly 50 people and a makeshift bridge of ropes and logs, but a complex rescue effort in Connecticut this weekend successfully freed two horses, Damascus and Beau, after they became stuck in a swampy mess.

headline: Russia Detains Senior General, Widening Military Purge
abstract: Lt. Gen. Yuri Kuznetsov became the second senior defense official to be detained on an accusation of corruption in the past month.
lead_paragraph: Russian security agents detained a senior general early Tuesday, widening a purge of the country’s sprawling Defense Ministry amid President Vladimir V. Putin’s broader shake-up of his government.

headline: Hades II’s Eternal Pursuit of a Tantalizing Past
abstract: The video game sequel’s central character struggles to exhume the memory of her former life. Out of the pandemic, our futures are just as murky.
lead_paragraph: Hades was officially released in late 2020, during the heights of the coronavirus pandemic. An endlessly replayable spin on Greek mythology, it came out to mass death, to fear, to a society trapped inside, avoiding neighbors and loved ones alike.

headline: ‘Don’t Flip, Don’t Speak’: How a Lawyer Became Cohen’s Back Channel to Trump
abstract: Robert J. Costello relayed messages to Michael D. Cohen telling him not to flip, Mr. Cohen said. But a web of alliances fell apart over unpaid bills.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors introduced a new name at Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial on Tuesday: Robert J. Costello.

headline: German Court Fines Far-Right Leader for Using Nazi Phrase
abstract: Björn Höcke, a state leader of the nationalist Alternative for Germany party, used the phrase “Everything for Germany,” a slogan of the Nazi paramilitary wing, during a campaign stop.
lead_paragraph: A German court on Tuesday found a prominent far-right politician from the Alternative for Germany party guilty of using a banned Nazi slogan during a campaign speech in 2021.

headline: Daniel Kramer, Who Photographed Bob Dylan’s Rise, Dies at 91
abstract: For 366 days, he captured intimate images of the singer-songwriter as he changed the look and sound of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Kramer, a photojournalist who captured Bob Dylan’s era-tilting transformation from acoustic guitar-strumming folky to electric prince of rock in the mid-1960s, and who shot the covers for his landmark albums “Bringing It All Back Home” and “Highway 61 Revisited,” died on April 29 in Melville, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 91.

headline: How the Pandemic Reshaped American Gun Violence
abstract: The footprint of gun violence in the U.S. has expanded, as shootings worsened in already suffering neighborhoods and killings spread to new places during the pandemic years.
lead_paragraph: The footprint of gun violence in the U.S. has expanded, as shootings worsened in already suffering neighborhoods and killings spread to new places during the pandemic years.

headline: Daniel Kramer’s Year With Bob Dylan
abstract: An intimate portrait of a music star on the rise in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: For six months in 1964, the photojournalist Daniel Kramer, who died at 91 on April 29, dialed the office of Bob Dylan’s manager, Albert Grossman, to ask if he could photograph Mr. Dylan, a rising star at the time. Finally, Mr. Grossman said yes.

headline: How Has Gun Violence Changed in Your Neighborhood?
abstract: The footprint of gun violence in the U.S. expanded during the pandemic. Use these maps to compare data on gun homicides in your area with others around the country.
lead_paragraph: The footprint of gun violence in the U.S. expanded during the pandemic. Use these maps to compare data on gun homicides in your area with others around the country.

headline: Google Takes the Next Step in Its A.I. Evolution
abstract: The tech giant showed off how it would enmesh A.I. more deeply into its products and users’ lives, from search to so-called agents that perform tasks.
lead_paragraph: Last May, Sundar Pichai, Google’s chief executive, said the company would use artificial intelligence to reimagine all of its products.

headline: Appeals Court Upholds Gag Order on Trump in Manhattan Trial
abstract: The judges found that Justice Juan M. Merchan’s rules had not violated the former president’s First Amendment rights. Justice Merchan had issued the gag order to protect the trial’s integrity.
lead_paragraph: A New York State appeals court on Tuesday upheld a gag order imposed on former President Donald J. Trump in his criminal trial in Manhattan, rejecting arguments that the measure had violated Mr. Trump’s First Amendment rights.

headline: The Best of Cass Elliot
abstract: Hear her extraordinary range in 10 tracks.
lead_paragraph: First of all, I’d like to thank the guest playlisters who filled in for me last week, Caryn Ganz and Ben Sisario. Caryn paid tribute to Madonna’s Celebration Tour (she’s seen it live seven times, which officially makes her an expert) and Ben supplemented his great profile of Mdou Moctar with a thorough primer on African guitar greats. That’s what I call something for everyone.

headline: Meeting Yourself Where You’re At
abstract: Whether you’re still in school, looking for a job or already working, we have some tips for you.
lead_paragraph: We want to meet you wherever you are.

headline: U.K. Summons Chinese Ambassador for Reprimand as Tensions Rise
abstract: Britain’s foreign office said it had reprimanded the Chinese ambassador, a day after three men were charged with assisting the Hong Kong intelligence service.
lead_paragraph: The day after U.K. police charged three men with assisting Hong Kong’s intelligence service, China’s ambassador to Britain was summoned for an official reprimand by the British foreign ministry in the latest sign of growing tension between London and Beijing.

headline: Can Google Give A.I. Answers Without Breaking the Web?
abstract: Publishers have long worried that artificial intelligence would drive readers away from their sites. They’re about to find out if those fears are warranted.
lead_paragraph: For the past year and a half since ChatGPT was released, a scary question has hovered over the heads of major online publishers: What if Google decides to overhaul its core search engine to feature generative artificial intelligence more prominently — and breaks our business in the process?

headline: The Prosecution’s Case Is Wrapping Up in Trump’s Trial. What Happens Next?
abstract: The prosecution is nearing its end. Then, defense lawyers will get their chance to poke holes in the case before the question is put in jurors’ hands.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney’s office will soon conclude its case against Donald J. Trump, after having questioned 19 witnesses in an effort to prove that the former president committed 34 felonies. For now, Michael D. Cohen, Mr. Trump’s one-time lawyer and fixer who is being cross-examined, will be the last witness of the prosecution's case.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘God, You Can Kiss’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: We kissed just once, standing by my living room windows on the 21st floor. A deep, full-throated kiss that shot electric waves through me. “God, you can kiss,” I murmured. “Men who kiss men learn that.” For a brief moment, we were in love. Then, his hands resting on my shoulders, he spoke. “You know it can’t work.” He wasn’t into women. “I know,” I replied. My friends thought we’d make a great couple. “We’re just friends,” I’d say; it was Texas, the ’80s. AIDS took Richard a few years later. But his kiss is still with me. — Michele LaNoue

headline: Under Fire for ‘Toxic’ Work Culture, Bank Regulator Apologizes Again
abstract: A scathing report revealed a culture of widespread sexual harassment and discrimination at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Martin Gruenberg will testify on Capitol Hill starting on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Just days after the release of a scathing report detailing a culture of widespread sexual harassment and discrimination at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, its chair, Martin Gruenberg, submitted congressional testimony on Tuesday that indicated he had no plans to step down.

headline: Preparing for the Second China Shock
abstract: Why the Biden administration is imposing new tariffs.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is an old-fashioned protectionist, and he has been suggesting for a while that if elected he will quickly impose tariffs of 10 percent or more on all imports — a “ring around the collar” for the U.S. economy.

headline: Blinken Tells Ukraine ‘You Are Not Alone’ as Russia’s Military Makes Gains
abstract: The Biden administration had warned for months that Congress’s delay in approving an aid package would leave the Ukrainians vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken sought to reassure Ukrainians on Tuesday that they could weather an ominous new Russian military offensive and count on long-term support from the United States and its European allies.

headline: Restaurant Review: ‘New Nordic’ Isn’t New, but ILIS Adds a Fresh Spin
abstract: Mads Refslund’s creative ideas at this Brooklyn restaurant can be dreamily seductive, even if the execution isn’t always as compelling.
lead_paragraph: The most talked-about dish at ILIS, the cavernous Brooklyn restaurant opened by the Danish-born chef Mads Refslund in October, has to be the clam flask. This is a drinking vessel made by opening a surf clam, removing the clam, resealing the halves of the shell and shearing off a bit of the top lip to create a small opening through which you sip the liquid inside.

headline: Read the N.T.S.B.’s Preliminary Report on the Baltimore Bridge Collapse
abstract: The 24-page report includes investigators’ initial findings into the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge after it was struck by a container ship.
lead_paragraph: The 24-page report includes investigators’ initial findings into the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge after it was struck by a container ship.

headline: Cohen Tells Jurors of Oval Office Deal to Pay Back the Hush Money
abstract: Michael D. Cohen’s story of an arrangement struck in the White House with Donald Trump was the only personal account tying the former president to falsified documents.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush-money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Ship That Hit Baltimore Bridge Had 2 Electrical Failures Before Departure
abstract: A report from the National Transportation Safety Board said crew members had adjusted the electrical configuration of the ship even before it left port.
lead_paragraph: In the hours before a wayward cargo ship lost electrical power and knocked down Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge, killing six people, the vessel suffered two blackouts while still in port, according to a preliminary report released on Tuesday.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Michael Cohen Faced Donald Trump’s Lawyers
abstract: Also, Antony Blinken visited Kyiv and President Biden announced new Chinese tariffs.
lead_paragraph: The testimony from Michael Cohen, Donald Trump’s former fixer, is a linchpin in the Manhattan case against the former president. Here’s the latest.

headline: Covering the Other Manhattan Trial
abstract: Tracey Tully’s reporting domain is New Jersey. But for the next six weeks, she’ll journey across the Hudson River to report on the federal corruption trial of Senator Robert Menendez.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the bribery trial of Senator Robert Menendez.

headline: Todd Blanche, Who Gambled Gilded Career to Represent Trump, Gets Shot at Cohen
abstract: This case is Mr. Blanche’s second criminal trial as a defense lawyer. He seemed to struggle to land a “gotcha” moment on Tuesday while grilling Michael D. Cohen about a dizzying variety of interactions spanning years.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s defense lawyer had waited a day and a half for this moment, to rise and begin the cross-examination of the prosecution’s star witness. Right out of the gate, he tried to set the tone for how the proceedings would unfold.

headline: Mike Pence Sought Public Funds as 2024 Presidential Bid Collapsed
abstract: The former vice president found little traction in his campaign and still had more than $1.3 million in unpaid bills at the end of March.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence sought public financing for his failed presidential primary campaign, a highly unusual move that if successful would make him the first Republican in more than a decade to receive such funds, according to Federal Election Commission documents that have not previously been disclosed.

headline: Bumble to Users: You Need Sex. Users to Bumble: Get Lost.
abstract: A new advertising campaign from the dating app set off a firestorm of criticism, prompting the company to apologize.
lead_paragraph: When the dating app Bumble received backlash over the weekend for an ad campaign telling women that “a vow of celibacy is not the answer,” the anger came as no surprise.

headline: In Kyiv, Blinken Adds Rock Notes to a ‘Free World’ Message
abstract: The secretary of state, a longtime guitarist, strummed along to a song chosen to underscore a central message of President Biden’s foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a somber day in the Ukrainian capital, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken slipped into a seat at Barman Dictat, a crowded basement cocktail bar where a punk-jazz band was squealing away.

headline: There is more to Westminster than the beauty contest.
abstract: Everyone is familiar with best in show, but the Masters Agility Championship over the weekend is action-packed.
lead_paragraph: The best in show competition, essentially a doggie beauty pageant, is the culmination of a multiday canine extravaganza here at Westminster. But it follows the possibly more fun portion of the program, the agility competition.

headline: Cohen Day 2: It’s Trump’s Lawyers’ Turn
abstract: The one-time fixer faced a furious pushback from the defense.
lead_paragraph: It was — and remains — the ultimate litmus test for anyone in the orbit of Donald Trump: Are you loyal, or not?

headline: Blinken Plays ‘Rockin’ in the Free World’ for Ukraine Soldiers
abstract: During a visit to Kyiv, Secretary of State Antony Blinken played Neil Young’s “Rockin’ in the Free World” with a local band at a bar in a show of support for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: During a visit to Kyiv, Secretary of State Antony Blinken played Neil Young’s “Rockin’ in the Free World” with a local band at a bar in a show of support for Ukraine.

headline: TikTok Creators Sue to Block U.S. Law Requiring Sale or Ban
abstract: The group, whose legal fees are being paid for by the company, said a ban of the app would violate their First Amendment rights.
lead_paragraph: A group of TikTok creators, including a rancher, a skin care entrepreneur and a promoter of biblical literacy, sued the federal government on Tuesday over a new law that would force the app’s Chinese owner, ByteDance, to sell the company or face a ban in the United States. They said it violated their First Amendment rights.

headline: Trump’s Defense Cast Michael Cohen as Untrustworthy
abstract: Also, Biden increased tariffs on Chinese imports. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Todd Blanche, the lead lawyer defending Donald Trump in his New York criminal trial, wasted no time today before aggressively questioning the prosecution’s star witness, Michael Cohen. He opened his cross-examination by pressing Cohen on whether he had described Blanche on social media as a “crying little shit.”

headline: ‘The Secret Is Out’: Joan Vassos Is the First ‘Golden Bachelorette’
abstract: ABC introduced a new season of the spinoff, after the ratings success of “The Golden Bachelor.”
lead_paragraph: It has only been a month since the storybook ending of “The Golden Bachelor,” ABC’s buzzy spinoff of “The Bachelor,” featuring cast members 60 and up, got a divorce-announcement epilogue.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: Red-Carpet Roundup
abstract: The best fashion from an event with a lot of photo ops.
lead_paragraph: Jane Birkin pairing her beaded dress with a basket. Madonna in a Jean-Paul Gaultier cone bra and a garter set. Kristen Stewart barefoot in Chanel chain mail. Spike Lee in a sunset-inspired suit.

headline: Anti-Abortion Activist Who Led Blockade of Clinic Gets Nearly 5 Years in Prison
abstract: Lauren Handy, who drew widespread attention after human fetal remains were found at her home, was sentenced to 57 months in prison for her role in a 2020 blockade of a reproductive health clinic.
lead_paragraph: An anti-abortion activist who led a blockade of a reproductive health clinic in Washington, D.C., in 2020 and drew widespread attention after the authorities found human fetuses at her home was sentenced on Tuesday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: Cohen on Cross: 5 Takeaways From Trump’s Criminal Trial
abstract: The key prosecution witness faced defense lawyers as the trial nears what may be an unexpectedly early conclusion.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush-money trial in Manhattan.

headline: What a ‘Free Palestine’ Means in Practice
abstract: Rather than the utopia envisioned by protesters, it would be an Islamist state that persecuted Jews and denied anyone real freedom.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that the campus protesters got their wish tomorrow: Not just “Cease-fire Now” in Gaza, but the creation of a “Free Palestine.” How free would that future Palestine be?

headline: Fossil Catches Starfish Cousin in the Act of Cloning Itself
abstract: The brittle star specimen suggests that the sea creatures have been splitting themselves in two to reproduce for more than 150 million years.
lead_paragraph: Some brittle stars give an arm and a leg (and still another appendage) to reproduce. When mates are scarce, these starfish-like sea creatures split themselves in half. Each side then regrows its missing half, creating two identical clones of the original animal.

headline: OpenAI’s Chief Scientist and Co-Founder Is Leaving the Company
abstract: In November, Ilya Sutskever joined three other OpenAI board members to force out Sam Altman, the chief executive, before saying he regretted the move.
lead_paragraph: Ilya Sutskever, the OpenAI co-founder and chief scientist who in November joined three other board members to force out Sam Altman, the company’s high-profile chief executive, before saying he regretted the move, is leaving the San Francisco A.I. company.

headline: Review: A Text-to-Speech Meet-Cute in ‘All of Me’
abstract: Laura Winters’s romantic comedy pays careful attention to the dynamics of living with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: Lucy has impeccable comic timing and a sense of humor as dry as a gin martini. Her expression deadpan but for a slightly furrowed brow, she delivers punchlines with Amazon Prime efficiency in a calm, even tone that may sound familiar to people who use Alexa or ride the New York City subway.

headline: Former Nickelodeon Star Says Dan Schneider ‘Preyed’ on Her as Boss
abstract: Lori Beth Denberg, who appeared on “All That,” told Business Insider that he showed her porn multiple times and fondled her once. He says her claims are “exaggerated” and “in most cases, false.”
lead_paragraph: Lori Beth Denberg, who starred in the hit children’s television show “All That” in the 1990s, has accused her former Nickelodeon boss, Dan Schneider, of having “preyed” on her then by showing her pornography, once fondling her and another time initiating phone sex.

headline: Wall Street Big Wigs Raise $68.5 Million to Fight Poverty
abstract: The Robin Hood Foundation, an antipoverty organization in New York City, threw a “Matrix”-inspired gala.
lead_paragraph: On the second Monday in May, the Empire State Building flickered Robin Hood green, for a night when some of New York City’s deepest pockets gathered for a charitable cause.

headline: Jim Justice Wins West Virginia’s Republican Senate Primary
abstract: The governor is now positioned to win the seat being vacated by Senator Joe Manchin III, a Democrat, and flip it to the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: Jim Justice, the second-term governor of West Virginia, won the Republican primary for Senate on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, positioning him to win the seat being vacated by Senator Joe Manchin III, a Democrat, and flip it to the G.O.P.

headline: Larry Hogan, Maryland’s Former Governor, Wins G.O.P. Senate Primary
abstract: Mr. Hogan’s popularity in the deep-blue state sets up an uncommonly competitive general election contest.
lead_paragraph: Larry Hogan, the popular former governor of Maryland, cruised to an easy victory in the Republican Senate primary on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, setting up an uncommonly competitive general election contest in the deep-blue state.

headline: Senators Push for Secret Service to Move Protests Away From G.O.P. Convention
abstract: In a meeting brokered by Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, Senate Republicans argued that a planned protest zone was too close to the convention site.
lead_paragraph: The director of the Secret Service met on Tuesday with Senate Republicans to discuss the party’s effort to push the expected protesters farther from the site of the Republican National Convention, set for July in Milwaukee.

headline: King Charles III Unveils First Official Painted Portrait Since Coronation
abstract: The king, who was diagnosed with cancer in February but has since returned to public duties, unveiled the striking painting by Jonathan Yeo at Buckingham Palace on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: King Charles III on Tuesday unveiled the first official painted portrait of himself since his coronation just over a year ago — a striking oil painting in which he stares head-on against a backdrop of mottled red, pink and fuchsia hues.

headline: Singapore’s Riches Grew Under Its Leader. So Did Discontent.
abstract: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who is stepping down after nearly 20 years, oversaw astounding successes, but some Singaporeans want a different kind of politics.
lead_paragraph: Singapore was once known as an affluent and strait-laced city-state. Today, it’s a glitzy international destination. It has hosted Taylor Swift concerts and Formula One night races. And it is substantially richer, per capita, than the United States.

headline: Boeing Violated Settlement Over 737 Max Problems, Justice Dept. Says
abstract: The department said the company had failed to design and enforce a compliance and ethics program to prevent violation of U.S. fraud laws.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice said on Tuesday that Boeing was in violation of a 2021 settlement related to problems with the company’s 737 Max model that led to two deadly plane crashes in 2018 and 2019.

headline: House Republican Don Bacon Puts Down Right-Wing Challenge in a Biden District
abstract: The mainstream four-term congressman easily dispatched an opponent on his right, clearing the way for what is expected to be a difficult re-election race in a competitive district in Nebraska.
lead_paragraph: Representative Don Bacon of Nebraska, a mainstream Republican, on Tuesday easily fended off a primary challenge from a right-wing businessman, advancing to what is expected to be a tight re-election contest in a competitive district won by President Biden in 2020.

headline: Brewer’s Implement
abstract: MaryEllen Uthlaut’s crossword is worth celebrating.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Angela Alsobrooks Defeats David Trone in Maryland Democratic Senate Primary
abstract: The Prince George’s County executive will now face Larry Hogan, the popular former two-term governor, in a race that could determine which party controls the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Angela Alsobrooks, the Prince George’s County executive, won the Democratic primary for Maryland’s Senate seat on Tuesday, setting up a showdown with a popular Republican former governor that could determine control of the chamber.

headline: Angela Alsobrooks Wants to Be Maryland’s First Black Senator
abstract: If she wins this fall, Maryland’s newly chosen Democratic nominee for Senate would also become the sole woman in Maryland’s congressional delegation.
lead_paragraph: Angela Alsobrooks, Maryland’s newly chosen Democratic nominee for Senate, is familiar with firsts.

headline: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, May 13, 2024
abstract: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Sarah Elfreth, Maryland’s Youngest Female State Senator, Wins House Primary
abstract: Ms. Elfreth, 35, was victorious in a crowded Democratic field in a deep-blue district to succeed Representative John Sarbanes.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Elfreth, the youngest woman ever elected to Maryland’s State Senate, won a crowded Democratic primary race on Tuesday in Maryland’s Third Congressional District, according to The Associated Press.

headline: West Virginia’s Attorney General Wins the Republican Nod for Governor
abstract: In November, Patrick Morrisey will face Steve Williams, a Democrat and the mayor of Huntington. The winner will succeed Jim Justice, who is running for U.S. Senate.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Morrisey, the attorney general of West Virginia, won the Republican primary for governor on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, making him the likely next chief executive of the deeply Republican state.

headline: Quotation of the Day: How One Crack in the Line Opened a Path for Russians
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Every event you did not predict can turn your situation completely upside down. And this is what happened in Ocheretyne.”

headline: Michael Cohen Says Trump Discussed Reimbursement in Oval Office
abstract: Michael Cohen’s story of a hush-money arrangement struck in the White House was the only personal account tying Donald J. Trump to falsified documents. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cohen’s story of a hush-money arrangement struck in the White House was the only personal account tying Donald J. Trump to falsified documents. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.

headline: Corrections: May 15, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a new federal rule concerning the planning and funding of electrical grids misspelled the given name of one of the commissioners. She is Allison Clements, not Alison.

headline: Biden Administration Advances $1 Billion Arms Sale to Israel
abstract: The notification of the deal to Congress even as the president holds up the delivery of other weapons shows the fine line the administration is trying to walk with its longtime ally.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has told Congress that it intends to move forward with a plan for the United States to sell more than $1 billion in new weapons to Israel, according to three congressional aides familiar with the deal.

headline: Best in Show: Sage Beats Out an ‘Absolutely Glorious’ Lineup
abstract: A miniature poodle outlasted a favored giant schnauzer and a crowd-pleasing German shepherd to win the top prize at Westminster.
lead_paragraph: Sage, an extravagantly coifed miniature poodle with a certain winsome mystery about her, won the 148th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday night, prevailing over a tough field of competitors including a majestic German shepherd, a silken Afghan hound and a proud giant schnauzer.

headline: YouTube Blocks Access to Protest Anthem in Hong Kong
abstract: Responding to a court order, YouTube and its sister company, Google, will block viewers in the region from viewing videos of the song, “Glory to Hong Kong.”
lead_paragraph: YouTube said on Tuesday that it would comply with a court order to block users in Hong Kong from viewing a popular democracy anthem, raising concerns about free speech and highlighting the increasing fraught environment for tech companies operating in the Chinese territory.

headline: Despite a Hack, the Show Goes On at Christie’s
abstract: Although a cyberattack hobbled its website, the auction house held two major sales, totaling $115 million, on Tuesday night. One expert praised the evening’s “really respectable sales in a difficult environment.”
lead_paragraph: The salesroom at Christie’s was packed on Tuesday evening, as spectators rubbernecked to see if buyers would compete for multimillion-dollar artworks at an auction house still hobbled by a cyberattack.

headline: China Deploys Dozens of Ships to Block Philippine Protest Flotilla
abstract: Filipino civilians set sail in fishing boats to oppose China’s control of a shoal claimed by the Philippines. A formidable Chinese fleet awaited them.
lead_paragraph: China has sent dozens of coast guard and maritime militia vessels toward a disputed atoll in the South China Sea, a large show of force aimed at blocking a civilian protest flotilla from the Philippines, as tensions between the countries have flared.

headline: White House Worries Russia’s Momentum Is Changing Trajectory of Ukraine War
abstract: Multiple factors are helping Russia’s military advance, including a delay in American weaponry and Moscow’s technological innovations on the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: Just 18 months ago, White House and Pentagon officials debated whether Russia’s forces in Ukraine might collapse and be pushed out of the country entirely.

headline: Few Chinese Electric Cars Are Sold in U.S., but Industry Fears a Flood
abstract: Automakers in the United States and their supporters welcomed President Biden’s tariffs, saying they would protect domestic manufacturing and jobs from cheap Chinese vehicles.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s new tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles won’t have a huge immediate impact on American consumers or the car market because very few such cars are sold in the United States.

headline: Mapping Russia’s Sudden Push Across Ukrainian Lines
abstract: All of a sudden, Russian forces are making progress in many directions at once.
lead_paragraph: All of a sudden, Russian forces are making progress in many directions at once.

headline: Scandal Brought Reforms to Soccer. Its Leaders Are Rolling Them Back.
abstract: FIFA tried to put a corruption crisis behind by changing its rules and claiming its governance overhaul had the endorsement of the Justice Department. U.S. officials say that was never the case.
lead_paragraph: The 12-page report was intended to save soccer’s governing body, FIFA, in its moment of existential crisis.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Michael Cohen’s second day on the witness stand.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cohen, Donald Trump’s former fixer, returned to the stand yesterday to face lawyers for the Manhattan district attorney’s office, as well as Donald Trump’s legal team, in the case against the former president.

headline: Seeking History in Maryland, and Zombie Campaigns Linger: Primary Takeaways
abstract: Angela Alsobrooks would be the third Black woman elected to the Senate if she wins her Maryland race against Larry Hogan; Nikki Haley keeps racking up votes.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of voters in Maryland, West Virginia and Nebraska went to the polls on Tuesday, weighing in on primaries whose results pointed to a desire for moderation, achievement and diversity, and a rejection of the political power of money.

headline: John Barbata, Drummer With Marquee Bands, Is Dead at 79
abstract: He played with Jefferson Airplane and Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young. The first song he recorded with the Turtles was “Happy Together.”
lead_paragraph: John Barbata, who played drums with the Turtles, Jefferson Airplane and Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, but walked away from rock music at the height of his career, has died. He was 79.

headline: These 12 Women Voted for Trump in 2020. How Do They See Him Now?
abstract: In our latest focus group, these voters said Trump was fallible in any number of ways, but that’s not what they cared about most.
lead_paragraph: In our latest focus group, these voters said Trump was fallible in any number of ways, but that’s not what they cared about most.

headline: The West Doesn’t Understand How Much Russia Has Changed
abstract: Never before has it been so entwined with China.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin’s trip to Beijing this week, where he will meet with Xi Jinping and top Chinese officials, is another clear demonstration of the current closeness between Russia and China.

headline: Word of the Day: innate
abstract: This word has appeared in 107 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word innate has appeared in 107 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 26 in the book review “3 Ways to Unlock Your ‘Hidden Potential’” by Melinda Wenner Moyer:

headline: Jimmy Fallon Celebrates 10 Years of Hosting ‘The Tonight Show’
abstract: Fallon thanked his wife, his kids, “and, most of all, my lawyer, Michael Cohen.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: What to Do if You Are Threatened With Sextortion
abstract: It’s not a hopeless situation, experts said. Here are four practical steps to take.
lead_paragraph: The picture-taker hits send. The threats begin. Take a breath; there are things you can do.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘Chelsea’ Asked for Nude Pictures. Then the Sextortion Began.
abstract: Young men are being tricked into sending naked pictures to scammers pretending to be women — who then demand money. The consequences can be devastating.
lead_paragraph: The Instagram message popped up from a girl named Chelsea: “Howdy.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,061
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 339
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Antisemitism Accusations Against Staff Pose Dilemma for School Leaders
abstract: Republicans have pressed educators to fire employees who they say crossed lines. But school leaders say that legal, political and union considerations complicate matters.
lead_paragraph: Throughout a series of congressional hearings about what public schools and universities are doing to combat antisemitism, Republicans keep hammering school leaders on one question.

headline: Rafah Operation Pushes Gazans Into Areas With Scarce Aid and Medical Care
abstract: Conditions are getting still more arduous for Palestinians as Israel pushes into Rafah. A look at the newest conflict zone.
lead_paragraph: Conditions are getting still more arduous for Palestinians as Israel pushes into Rafah. A look at the newest conflict zone.

headline: Senators Propose $32 Billion in Annual A.I. Spending but Defer Regulation
abstract: Their plan is the culmination of a yearlong listening tour on the dangers of the new technology.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of senators released a long-awaited legislative plan for artificial intelligence on Wednesday, calling for billions in funding to propel American leadership in the technology while offering few details on regulations to address its risks.

headline: How to Build a Skin Care Routine for Adult Acne
abstract: An expert-approved guide to the most effective products and techniques for dealing with stubborn breakouts at home.
lead_paragraph: Why do we get acne well beyond our teenage years? The answer is complex. Myriad factors — including genetics, environment, stress levels, hormonal changes, medical conditions and diet — can lead to blemishes at any stage in life. Some of these triggers can send sebaceous glands, the tiny organs that lubricate your skin with oil, into overdrive, clogging your pores. That buildup of oil and dead skin can then become a breeding ground for acne-causing bacteria. While some variables aren’t always in our control, the best defense against adult acne is a consistent, strategic skin care routine. (A few other basic rules: Try to keep your hands away from your face as much as possible, use a clean towel after cleansing and wash your bed linens weekly.) Here, a simple regimen that aestheticians and dermatologists suggest for managing breakouts at home.

headline: Emma Seppälä Has Thoughts on How to Avoid Kneejerk Decisions
abstract: The psychologist studies how to recognize emotions and cope with them. She learned the hard way.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to your brain, who’s in charge: you, or the onslaught of incoming stimulation? In “Sovereign: Reclaim Your Freedom, Energy, and Power in a Time of Distraction, Uncertainty and Chaos,” Emma Seppälä, a psychologist with academic postings at Yale and Stanford, argues that modernity has forced the human brain into a highly reactive mode, effectively hijacking it with nonstop information and noise.

headline: How Americans Learned to Be Kinder to (Some) Animals
abstract: “Our Kindred Creatures” details the rise, and contradictions, of the animal welfare movement.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals moistened eyes with TV ads featuring the singer Sarah McLachlan. As her song “Angel” played in the background, viewers were confronted with a parade of despair: images of neglected and abused cats and dogs, some of them grievously injured. “Will you be an angel for a helpless animal?” McLachlan pleaded.

headline: Do Pimple Patches Work?
abstract: Not all patches — or pimples — are created equal.
lead_paragraph: In a video on TikTok, a woman sprays a clear solution onto a pair of tweezers as she prepares to peel off a small, circular bandage from the side of her nose. “I don’t know what this peel is going to look like,” she says, “but I’m pretty sure it’s going to be juicy.”

headline: The Old-Fashioned Library at the Heart of the A.I. Boom
abstract: OpenAI may be changing how the world interacts with language. But inside headquarters, there is a homage to the written word: a library.
lead_paragraph: The two-story library has Oriental rugs, shaded lamps dotting its desks and rows of hardbacks lining its walls. It is the architectural centerpiece of the offices of OpenAI, the start-up whose online chatbot, ChatGPT, showed the world that machines can instantly generate their own poetry and prose.

headline: Why Did the Hotel Chain Hire a Marine Biologist?
abstract: Megan Morikawa of the Iberostar Group is applying science — and scale — to eliminate food waste, save coral and collaborate across the travel industry to cut carbon.
lead_paragraph: Carbon neutrality, zero waste and serving seafood solely from responsible suppliers: Many boutique eco-tourism destinations — particularly those catering to small numbers of luxury travelers — can reach or come close to sustainability goals such as these, but what about a decades-old resort company operating 97 properties across 14 countries?

headline: A Case Against a Top New York Restaurant Could Lower Barriers to Unions
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board says the management at Lodi unlawfully fought a union drive. If the allegations are upheld, the board could force the company to bargain.
lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board has issued a complaint against the New York City restaurant group headed by the acclaimed chef Ignacio Mattos, saying that it engaged in illegal practices to dissuade workers from forming a union at Lodi, in Rockefeller Center.

headline: Emcee Squared: Joel Grey and Eddie Redmayne on ‘Cabaret’
abstract: When two actors who have played the Emcee several times finally met, they discussed fear, courage and Berlin’s bawdiest nightclub.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Redmayne had never seen “Cabaret” when, as a 15-year-old student at Eton, he was first cast as the Emcee, the indecorous impresario of the bawdy Berlin nightclub where the musical is set. So Redmayne did what anyone wondering about the character would do: He watched the 1972 film, and studied Joel Grey’s performance.

headline: Why We’re All Living in Matthew Barney’s Sticky, Slimy World
abstract: Five trends the artist has spawned, from men baring it all to waterfalls of ooze.
lead_paragraph: In May and June, Matthew Barney, the visionary artist behind the epic “Cremaster Cycle” film series (1994-2002) and “River of Fundament” (2014), will be showing his newest body of work, “Secondary,” at four galleries: Gladstone Gallery in New York; Sadie Coles HQ in London; Regen Projects in Los Angeles; and Galerie Max Hetzler in Paris.

headline: Sunny Yellow Bags for Summer
abstract: Bright carryalls and cross-bodies enliven any outfit.

headline: Why Is Car Insurance So Expensive?
abstract: Soaring premiums have become a prominent driver of inflation, and insurers say that more increases could be on the way. How did it get like this?
lead_paragraph: If your car broke down two years ago, it probably became a bigger problem than you bargained for.

headline: A.I. Program Aims to Break Barriers for Female Students
abstract: A new program, backed by Cornell Tech, M.I.T. and U.C.L.A., helps prepare lower-income, Latina and Black female computing majors for artificial intelligence careers.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 10 months, Chelsea Prudencio, a junior at Baruch College in Manhattan, got a crash course in artificial intelligence through a new program for lower-income, Latina and Black young women majoring in computing.

headline: A Modern Shakespeare Retelling Filled With Drugs, Sex and Trauma
abstract: Allen Bratton’s novel transforms the rise of Henry V into a contemporary story about a brash gay man grappling with abuse and guilt.
lead_paragraph: In Allen Bratton’s debut novel, “Henry Henry,” Shakespeare’s Henriad (the tetralogy of plays that, combined, trace the rise of Henry V) is given a modern queer makeover. In Bratton’s version, which is set in 2014, Prince Hal is now just “Hal Lancaster,” our young gay protagonist who is possessed of “nothing but a subsidiary title, an unignorable sense of his own pre-eminence and a daily terror of this pre-eminence going unnoticed by everyone in the world except his father.” Hal’s father, Henry, is the Duke of Lancaster only because the main line of inheritance ended when Henry’s cousin Richard, the intended heir, died of AIDS. Hal and his siblings have been both maintained and stunted (fiscally, socially and spiritually) by this (fiscal, social and spiritual) inheritance, and as the novel begins, their father’s decision to remarry threatens to upend their static existence.

headline: This Impressive Cake Has Many Layers
abstract: Strawberry cake, a Southern staple, is full of meaning.
lead_paragraph: In 1976, Johnny Cash released a song called “Strawberry Cake.” It was a bit of an outsider tune, not altogether popular. But to me, it falls well within the canon of simple yet great Americana storytelling.

headline: How Long Does Chicken Last in the Fridge? Your Meat Expiration Date Questions, Answered
abstract: Spoiler (no pun intended): It’s not as long as you think.
lead_paragraph: In the vexing moments when we stumble on an abandoned package of chicken thighs in the back of the fridge, we really have to consider two questions: Is it spoiled? And will it make us sick? They aren’t the same thing.

headline: 9 Tips to Stretch Your Food Budget
abstract: These expert hacks can help you lower your grocery bill.
lead_paragraph: There’s no getting around it: Food is expensive right now. It may be hard to stick to your budget, but there are many ways to be resourceful with what you have without feeling as though you have your head just above water. The tips below, from four budgeting experts, can help you maximize your food budget.

headline: What Congestion Pricing Would Mean for the Subways
abstract: Congestion pricing revenue would go to pay for infrastructure, like modernizing signals that date back to the 1930s, if the program survives legal challenges.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll take a closer look at the congestion pricing plan for Midtown and Lower Manhattan, which could become reality next month. We’ll also find out about New York City’s plan to revitalize the docks in Brooklyn.

headline: The Massacre America Forgot
abstract: In a new book, the historian Kim A. Wagner investigates the slaughter by U.S. troops of nearly 1,000 people in the Philippines in 1906 — an atrocity long overlooked in this country.
lead_paragraph: They are sites of atrocity so shameful that they have become a searing shorthand: Wounded Knee, where American troops murdered as many as 300 Lakota men, women and children in 1890; My Lai, where American troops murdered as many as 500 unarmed Vietnamese villagers in 1968.

headline: The Power of the ‘Planet of the Apes’
abstract: Why is this long-running film series so gripping and effective? Because it doesn’t monkey around.
lead_paragraph: When the very first “Planet of the Apes” movie opened in 1968, the movie critic at The Times, Renata Adler, found it unremarkable. “It is no good at all, but fun, at moments, to watch,” she wrote, deeming it an “anti-war film and a science-fiction liberal tract,” with the apes representing “militarism, fascism and police brutality.” It’s probably safe to say she wasn’t expecting it to become one of the longest-running science-fiction franchises in Hollywood history.

headline: 17% of Voters Blame Biden for the End of Roe
abstract: The mistaken belief, in a new poll, shows how even as abortion is mobilizing Democrats, confusion over the issue is also a challenge.
lead_paragraph: Nearly one in five voters in battleground states says that President Biden is responsible for ending the constitutional right to abortion, a new poll found, despite the fact that he supports abortion rights and that his opponent Donald J. Trump appointed three Supreme Court justices who made it possible to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: ‘A Calculating Killer or a Damsel in Distress?’: The Trial Transfixing Boston
abstract: Karen Read has been accused of murdering her boyfriend, Officer John O’Keefe. But her lawyers say she’s innocent, alleging a cover-up to hide the truth about his death.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Jan. 29, 2022, as a snowstorm raged, a 46-year-old Boston police officer, John O’Keefe, was discovered unresponsive outside the home of a fellow officer in Canton, Mass.

headline: How MSNBC’s Leftward Tilt Delivers Ratings, and Complications
abstract: NBC’s leaders have been forced to grapple with how to square its cable news network’s embrace of progressive politics with the company’s straight-news operation.
lead_paragraph: MSNBC placed a big bet on becoming comfort TV for liberals. Then it doubled down.

headline: Inside the Rent Inflation Measure That Economics Nerds Love to Hate
abstract: The Consumer Price Index inflation measure accounts for housing costs in a complicated way. There are reasons for it.
lead_paragraph: There’s a three-letter abbreviation that economists have started pronouncing with the energy of a four-letter word: “O.E.R.”

headline: First, He Conquered Paris. Now, a Japanese Chef Wants to Become a Brand.
abstract: Kei Kobayashi, who earned three Michelin stars in France, has come home to build an empire.
lead_paragraph: In cooking, timing is everything. So much so that if the chef Kei Kobayashi spots diners heading to the restroom as he sends a dish out from the kitchen, he stops them. Nature’s call can wait; his culinary offerings should be tasted at peak flavor.

headline: Press Pause on the Silicon Valley Hype Machine
abstract: A.I. is looking less like an all-powerful being and more like an unreliable intern.
lead_paragraph: It’s a little hard to believe that just over a year ago, a group of leading researchers asked for a six-month pause in the development of larger systems of artificial intelligence, fearing that the systems would become too powerful. “Should we risk loss of control of our civilization?” they asked.

headline: Liza Colón-Zayas, of ‘The Bear,’ on Loving Someone Who’s in the Fight of Their Life
abstract: Why it’s so hard to know what to say when the people we’re closest to need us most.
lead_paragraph: On the Emmy- and Peabody-winning series “The Bear,” Liza Colón-Zayas plays Tina Marrero, a cook at the Chicago restaurant at the center of the story. Tina and her fellow workers are in a constant struggle for the survival of their restaurant, and they fight just as fiercely with one another. Only at rare moments do we see them drop the tough exterior and show one another love or respect.

headline: $450,000 Homes in Kentucky, New Jersey and New York
abstract: A two-bedroom bungalow in Lexington, a 1925 home in Blairstown and a Colonial Revival house in Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Kenwick, a neighborhood less than two miles from downtown and a five-minute drive from the University of Kentucky. It is within walking distance of a coffee shop, several breweries and restaurants serving Italian food, Hawaiian barbecue and New American cuisine. Woodland Park, which has a playground, is 20 minutes away on foot. The Arboretum State Botanical Garden of Kentucky is a 10-minute drive.

headline: C.D.C. Director Mandy Cohen on Avian Flu and Public Mistrust
abstract: An interview with America’s top public health official about new challenges and the recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The editorial board and our colleagues in Times Opinion met on Monday with Dr. Mandy Cohen, who became the director for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention last year. Dr. Cohen was the top public health official in North Carolina during the Covid pandemic, winning praise for working with Gov. Roy Cooper to steer the state’s response without allowing it to become politicized.

headline: ‘The Seeds Had Been Planted. Trump Didn’t Do It Himself.’
abstract: Authoritarianism has moved from the periphery to the center, even the core, of global politics.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 30 years, authoritarianism has moved from the periphery to the center, even the core, of global politics, shaping not only the divide between left and right in the United States but also the conflict between the American-led alliance of democratic nations and the loose coalition of autocratic states including Russia, China, Iran and North Korea.

headline: Inflation Moderated Slightly in April, Offering Some Relief for Consumers
abstract: Prices rose 3.4 percent in April from a year earlier, a slight easing from the previous month and a positive sign for the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Finally, some good news on inflation.

headline: Trump’s O.G. Henchmen Would Like a Word With America
abstract: Voters are getting a fresh reminder of the ethics and integrity of Donald Trump’s original innermost circle.
lead_paragraph: Have you all noticed the Republican stars and wannabes showing up at Donald Trump’s trial? Speaker Mike Johnson; Senators J.D. Vance and Rick Scott; Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota; Texas’ attorney general, Ken Paxton; the professional irritant Vivek Ramaswamy … the G.O.P. is clearly eager to show it is standing by its man.

headline: What Is Your Favorite Word?
abstract: What word in any language feels especially beautiful, interesting or meaningful to you?
lead_paragraph: Are you someone who loves words? Do you delight in discovering new words or trying to translate them into different languages? Do you enjoy using slang or exploring how language has evolved over time?

headline: I Don’t Write Like Alice Munro, but I Want to Live Like Her
abstract: We are very different writers, but I have kept Alice Munro in mind, daily and for decades, as an example to follow.
lead_paragraph: It is common to say “I was heartbroken to hear” that so-and-so died, but I really do feel heartbroken having learned about Alice Munro, who died on Monday.

headline: What MAGA’s Beef With Lab-Grown Meat Says About the G.O.P.
abstract: Paul Krugman on how burgers became the focus of a conspiracy theory.
lead_paragraph: Governor Ron DeSantis of Florida recently signed a bill that bans both the production and the sale of lab-grown meat. In this audio essay, the columnist Paul Krugman argues that DeSantis’s actions represent a window into the modern Republican Party, a party in which “politics is about displaying what kind of person you are and what your allegiance is, as opposed to actually getting policies that work in place.”

headline: Explaining the Surprising Patterns of Fatal Shootings
abstract: We made a block-by-block interactive map of the U.S. to show how gun violence changed during the pandemic. Eli Murray, a graphics editor for The New York Times, gives some takeaways.
lead_paragraph: We made a block-by-block interactive map of the U.S. to show how gun violence changed during the pandemic. Eli Murray, a graphics editor for The New York Times, gives some takeaways.

headline: Putin Is Selling Victory, and Many Russians Are Buying It
abstract: Vladimir Putin’s message to his country appears to be taking hold: that Russia is fighting against the whole Western world — and winning.
lead_paragraph: The word “victory” is everywhere in Moscow these days.

headline: The Possible Collapse of the U.S. Home Insurance System
abstract: A Times investigation found climate change may now be a concern for every homeowner in the country.
lead_paragraph: Across the United States, more frequent extreme weather is starting to cause the home insurance market to buckle, even for those who have paid their premiums dutifully year after year.

headline: Russian War Advances Worry White House, and Mexico Buses Migrants South
abstract: Plus, the miniature poodle pulls it off.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Ethnic ‘Balancer’ for Government Jobs Becomes Focus of Ethnic Division
abstract: North Macedonia tries to ensure diversity — and keep the peace — with computer-generated state hiring quotas. Fraud and bloat have tainted that effort.
lead_paragraph: After drawing up a plan for 20 hires this year by the city administration, the head of the municipal personnel department plugged it into the Balancer — a website run by the government of the Balkan nation of North Macedonia.

headline: Mapping Gun Violence
abstract: The Times found that, by the end of last year, one in seven Americans lived within a quarter mile of a recent fatal shooting
lead_paragraph: As Covid swept the United States, another epidemic took hold: Americans shot one another at the fastest pace since the 1990s.

headline: Interpol Issues Alert for French Inmate on the Run After Deadly Ambush
abstract: Hundreds of police officers in France were engaged in a manhunt for the escaped prisoner and the armed assailants who freed him.
lead_paragraph: Interpol issued an alert on Wednesday for a French inmate who was freed during a violent ambush of a prison convoy a day earlier, an attack that left two guards dead, deeply shocked France and set off a large-scale police manhunt.

headline: Ukraine Fights to Hold Off Fierce Russian Assaults in Northeast
abstract: While Ukrainian officials and analysts said that a Russian advance across the border appeared to be slowing, President Volodymyr Zelensky canceled his participation in international events.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces on Wednesday were putting up a fierce defense in Vovchansk, a village in northeastern Ukraine about five miles from the Russian border, engaging in what appeared to be street fighting as they tried to contain the Russian advance in the area.

headline: Butterflies Know: These Native Plants Aren’t Weeds
abstract: Pollinators recognize a good thing when they see it — and so do gardeners in search of organic pest control. As one put it, “My prairie is my pesticide.”
lead_paragraph: The first time I met Neil Diboll, he set his front yard on fire. On purpose.

headline: Michael Cohen and Rosie O’Donnell: A Love Story
abstract: For years, Donald J. Trump hurled insults her way. Now, she is BFF with his former enforcer.
lead_paragraph: The text came through on Michael D. Cohen’s iPhone on Monday morning, shortly before he took the stand in a Manhattan courtroom as the star witness in the criminal case against his former boss, Donald J. Trump: “breathe - relax - tell the truth - u got this - i love u.”

headline: Prizewinning Miniature Poodle
abstract: Did you watch the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show?
lead_paragraph: Sage, an extravagantly coifed miniature poodle, won best in show at the 148th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on May 14, prevailing over a tough field of competitors including a majestic German shepherd, a silken Afghan hound and a proud giant schnauzer.

headline: Biden and Trump Agree to Two Debates in June and September
abstract: The first debate, on June 27 on CNN, raises the likelihood of the earliest general-election debate in modern history.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Donald J. Trump have agreed to two debates, one on June 27 on CNN and one on Sept. 10 on ABC News, the first onstage clashes between the former president and his successor in more than three years.

headline: A Big Plot Twist at OpenAI
abstract: Ilya Sutskever, a co-founder at the artificial intelligence start-up and one of the world’s leading researchers, is out, and Sam Altman’s control looks firmer than ever.
lead_paragraph: A day after OpenAI announced major updates to its ChatGPT chatbot, the company said its chief scientist and co-founder was leaving.

headline: How Much Do You Know About Kuwait?
abstract: Can you find Kuwait on a map? What else do you know about this Middle East nation?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Kuwait on a map? What else do you know about this Middle East nation?

headline: Gaza aid gains may be lost as fighting rages in Rafah, the U.S. secretary of state says.
abstract: Nearly 10 days after Israel began a military operation in the southernmost city of Gaza, aid trucks are backed up at the border.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken warned on Wednesday that recent gains in getting desperately needed humanitarian aid to people in the Gaza Strip risked being undone by the fighting in southern Gaza.

headline: Stepping Cautiously Into the ‘Bridgerton’ Spotlight
abstract: Luke Newton has been in the sexy Netflix hit from the start. But a new season, premiering Thursday, will be his first as co-lead — or chief hunk.
lead_paragraph: Luke Newton is yet to experience what it means to be a “Bridgerton” leading man, but he has been trying to prepare himself.

headline: A Shock of Red for a Royal Portrait
abstract: A new portrait of King Charles III is bathed in symbolism.
lead_paragraph: Royal portraits, as a rule, tend to be fairly staid, predictable affairs. Full of symbolism, sure, but generally symbolism of the traditional, establishment kind: symbols of state, of office, of pomp and lineage.

headline: What Kind of Person Lies to a Child With Cancer?
abstract: A reader is fuming after a friend lied about her efforts to get a wig made for a sick child, and thinks her other friends should know about the deception.
lead_paragraph: I am part of a large friend group. One of us has a 13-year-old daughter with cancer; she lost her hair during treatment. Before she did, I found a company to make a wig using her hair. I raised the money to pay for it and sent it to another friend who is a stylist. She cut the girl’s hair and told us she sent it to the wig company. The girl texted our stylist friend several times for updates, and the stylist told her they were working on it. Finally, the girl’s mother contacted the wig company: The stylist never sent the hair. She’d been holding it for five months! She finally returned the hair and the money. But the girl is crushed! Her mom doesn’t want anyone to know what the stylist did; she doesn’t want the drama. But I think our friends should know what a lousy person she is. Should I respect the mother’s wishes?

headline: California Leaders Try to Solve Another Big Budget Deficit
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom released his revised spending plan to close a $27.6 billion gap, touching off what will probably be weeks of negotiations.
lead_paragraph: May has many pleasures in California. Poppies. Jumping frog contests. Waterfalls in Yosemite National Park.

headline: Smartphones Can Now Last 7 Years. Here’s How to Keep Them Working.
abstract: Google and Samsung used to update smartphone software for only three years. That has changed.
lead_paragraph: Every smartphone has an expiration date. That day arrives when the software updates stop coming and you start missing out on new apps and security protections. With most phones, this used to happen after about only three years.

headline: ‘Tradwife’ Content Isn’t Really for Women. It’s for Men Who Want Submissive Wives.
abstract: Young American women aren’t buying what these influencers are selling.
lead_paragraph: Tradwife content has been a social media phenomenon for a few years, and even though the trend creates a lot of discourse online and off, I’ve resisted writing about it because I think it’s a trap.

headline: After Outlawing Public Zoos, Costa Rica Relocates Hundreds of Animals
abstract: Some of the animals will stay in sanctuaries, while others may be released into the wild.
lead_paragraph: Costa Rica announced last week that it would close its two remaining state zoos, more than a decade after it passed a law to ban keeping wild animals in government-sponsored captivity but was met with legal blowback.

headline: ‘Death Becomes Her’ Musical to Open on Broadway This Fall
abstract: The musical comedy, which is now running in Chicago, stars Megan Hilty and Jennifer Simard. It is based on the 1992 film.
lead_paragraph: “Death Becomes Her,” a musical comedy based on the zany 1992 film about two warring women who turn to a magical potion in their quests for eternal youth, will transfer to Broadway this fall.

headline: Overdose Deaths Dropped in U.S. in 2023 for First Time in Five Years
abstract: Preliminary numbers show a nearly 4 percent decrease in deaths from opioids, largely fentanyl, but a rise in deaths from meth and cocaine.
lead_paragraph: Overdose deaths in the United States declined slightly last year, the first decrease in five years, according to preliminary federal data released Wednesday.

headline: East Texas, Already Soaked, Prepares for a ‘Nightmare Scenario’ of More Rain
abstract: Some places in Texas have seen a year’s worth of rainfall since January.
lead_paragraph: In a densely forested region of East Texas called the Piney Woods, rivers are still in moderate to major flood stage after recent weeks of heavy rainfall. Now, the region is preparing for what forecasters are calling a “nightmare scenario” with another round of excessive rain, which could lead to more considerable flooding on Thursday into Friday morning.

headline: How Wild Rice Forecasts Climate Change
abstract: Manoomin, a crop vital to the Indigenous peoples of the Upper Midwest, has been threatened in recent years. But careful stewardship is helping to bring it back.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Dwayne Jarman is often tinkering with the wild rice machines in his garage in this tree-lined suburb of Detroit. He has threshers to crack the hulls and winnowers to blow the chaff. He smiles and flips the switch. It’s time to process last summer’s harvest from his Anishinaabe homeland near Traverse City in Northern Michigan.

headline: France Declares State of Emergency Amid Protests in New Caledonia
abstract: The French authorities have undertaken a “massive” mobilization of security forces since violence broke out over a constitutional amendment that changes voting rules in the South Pacific territory.
lead_paragraph: France’s government declared a state of emergency in New Caledonia on Wednesday as it struggled to quell deadly riots in the semiautonomous French Pacific territory.

headline: A Recipe for Perfect Broiled Shrimp Every Time
abstract: Cooking the tiny crustaceans on a sheet pan can be tricky. This vibrant dish, full of golden-edged zucchini, from Melissa Clark changes that.
lead_paragraph: Some sheet-pan meals are so simple you could almost cook them in your sleep. Throw some chicken legs and sturdy root vegetables on a pan, sprinkle with salt and maybe herbs or spices, then drizzle with oil and stick it all in a hot oven. About 40 minutes later, the dark meat is reliably juicy, the vegetables golden and bathed in rendered chicken fat, and both take about the same amount of time. It’s an adaptable meal that would be hard to get wrong.

headline: They Were Once ‘Hippie vs. Soviet.’ Now They’re the Best of Friends.
abstract: “We genuinely like each other,” Alex Yaroslavsky said of his ex-wife and co-parent, Liza Cooper. They even live in the same apartment building.
lead_paragraph: In Unhitched, couples tell the stories of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.

headline: The Unusual Evolutionary Journey of the Baobab Tree
abstract: New research shows the “upside-down trees” originated in Madagascar and then caught a ride on ocean currents to reach mainland Africa and Australia.
lead_paragraph: Baobabs are one of the most charismatic trees on Earth, thanks in part to their unusual appearance. Their cartoonishly thick trunks are conspicuously oversized relative to their diminutive crowns, earning them the nickname “upside-down trees.” They can also live for thousands of years, contributing to their prominent place in cultural traditions and works of art.

headline: This Coconut-Miso Salmon Curry Has Over 12,000 Ratings
abstract: Kay Chun’s recipe keeps things bright with a squeeze of lime and a flurry of fresh herbs.
lead_paragraph: Kay Chun has a brilliant way to unleash the magic of miso. In her beloved, five-star recipe for coconut-miso salmon curry, she adds a dollop of white miso to the pot at the very beginning, letting it sear, caramelize and integrate with the ginger and garlic to deepen their character. Then she stirs in some coconut milk to create a creamy, lightly sweet broth to simmer the salmon and the spinach. Finished with sliced fresh chiles and herbs and served over rice, it’s no wonder it has over 12,000 ratings. Who doesn’t love a light and umami-rich weeknight meal, especially when it’s this easy to make?

headline: Diabetes Often Leads to Heart and Kidney Disease, Too
abstract: The three illnesses are closely linked — and increasingly common. Here’s what to know about the shared risk factors for these conditions.
lead_paragraph: Heart disease, diabetes and kidney disease are among the most common chronic illnesses in the United States — and they’re all closely connected.

headline: Buildings Burn After Riots Break Out in New Caledonia
abstract: Protesters burned cars and businesses in New Caledonia’s capital after France’s Parliament approved a change to the territory’s voting rules.
lead_paragraph: Protesters burned cars and businesses in New Caledonia’s capital after France’s Parliament approved a change to the territory’s voting rules.

headline: Biden and Trump agree to a CNN debate on June 27.
abstract: President Biden said in a statement that he has received, and accepted, an invitation from CNN for a debate on June 27.
