Yet from 1968 to 2005 it was actually illegal to import it to the United States, because it was thought that the dried prickly ash berry (the Sichuan peppercorn) might carry a bacterial disease that threatens citrus trees. During that dark time, American versions of dishes like kung pao chicken simply left out the spice, replacing its pungency and heat with extra red chiles and ginger. Tasty, sure. But tingly? Not so much.

headline: Legalized Weed Is Landing More Seniors in the E.R.
abstract: In Canada, cannabis poisonings rose sharply among people 65 and older after the country legalized the drug, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: As more places legalize marijuana, policymakers and health officials have worried about the health risks that the drug may pose to adolescents. But a new study suggests that an additional demographic is at risk: seniors.

headline: The Author of ‘Crazy Rich Asians’ Can’t Go Home, Except in His Books
abstract: Kevin Kwan left Singapore’s opulent, status-obsessed, upper crust when he was 11. He’s still writing about it.
lead_paragraph: A reader of Kevin Kwan’s books could be forgiven for expecting him to make a grand entrance at lunch in Beverly Hills — in a Lamborghini, perhaps, or wearing a slick pair of shades.

headline: Do You Know the Literary Influences of These Animated Films?
abstract: Several 21st-century movies were inspired by popular literature that is much older. Try this short quiz to see how many books and films you recognize.
lead_paragraph: Several 21st-century movies were inspired by popular literature that is much older. Try this short quiz to see how many books and films you recognize.

headline: James Greenfield, Globe-Trotting Reporter and Times Editor, Dies at 99
abstract: He wrote about world affairs for Time magazine and worked at the State Department before becoming a senior editor at The New York Times in 1967.
lead_paragraph: James L. Greenfield, an urbane journalist who covered postwar world affairs for Time magazine, served as a State Department official in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, and for nearly 25 years was a senior editor of The New York Times, died on Sunday at home in the rural town of Washington, Conn. He was 99.

headline: Wonderful Words: The Winners of Our 11th Annual 15-Second Vocabulary Video Challenge
abstract: Thank you to the more than 1,200 students who participated this year. Check out the winning videos to learn nine new words.
lead_paragraph: Do you have an aptitude for learning new words? Or, does your hippocampus have trouble retaining fresh vocabulary? But, whether you are oblivious to the pleasures of linguistic mastery, or the thought of expanding your lexicon makes you dyspeptic, we promise that you won’t kvetch after watching these nine clever and informative student videos.

headline: At Cannes, Lily Gladstone Scores a Familiar Seat
abstract: The juror found herself at the center of the Kering Women in Motion dinner, a year after she was a little-known guest for “Killers of the Flower Moon.”
lead_paragraph: At the Cannes Film Festival, much is made of the standing ovation. Every round of applause earns breathless headlines, with outlets racing to report which movie received the most prolonged cheers.

headline: Faced With a Russian Onslaught, Ukraine Struggles to Keep the Lights On
abstract: The government has for the first time ordered nationwide rolling blackouts for Monday night to conserve energy.
lead_paragraph: As Ukraine struggles to hold back Russian advances, the country’s officials say they are once again facing the formidable challenge of keeping electricity flowing as Moscow’s forces increasingly strike power plants.

headline: Ivan F. Boesky, Rogue Trader in 1980s Wall Street Scandal, Dies at 87
abstract: An inspiration for the Gordon Gekko character in the movie “Wall Street,” he made a fortune from insider trading before his downfall brought a crashing end to a decade of greed.
lead_paragraph: Ivan F. Boesky, the brash financier who came to symbolize Wall Street greed as a central figure of the 1980s insider trading scandals, and who went to prison for his misdeeds, died on Monday at his home in the La Jolla neighborhood of San Diego. He was 87.

headline: Amal Clooney Was Among the Experts Consulted on I.C.C. Warrants
abstract: Ms. Clooney, a prominent human rights lawyer, was on a panel that recommended arrest warrants for leaders of Israel and Hamas. She had been criticized for not speaking out on the war.
lead_paragraph: Amal Clooney revealed on Monday that she had reviewed the International Criminal Court prosecutor’s investigation that led to the request for arrest warrants for three Hamas leaders and two Israeli leaders, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant.

headline: The Best of ‘S.N.L.’: Trump Trolling, ‘Dune’ Buckets and Beavis Breakdowns
abstract: Season 49 of “Saturday Night Live” has just ended. Here’s a look back at its most memorable monologues, sketches, product parodies and impressions.
lead_paragraph: Season 49 of “Saturday Night Live” is barely in the history books, and everyone seems ready to turn the page to next season, when this long-running NBC sketch comedy series will tackle the 2024 presidential election and celebrate its golden anniversary.

headline: Taylor Swift Beats Gunna on the Chart. Her Next Rival? Billie Eilish.
abstract: “The Tortured Poets Department” logs a fourth week at No. 1. Next week’s competition is a battle between two stars with multiple versions of their LPs for sale.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift stays at No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart for a fourth time, easily holding off a new release by the Atlanta rapper Gunna. But next week she may face a challenge from Billie Eilish — and its result could come down to fans’ appetites for buying multiple “versions” of the stars’ albums.

headline: Does Legalizing Cannabis Increase Adolescent Use? This Expert Found Mixed Results.
abstract: Contrary to expectation, a major study found that weed use among minors was lower in states where the drug was legal.
lead_paragraph: With weed these days, it’s a Willy Wonka world: chocolate bars, lollipops, exotic-flavored gummies — to say nothing of joints, vapes, drinks and the rest. Twenty-four states and the District of Columbia have now legalized the sale of marijuana for recreational use, prompting innovation, lowering prices and making the drug — more potent than ever — more widely available. The Biden administration this week recommended easing the federal regulations on cannabis.

headline: ‘Stax: Soulsville, U.S.A.’ Review: Looking for a Little Respect
abstract: An HBO series tells the triumphant, tragic story of the record label Otis Redding, Isaac Hayes and the Staple Singers called home.
lead_paragraph: Multipart music documentaries come at us these days with the insistence and abundance of the old K-tel collections, scrambling to satisfy the cravings of every variety of pop nostalgist. Recent months have added “James Brown: Say It Loud” (A&E), “In Restless Dreams: The Music of Paul Simon” (MGM+), “Kings From Queens: The Run DMC Story” (Peacock) and “Thank You, Goodnight: The Bon Jovi Story” (Hulu), among others, to the rotation.

headline: Israel and Gaza: Despair and What-Ifs
abstract: Readers disagree about a guest essay by Megan K. Stack. Also: Big politics in politics; “journey” as metaphor; helping the mentally ill and homeless.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dublin-New York Portal Reopens After Flashing and Other Shenanigans
abstract: After closing because of questionable behavior last week, a video connection between Ireland and New York City is back on. Crowds rejoiced — in Dublin, anyway.
lead_paragraph: The Portal is back. For now.

headline: Cooking for One Can Be Fun, Easy and Delicious. Here’s How.
abstract: Making food for just yourself can feel like a burden night after night, but there are ways to make it less of a chore.
lead_paragraph: The new season of “The Bear” is coming soon, and one memorable scene from the last season starts with the chef Sydney Adamu, played by Ayo Edebiri, cracking a few eggs into a bowl. She then enters the meditative bliss that is making a perfect omelet. Watching her nudge the golden disk over and around a line of creamy cheese brings to mind the sandwich scene from the 2004 movie “Spanglish,” where Adam Sandler, playing a chef alone in his home kitchen after a long night at the restaurant, slides a fried egg over bacon and tomatoes shingled on a thick slice of toast.

headline: Cannes Meets Trump: ‘The Apprentice’ Sells a Controversial Origin Story
abstract: The film covers Donald J. Trump’s relationships with the fixer Roy Cohn and his first wife, Ivana, and tries to explain the future president, at least as a young man.
lead_paragraph: Would Donald J. Trump enjoy Cannes? It’s possible, since the extravagant displays of wealth here — all the yachts and glamour — are typically his thing.

headline: As New Yorkers Turn on Mayor Adams, Prominent Democrats Join the Pile-On
abstract: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Jumaane Williams, New York City’s public advocate, criticized the mayor over his management of public housing and campus protests.
lead_paragraph: For the nearly two and a half years since Eric Adams took office as mayor of New York City, many of his fellow Democrats have kept their criticism over his management of the city relatively muted or private in deference to the mayor.

headline: With I.C.C. Arrest Warrants, Let Justice Take Its Course
abstract: The request for International Criminal Court arrest warrants promotes the idea that the basic rules of international humanitarian law apply to all.
lead_paragraph: In seeking the arrests of senior leaders of Israel and Hamas, the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court has given the world a promise of accountability.

headline: Biden Will Choose a New Leader for Bank Regulator With ‘Toxic’ Culture
abstract: Martin Gruenberg, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said he would step down once the Senate confirmed a successor.
lead_paragraph: President Biden plans to quickly choose a new leader to oversee the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a bank regulator rocked by revelations of senior managers’ widespread harassment and abuse of junior employees, a White House official said on Monday.

headline: Sexual Assault Suit Against Neil Portnow, Ex-Grammys Chief, Is Dismissed
abstract: The plaintiff, who had filed her suit anonymously, told a judge that she feared the consequences if efforts to reveal her name during the proceeding were successful.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has dismissed a sexual assault lawsuit against the former head of the Grammy Awards, after the plaintiff fell out with her lawyers and said in court papers that she feared for her safety and well-being if her real name were revealed during the case.

headline: Hecklers Drown Out Trump’s Backers With Cowbells and Whistles
abstract: A contingent of supporters of the former president came to speak across from the courthouse, but they were inaudible.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has been joined in recent days by entourages of supporters who watch his prosecution in the morning and then give statements backing him outside the courthouse.

headline: After Raisi’s Death, Speculation Over Succession Turns to Ayatollah’s Son
abstract: Mojtaba Khamenei, 55,  plays an influential role in the office of the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and has fostered ties within the security apparatus.
lead_paragraph: He is known as a man in the shadows of Iranian politics. Yet Mojtaba Khamenei has a powerful influence over a country that rarely sees or hears him.

headline: In a House Race in N.H., a Famous Spouse, and a Traumatic Pregnancy
abstract: Maggie Tamposi Goodlander, the wife of the national security adviser, is navigating a personal landscape with little precedent in her run for Congress in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Tamposi Goodlander gave birth to her stillborn son in a hotel bathtub on Easter.

headline: Can Artificial Intelligence Make the PC Cool Again?
abstract: Microsoft, HP, Dell and others unveiled a new kind of laptop tailored to work with artificial intelligence. Analysts expect Apple to do something similar.
lead_paragraph: The race to put artificial intelligence everywhere is taking a detour through the good old laptop computer.

headline: Renting or Buying Is Often Personal, but It’s Also Helpful to Look at the Numbers
abstract: The Upshot’s financial calculator has been updated with new features.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot last week updated one of its earliest and most popular projects: the Rent or Buy calculator. Its lasting popularity is no mystery: All of us make this decision at some point. But it may be even more relevant today, with a changed environment of higher interest rates, than it was when the Upshot was created a decade ago.

headline: Aggression or Caution: The Choice Facing Iran’s Next Leaders
abstract: The question is whether the successors to the president and foreign minister will take a similar path by keeping slivers of communication open, and avoiding direct conflict with the United States.
lead_paragraph: In their three years in power, President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran and his equally hard-line foreign minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian, did everything they could to consolidate the “Axis of Resistance” against the United States and Israel.

headline: Iran’s President Is Not the First Leader to Die in a Helicopter Crash
abstract: Officials from Ukraine, Kenya and Sudan are just some of the others who have also died in crashes.
lead_paragraph: The president of Iran, Ebrahim Raisi, is but the latest leader to die in a helicopter crash. Mr. Raisi and Iran’s foreign minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian, died on Sunday when the helicopter in which they were traveling went down in a mountainous area near the city of Jolfa in northwestern Iran.

headline: F.B.I. Shed Informants Linked to Russian Influence Operations
abstract: After a secret review several years ago, the bureau cut off confidential sources thought to be connected to Russian disinformation.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. cut ties to at least a handful of informants and issued warnings about dozens of others after an internal review prompted by concerns that they were linked to Russian disinformation, current and former U.S. officials said.

headline: How Did You Grow and Change This School Year?
abstract: In this forum, we invite both students and teachers to reflect on their challenges and successes — and to consider how to build on them for next year.
lead_paragraph: The 2023-24 academic year is coming to a close, and we have a post describing 10 ways to reflect on these last months and learn from them. But the 10 ways aren’t just for students — we also hope teachers can benefit from them. In fact, we would be delighted if teachers and students did some of the exercises together and told us what happened!

headline: How the Cockroach Took Over the World
abstract: A genetic analysis of the German cockroach explained its rise in southern Asia millenniums ago, and how it eventually turned up in your kitchen.
lead_paragraph: They come out of hiding at night and scuttle across the house in search of starchy crumbs on the floor, a sticky sugary stain on the counter and sometimes even a nibble of toothpaste or soap.

headline: Biden and Blinken Accuse I.C.C. Prosecutor of Falsely Equating Israel and Hamas
abstract: The forceful denunciations of the International Criminal Court came even as tensions have risen between the United States and Israel over its conduct of the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Monday condemned the decision by the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor to seek arrest warrants for two top Israeli officials — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant — when he requested warrants for the leaders of Hamas, saying in a White House statement that “whatever this prosecutor might imply, there is no equivalence — none — between Israel and Hamas.”

headline: She Helped Wage the Fight for $15. Where Will Labor Go After Her?
abstract: Low-wage workers owe a lot to Mary Kay Henry.
lead_paragraph: Mary Kay Henry had one big success and one big disappointment in her 14 years as president of the Service Employees International Union, which is one of the biggest and most politically powerful in the United States.

headline: Choreographer’s ‘Dog Poop Attack’ on a Critic Inspired This New Play
abstract: At this year’s Theatertreffen drama festival, one production explores an incident that shocked the German theater world last year.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 11, 2023, the choreographer Marco Goecke cornered a dance critic, Wiebke Hüster, during intermission of a performance at the Hanover State Opera in northern Germany. After asking her about negative reviews that she had written about his past productions, Goecke took out a bag of dog feces and smeared her face with it.

headline: Penguin Random House Dismisses Two of Its Top Publishers
abstract: The departures of Reagan Arthur, who led Alfred A. Knopf, and Lisa Lucas, who held the top job at Pantheon and Schocken, came as a surprise to many in the company.
lead_paragraph: In a significant shake up, Penguin Random House, the largest publishing house in the United States, announced on Monday that the publishers of two of its most prestigious literary imprints had been let go.

headline: When Michael Cohen’s Lies Help the Case Against Trump
abstract: The prosecution gets some help for its theory of the crime behind the false documents.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible to use a lie to illuminate the truth? If the lie is told by the serial liar Michael Cohen in the right context, the answer is yes. Credit the prosecution in the Trump felony trial for pulling off this tricky maneuver.

headline: Top Education Officials Were Warned of FAFSA Overhaul Hurdles in 2020
abstract: Documents obtained by The Times show the department’s troubled FAFSA rollout this year came in spite of early warnings that the project required sustained attention.
lead_paragraph: Long before the Education Department’s overhaul of the federal student aid application fell apart this year, officials who now lead the department were warned of a complex and time-consuming effort and its potential pitfalls in 2020, according to internal emails and documents obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Jim Otto, Hall of Fame Raiders Center, Is Dead at 86
abstract: Despite his accomplishments on the field, he was remembered mostly for the many beatings his body absorbed, which left him in constant pain.
lead_paragraph: Jim Otto, who played center for 15 years for the Oakland Raiders and underwent more than 70 football-related operations, including the amputation of his right leg, has died. He was 86.

headline: Trump Courtroom Plays Host to Nonstop Spectacle as Prosecution Rests
abstract: Michael D. Cohen admitted stealing from the Trump Organization. The judge excoriated a defense witness. And Donald J. Trump’s entourage included a former leader of the Hells Angels.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush-money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Robert Costello, Defense Witness in Trump Trial, Is Scolded by Judge
abstract: Mr. Costello tried to cast Michael D. Cohen, the witness at the heart of the prosecution’s case, as a liar, but the judge lost his patience with the witness.
lead_paragraph: After the prosecution rested its case against Donald J. Trump on Monday, the defense began a simple mission: destroy the credibility of the prosecution’s star witness, Michael D. Cohen.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: What’s Next for Iran
abstract: Also, an international prosecutor’s request for arrest warrants for leaders of Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian authorities have aimed to project order and control after President Ebrahim Raisi and Foreign Minister Hossein Amir Abdollahian were killed in a helicopter crash. The supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said that the first vice president, Mohammad Mokhber, would assume the role of acting president and must organize elections within 50 days.

headline: Iran Moves to Project Stability After Crash Kills Key Leaders
abstract: The ayatollah announced five days of mourning for the president and foreign minister who died when their helicopter plunged into a mountainous region. Some Iranians celebrated the deaths.
lead_paragraph: Iran sought to project a sense of order and control on Monday by quickly naming an acting president and foreign minister a day after a helicopter crash killed both leaders. The change in leadership came at a time of heightened tensions in the Middle East and domestic discontent in Iran, where many residents have called for an end to decades of repressive clerical rule.

headline: Design Popularized by Internet ‘It’ Girls Gets a Pop-Up
abstract: A crowd lined up in Los Angeles’s Echo Park neighborhood to buy designer Gustaf Westman’s curvy, chunky, bold objects.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, the multi-hyphenate creatives of Los Angeles found a new reason to line up on Sunset Boulevard. Instead of sipping natural wine outside El Prado or waiting hours for a seat at Pijja Palace, they showed up for the designer Gustaf Westman’s pop-up shop.

headline: A High-Stress Countdown Begins
abstract: The prosecution rested its case and closing arguments are expected to begin next week.
lead_paragraph: For many Americans, the Memorial Day break will mean barbecues, flag-draped parades and the glory of a three-day weekend. But for those centrally involved in the criminal trial of Donald Trump — including the defendant — it will be an anxious countdown to the culmination of the first trial of an American president.

headline: Trump Media Reports Lackluster Revenues and Large Losses
abstract: The former president’s social media company reported taking in $770,000 in advertising revenue in the first quarter, sharply down from the year-earlier period.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company reported taking in $770,000 in advertising revenue in the first three months of the year, largely from its Truth Social platform, as it continued to incur hefty losses.

headline: Iran’s President Died, Opening a New Chapter of Instability
abstract: Also, prosecutors rested their case against Trump. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Ebrahim Raisi, Iran’s president, was killed yesterday in a helicopter crash along with the country’s foreign minister. A conservative Shiite Muslim cleric, Raisi had a hand in brutal crackdowns on opponents of the Islamic Republic, and he was widely viewed as a possible successor to Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

headline: Who Is Karim Khan, the I.C.C. Prosecutor?
abstract: Mr. Khan, known as a gifted speaker and a tough-minded litigator, took an unusual approach to announcing his request for arrest warrants for leaders of Hamas and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Karim Khan, the International Criminal Court prosecutor who announced on Monday that he would apply for arrest warrants for leaders of Israel and Hamas, has gained a reputation over a long career in international law as a gifted speaker and a tough-minded litigator.

headline: Not Your Grandparents’ Mahjong Table
abstract: Green Tile Social Club hosted its first tournament, where a younger generation gathered to play an old game and meet new friends.
lead_paragraph: On a drizzly Saturday afternoon, hundreds of mahjong enthusiasts gathered in Downtown Brooklyn to play the 19th-century Chinese game of strategy and luck.

headline: The Death of Iran’s President Does Not Bode Well
abstract: The generation on the cusp of taking power in Iran sees domestic oppression and foreign aggression as indispensable to the success of the revolution.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s supreme leader, Ali Khamenei, has not always seen eye to eye with his country’s presidents. Akbar Hashemi-Rafsanjani nudged the Islamic Republic too close to the West for the supreme leader’s liking. Mohammad Khatami rattled the conservative elite with subversive talk of how faith and freedom could coexist. Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was too insubordinate and too populist, while Hassan Rouhani’s flirtation with the Americans and his disappointing arms-control agreement drove him out of the inner circle.

headline: Former Trump Officials Meet in Israel With Netanyahu.
abstract: Robert O’Brien, one of Donald Trump’s closest foreign policy advisers, said he was there as a “private citizen.”
lead_paragraph: One of former President Donald J. Trump’s closest foreign policy advisers, Robert O’Brien, met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday as part of a delegation of former Trump officials that visited a number of Israeli leaders.

headline: The Prosecution Rests: Five Takeaways From Trump’s Criminal Trial
abstract: The judge became furious with a defense witness, and Michael D. Cohen kept his cool.
lead_paragraph: After 15 days of testimony from 20 witnesses, the Manhattan district attorney’s office on Monday rested its case against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: U.S. ‘Condolences’ for Raisi Reflect a Delicate Diplomatic Ritual
abstract: Whether it’s Stalin or Castro or Kim Jong-il, the United States struggles for the right words when a reviled foreign strongman dies.
lead_paragraph: In the eyes of the Biden administration, Ebrahim Raisi was a brutal tyrant, a sworn enemy and a threat to world peace.

headline: N.Y.C. Parents Rebuked for Questioning Transgender Student-Athlete Rules
abstract: Over a dozen Democratic elected officials criticized a parent group that asked for a review of rules that let students play on sports teams that align with their gender identity.
lead_paragraph: This spring, a group of elected parent leaders in New York asked the city to review education department rules allowing transgender students to play on sports teams that align with their gender identity.

headline: Trump’s Eyes Wide Shut Strategy
abstract: The prosecution rested its case. And Trump rested his eyes.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of rules in Courtroom 1530 inside the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building, many of which are posted next to the swinging entry doors.

headline: Biden Says Israeli Military Assault in Gaza Is ‘Not Genocide’
abstract: At a celebration of Jewish Heritage Month, President Biden pledged support to Israel and condemned a decision by the prosecutor for the International Criminal Court to seek arrest warrants for top Israeli officials.
lead_paragraph: At a celebration of Jewish Heritage Month, President Biden pledged support to Israel and condemned a decision by the prosecutor for the International Criminal Court to seek arrest warrants for top Israeli officials.

headline: Biden says there is ‘no equivalence between Israel and Hamas.’
abstract: The president, s
lead_paragraph: President Biden said flatly on Monday that Israel’s military assault in Gaza in the wake of the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks “is not genocide.” “We reject that,” he said, telling an audience of Jewish leaders and activists that Americans “stand with Israel.”

headline: City Hall Aide Is Cooperating With Corruption Investigation Into Adams
abstract: Eric Adams’s former liaison to the Turkish community, Rana Abbasova, had knowledge of some of the mayor’s dealings with Turkish officials.
lead_paragraph: An aide to Mayor Eric Adams who served as his longtime liaison to the Turkish community has turned against him and is cooperating with the corruption investigation into Mr. Adams and his 2021 campaign, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: What Does the Dow Hitting 40,000 Tell Us?
abstract: The stock market isn’t the economy — but its record high refutes conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: Last week, for the first time in history, the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 40,000.

headline: A Tongue-Lashing for a Defense Witness Isn’t Great News for Trump
abstract: The witness tried to play judge, and the real judge was not pleased.
lead_paragraph: Eight times a day during his felony trial, a former president of the United States must stand and honor 12 jurors and six alternates as they walk past, eyes straight ahead or down, casting no glances at him. It’s inspiring to watch these ordinary citizens as sovereign soldiers for justice.

headline: Scarlett Johansson Said No, but OpenAI’s Virtual Assistant Sounds Just Like Her
abstract: Last week, the company released a chatbot with an option that sounded like the actress, who provided the voice of an A.I. system in the movie “Her.”
lead_paragraph: Days before OpenAI demonstrated its new, flirty voice assistant last week, the actress Scarlett Johansson said, Sam Altman, the company’s chief executive, called her agent and asked that she consider licensing her voice for a virtual assistant.

headline: The Trump Trial’s Great Anticlimax
abstract: A strange sense of anticlimax hangs over the Trump trial.
lead_paragraph: If I’d pictured Donald Trump’s first criminal trial a few years ago, I’d have imagined the biggest, splashiest story in the world. Instead, as we lurch toward a verdict that could brand the presumptive Republican nominee a felon and possibly even send him to prison, a strange sense of anticlimax hangs over the whole affair.

headline: Brooklyn Protest Raises Doubts About N.Y.P.D. Commitment to New Tactics
abstract: Violent responses to pro-Palestinian activists follow a sweeping agreement aimed at striking an equilibrium between preserving public safety and the rights of protesters.
lead_paragraph: Last September, the New York Police Department signed a sweeping agreement in federal court that was meant to end overwhelming responses to protests that often led to violent clashes, large-scale arrests and expensive civil rights lawsuits.

headline: Scarlett Johansson’s Statement About Her Interactions With Sam Altman
abstract: The actress released a lengthy statement about the company and the similarity of one of its A.I. voices.
lead_paragraph: Here is Scarlett Johansson’s statement on Monday:

headline: Review: In ‘Three Houses,’ a Dark Karaoke Night of the Soul
abstract: It’s open mic at the post-pandemic cocktail bar where Dave Malloy’s hypnotic triptych of monodramas takes place.
lead_paragraph: It’s only fitting that a bar, replete with liquor and raised like an altar, presides over Dave Malloy’s “Three Houses,” which opened on Monday at the Signature Theater. Malloy’s music is, after all, intoxicating. Alcohol is the accelerant for the show’s linked monodramas. And hung over is how it leaves its pandemic-sozzled characters at the end of a dark karaoke night of the soul.

headline: Dartmouth’s President Is Censured by Faculty Over Protest Actions
abstract: The president, Sian Leah Beilock, called in the police just hours after a pro-Palestinian encampment went up on campus. A bystander and a professor were injured.
lead_paragraph: The Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Dartmouth College voted on Monday to censure the university’s president, Sian Leah Beilock, over her decision to summon the police to remove a pro-Palestinian encampment on campus, calling her action harmful to the community and disruptive to the university’s educational mission.

headline: Down in the Dumps
abstract: Zachary David Levy is really rocking it.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: The Disease Detectives Trying to Keep the World Safe From Bird Flu
abstract: When a child in a small Cambodian town fell sick recently, his rapid decline set off a global disease surveillance system.
lead_paragraph: As Dr. Sreyleak Luch drove to work the morning of Feb. 8, through busy sunbaked streets in Cambodia’s Mekong river delta, she played the overnight voice messages from her team. The condition of a 9-year-old boy she had been caring for had deteriorated sharply, and he had been intubated, one doctor reported. What, she wondered, could make the child so sick, so fast?

headline: Quote of the Day: A Call to Arrest Hamas Leaders and Netanyahu
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 21, 2024
lead_paragraph: “No foot soldier, no commander, no civilian leader — no one — can act with impunity.”

headline: Corrections: May 21, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, May 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about several universities that struck agreements with pro-Palestinian demonstrators misstated the title of the head of the University of California, Berkeley. It is chancellor, not president.

headline: Tensions Rise in Trump Trial After Cohen Completes Testimony
abstract: The prosecution rested its case against Donald J. Trump. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution rested its case against Donald J. Trump. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.

headline: Trump Posts, Then Takes Down, Video Online With Headlines About a ‘Unified Reich’
abstract: The 30-second video shared from Donald Trump’s Truth Social account, which included references to “the creation of a unified Reich” was denounced by President Biden as using “Hitler’s language.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump posted a video on Monday afternoon that features images of hypothetical newspaper articles celebrating a 2024 victory for him and referring to “the creation of a unified Reich” under the headline “What’s next for America?”

headline: How a Haitian Gang Is Trying to Turn Itself Into a Militia
abstract: Haiti's gangs have always been deadly. But now at least one group is portraying itself as a paramilitary force, with more weapons, equipment and uniforms than ever before.
lead_paragraph: Haiti's gangs have always been deadly. But now at least one group is portraying itself as a paramilitary force, with more weapons, equipment and uniforms than ever before.

headline: Haiti’s Gangs Grow Stronger as Kenyan-Led Force Prepares to Deploy
abstract: Gang leaders with suspected links to the 2021 Haitian president’s assassination now control key infrastructure, and pose a major threat to the incoming Kenya-led force.
lead_paragraph: They have a stranglehold on the country’s infrastructure, from police stations to seaports. They have chased hundreds of thousands of people from the capital. And they are suspected of having ties to the 2021 assassination of Haiti’s president.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The fallout after the death of Iran’s president.
lead_paragraph: A deadly helicopter crash that killed the Iranian president and foreign minister on Sunday resulted from “technical failure,” Iranian state news media reported. Here’s the latest news, and what we know about the crash.

headline: Trump’s Reported Fund-Raising Tops Biden’s for First Time
abstract: The pace of giving to Donald Trump’s campaign and the Republican Party picked up in April, according to his advisers. But President Biden still has far more cash on hand.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump and the Republican Party out-raised President Biden and the Democrats last month for the first time in this election cycle, according to campaign officials, as Mr. Biden’s pace of fund-raising slowed significantly from March.

headline: Stephen Colbert Slams Justice Alito for Using His Wife as a Scapegoat
abstract: Colbert joked that Alito “dropped a dime on his gal” when the Supreme Court justice blamed his wife for the flying of an upside-down American flag at their home shortly after Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: After Anti-Israel Speeches, a Law School Curtails Graduation Traditions
abstract: CUNY Law School is known for its diversity and activism, and lately for strongly worded pro-Palestinian commencement addresses. This year, the administration canceled its annual student speech.
lead_paragraph: For the past two years, commencement speakers at the City University of New York School of Law have made support for Palestinians and opposition to Israel a focus of their speeches.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: In the House of Psychiatry, a Jarring Tale of Violence
abstract: At the American Psychiatric Association’s annual meeting, a patient described a restraint that haunts him, more than eight years later.
lead_paragraph: The annual gathering of the American Psychiatric Association is a dignified and collegial affair, full of scholarly exchanges, polite laughter and polite applause.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,067
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 345
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: In Germany, Far-Right Plotters of an Improbable Coup Go on Trial
abstract: Members of a group called the “United Patriots” are accused of planning to bring a prince into power by violently overthrowing the government.
lead_paragraph: Prince Heinrich XIII of Reuss, the obscure aristocrat who wanted to become German chancellor, and eight men and women who planned to bring him into power by violently overthrowing the government, went on trial on Tuesday in Frankfurt.

headline: Iran Begins Funeral Events for President Raisi
abstract: A procession in the city of Tabriz was the first in a string of events after Ebrahim Raisi’s death in a helicopter crash. Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has announced five days of mourning.
lead_paragraph: Funeral commemorations for Iran’s president and foreign minister were underway in Iran on Tuesday as investigators looked into the helicopter crash that killed them and the country grappled with the shock of losing two of its most prominent leaders at a volatile moment.

headline: Two Weeks Inside Gaza’s Ruined Hospitals
abstract: Dr. Samer Attar, an American surgeon, shows the unfathomable brutality of the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Samer Attar, an American surgeon, shows the unfathomable brutality of the war in Gaza.

headline: Supernova or Coronavirus: Can You Tell the Difference?
abstract: A scientist finds beauty in the “visual synonyms” that exist in images seen through microscopes and telescopes.

headline: Have a Tiny Outdoor Space and a Budget to Match? Follow These Rules.
abstract: Here’s how to make the most of an outdoor space in the city — even if it’s small, awkwardly shaped or hemmed in by other buildings.
lead_paragraph: Any outdoor space in the city, no matter how small, is a precious thing.

headline: Their Palm Springs Neighborhood Burned More Than 50 Years Ago. They Want Compensation.
abstract: The Black and Latino families of Section 14, who made up much of the labor force of Palm Springs, are asking for reparations for what they say was a racially motivated attack.
lead_paragraph: The billboards rise above the desert valley, introducing millions of visitors to what was an almost forgotten chapter in Palm Springs history. “Know before you go. Palm Springs Section 14,” one billboard reads. “We smelled the smoke, we watched our houses burn.”

headline: This Man Did Not Invent Bitcoin
abstract: For years, Craig Steven Wright, an Australian cryptocurrency enthusiast, claimed to be Satoshi Nakamoto, the mysterious creator of Bitcoin. Then the courts got involved.
lead_paragraph: For much of its existence, the cryptocurrency company nChain was governed by a golden rule of office politics: It was not a good idea to challenge Craig Steven Wright, the chief science officer.

headline: Are Ingrown Hairs Preventable?
abstract: The dreaded bumps can occur anywhere you shave, wax or pluck. Here’s how to avoid them.
lead_paragraph: Q: I get ingrown hairs every time I shave. Can I get rid of them?

headline: Young, Gay and Searching for Selfhood in 9/11-Era New York
abstract: Thomas Grattan’s queer coming-of-age novel “In Tongues” unfurls in the Manhattan art world at the turn of the millennium.
lead_paragraph: Those who say that youth is wasted on the young ought to read a coming-of-age novel. “In Tongues,” Thomas Grattan’s second book, would cure any unwarranted nostalgia.

headline: Cinematic, Undiscovered, Cilento
abstract: In this less-traveled region of Italy, the scenery is spectacular, the water wine-dark. It has sun and sea, along with important Greek ruins, wild nature, curious legends and medieval religious sanctuaries.
lead_paragraph: From a piazza in the town of Castellabate on the Cilento coast of Italy, you may lift your eyes over the rim of your cappuccino and drink in a panorama of sky and Mediterranean Sea from Salerno to the Gulf of Policastro. Looking way, way down, a fruited plain of vineyards, lemon trees and white fig stretches to the flanks of green mountains decked with wisps of vapor.

headline: Sebastian Junger Is Reporting Live From the Brink of Death
abstract: In his new memoir, Junger, the veteran journalist, makes sense of — and an uneasy peace with — an experience few have survived.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of his reporting career, Sebastian Junger has had several close calls with death. A bullet whizzed past his face in Afghanistan; another time, a bomb exploded in his Humvee. Even when he wasn’t covering war, death was a theme in his work. Junger’s most famous book, “The Perfect Storm,” is about extreme weather, but it’s also about a group of men who never came home.

headline: An East Hampton Home Tailor-Made for the Owner of Il Buco
abstract: When Donna Lennard bought the house, ‘it was an adorable cottage’ surrounded by water. Now it’s even better.
lead_paragraph: After years of renting houses in the Hamptons, Donna Lennard was ready to buy a place of her own in 2017. And she knew exactly where she wanted to live: on Gerard Drive, in the hamlet of Springs, N.Y., in the town of East Hampton.

headline: How Long Do Eggs Really Last?
abstract: Believe it or not: It’s longer than you think.
lead_paragraph: That carton of eggs has been sitting in the fridge for a while. You check the expiration date, and you’re a few days past. Are they still OK to eat? It’s the stuff of common domestic disagreements, frantic internet searches and self-doubt. How long do eggs really last, anyway?

headline: How Free School Meals Went Mainstream
abstract: Over the past decade, many more schools started to offer free meals to all children, regardless of family income.
lead_paragraph: Kurt Marthaller, who oversees school food programs in Butte, Mont., faces many cafeteria-related challenges: children skipping the lunch line because they fear being judged, parents fuming about surprise bills they can’t afford, unpaid meal debts of $70,000 districtwide.

headline: The Real Danger if Trump Is Re-elected
abstract: He could convert the United States from a dominant economic and military power into something he purports to abhor — a global loser.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump may be regularly depicted as an impetuous toddler in chief, but he appears to possess genuine convictions about international relations. Ever since he gave an interview to Playboy magazine in 1990 decrying Mikhail Gorbachev for failing to hold the Soviet empire together (“not a firm enough hand”) and praising the Chinese Communist leadership for crushing the student uprising at Tiananmen Square (“they were vicious, they were horrible, but they put it down with strength”), Mr. Trump has extolled authoritarian leaders as possessing the right stuff, while he has dismissed democratic ones as weak and feckless.

headline: Two Weeks Inside Gaza’s Ruined Hospitals
abstract: Dr. Samer Attar, an American surgeon, shows the unfathomable brutality of the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: In the Opinion video above, Dr. Samer Attar, an American surgeon from Chicago, shows us the unfathomable brutality of the war in Gaza. He was a member of the first delegation of international doctors to embed in the northern part of the territory this spring.

headline: He Made the Met Opera’s Chorus the Best in the World
abstract: Donald Palumbo, a mild-mannered but relentless perfectionist, is stepping down after 17 years as the company’s chorus master.
lead_paragraph: During the second intermission of the Metropolitan Opera’s gilded, gargantuan production of “Turandot” one Friday last month, Donald Palumbo raced up to a tiny broadcast studio on the top floor for an interview.

headline: The Power of the Kennedy Look
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has a secret weapon up his rolled-up shirt sleeves.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the most attention-getting independent candidate for president since Ross Perot, may not have the poll numbers to end up on the debate stage next month. But he increasingly has something else: a reputation as the electoral “X factor.” Which means it is increasingly impossible to ignore what may be termed his “P factor.” Or even “K factor.”

headline: Review: Rocking Out, and Falling in Love, in ‘The Lonely Few’
abstract: Lauren Patten and Taylor Iman Jones star in an achingly romantic, softly sexy new musical by Rachel Bonds and Zoe Sarnak.
lead_paragraph: Of all the juke joints in all the towns in all the South, Amy had to walk into Paul’s.

headline: A Conservative Futurist and a Supply-Side Liberal Walk Into a Podcast …
abstract: Could the U. S. economy be twice as large today if it hadn’t made policy mistakes in the 1970s?
lead_paragraph: “The Jetsons” premiered in 1962. And based on the internal math of the show, George Jetson, the dad, was born in 2022. He’d be a toddler right now. And we are so far away from the world that show imagined. There were a lot of future-trippers in the 1960s, and most of them would be pretty disappointed by how that future turned out.

headline: Biden’s Get-Tough-on-China Tariffs May Backfire
abstract: Some of Biden’s new tariffs targeting China make sense. But others seem motivated by a desire to outflank Trump in Rust Belt swing states.
lead_paragraph: The tide of globalization is receding, at least from American shores. Two successive presidents have come down firmly on the side of tariffs rather than trade agreements as the preferred mechanism for managing international commerce.

headline: Is the Party That Ended Apartheid Losing Its Grip on South Africa?
abstract: The African National Congress has long rested on its legacy. But increasingly that isn’t enough to persuade voters to keep it in power.
lead_paragraph: The campaign to keep the African National Congress in power kicked off, unofficially, under a scorching January sun in a packed soccer stadium. Addressing the crowd was Cyril Ramaphosa, president of South Africa and the A.N.C., Africa’s oldest liberation movement, which was at the forefront in the battle against apartheid and has governed the country since the first fully democratic elections in 1994, when Nelson Mandela was elected president. Ramaphosa was at Mandela’s side in those years, serving as a chief negotiator to end apartheid and later as a top A.N.C. official. But the tone he struck at the kickoff event, which was also the A.N.C.’s annual birthday celebration, was one of anger and even, perhaps, political desperation.

headline: How a $10 Fee on Your Car Insurance Bill Is Actually Spent
abstract: The fee collected by New York State is supposed to go toward fighting car thefts and fraud. But an audit found that the program was poorly run.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about a $10 annual fee that’s added in every car insurance policy in New York State. We’ll also see what former Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the city’s public advocate, Jumaane Williams, said when they criticized Mayor Eric Adams.

headline: ‘Butcher’ Tells the (Mostly) True Story of a Very Bad Gynecologist
abstract: Through the lens of a 19th-century doctor, Joyce Carol Oates explores gothic medical horror.
lead_paragraph: There are many things one could note about Joyce Carol Oates’s long writing career — including, most strikingly, its legendary prolificness. Gifted with a protean talent, she has shifted with ease from one literary genre to another, be it novels, short stories, memoir, poetry, children’s books, essay collections, plays or librettos.

headline: Orlando Museum of Art Gets a Gift With Strings and Tries to Cut Them
abstract: The museum has asked a Florida court to modify restrictions on a donor’s bequest amid a financial crisis in the wake of its failed, “fake” Basquiat show.
lead_paragraph: Any day that a museum is handed a seven-figure gift is a very good day. But for the Orlando Museum of Art, which recently received a $1.8 million bequest from the estate of Margaret Young, that gift couldn’t have come at a better time.

headline: My Secret to Creative Rejuvenation? Conferences.
abstract: Vacations are cool, but sometimes you need more than an escape.
lead_paragraph: On the soundless paisley carpeting, in dimly lit hotel hallways and at the circular tables in ballrooms, I temporarily leave behind my long to-do lists and fall under the spell of a good conference. I find space to reimagine my routine. A conference is obviously not the same as a vacation, though I do sometimes arrive a day early and visit a site or two, have lunch with an old friend or meet a sibling for dinner. But the change of scenery, the subtle reframing of who I am, where I’m from and what I do creates a meaningful shift. Vacations provide an escape; the best conferences give me momentum. For a little while, I forget about my aging parents, my daughter’s looming college search and my own midlife malaise. I think about possibilities instead of obligations.

headline: ‘Bromakase’ Is the New Steakhouse
abstract: The power protein rituals of man dining are taking over the once staid world of premium sushi.
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking for the moment when American omakase restaurants began to threaten steakhouses as the preferred venues for young men of means to commune around prohibitively expensive protein, you could do worse than the weekend of Jan. 8, 2021.

headline: The Siblings Who Changed How We Party
abstract: When James and Alexa Hirschfeld started Paperless Post 15 years ago, some saw its digital invitations as a fad. Instead, they have become a fixture of events and have spawned imitators.
lead_paragraph: On an afternoon this spring, James Hirschfeld, a founder of Paperless Post, was at the company’s Lower Manhattan office surveying moodboards for digital invitation designs. They included materials for forthcoming motifs like New Victorian, a collection inspired by 19th-century décor, and a line by Annie Atkins, a graphic designer known for her collaborations with the director Wes Anderson.

headline: Justice Alito Is a True Believer
abstract: It is comforting to think that the red meat is for someone else.
lead_paragraph: In a large part of American political discourse, overt cynicism is the currency of sophistication. It is a sign of political savviness, even worldliness, to know that politicians are creatures of pure self-interest, with no solid beliefs, concerns or preoccupations. It becomes a little naïve to take politicians at their word and to say, even adjusting for political considerations, that people tend to say what they believe and try to act on those beliefs.

headline: There’s No Sense of Shame at the Supreme Court
abstract: Congress and the judiciary can no longer allow a few justices to trample on the court’s reputation.
lead_paragraph: An earlier generation of Supreme Court justices seemed to possess the capacity for shame.

headline: At Cannes, the Dogs Were Good Again This Year
abstract: The festival has long embraced canine stars like Messi, the hero of “Anatomy of a Fall,” while human stars are happy to take their furry friends along.
lead_paragraph: On the morning the Cannes Film Festival opened, Messi, the canine hero of last year’s Palme d’Or-winning “Anatomy of a Fall,” was practicing climbing the stairs of the Grand Lumière Theater. The majestic entry is typically reserved for stars dressed in their finery, but the official red carpet had not yet been rolled out. Messi’s owner and trainer, Laura Martin Contini, coached him to bound up to the first landing and pose. He wasn’t quite hitting his mark, stopping just one step below, but he eventually got the hang of it. Contini rewarded him with coos of “Oui, jolie” and “Oui, bravo” and a squeaky soccer ball toy he seemed to particularly enjoy, his blue eyes growing even more intense at the sight of it.

headline: V.A. Has Approved 1 Million Claims Under Burn Pit Law, Biden Announces
abstract: The president was in New Hampshire to discuss care for veterans suffering from toxic exposure, an issue that resonates for him personally and, his campaign hopes, politically.
lead_paragraph: President Biden announced on Tuesday that his administration had approved more than one million claims from veterans injured by toxic exposures during their service, actions made possible by a new law he championed, officials said.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Join Forces With Europe to Combat Excess Chinese Goods
abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned that China’s industrial strategy posed a global threat that requires a united response.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Tuesday that the United States and Europe needed to work together to push back against China’s excess industrial capacity, warning that a wave of cheap Chinese exports represents a grave threat to the global economy.

headline: Multiple People Dead as Damaging Storms Strike Iowa
abstract: Bad weather, including at least one tornado, left extensive damage in two counties. The exact death toll was unclear.
lead_paragraph: Damaging storms that brought punishing winds and at least one confirmed tornado to Iowa on Tuesday left multiple people dead and carved swathes of destruction through some towns, toppling wind turbines and reducing stretches of homes to wood and rubble.

headline: Billie Eilish Hits You Hard and Soft
abstract: Her new album reviewed.
lead_paragraph: Billie Eilish’s third studio album, “Hit Me Hard and Soft,” is here. Over 10 tracks, she sings about the highs and lows of love, accompanied by her brother Finneas’s sonically experimental production.

headline: The Crypto Comeback
abstract: The fate of Sam Bankman-Fried’s FTX, and what it says about the improbable resurgence of cryptocurrencies.
lead_paragraph: This month, customers of FTX — Sam Bankman-Fried’s cryptocurrency exchange, which collapsed in 2022 — were told that they would get their money back, with interest.

headline: What’s Next for Iran, and Drama at the Trump Trial
abstract: Plus, Scarlett Johansson calls out OpenAI.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: After Raisi’s Death, Elections Pose Tricky Test for Iran’s Rulers
abstract: Iran’s political establishment must choose between opening the race and facing moderate rivals, or limiting candidates and risking the embarrassment of low turnout.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Iran’s leaders could point to high voter turnouts in their elections as proof of the legitimacy of the Islamic Republic’s political system. But as voter turnout has plummeted in recent years, the election they will be now obliged to hold after the death of President Ebrahim Raisi will force the political establishment into a decision it does not want to make.

headline: One Dead and Dozens Injured After ‘Extreme Turbulence’ on Flight
abstract: A Singapore Airlines flight from London was diverted to Bangkok, where more than 70 people were being treated for injuries.
lead_paragraph: A 73-year-old man from Britain died and dozens of people were injured after a plane encountered “sudden extreme turbulence” about 10 hours into a flight from London to Singapore, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Has Fentanyl Peaked?
abstract: We explain a decline in overdose deaths.
lead_paragraph: Last week brought some rare good news on drugs: Overdose deaths declined in 2023. And while the opioid crisis has taken some surprising and terrible twists over the years, it may finally be turning around.

headline: Gazans Say I.C.C. Prosecutor’s Pursuit of Hamas Leaders Is Misguided
abstract: Some said the decision to seek arrest warrants for both Israeli and Hamas leaders on war crimes charges seemed to equate victim with perpetrator.
lead_paragraph: Palestinians in Gaza expressed mixed feelings after the chief prosecutor at the world’s top criminal court said he was seeking arrest warrants for leaders of both Israel and Hamas on war crimes charges, a move that many said equated victim with perpetrator.

headline: Macy’s Reports Another Drop in Sales but Sees ‘Traction’ in Turnaround
abstract: The largest department store chain in the United States has not reported an increase in comparable-store sales since early 2022.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s, the largest department store chain in the United States, reported a decline in sales Tuesday for the first quarter of the year, a sign that American shoppers were continuing to pull back on discretionary purchases. But the retailer said there were signs that its turnaround plan was gaining “traction.”

headline: Biden and Big Oil Had a Truce. Now, It’s Collapsing.
abstract: Companies were enjoying record profits. But the president’s decision to pause permits for gas export terminals has whipped up industry support, and donations, for Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Early in his term, President Biden seemed to have struck an uneasy truce with the oil and gas industry.

headline: I.C.C. Warrant Request Appears to Shore Up Domestic Support for Netanyahu
abstract: “The Hypocrisy of The Hague,” read the front page of one mainstream daily that has often been critical of Israel’s prime minister.
lead_paragraph: If the headlines in Israel were anything to go by, the request by the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor for an arrest warrant against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seemed to have granted the Israeli leader one of the most fortuitous turnarounds in his long and turbulent political career.

headline: Word of the Day: apathetic
abstract: This word has appeared in 41 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word apathetic has appeared in 41 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 29 in “Today’s Teenagers: Anxious About Their Futures and Disillusioned by Politicians” by Claire Cain Miller:

headline: Boys and Cologne
abstract: Do the teen and tween boys you know love high-end fragrances?
lead_paragraph: According to a recent Times article, teen boys’ annual spending on fragrance rose 26 percent in the year ending in March. Axe, Old Spice and Bath & Body Works fell in its rankings of teens boys’ favorite fragrance brands, while luxury brands including Valentino and Jean Paul Gaultier climbed.

headline: Scarlett Johansson and OpenAI’s Trust Issues
abstract: The actress, who criticized the use of a soundalike voice for ChatGPT, is the latest to raise concerns about the artificial intelligence start-up’s practices.
lead_paragraph: When OpenAI unveiled the latest version of ChatGPT last week, a chatbot that can listen to spoken questions and respond verbally, many users had one question: Is that Scarlett Johansson?

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Prime Minister Shot, Westminster Dog Show, Gen Z Trend
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Russian Forces Close In on Ukrainian Town in Northeast
abstract: Vovchansk has been a prime target of Russia’s offensive in the northeast as it seeks to push back Ukrainian troops from the border.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces on Tuesday inched closer to the central part of Vovchansk, a town in Ukraine’s northeast that they have been attacking for the past 10 days as part of a new offensive in the region.

headline: Threats of Violence Become the New Normal for Politicians
abstract: Some elected officials in California are rethinking public office in the face of increasing harassment.
lead_paragraph: Some startling beliefs in the United States were revealed in a study last fall by the University of California, Davis: Nearly one in three respondents said violence was justified to advance political objectives, like stopping an election from being stolen, or to “preserve an American way of life I believe in.”

headline: Michael Cohen’s Trump Testimony Was Intense. Here Are the Highlights.
abstract: Mr. Cohen, Donald J. Trump’s former personal lawyer and fixer, spent four days on the stand in Mr. Trump’s criminal trial. He was the last witness called by prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: Michael D. Cohen, the former personal lawyer for Donald J. Trump and the star witness in his criminal trial, ended four days of bruising, intense and revealing testimony on Monday as the case against Mr. Trump neared an end.

headline: Zelensky Says ‘Escalation Has Already Occurred’ in Ukraine War
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine suggested that Western allies were hesitant to take bolder steps to aid his country in part because they wanted to maintain trade and diplomatic ties with Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine suggested that Western allies were hesitant to take bolder steps to aid his country in part because they wanted to maintain trade and diplomatic ties with Russia.

headline: Zelensky Presses for Approval to Fire American Weapons at Targets in Russia
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that he needed “weapons and permission” to better defend his country.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that he needed “weapons and permission” to better defend his country.

headline: NATO’s Reluctance to Shoot Down Russian Missiles Frustrates Zelensky
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged NATO allies to play an active role in the war, saying it was a matter of defense.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged NATO allies to play an active role in the war, saying it was a matter of defense.

headline: ‘What’s the Problem?’ Zelensky Challenges West Over Hesitations.
abstract: “Shoot down what’s in the sky over Ukraine,” he said in a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times. “And give us the weapons to use against Russian forces on the borders.”
lead_paragraph: With his army struggling to fend off fierce Russian advances all across the front, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the United States and Europe to do more to defend his nation, dismissing fears of nuclear escalation and proposing that NATO planes shoot down Russian missiles in Ukrainian airspace.

headline: Top Oceans Court Says Nations Must Reduce Greenhouse Gas Emissions
abstract: Experts say the opinion, though nonbinding, is likely to lead to more claims for damages against polluting nations.
lead_paragraph: The world’s highest court dealing with the oceans issued a groundbreaking opinion on Tuesday that said excessive greenhouse gases were pollutants that could cause irreversible harm to the marine environment and must be cut back.

headline: Israel Says It Will Return Camera It Seized From A.P.
abstract: Officials had confiscated camera equipment from the news agency as a part of a feud with the Pan-Arab broadcaster, but the decision was reversed after the Biden administration privately expressed concerns.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Communications Ministry confiscated camera equipment from The Associated Press on Tuesday afternoon, claiming the agency had violated a new broadcasting law by providing images of northern Gaza to Al Jazeera.

headline: 1899: No More Exile To Siberia
abstract: Nicholas II. orders a committee to devise some substitute for transportation.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG — A proposal is under consideration for doing away with transporting criminals to Siberia. The Tsar has been guided in this matter by the following considerations.

headline: Trump Calls Cannes Biopic ‘Garbage’ and Says He Plans to Sue
abstract: The director of “The Apprentice” was unfazed by the threat to the film, which covers the ex-president’s relationships with his first wife and the fixer Roy Cohn.
lead_paragraph: The day after the Cannes Film Festival premiered “The Apprentice,” a biopic of Donald J. Trump, the former president hit back at the movie, calling it “malicious defamation” and threatening legal action.

headline: A Black Teenager Was Wrongfully Executed in 1931. Now His Family Is Suing.
abstract: Alexander McClay Williams was 16 when he was executed in Pennsylvania for the murder of a 34-year-old white woman. His conviction was overturned in 2022.
lead_paragraph: On June 8, 1931, Alexander McClay Williams, a 16-year-old Black student, was executed by electric chair, the youngest person to be put to death in Pennsylvania history.

headline: Rudy Giuliani and Other Trump Allies Plead Not Guilty in Arizona Election Case
abstract: A total of 50 people, including former President Donald J. Trump, are now facing charges in four states related to efforts to keep Mr. Trump in power after he lost in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani and 10 other allies of Donald J. Trump were arraigned and entered not-guilty pleas on Tuesday in an Arizona criminal case that charges them with trying to keep Mr. Trump in power after he lost the 2020 presidential election.

headline: Elvis’s Granddaughter Sues to Block Sale of Graceland, Charging Fraud
abstract: His granddaughter, the actress Riley Keough, claims that a company is fraudulently planning to auction off Elvis’s home in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the actress Riley Keough, the granddaughter of Elvis Presley, have sued to stop what they say is a fraudulent scheme to sell Graceland, the family’s cherished former home in Memphis.

headline: We Wrote a Cookbook!
abstract: In it you’ll find 100 of my most favorite weeknight dinners, like chimichurri chicken, coconut-miso salmon curry and chile crisp fettuccine Alfredo.
lead_paragraph: When I started writing this newsletter six years ago, I pitched it as “recipes for busy people who still want something good to eat.” I wanted to solve the dinner problem, that daily 5 p.m. quandary of what to cook when you’re hungry and tired out from the day. Every week since, I’ve picked five New York Times Cooking recipes to help ferry you to dinner as quickly as possible — and maybe even get you excited about it.

headline: Wirecutter Wants to Hear From You
abstract: Do you have a story idea, feedback on our coverage or a question for our journalists? Let us know.
lead_paragraph: We’re eager to hear from our readers. Please fill out the form below if you have feedback on our recommendations or website, or a question for our team. If you have a problem you think could be solved by a product, share it with our advice column, Ask Wirecutter, which explores the best approaches to buying, using, and maintaining stuff.

headline: An NBA Star’s Remark Becomes a Minnesota Rallying Cry
abstract: Minnesota Timberwolves fans have picked up on a phrase uttered by their star, and are hardly put off by its mild vulgarity.
lead_paragraph: Dearest Times readers:

headline: What to Watch as Voters Head to Polls in Georgia, Oregon and Elsewhere
abstract: The Trump prosecutor Fani Willis will be on the ballot in Georgia, as will Scott McAfee, the judge overseeing the former president’s trial there.
lead_paragraph: Voters are headed to the polls on Tuesday in several states.

headline: Up to 70 Percent of People With Asthma and C.O.P.D. Go Undiagnosed
abstract: Here’s how to tell if you’re one of them.
lead_paragraph: In spring 2020, Jazzminn Hein received an automated phone call from The Ottawa Hospital in Canada, asking if she or anyone in her household had experienced wheezing, shortness of breath or other breathing problems in recent months. The question caught her attention: Just a week earlier, Ms. Hein, then 24, had gone on a stroll with her mother-in-law and newborn only to end up feeling like her chest was burning.

headline: A.I.’s Black Boxes Just Got a Little Less Mysterious
abstract: Researchers at the A.I. company Anthropic claim to have found clues about the inner workings of large language models, possibly helping to prevent their misuse and to curb their potential threats.
lead_paragraph: One of the weirder, more unnerving things about today’s leading artificial intelligence systems is that nobody — not even the people who build them — really knows how the systems work.

headline: How Media Outlets Are Covering Justice Merchan in Trump’s Criminal Trial
abstract: Conservative outlets have criticized Justice Juan M. Merchan as politically motivated, while some liberal media organizations have praised him for muzzling Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Conservative media has been preoccupied for weeks with Justice Juan M. Merchan, the New York judge presiding over the Manhattan criminal trial against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews James Pethokoukis
abstract: The May 21, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with James Pethokoukis. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Bourbon Steak Lands in New York With a Local Wine List
abstract: Cafe Mado replaces Oxalis, Strange Delight channels the Big Easy and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: The chef and global restaurateur Michael Mina, first known for Aqua in San Francisco, is now making his New York debut in this grand, bronzed space overlooking Central Park, after scouting dozens of New York locations. The New York cut of his Bourbon Steak brand includes trolleys serving raw bar items, foie gras, steak tartare and salt-baked fish. “There are dishes you want in a steak house but other things, too,” he said. The wine list pays attention to New York, which is unusual for steak houses. The executive chef is Bryan Ogden, whose father, Bradley Ogden, is a notable California chef of Mr. Mina’s generation.

headline: Student Activism Over Gaza: Admirable or Ill Informed?
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay responding to critics of the protests. Also: Faith, family and the G.O.P.; deep dish pizza.
lead_paragraph: Re “Dear Boomers, the Student Protesters Are Not Idiots,” by Elizabeth Spiers (Opinion guest essay, nytimes.com, May 17):

headline: A Son of the Mexican Elite Who Can’t Escape His Roots
abstract: In a debut novel, history and family legacy — going back to the conquistadors — confound a man’s search for identity.
lead_paragraph: The grandiose title of Nicolás Medina Mora’s first novel, “América del Norte” (“North America”), gives a good sense of its ironic tone and its unabashed desire to include everything on the continent, past and present: Hernán Cortés, Montezuma, NAFTA, the war on drugs, Trump, AMLO, José Vasconcelos, Alfonso Reyes, the murdered students of Ayotzinapa — even the Iowa Writers’ Workshop. The book takes the form of a collage of short essays about these and other subjects, intercut with the story of its young protagonist, Sebastián Arteaga y Salazar, who is obsessed with history and his place in it.

headline: ‘Outer Range’ Is a Dizzying Sci-Fi Drama, With Buffalo
abstract: The second season of this Amazon series, all of which is available now, cranks up both the time-travel and the outrageous soapiness.
lead_paragraph: Season 1 of “Outer Range,” on Amazon, was intriguing and unsatisfying — lush, expansive and compelling, but also marred by abundant faux-deep nonsense and a total lack of resolution. It’s a “this is my family’s land, grumble grumble” ranch drama ostensibly starring Josh Brolin, but the real star of the show is a big hole. And not just any hole — a magic hole! A hole that transports you through time! Sometimes people disappear. Sometimes the hole disappears.

headline: How Donald Trump’s Financial Future Became Tied to Trump Media
abstract: Mr. Trump has treated Trump Media, which runs his social network Truth Social, as a low-cost sideshow. Now a big portion of his wealth hinges on its success.
lead_paragraph: At Mar-a-Lago on a Wednesday evening last month, Donald J. Trump mingled with partygoers, greeting his supporters and making small talk. The country star Lee Greenwood sang “God Bless the U.S.A.,” and the former president’s oldest son, Donald Jr., gave a speech.

headline: Rent Is Harder to Handle and Inflation Is a Burden, a Fed Financial Survey Finds
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s 2023 survey on household financial well-being found Americans excelling in the job market but struggling with prices.
lead_paragraph: American households struggled to cover some day-to-day expenses in 2023, including rent, and many remained glum about inflation even as price increases slowed.

headline: Can Republicans Embrace Voting by Mail? Pennsylvania Offers a Test.
abstract: Republicans are now trying to sell voters on voting methods that the party has demonized for years. It won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: When voters turned out in February to fill a vacant seat in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives, the stakes were nothing less than control of the chamber, which Democrats held by a single seat.

headline: Pixar Lays Off 175 Workers as It Returns Its Focus to Films
abstract: The animation studio, which has struggled over the past few years, will stop making original shows for Disney+.
lead_paragraph: Pixar will stop making original shows for Disney+ as part of a broader retrenchment, resulting in layoffs that will reduce its work force by 14 percent.
