abstract: This Disney documentary looks at the family ties and sweet harmonies that turned a California band into a popular treasure.
lead_paragraph: The wholesome ocean-breeze look of the Beach Boys could make the group a punchline if it weren’t for their sweet sunshine sound. The origins of their intricate harmonies undergird “The Beach Boys,” a Disney documentary directed by Frank Marshall and Thom Zimny that notes obstacles in the band’s career but mostly tries to keep the good vibrations going.

headline: Some Eye Shadows
abstract: Carolyn Davies Lynch opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Israel says it destroyed weapons and tunnels in Rafah, and other news.
U.N. Court Orders Israel to Halt Rafah Offensive
abstract: The International Court of Justice ruling deepens Israel’s international isolation, but the court has no enforcement powers.
lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice on Friday ruled that Israel must immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, dealing another blow to the country as it faces increasing international isolation.

headline: Australia’s ‘National Crisis’ of Domestic Abuse
abstract: The government has committed hundreds of millions of dollars for people fleeing domestic violence, but among those who work with victims and survivors, optimism is hard to find.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese declared that violence against women had become a “national crisis.” His comments came after thousands rallied in Australia’s big cities to demand action from the government in the face of alarming statistics, with activists identifying at least 29 women who have been killed in Australia so far this year.

headline: Try Living in Elon Musk’s Company Town
abstract: To some, Elon Musk has given Brownsville, Texas, a reason for being, a future. To others, he’s a colonizer, flirting with white nationalists online while exploiting a predominantly brown work force.
lead_paragraph: Just after 7 a.m. on Saturday, Nov. 18, as the sun was rising in the Gulf of Mexico, Noel Rangel, a 26-year-old native of Brownsville, Texas, was brought unwillingly into wakefulness by an uninvited sensation: The richest man in the world was shaking him. Or rather, his entire apartment. His bed was rumbling, his windows rattling. “I could hear the glass,” he said. He was confused. He woke as if Elon Musk himself had grabbed him by the shoulders.

headline: For the Best Nonalcoholic Wines, Look to Germany
abstract: The country has a long history — more than a century — of making nonalcoholic wines. It’s no wonder they’re good.
lead_paragraph: As interest in nonalcoholic wines grows, some of the best in the genre are being made in Germany, which started producing nonalcoholic wines more than 100 years ago.

headline: The Architect Who Made Singapore’s Public Housing the Envy of the World
abstract: With a focus on affordability, community, convenience and light, Liu Thai Ker replaced squalid slums with spacious high-rises. A recent spike in some sale prices, however, has saddened him.
lead_paragraph: The high-rise apartments — some with panoramic views of Singapore’s tropical cityscape — are airy, light-filled and spacious enough to comfortably raise a family. They are also public housing units, and for decades, were emphatically affordable, giving Singapore an enviable rate of homeownership.

headline: What Set the A.T.F. and an Airport Leader on the Path to a Deadly Encounter?
abstract: Bryan Malinowski was the executive director of the airport in Little Rock, Ark., and sold firearms at gun shows. Federal agents believed he was breaking the law.
lead_paragraph: The loud noises outside their bedroom door woke them before dawn. Bryan Malinowski bolted up and looked at his wife, Maer. “Stay back,” she remembers him saying after he reached into a drawer for his gun and loaded it.

headline: These Teens Adopted an Orphaned Oil Well. Their Goal: Shut It Down.
abstract: Students, nonprofit groups and others are fund-raising to cap highly polluting oil and gas wells abandoned by industry.
lead_paragraph: As a child in Bolivia, Mateo De La Rocha told his family he wanted to work as a garbage man when he grew up. In La Paz, his home city at the time, trash piles were everywhere. In Mr. De La Rocha’s eyes, the local sanitation worker was the only person cleaning up pollution. “I didn’t really see anyone doing anything about it, apart from the garbage man,” he said.

headline: 48 Attempts to Understand the Creative Spirit
abstract: In “The Work of Art,” famed creators from the worlds of film, fashion, theater and more explore the hidden alchemy of their craft.
lead_paragraph: Why anything exists at all is the first question of philosophy, Heidegger once said.

headline: Can Reading About Trauma Help Kids Cope?
abstract: Two new picture books dive into refugee childhoods.
lead_paragraph: Do children’s books about frightening events make the very young more afraid, or do they comfort them?

headline: With a Body Double, an Artist Reflects on Life as a Trans-Deaf Influencer
abstract: Chella Man, a 25-year-old model and actor, has turned to performance and sculpture to understand their identity.
lead_paragraph: A spotlight dimmed as the artist Chella Man signaled to a section of the audience where their parents were seated in all-white costumes. In a haunting approach, the parents tiptoed toward an eerily lifelike replica of their child’s body and carefully transferred the silicone doppelgänger to an operating table. There, as part of the performance piece “Autonomy,” Man performed two surgeries that had helped define their experience as a deaf and trans teenager.

headline: DanceAfrica Brings Cameroon to Brooklyn
abstract: DanceAfrica Festival 2024, the nation’s largest festival of African dance, is what some consider Brooklyn’s unofficial start to summer.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today, and on Fridays through the summer, we’ll focus on things to do in New York over the weekend.

headline: A Lender to Consumer Start-Ups Falters, Rattling Its Clients
abstract: Ampla, which lent money to smaller businesses that sold clothing, home furnishings and other items directly to consumers, is struggling financially and seeking a buyer.
lead_paragraph: A popular lender backed by venture capital firms is struggling financially, sending shock waves through the small clothing and home furnishing companies that count on its financing.

headline: Elon Musk Ramps Up Anti-Biden Posts on X
abstract: The billionaire owner of X has increasingly been using his social media platform to criticize President Biden for his health and immigration policies, according to a New York Times analysis.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Elon Musk posted on X that President Biden “obviously barely knows what’s going on.”

headline: How to Stay Safe in Extreme Heat
abstract: We asked emergency room doctors for their advice on protecting yourself from dehydration, heat stroke and other serious health problems.
lead_paragraph: The heat index hit 112 degrees in Miami this week. Monkeys have been dropping dead amid scorching heat in Mexico. India is experiencing its latest heat crisis.

headline: Where Public Housing Apartments Can Go for More Than $1 Million
abstract: Singapore’s public housing system has been a great success and a key factor in the nation’s development. But in recent years, rising prices have raised questions about affordability.
lead_paragraph: Six decades ago, when Singapore was emerging as an independent nation, three out of four residents lived in overcrowded and filthy slums. The ramshackle houses had tin walls and were known as squatters.

headline: An Extraordinary Documentary About the Most Precious of Lives
abstract: Margreth Olin’s “Songs of Earth” works almost like a poem as she records her parents and the Norwegian landscape.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare to see a film that feels not just poetic in nature, but like actual poetry. The rhythm and cadence, the imagery and metaphor, even the sense of movement and time that often accompany a great poem don’t translate easily to the screen. Filmmakers need a light touch and trust in the viewer to lean in and let their work wash over them, rather than trying to decode everything.

headline: A Family’s Escape From Rafah, Days Before the Israeli Offensive
abstract: Anwar Ghilan, an English teacher from Gaza, made the difficult decision to cross into Egypt, leaving some family members behind. The New York Times first spoke to Mr. Ghilan in March, when he and his family were living in a tent in Rafah after being displaced due to the war.
lead_paragraph: Anwar Ghilan, an English teacher from Gaza, made the difficult decision to cross into Egypt, leaving some family members behind. The New York Times first spoke to Mr. Ghilan in March, when he and his family were living in a tent in Rafah after being displaced due to the war.

headline: Audiobooks for Long-Haul Listening
abstract: Some books sprint; others take the scenic route. The heady, highly absorbing titles here earn their marathon run times.
lead_paragraph: Hear me out: Summer, with its hikes and bikes trips, is the perfect season for long audiobooks. I mean, the sound of birds is nice and all. Just not for three hours.

headline: As Rafah Offensive Grinds On, Hunger in Gaza Spirals
abstract: Aid officials and health experts expect famine this month unless Israel lifts barriers to aid, the fighting stops and vital services are restored.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, the Gaza Strip’s southernmost city, Rafah, was one of the few places where desperate Gazans could find some aid and food. Bakeries sold bread; fuel powered generators; markets were open, if expensive.

headline: $750,000 Homes in Barbados
abstract: A colonial-style townhouse, a four-bedroom house with a turret and koi pond, and a one-bedroom condominium in a beachfront midrise.
lead_paragraph: This two-bedroom, two-bath townhouse with Atlantic Ocean views is in the Forest Hills enclave and situated inside the gated Royal Westmoreland golf and beach resort, on the western side of Barbados. Covering about 750 verdant acres overlooking the Caribbean island’s “Platinum Coast,” the Royal Westmoreland resort includes as championship 18-hole golf course, a beach club at nearby Mullins Beach, several restaurants, facilities for racket sports, and a pool, spa and gym, among other amenities.

headline: The Best Films of 2024, So Far
abstract: Our critics pick nine films that they think are worth your time on this long holiday weekend.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a good movie to pass the time this Memorial Day weekend? The New York Times’s chief film critic, Manohla Dargis, and movie critic, Alissa Wilkinson, have you covered. Here are their top picks for the year so far. All are in theaters or available on demand.

headline: Judge Judy’s Manhattan Duplex Is Listed for $9.5 Million
abstract: Judith Sheindlin and her husband’s Manhattan penthouse at 14 Sutton Place South is for sale for the first time in a decade.
lead_paragraph: Judith Sheindlin, better known as TV’s Judge Judy, is putting her Manhattan home, a duplex penthouse with a wraparound terrace and scenic East River views, on the market for the first time in more than a decade.

headline: The Shaky Foundation of Trump’s Lead: Disengaged Voters
abstract: The Biden team faces questions of its own: Why have these voters backed away from him, and can his campaign find a way to reach them?
lead_paragraph: The polls have shown Donald J. Trump with an edge for eight straight months, but there’s one big flashing warning sign suggesting that his advantage might not be quite as stable as it looks.

headline: Is This the End of Instagram Cookware?
abstract: Once-hot direct-to-consumer pots and pans are up for grabs on secondhand marketplaces at steep discounts — or ending in the garbage.
lead_paragraph: Just a few months after the pandemic sent Americans indoors, Mia Graber received a lidded nonstick skillet the color of spruce pine needles, complete with a steamer basket and a wooden spatula on the handle, as a gift from her husband.

headline: Trump’s Taste for Tyranny Finds a Target
abstract: Once you start talk about immigrants “poisoning the blood of our country,” what comes next?
lead_paragraph: Among the worst episodes in American history are those moments when the federal government deploys the full weight of its power against the most vulnerable people in the country: the Trail of Tears and the Fugitive Slave Act in the 19th century and Japanese internment in the middle of the 20th, to name three.

headline: At These Restaurants, Feeding the Staff Comes First
abstract: The “family meal” tradition of serving workers before customers is getting new life as a perk, a motivator and a teaching tool.
lead_paragraph: When Eric Ripert was a young cook at La Tour D’Argent, possibly the oldest restaurant in Paris and certainly one of the stuffiest, all the cooks sat down before service to a proper French meal: appetizer, entree, dessert and cheese.

headline: ‘Artificial Intelligence’? No, Collective Intelligence.
abstract: The artist and musician Holly Herndon explores the promise — and complications — of collaborating with A.I.
lead_paragraph: A.I.-generated art has flooded the internet, and a lot of it is derivative, even boring or offensive. But what could it look like for artists to collaborate with A.I. systems in making art that is actually generative, challenging, transcendent?

headline: How ‘Furiosa’ Fits Into the ‘Mad Max’ Timeline
abstract: “Furiosa” is a prequel that intersects with the earlier movies in surprising ways. Here’s a chronology, plus our ideal order for watching the whole series.
lead_paragraph: “Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga” is roaring into theaters, widely advertised as a prequel to the director George Miller’s 2015 hit, “Mad Max: Fury Road.” But that was the fourth film in a series that, until now, was chronological, so where does “Furiosa” fit in? How else do these movies intersect, with the numerous cast changes and recalibrations in the 45 years since the inaugural entry? Whether you’re approaching the franchise as a novice or looking for a quick refresher, here’s how it all fits together:

headline: Life in the Dirt Is Hard. And Climate Change Isn’t Helping.
abstract: Heat and drought are taking a toll on the tiny soil creatures that help to lock away planet-warming carbon, according to a new analysis.
lead_paragraph: They’re dirt-dwelling invertebrates, but, in a sense, they’re the real backbone of Earth’s carbon cycle.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's selection includes titles by Juan Gabriel Vásquez, Emma Donoghue, Elizabeth Acevedo and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's selection includes titles by Juan Gabriel Vásquez, Emma Donoghue, Elizabeth Acevedo and more.

headline: Why Bad Commencement Speeches Are a Good Thing
abstract: At a time of extreme polarization on campus, the banality of the graduation ceremony is a tradition worth celebrating.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weekends, graduating seniors at American colleges and universities have been reminded of the necessity of laughter, the importance of failure and the need for empathy in a troubled and divided world.

headline: A Federal Judge Wonders: How Could Alito Have Been So Foolish?
abstract: Displaying an upside-down American flag shouldn’t have happened.
lead_paragraph: The controversy about the decision to fly an upside-down American flag outside the home of Justice Samuel Alito recalls St. Paul’s admonition that while some things may be lawful, “not all things are helpful.”

headline: This Is the Democrats’ Best Shot in 2024. And They Are Spending Like Crazy on It.
abstract: Democrats have continued to leverage abortion rights as a powerful culture-war wedge issue against Republicans, seen in their ad campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Democrats have continued to leverage abortion rights as a powerful culture-war wedge issue against Republicans, seen in their ad campaigns.

headline: 5 Knockout Stand-Up Specials for the Long Weekend
abstract: In new hours out now, the comedians Nikki Glaser, Neal Brennan, Rachel Feinstein, Nathan Macintosh and Ian Abramson can be smart, fun or joyfully weird.
lead_paragraph: The Tom Brady celebrity roast on Netflix ended with regret (he said he wouldn’t do it again), outrage (“Super Bowl of Cruelty,” The Washington Post thundered) and weeks of chatter. In other words, it was exactly what the streamer surely had hoped for. The other major winner was the stand-up Nikki Glaser, whose set was perfect promotion for her knockout new special.

headline: The Cannes Love Affair With American Cinema Takes Unexpected Turns
abstract: Whether it’s Demi Moore’s performance in “The Substance” or Sean Baker’s tale of a Brooklyn sex worker, this year’s jury will have a lot to ponder.
lead_paragraph: One truism of the Cannes Film Festival is that no matter how alarming the news about the American movie world, Hollywood — however you understand that word — retains a powerful grip on this event. Cannes is a thoroughly French affair, but its love for le cinéma américain is evident everywhere from the faded images of Hollywood stars that are scattered about to the honorary awards that the event bestows. On Saturday, it will present an honorary Palme d’Or to George Lucas, the 11th American to get an award that it’s given out just 22 times.

headline: Trump’s V.P. Pageant Has an Unexpectedly Strong Contender: Tom Cotton
abstract: Donald Trump’s interest in the Arkansas senator reflects a desire to choose a running mate with experience and the ability to run a disciplined campaign.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas has unexpectedly emerged as a top contender to become Donald J. Trump’s running mate, a signal that the former president is heavily weighing experience and the ability to run a disciplined campaign over other factors.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, May 24, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: In Interview, Zelensky Challenges West Over Hesitations to Support Ukraine
abstract: In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the United States and Europe to do more to defend his nation, dismissing fears of nuclear escalation and proposing that NATO planes shoot down Russian missiles in Ukrainian airspace.
lead_paragraph: In a wide-ranging interview with The New York Times, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged the United States and Europe to do more to defend his nation, dismissing fears of nuclear escalation and proposing that NATO planes shoot down Russian missiles in Ukrainian airspace.

headline: University Leaders Face a Long, Complex Summer
abstract: Many officials may be confronting federal investigations, disputes over student discipline — and the prospect that the protests start all over again in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Around now, university officials might usually take a deep breath. Campuses are emptying out for the end of the academic year. Gone, for the most part, are the tent cities that student activists erected as a symbol of opposition to Israel’s war in Gaza.

headline: Women Have Gotten ‘Too Mouthy,’ Says This Republican Senate Candidate
abstract: Alex Jones, Steve Bannon and the left-to-right pipeline.
lead_paragraph: Royce White, a Black former pro basketball player who led protests in Minneapolis after the murder of George Floyd, made his first appearance on “The Alex Jones Show” about two years ago. As he spoke, it became clear that the deep suspicion of government authority that inspired him to march in the summer of 2020 had carried him into Jones’s paranoid orbit. “We all know when the time comes and authoritarianism is at its peak, the police and the troops who just take marching orders are going to be the ones forcibly vaccinating you and your kids,” he said. Jones, a purveyor of conspiracy theories about everything from 9/11 to the murder of children at Sandy Hook Elementary School, was thrilled by their conversation. “You’re awesome, you’re dead-on, and we’re going to learn a lot from you,” he enthused.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga."
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga."

headline: Trump’s Pattern of Sowing Election Doubt Intensifies in 2024
abstract: A false, familiar claim by the former president — that the contest in which he’s participating is “rigged” — has reached a fever pitch in this cycle.
lead_paragraph: A false, familiar claim by the former president — that the contest in which he’s participating is “rigged” — has reached a fever pitch in this cycle.

headline: How to Make the Most of Summer
abstract: You don’t need a vacation to embrace a sunnier state of mind.
lead_paragraph: Summer may be a few weeks away, but Memorial Day weekend is often when people start asking if you have vacation plans. And for many reasons, including work demands or a tight budget, the answer might be “nope.”

headline: ScarJo vs. ChatGPT, Neuralink’s First Patient Opens Up, and Microsoft’s A.I. PCs
abstract: “Did you ever think we would have a literal Avenger fighting back against the relentless march of A.I.? Because that’s sort of what this story is about.”
lead_paragraph: This week, more drama at OpenAI: The company wanted Scarlett Johansson to be a voice of GPT-4o, she said no … but something got lost in translation. Then we talk with Noland Arbaugh, the first person to get Elon Musk’s Neuralink device implanted in his brain, about how his brain-computer interface has changed his life. And finally, the Times’s Karen Weise reports back from Microsoft’s developer conference, where the big buzz was that the company’s new line of A.I. PCs will record every single thing you do on the device.

headline: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Gary (played by Glen Powell) is a reserved philosophy professor who finds himself posing as a hit man for a sting operation in this Richard Linklater comedy. While in disguise, he falls for one of his clients (Adria Arjona).

headline: The New Hospitality? Customers Can Sue Restaurants Over Pricing.
abstract: A California law aimed at banning hidden fees has put restaurant service charges at risk. But it could still change.
lead_paragraph: The Southern California restaurateur Kwini Reed has spent years tying herself — and her business model — in knots trying to meet the competing needs of her customers and her staff.

headline: Here It Comes: Another Hot Summer in Europe
abstract: Extreme heat and other weather challenges are in the forecast this summer, and travel advisers, tourists and local officials are getting prepared.
lead_paragraph: Europe, the world’s fastest-warming continent, is headed for another scorching summer, meteorologists warn. And travelers, once again, are heading to the hot spots.

headline: The Capital of Women’s Soccer
abstract: The success of Barcelona’s team has made Catalonia a laboratory for finding out what happens when the women’s game has prominence similar to the men’s.
lead_paragraph: A little more than an hour before the game begins, the gates outside the Johan Cruyff Stadium swing open and a thousand or so fans rush inside. Some scurry to the turnstiles. Others wait patiently at the merchandise stalls, anxious to buy a jersey, a scarf, a commemorative trinket.

headline: Meet the Jimi Hendrix of the Sahara
abstract: Our music reporter on Mdou Moctar and other African guitar heroes
lead_paragraph: Our music reporter Ben Sisario takes us on a journey through West Africa’s guitar music scene past and present, highlighting a handful of songs from the genre’s most innovative and influential bands. This playlist showcases an eclectic mix of styles — from desert blues and psychedelic rock to Afro-Cuban music.

headline: How FaceTime Calls With Mom Became a TV Hit
abstract: What started as a way for the filmmaker Josh Seftel and his mother, Pat, to stay in touch has become a popular feature on “CBS Sunday Morning.”
lead_paragraph: At 87, Pat Seftel has a thought to share about almost everything.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,071, May 25, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 349, May 25, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Whales Have an Alphabet
abstract: Until the 1960s, it was uncertain whether whales made any sounds at all.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the discovery of whale songs almost 60 years ago, scientists have been trying to decipher the lyrics.

headline: A Week of Diplomatic Blows to Israel, and Calls for Alito’s Recusal
abstract: Plus, a big step toward college athlete pay.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Ukraine Starts Freeing Some Prisoners to Join Its Military
abstract: Nearly 350 inmates have been freed under a new law that allows them to serve in exchange for the possibility of parole, the country’s justice minister said.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has begun releasing prisoners to serve in its army, part of a wider effort to rebuild a military that has been depleted by more than two years of war and is strained by relentless Russian assaults.

headline: Ozempic Cuts Risk of Chronic Kidney Disease Complications, Study Finds
abstract: A major clinical trial showed such promising results that the drug’s maker halted it early.
lead_paragraph: Semaglutide, the compound in the blockbuster drugs Ozempic and Wegovy, dramatically reduced the risk of kidney complications, heart issues and death in people with Type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease in a major clinical trial, the results of which were published on Friday. The findings could transform how doctors treat some of the sickest patients with chronic kidney disease, which affects more than one in seven adults in the United States but has no cure.

headline: A Polling Risk for Trump
abstract: His advantage may not be as stable as it looks.
lead_paragraph: The polls have shown Donald Trump with an edge for eight straight months, but there’s a sign his advantage might not be quite as stable as it looks: His lead is built on gains among voters who aren’t paying close attention to politics, who don’t follow traditional news and who don’t regularly vote.

headline: Israeli Forces Recover Bodies of 3 More Hostages in Northern Gaza
abstract: The bodies were found in Jabaliya, where the Israeli military has been trying to root out a renewed Hamas insurgency.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces retrieved the bodies of three Oct. 7 Hamas attack victims in an overnight operation in northern Gaza, the Israeli military said on Friday, further heightening fears for the fate of the remaining hostages held in Gaza.

headline: ‘Romeo and Juliet’ Review: Plenty of Style, but Little Love
abstract: The London production, starring Tom Holland, sold out in hours. But its understated rendering of the central romance may leave some theatergoers wanting more.
lead_paragraph: As the male lead entered the stage in a new production of “Romeo and Juliet” in London, a single, very loud whoop erupted from the orchestra level. Nobody else joined in — this is Britain, after all — but the breach of decorum was telling. This particular Romeo is the big-screen superstar Tom Holland, of “Spider-Man” fame, and his pulling power helped tickets for this show’s run sell out within hours — even though the actor playing Juliet wasn’t cast until many weeks later.

headline: ‘Zarqa’ Is a Madcap Canadian Comedy
abstract: This new CBC sitcom from the creator of “Little Mosque on the Prairie” follows a divorced Muslim mother trying to pull one over on her ex.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian sitcom “Little Mosque on the Prairie” premiered in 2007 and centered on a small Muslim community in a fictional Saskatchewan town. It ran for 91 episodes over six seasons, eventually showing around the world (it is streaming on Freevee, the Roku Channel and Tubi). Now its creator, Zarqa Nawaz, has a new short-form comedy with a narrower focus but a similar cartoony vibe.

headline: Landslide Buries Village in Papua New Guinea, Killing at Least 3
abstract: Many more were missing in the Pacific nation as recovery and rescue efforts were delayed by a blocked highway and fallen boulders.
lead_paragraph: A massive landslide devastated a remote village in Papua New Guinea early Friday, killing at least three people and leaving many more missing, as at least 100 homes were damaged and water, power and a major highway were cut off, United Nations officials said.

headline: Kabosu, Shiba Inu Who Helped Define the Doge Meme, Dies at 18
abstract: The dog, whose face helped spread the popular doge meme and later became the logo of the Dogecoin cryptocurrency, died on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Kabosu, a Shiba Inu whose “much wow” face helped launch one of the defining memes of the last decade and inspired the cryptocurrency Dogecoin, died on Friday. She was 18 years old.

headline: Are University Athletes About to Earn a Big Payday?
abstract: A $2.8 billion class-action settlement proposal could finally erase the notion that college stars are amateurs — though the plan has drawn skeptics.
lead_paragraph: The other shoe has dropped for the N.C.A.A.: That college sports association just agreed to a $2.8 billion class-action settlement that, if approved by a judge in California, would pay student athletes after a century of deeming them amateurs.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Holly Herndon
abstract: The May 24, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Holly Herndon. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Would You Want a Robot to Speak at Your Graduation?
abstract: An A.I. robot gave a commencement address at a university in Buffalo. What do you think? Who would you want to speak at your graduation?
lead_paragraph: It’s graduation season — a time for caps and gowns, tears, hugs and inspirational speeches.

headline: Did You Recently Choose Between Renting and Buying? We Want to Hear About It.
abstract: The New York Times is telling the stories of people who made this difficult choice. Maybe we can tell yours.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times recently republished its Rent vs. Buy calculator, designed to help our readers make one of life’s biggest financial decisions. But the choice to rent or buy a home is based on much more than just numbers — it’s also about neighborhoods, schools, family, and what the future might hold. We want to tell those stories, too. Have you gone through the buy-versus-rent debate in the past year or two? Did you think you were going to rent a home, but end up buying? Did you come close to making an offer on a home, then renew your lease instead? We want to hear from you.

headline: At the Kenya State Dinner, Jill Biden Is True Blue
abstract: In Sergio Hudson, the first lady is stepping up her fashion diplomacy game.
lead_paragraph: There are few moments of political theater as grand as a state dinner, essentially a pantomime of diplomacy and national pride from the set to the staging to the scripts — and the costumes. In that drama, the first lady is cast as both hostess and symbol, her dress a part of the decorative storytelling of the night.

headline: How Algebra Became a Flashpoint in Schools
abstract: A tug of war in San Francisco over whether to teach algebra in eighth or ninth grade gets at wider national questions about serving all students fairly.
lead_paragraph: Controversy over school curriculum is nothing new. But one subject that has led to lawsuits, ballot measures and fighting among parents, teachers and district officials may come as a surprise: It’s algebra.

headline: The Business Ties That Bind the U.S. and China Are Strong but Fraying
abstract: The prospects for future commerce, and peace, are intertwined, our columnist writes.
lead_paragraph: If you follow the news, you know that tensions between the United States and China are high and that the commercial relationship between the two biggest trading nations on the planet has been fraying.

headline: Interest on Federal Student Loans Is Rising to 6.53%
abstract: The rate for undergraduate loans is up from 5.5 percent this past school year and higher than it has been in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: This has already been a challenging year for college applicants, starting with the problems with a crucial federal form that delayed financial aid offers. Now, students and families have more to worry about: The cost of borrowing for college for the next school year is rising to the highest rate in more than a decade.

headline: After Outcry, Chuck E. Cheese Says It Will Keep More Animatronic Bands
abstract: Plans to phase out most of Chuck E. Cheese’s animatronic bands prompted fans to plead for their survival. The bands will now play on at three additional locations.
lead_paragraph: After Chuck E. Cheese’s plans to retire most of its animatronic bands sparked an outcry from wistful fans, the pizzeria-arcade chain said it would keep a few more of the bands.

headline: Weinstein’s Lawyer Tried to Intimidate Witnesses, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Arthur Aidala, one of Harvey Weinstein’s lawyers, has questioned a witness’s credibility as prosecutors seek to retry Mr. Weinstein on sex crimes charges.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney’s office has asked the judge overseeing Harvey Weinstein’s retrial on sex crimes charges to urge the lead defense lawyer to stop making public statements that prosecutors said were intended to intimidate and to attack the “credibility and character” of witnesses.

headline: ‘Old’ Amsterdam Looks Back at New Amsterdam Through Indigenous Eyes
abstract: The violent history of the Dutch colony that is now New York is not well known in the Netherlands. The curators of a new exhibition want to change that.
lead_paragraph: In the language of the Lenape Indigenous people, the word for European explorers who crossed the Atlantic in the 17th century to settle on their lands was “shuwankook,” or “salty people.”

headline: A State Fund That Helps Children Hurt at Birth Is Quietly Suspended
abstract: New York officials said the fund would accept new beneficiaries into the new year, but a projected shortfall of at least $3.2 billion raises questions about its future.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, a little-known New York State fund has paid the medical expenses of children who have suffered neurological injuries as a result of medical malpractice during childbirth.

headline: Memorial Day Weekend Forecast Sees More Storms Across the Country
abstract: After several days of severe storms, more are likely across portions of the United States during the long weekend as stifling summer heat settles in across the South.
lead_paragraph: A weeklong string of severe weather is expected to continue through the holiday weekend, with the possibility of more tornadoes, large hail and damaging winds in parts of the United States.

headline: How to Clean Your Grill
abstract: Don't leave those burnt pieces from last year.
lead_paragraph: Don't leave those burnt pieces from last year.

headline: Hsieh Su-Wei, at 38, Is a Dominant Force in Doubles
abstract: She has won seven majors, including the French Open twice.
lead_paragraph: When Hsieh Su-Wei walked on the court to play doubles at the Miami Open in March with her partner, Elise Mertens, she wasn’t burdened by a cumbersome tennis bag holding half a dozen rackets, an assortment of snacks and multiple changes of clothes and shoes.

headline: Raw Milk Containing Bird-Flu Virus Can Sicken Mice, Study Finds
abstract: The results bolster evidence that virus-laden raw milk may be unsafe for humans.
lead_paragraph: Unpasteurized milk contaminated with H5N1, the bird-flu virus that has turned up in dairy herds in nine states, has been found to rapidly make mice sick, affecting multiple organs, according to a study published on Friday.

headline: Raw Milk’s Risks Don’t Stop Right-Wing Commentators From Defiantly Pushing It
abstract: On sites like Infowars, Gab and Rumble, federal concerns about raw milk are seen as overreach, but there are serious health risks and no scientifically proven benefits.
lead_paragraph: Health officials are warning Americans not to drink raw milk as bird flu spreads through American cows. But some media figures and influencers are misleadingly suggesting that the product is safe or even healthier than traditional milk. And sales are growing.

headline: Review: In ‘The Fires,’ a Triptych of Stories About Gay Men and Love
abstract: Raja Feather Kelly makes his playwriting debut with a spellbinding story of three generations of Black men at Soho Rep.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Raja Feather Kelly’s dance-theater works have made him a mainstay on the downtown arts scene. With his latest piece, “The Fires,” Kelly is making his debut as a playwright. Rarely does a show live up so honestly to its title — wrecking and illuminating in equal measure.

headline: Trump Warms Up to Bringing Haley ‘On Our Team in Some Form’
abstract: The former president praised Nikki Haley, once his bitter rival for the Republican nomination, a day after she said that she would vote for him.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Thursday opened the door to bringing Nikki Haley into his circle, another step in what looked to be a thawing of hostilities between the two former rivals.

headline: The ‘Nontraditional’ Bridal Brand Capturing Hearts Online
abstract: Madison Chamberlain is carving a niche with her vibrant, over-the-top bridal designs.
lead_paragraph: “Make me look like a disco ball.” For most designers this isn’t a common request, but for Madison Chamberlain, so-called disco brides, and anyone looking to splash extra color, sparkle or glam into their wedding day, are a mainstay of her business.

headline: Why We Should Have Nice Things
abstract: Modern soccer shouldn’t be set up to rob fans of their joy.
lead_paragraph: All being well, Bayer Leverkusen will end this season with one record, two trophies and just three haunting, existential questions. They will all trace back to Wednesday, back to Dublin, back to the Europa League final, and they will all take exactly the same, baleful form: What if?

headline: Morgan Spurlock, Documentarian Known for ‘Super Size Me,’ Dies at 53
abstract: His 2004 film followed Mr. Spurlock as he ate nothing but McDonald’s for a month. It was nominated for an Oscar, but it later came in for criticism.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Spurlock, a documentary filmmaker who gained fame with his Oscar-nominated 2004 film “Super Size Me,” which followed him as he ate nothing but McDonald’s for 30 days — but later stepped back from the public eye after admitting to sexual misconduct — died on Thursday in New York City. He was 53.

headline: Robert De Niro Narrates an Anti-Trump Ad for Biden
abstract: The ad uses the actor’s distinctive voice to try to remind voters of the chaos of Donald Trump’s presidency and warn them about a second Trump term.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s campaign released a new ad on Friday narrated by the actor Robert De Niro that seeks to remind voters of the chaos of Donald J. Trump’s presidency and warn them that a second Trump term would be even worse.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s villains include naughty gay ghosts, savage seniors and a dangerously unhinged bro.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever said to someone: “I would kill to spend more time with you”? The characters in Daniel Montgomery’s gay horror comedy say it a lot, with macabre but unexpectedly tender and very funny consequences for the living and the dead.

headline: Younger Adults Are Missing Early Warning Signs of Colon Cancer
abstract: A new analysis of dozens of studies has identified the most common warning symptoms in adults under 50, whose rates of colon and rectal cancer are on the rise.
lead_paragraph: Colorectal cancer rates are rapidly rising among adults in their 20s, 30s and 40s, and the most common warning sign for the disease is passing blood in the stool, according to a new scientific review.

headline: Hot dogs, hot slaw and plenty of ranch
abstract: The point, on a long weekend that heralds the start of a new season, is to cook with the intention of delivering pleasure as much as sustenance.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There’s always something celebratory about Memorial Day weekend, even though it’s meant to be a somber affair, honoring those who have given their lives in service to the nation. We raise our flags high, but also our grilling tools, our string lights over the yard (or around the railings of the fire escape), our hopes for a long, pleasant summer.

headline: Three Missionaries in Haiti Killed in Gang Attack
abstract: The latest assault by Haitian gangs left three people, including two American missionaries and a local pastor, dead in Port-au-Prince.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma-based missionary group working in Haiti’s capital was attacked by gangs on Thursday night, leaving two Americans and the group’s director dead, the organization, Missions in Haiti, announced on Facebook.

headline: Nikki Haley’s Path Back to Donald Trump
abstract: Readers offer their analysis of why she said she would vote for him. Also: Blaming the wife; maligning Justice Juan Merchan; a caregiver’s story.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Read the I.C.J. Ruling on Israel’s Rafah Offensive
abstract: The International Court of Justice ruled on Friday that Israel must immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, dealing another blow to the country as it faces increasing international isolation.
lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice ruled on Friday that Israel must immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, dealing another blow to the country as it faces increasing international isolation.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on What Constitutes ‘Visiting’ a State
abstract: Does it count if you never leave the car?
lead_paragraph: Caroline writes: My husband and sons and I stick a pin in a map whenever we visit a new state. But we disagree about what counts. They say if we cross the border in a car, even if we don’t get out, we’ve visited. I say no. Where does one draw the line?

headline: Brooke Shields Elected President of Stage Actors’ Union
abstract: She takes office immediately. The previous leader of Actors’ Equity, Kate Shindle, had been president since 2015, and did not run again.
lead_paragraph: Brooke Shields, the model-turned-actor who has starred in films, on television and onstage, has been elected as the next president of Actors’ Equity Association, the labor union representing stage actors and stage managers.

headline: She Was More Than the Woman Who Made Julia Child Famous
abstract: In “The Editor,” Sara B. Franklin argues that Judith Jones was a “publishing legend,” transcending industry sexism to champion cookbooks — and Anne Frank.
lead_paragraph: People outside the publishing industry often wonder what it is, exactly, that editors do. “Most of them do nothing,” one of the most storied, Robert Gottlieb, told the author Sara B. Franklin. Nothing is as bad as too much, and yet I’ve long thought the profession — not for nothing does it include “book doctors” — should have its own version of the Hippocratic oath.

headline: I Was a Nude Model for a Half Hour. Revelatory? Actually, Yes.
abstract: Two shows — an art fair in Brooklyn and an Yves Klein exhibition uptown — ask if nude art can still inspire or shock. I joined in to find out.
lead_paragraph: Before last week, I had never interviewed someone who had seen me naked.

headline: Fixing the Calamity in U.S. Math Knowledge Starts With Algebra
abstract: Giving up means that math scores will continue to plummet and racial gaps will grow.
lead_paragraph: The federal government made a disastrous choice a decade ago when it abandoned an accountability system (known as No Child Left Behind) that required schools to focus intently on helping the lowest-performing students catch up with their peers. Since then, the already alarming achievement gaps that separate poor and wealthy children have only widened.

headline: Where New Yorkers Start Being Polite and Stop Getting Real
abstract: The Portal, a video art installation connecting the city with Dublin, is open again, now with safeguards. But does changing the rules change the artwork?
lead_paragraph: At 2:45 p.m. on a sunny Wednesday in a plaza near the Flatiron Building, a crowd of a few dozen was watching, and appearing in, New York City’s most infamous new reality show.

headline: Review: A Delightful ‘Orfeo’ Returns to the Met Opera
abstract: The countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo stars in a revival of Mark Morris’s witty, sensitively choreographed production.
lead_paragraph: Gluck’s opera “Orfeo ed Euridice” is a funny thing: a timeless Greek myth of separation and loss, twisted into a Viennese cream puff.

headline: The Big Number: $48.75
abstract: A series of cryptic social media posts was all it took to push up the stock price of the otherwise struggling video game retailer GameStop.
lead_paragraph: A series of cryptic social media posts was all it took to push up the stock price of the otherwise struggling video game retailer GameStop.

headline: A Mexican Taco Stand Goes From Local Favorite to Michelin Darling
abstract: Taquería El Califa de León, in Mexico City, became the first Mexican taco stand to win a Michelin star. Since then, it has been deluged with customers and fame.
lead_paragraph: Over a week ago, Taquería El Califa de León was simply one of Mexico City’s nearly 11,000 registered taco shops, though there are undoubtedly many more that aren’t. Sure, it had been around nearly 60 years and was popular, especially among politicians who worked nearby. But it was mostly a locally known taco stand.

headline: U.C.L.A. Police Make First Arrest in Attack on Protest Encampment
abstract: Edan On, an 18-year-old, was charged with assault. The police said he beat pro-Palestinian protesters with a wooden pole.
lead_paragraph: More than three weeks after counterprotesters attacked a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of California, Los Angeles, the university police have made the first arrest related to the attack: an 18-year-old who officers said had beaten pro-Palestinian protesters with a wooden pole.

headline: Caleb Carr, Author of Dark Histories, Dies at 68
abstract: His own dark history prompted him to write about and investigate the roots of violence, notably in his best-selling novel “The Alienist.”
lead_paragraph: Caleb Carr, a military historian and author whose experience of childhood abuse drove him to explore the roots of violence — most famously in his 1994 best seller, “The Alienist,” a period thriller about the hunt for a serial killer in 19th-century Manhattan — died on Thursday at his home in Cherry Plain, N.Y. He was 68.

headline: Countries Fail to Agree on Treaty to Prepare the World for the Next Pandemic
abstract: Negotiators plan to ask for more time. Among the sticking points are equitable access to vaccines and financing to set up surveillance systems.
lead_paragraph: Countries around the globe have failed to reach consensus on the terms of a treaty that would unify the world in a strategy against the inevitable next pandemic, trumping the nationalist ethos that emerged during Covid-19.

headline: Bird Flu Virus Found in Beef Tissue
abstract: Muscle from a sick dairy cow tested positive for the virus. The meat did not enter the commercial food supply, which officials said remained safe.
lead_paragraph: Beef tissue from a sick dairy cow has tested positive for the bird flu virus, federal officials said on Friday.

headline: Israeli Forces Cut Off Access to Kamal Adwan Hospital in Northern Gaza
abstract: Israeli bombardments and raids have put many of Gaza’s hospitals out of operation and only a few remain even partially functional.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces massed at the entrance to a major hospital in the northern Gaza Strip on Friday, trapping more than a dozen medical personnel inside and all but putting one of the last functioning hospitals out of operation, according to a doctor and Palestinian news media.

headline: Top U.N. Court Decision Adds to Israel’s Growing Isolation
abstract: An order to stop the Rafah offensive was the latest action against Israel, all of which create “a tremendous sense of pressure,” a former consul general said.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, a former Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, warned that Israel faced a “diplomatic-political tsunami” of censure if its conflict with the Palestinians went unresolved, as peace talks faltered and revolution spread across the Middle East.

headline: The Best Books of the Year (So Far)
abstract: The nonfiction and novels we can’t stop thinking about.
lead_paragraph: We’re almost halfway through 2024 and we at The Book Review have already written about hundreds of books. Some of those titles are good. Some are very good. And then there are the following.

headline: Google’s A.I. Search Errors Cause a Furor Online
abstract: The company’s latest A.I. search feature has erroneously told users to eat glue and rocks, provoking a backlash among users.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Google unveiled its biggest change to search in years, showcasing new artificial intelligence capabilities that answer people’s questions in the company’s attempt to catch up to rivals Microsoft and OpenAI.

headline: A Bouquet of Songs for May Flowers
abstract: Tom Petty, Patrice Rushen, Billie Eilish and more.
lead_paragraph: Last month, I sent you a playlist of rainy songs, in honor of April showers. I also promised a sequel. I bet you have spent weeks racking your brain thinking what that playlist’s theme could possibly be. Well, wonder no more. It’s time for a selection of songs about (say it with me) …. um, no, not bell towers. And also not cauliflower, but that’s a fun guess.

headline: Harrison Butker’s Very American Traditionalism
abstract: How Latin Mass Catholics embody the spirit of Vatican II.
lead_paragraph: Across almost two weeks of controversy over the commencement speech that Kansas City Chiefs kicker Harrison Butker gave at Benedictine College in Atchison, Kan., one of the most useful pieces of commentary came from Kevin Tierney, writing in Catholic World Report. Tierney neither defended nor attacked Butker’s sweeping condemnation of modern secular culture and lukewarm forms of Catholic faith. Instead he identified the kicker’s worldview as part of a distinctive tendency that Tierney calls “DIY traditionalism” — a form of Catholic piety that offers a “radical emphasis on personal accountability, is inherently populist, and has little direct connection to Church authorities.”

headline: The Rolling Stones Really Might Never Stop
abstract: During a 19-song set at MetLife Stadium that spanned 60 years, the band tapped into what seems like a bottomless well of rock ’n’ roll energy.
lead_paragraph: “This song’s for Manhattan!” Mick Jagger told the crowd on Thursday night at MetLife Stadium, before launching into a punchy rendition of “Shattered,” that agitated ode to late-70s New York City that closes out the band’s 1978 album “Some Girls.” In the ensuing 46 years, the city has changed in some superficial ways but somehow remained essentially the same — much, as they showed throughout an impressively energetic two-hour set, like the Rolling Stones.

headline: ‘Atlas’ Review: A.I. Shrugged
abstract: Jennifer Lopez stars in a sci-fi action thriller that wonders whether artificial intelligence is really all that bad.
lead_paragraph: In 1927, a humanoid robot showed up and wreaked havoc in Fritz Lang’s expressionist science fiction film “Metropolis,” a memorable early example of cinema’s artificial intelligence antagonists. Since then, many a sci-fi movie, from “2001: A Space Odyssey” to the “Terminator” offerings to “The Matrix,” has proposed that some kind of A.I. will try to take us out.

headline: ‘Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga’: What Do Critics Say? What Do You Say?
abstract: The reviews all agree that the follow-up to “Fury Road” feels sadder and heavier. But is that a good thing? That’s where the disagreements start.
lead_paragraph: Following up what is considered one of the greatest action movies of the last decade is no easy feat. But that was the task facing George Miller as he set out to make a prequel to his Oscar-winning 2015 blockbuster, “Mad Max: Fury Road.” The result, “Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga,” tells the origin story of the Imperator Furiosa, the breakout character who first appeared in “Fury Road” — played by Charlize Theron then and Anya Taylor-Joy now.

headline: NASA Astronauts to Wait Another Week for Boeing Starliner Launch
abstract: Officials from NASA and Boeing say they have worked out a solution to a helium leak that has kept the Starliner astronaut capsule grounded.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s Starliner spacecraft, which was scheduled to take two NASA astronauts to the International Space Station on May 6, will remain on the ground for at least another week as engineers chase down a small helium leak.

headline: Can I Use A.I. to Grade My Students’ Papers?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on artificial intelligence platforms, and whether it’s hypocritical for teachers to use these tools while forbidding students from doing the same.
lead_paragraph: I am a junior-high-school English teacher. In the past school year, there has been a significant increase in students’ cheating on writing assignments by using artificial intelligence. Our department feels that 13-year-old students will only become better writers if they practice and learn from the successes and challenges that come with that.

headline: Want to Better Understand America? Consider All-You-Can-Eat Shrimp.
abstract: The downfall of Red Lobster suggests consumers are parched for value.
lead_paragraph: The great economist George Stigler wrote a paper called “The Cost of Subsistence” that calculated the minimum cost of food that would satisfy the nutritional requirements of “an active economist” who “lives in a large city.”

headline: Cher and the Jonas Brothers Dazzle the French Riviera
abstract: Demi Moore, Michelle Yeoh and Diane Kruger and many more attended the amfAR gala, the unofficial closing party for the Cannes Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, roads were closed for miles around the Hotel Du Cap-Eden-Roc on the French Riviera, helping to keep out paparazzi and eager fans.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The hosts spent much of the week riffing on the news that flags associated with the Jan. 6 insurrection were flown at two of Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito’s homes. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: The hosts spent much of the week riffing on the news that flags associated with the Jan. 6 insurrection were flown at two of Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito’s homes. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: New York Man Who Grabbed Officer’s Pepper Spray on Jan. 6 Pleads Guilty
abstract: Troy Weeks was at “the site of some of the most violent attacks against law enforcement” during the U.S. Capitol riot, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: An upstate New York man who grabbed a police officer’s can of pepper spray as he and other supporters of former President Donald J. Trump rioted at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, has pleaded guilty to federal felony and misdemeanor charges, prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: Are These Drones Too Chinese to Pass U.S. Muster in an Anti-China Moment?
abstract: U.S.-based Anzu Robotics is selling drones using technology from DJI, a Chinese firm that is the target of efforts by lawmakers to limit Chinese technology in America.
lead_paragraph: A one-man startup believes it has an answer to U.S. government concerns over the Chinese-made drones that dominate commercial sales in the American market.

headline: U.A.W. Seeks a New Election at Mercedes-Benz Plants in Alabama
abstract: The union, which lost an organizing vote at two factories last week, argued to federal officials that the automaker had violated labor laws.
lead_paragraph: A week after losing a hard-fought election at two Mercedes-Benz factories in Alabama, the United Automobile Workers asked federal officials on Friday to order a new vote, saying the German carmaker violated labor laws to suppress support for the union.

headline: Are You Wearing Sunscreen the Right Way?
abstract: And other essential questions about protecting your skin from the sun, answered by experts.
lead_paragraph: You probably know that you need to wear sunscreen. And you probably know the effects of not doing so: Too much exposure to UV rays can hasten signs of aging, worsen skin conditions and even lead to skin cancer — not to mention leave you with a painful burn. But when and how much sunscreen should you be applying? Does it matter what kind? And what do you do if, despite your best efforts, you do get a burn? Here, skin-care and cosmetic experts share their advice for protecting your body, from head to toe.

headline: The N.C.A.A.’s Landmark Athlete-Pay Settlement, Explained
abstract: The $2.8 billion agreement announced on Thursday would, if approved by a judge, allow college athletes to share team revenue for the first time. Here is what we know.
lead_paragraph: When the N.C.A.A. and the major athletic conferences agreed on Thursday night to a $2.8 billion settlement of a class-action antitrust lawsuit by college athletes, it was a pivotal moment in the long history of college sports.

headline: Biden’s Chance to Do the Right Thing in Gaza
abstract: The U.S. should side with the International Court of Justice in the Gaza war.
lead_paragraph: In a speech in Warsaw two years ago, President Biden declared that “the great battle for freedom” is one “between a rules-based order and one governed by brute force.”

headline: Fred Roos, Casting Director and Coppola Collaborator, Dies at 89
abstract: Widely considered to have the best eye for talent in Hollywood, he shared the best-picture Oscar with Francis Ford Coppola for “The Godfather Part II.”
lead_paragraph: Fred Roos, a casting director and producer who championed the early careers of A-list actors like Al Pacino, Jack Nicholson and Carrie Fisher, and whose long collaboration with Francis Ford Coppola and his family, stretching from “The Godfather” (1972) to this year’s “Megalopolis,” earned him an Oscar and an Emmy, died on Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Uvalde Families Accuse Instagram, ‘Call of Duty’ and Rifle Maker of ‘Grooming’ Gunman
abstract: The unusual lawsuits filed on Friday are among the most far-reaching to be filed in response to the escalating number of mass shootings in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The families of schoolchildren who were shot at Robb Elementary School in 2022 filed two lawsuits on Friday accusing Instagram, the publisher of the popular “Call of Duty” video game and a manufacturer of semiautomatic rifles of helping to train and equip the teenage gunman who committed the massacre.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, May 25, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Courting Black Voters, Trump Turns to Rappers Accused in Gang Murder Plot
abstract: The joint appearance was one in a series of the former president’s blunt and sometimes clumsy overtures to court Black voters, and particularly Black men.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of a rally in the Bronx on Thursday that his campaign staged to try to bolster and highlight his support among Black and Hispanic voters, former President Donald J. Trump called upon two hip-hop artists who have been accused of participating in violent gang warfare fueled in part by their music.

headline: Lloyd Austin Undergoes Procedure Related to Bladder Issue
abstract: The Pentagon called the procedure a “minimally invasive,” nonsurgical follow-up to previous treatment, and said the defense secretary had resumed his duties after temporarily handing them over.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III underwent a nonsurgical procedure on Friday night to address a bladder-related issue and during the hospitalization temporarily turned over duties to his deputy, the Pentagon said on Friday.

headline: The Top U.N. Court Told Israel to Halt Its Rafah Offensive
abstract: Also, countries failed to agree on how to prepare for the next pandemic. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice ruled today that Israel must immediately halt its military offensive in the southern Gazan city of Rafah.

headline: Justice Sotomayor Describes Frustration With Being a Liberal on the Supreme Court
abstract: In a conversation at Harvard, the justice spoke of her despair at some of the court’s decisions, but she urged optimism and a focus on future generations.
lead_paragraph: Some days, after Justice Sonia Sotomayor listens to the Supreme Court announce its decisions, she goes into her chambers, shuts the door and weeps.

headline: John Koerner, Bluesman Who Inspired a Young Bob Dylan, Dies at 85
abstract: A spindly guitarist nicknamed Spider, Mr. Koerner was Mr. Dylan’s first friend in the scruffy world of Minneapolis bohemia where he learned about folk music.
lead_paragraph: Spider John Koerner, a blues and folk singer whose work drew praise from the Doors and the Beatles (if not the general public) and who, in 1960, taught his friend Bobby Zimmerman about traditional American music, then watched as the young man metamorphosed into Bob Dylan, died on Saturday at his home in Minneapolis. He was 85.

headline: Chinese Billionaire Accused of Fraud Didn’t Need the Money, Lawyers Say
abstract: Prosecutors put Guo Wengui on trial in New York for defrauding investors of $1 billion. His lawyers told jurors he was building an anti-Communist movement.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Guo Wengui, an exiled Chinese billionaire charged with defrauding investors of more than $1 billion, portrayed him on Friday as the dedicated leader of an anti-Communist movement who did not need the money he is accused of stealing.

headline: The Emails at the Heart of the Government’s Ticketmaster Case
abstract: Live Nation Entertainment, which owns Ticketmaster, is accused of violating antitrust laws. The Justice Department drew on the concert behemoth’s internal communications in its lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: In its lawsuit accusing Live Nation Entertainment, the concert behemoth that owns Ticketmaster, of being an illegal monopoly, the Justice Department drew on a raft of internal communications that offered a rare behind-the-scenes look at the industry.

headline: Blackstone’s Chief, a G.O.P. Megadonor, Says He Will Again Back Trump
abstract: Stephen A. Schwarzman, the billionaire co-founder and chief executive of the investment group, had previously called for a “new generation of leaders.”
lead_paragraph: Stephen A. Schwarzman, the billionaire chairman and chief executive of the Blackstone Group, said he would back former President Donald J. Trump in the 2024 election, a reversal from his call for a “new generation of leaders” after the midterm elections.

headline: Judge Denies Alec Baldwin’s Bid to Dismiss Manslaughter Indictment
abstract: The ruling increases the likelihood that Mr. Baldwin will stand trial this summer in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust.”
lead_paragraph: A judge in New Mexico denied Alec Baldwin’s bid to dismiss the involuntary manslaughter charge he faces in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the movie “Rust,” ruling on Friday that the case had been properly presented to a grand jury.

headline: Sean Kingston Arrested on Fraud and Theft Charges After Raid at His Home
abstract: Mr. Kingston, a singer and rapper, best known for his 2007 hit single “Beautiful Girls,” was taken into custody on Thursday. His mother was also arrested.
lead_paragraph: The singer and rapper Sean Kingston was arrested in California on Thursday, hours after a SWAT team raided his home in Broward County, Fla., and took his mother into custody, the authorities said.

headline: Kennedy and Trump Go to Battle Over Libertarians
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. made his case to the Libertarian Party convention on Friday, jumping into a fight over right-leaning, independent-minded voters.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the independent candidate for president, pitched his bid to the Libertarian Party on Friday, telling a potentially critical group of voters that he stands with them on “valuing personal liberty” and vowing to protect their rights to speak, to assemble and to “keep and bear arms.”

headline: The Anti-Trump Republicans Worried About the Biden Campaign
abstract: Some G.O.P. Trump opponents want to hear more from the Biden campaign. It says it’s on it.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, a couple of former Republican members of Congress sent an email to dozens of fellow G.O.P. retirees with a clear and urgent subject line.

headline: Menendez Judge Bars Some Prosecution Evidence in Bribery Trial
abstract: Prosecutors immediately asked the judge to reconsider his ruling, which could undermine their ability to prove certain elements of their case against Senator Robert Menendez.
lead_paragraph: In a potential setback for the government, a federal judge on Friday blocked the introduction of certain evidence that prosecutors wanted to use to support their case that Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey accepted bribes in exchange for approving billions of dollars in aid to Egypt.

headline: World Court Orders Israel to Halt Its Military Offensive Into Rafah
abstract: The International Court of Justice has no means to enforce its order in the Gazan city, but the ruling added pressure on the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice on Friday ordered Israel to “immediately” halt its military offensive in the city of Rafah in southern Gaza, dealing another blow to the country as it faces increasing international isolation and a drumbeat of criticism over its conduct in the war.

headline: ‘Doctor Who’ Episode 4 Recap: Now You See Her
abstract: A strong episode focuses on Ruby, the Doctor’s companion, and the mysterious older woman who starts following her from a distance.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get the easy bit out of the way. “73 Yards” is not just the best episode of the season so far, but also the strongest story “Doctor Who” has produced in years — despite the Doctor (Ncuti Gatwa) hardly featuring.

headline: N.C.A.A. Athletes’ Pay Deal Raises Questions About Future of College Sports
abstract: The landmark settlement made many wonder what the reality — and impact — of revenue-sharing plans with college athletes would look like.
lead_paragraph: Brent Jacquette knows a thing or two about college sports. A former collegiate soccer player and coach in Pennsylvania who is now an executive at a consulting firm for athletic recruiting, he’s well aware of issues surrounding pay for college athletes.

headline: Red Sauce
abstract: The poetic plot thickens in this themeless thicket by David P. Williams.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Lo, the fourth installment of this series is upon us, if solvers are counting. David P. Williams is creating themeless puzzles, of identical topology, that are all inspired by the Wallace Stevens poem “Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.” The previous three iterations appeared in August 2023, November 2023 and January 2024. They’ve all been good, chewy challenges. Any connections between these crosswords and the Stevens poem aren’t exactly emerging from the mist for me, personally, and I welcome observations and theories from other solvers.

headline: Prosecutors Seek to Bar Trump From Attacking F.B.I. Agents in Documents Case
abstract: The prosecutors said the former president had made “grossly misleading” assertions about the F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago that could endanger the agents involved.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Friday night asked the judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case to bar him from making any statements that might endanger law enforcement agents involved in the proceedings.

headline: Corrections: May 25, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about President Biden’s meeting with President William Ruto of Kenya misstated Ruth Porat’s title at Alphabet and Google. She is president and chief investment officer, not president and chief information officer.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Study Bolsters Evidence Raw Milk May Be a Risk for Bird Flu in Humans
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t drink raw milk — that’s the message.”

headline: Sometimes U.S. and U.K. Politics Seem in Lock Step. Not This Year.
abstract: In 2016, Britain voted for Brexit and America for Trump, heralding a populist wave. Both countries face pivotal elections this year — but their paths appear to have diverged.
lead_paragraph: A Conservative British prime minister sets the date for a long-awaited vote in the early summer and the United States follows with a momentous presidential election a few months later. It happened in 2016, when Britons voted for Brexit and Americans elected Donald J. Trump, and now it’s happening again.

headline: Xi Jinping’s Recipe for Total Control: An Army of Eyes and Ears
abstract: Reviving a Mao-era surveillance campaign, the authorities are tracking residents, schoolchildren and businesses to forestall any potential unrest.
lead_paragraph: The wall in the police station was covered in sheets of paper, one for every building in the sprawling Beijing apartment complex. Each sheet was further broken down by unit, with names, phone numbers and other information on the residents.

headline: Hundreds Feared Dead in Papua New Guinea Landslide
abstract: Nearly 4,000 people live in villages that were engulfed, a local official said. Unstable debris was complicating search and rescue efforts in a rural part of the Pacific nation.
lead_paragraph: Unstable rubble and debris were complicating search and rescue efforts in rural Papua New Guinea on Saturday, a day after a massive landslide buried villages and killed at least three people. Local officials said the death toll was likely to be at least in the hundreds.

headline: Who’d Want to Give a Commencement Speech Anymore?
abstract: Executive communications experts say the gig is becoming a harder sell for business leaders.
lead_paragraph: Tim Cook has delivered at least seven commencement addresses since becoming the chief executive of Apple. The superstar Taylor Swift, whose concerts have been credited with lifting local economies, addressed New York University’s graduation ceremony in 2022. Bill Gates, Oprah Winfrey, Jamie Dimon — they’ve all given graduation speeches more than once.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Rob Menendez’s Family Name Fueled His Rise. Will It Also Be His Undoing?
abstract: Representative Rob Menendez is facing a serious primary threat at the same time that his father, Senator Robert Menendez, stands trial for corruption.
lead_paragraph: The question at a recent candidate forum was simple enough. What would you do to help move New Jersey past its notorious culture of cronyism and corruption?

headline: How a Horror-Loving Librarian Spends His Sundays
abstract: Rafael Rodriguez works at one of the few libraries open on Sundays in New York City. That means his day is busy, but he still finds time for a little “Mad Men.”
lead_paragraph: The “Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark” series, by Alvin Schwartz, were the first books to have a deep effect on Rafael Rodriguez.

headline: Why N.Y.C. Hotel Rooms Are So Expensive Right Now
abstract: The average hotel room rate in the city is $301 a night, a record. A major reason: One of every five hotels is now a shelter, contributing to a shortage of tourist lodging.
lead_paragraph: In late 2022, as thousands of migrants began to arrive in New York City, city officials scrambled to find places to house them. They quickly found takers: hotels that were still struggling to recover from the pandemic-driven downturn in tourism.

headline: He Threw ‘Spaghetti at the Wall’ for Trump. Now He’s After a Top Job.
abstract: If Donald Trump wins the presidency, Richard Grenell hopes to be secretary of state. But his work raises questions, even from his former boss.
lead_paragraph: Richard Grenell’s quest to be secretary of state in a second Trump administration began late on Election Day in 2020, when the defeated president dispatched loyalists to run shambolic “stop the steal” operations in battleground states.

headline: Why Are Divorce Memoirs Still Stuck in the 1960s?
abstract: Recent best sellers have reached for a familiar feminist credo, one that renounces domestic life for career success.
lead_paragraph: “The only way for a woman, as for a man, to find herself, to know herself as a person, is by creative work of her own,” Betty Friedan wrote in “The Feminine Mystique,” in 1963. Taking a new role as a productive worker is “the way out of the trap,” she added. “There is no other way.”

headline: One of the Deadliest Jobs in Mexico: Running for Office
abstract: The assassination of Gisela Gaytán shocked Mexico. She was among dozens of aspirants for public office killed in recent months.
lead_paragraph: Gisela Gaytán had just arrived at an event on the first day of her mayoral campaign in central Mexico’s industrial heartland when the gunfire broke out.

headline: 10 Artists on Working, Living and Creating Through Loss
abstract: Jesmyn Ward, Bridget Everett, Sigrid Nunez and seven other writers, actors, musicians and filmmakers talk to us about grief — how they’ve experienced it and how it has changed them.
lead_paragraph: When Jesmyn Ward was writing her 2013 book, “Men We Reaped,” she could feel the presence of her brother, who had been killed years earlier by a drunk driver. She still talks to him, as well as to her partner, who died in 2020.

headline: Forget Partying Till the Wee Hours. Newlyweds Want to End Early.
abstract: Last call by 9 p.m. or sooner is becoming the new normal for some weddings.
lead_paragraph: When Betsy and Gabriel Martinez planned their wedding for April 23, 2023, at the Cordelle, an event space in Nashville, they envisioned an enchanted outdoor garden — with plenty of daylight.

headline: U.Va. Faculty Calls for Review of Police Response to Protests
abstract: When the police dismantled a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of Virginia, several professors put their own safety and job security on the line to protect student protesters. Now, faculty members give us a closer look into what happened.
lead_paragraph: When the police dismantled a pro-Palestinian encampment at the University of Virginia, several professors put their own safety and job security on the line to protect student protesters. Now, faculty members give us a closer look into what happened.

headline: An Erotic Story of Love and Obsession in 1960s Amsterdam
abstract: An unlikely romance blooms in Yael van der Wouden’s tricky, remarkable novel, “The Safekeep.”
lead_paragraph: What a quietly remarkable book. I’m afraid I can’t tell you too much about it. Here, though, are some non-spoiling notes on Yael van der Wouden’s debut novel, “The Safekeep,” to help define and recommend it. It’s 1961 in Amsterdam and the book’s protagonist, Isabel, is having dinner with her brothers, Hendrik and Louis, and Louis’s latest girlfriend, Eva.

headline: He Took a Terrible, Horrible, No-Good 800-Mile Hike So You Don’t Have To
abstract: In “A Walk in the Park,” Kevin Fedarko recounts a trek-of-a-lifetime that becomes a nightmare in one of America’s most stunning sites. At least he can laugh about it.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s when he’s extracting drinking water from damp sand with a syringe, trying desperately not to die from dehydration, but there came a point in “A Walk in the Park,” Kevin Fedarko’s memoir about walking the length of the Grand Canyon, that I thought: Wow, this hike is a terrible idea.

headline: 6 Podcasts About the Joys and Terrors of Air Travel
abstract: In this month’s roundup, true stories of air disasters (and why they’re so rare), as well as love letters to life in the skies.
lead_paragraph: It’s a nerve-racking time to be a frequent flier in the United States. Boeing, the nation’s once-proud aircraft manufacturer, has faced a cascading quality crisis since 2018, which escalated this year after a door panel blew off one of the company’s planes mid-flight, prompting multiple F.A.A. investigations and a criminal inquiry from the Justice Department. And it’s not just Boeing — a New York Times investigation last summer found that understaffing and overscheduling led to an alarming number of unreported near misses on American runways.

headline: The Women of Greek Myths Are Finally Talking Back
abstract: Novels that take on the marginalized or vilified women in mythology are flooding bookstores and reigniting questions about who gets to tell these stories, and how.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, the Greek Gorgon Medusa has been cast as a vicious monster, a beastly woman with writhing snakes for hair and a deadly gaze that turns living creatures to stone.

headline: Come On Over, I Just Installed a Pond
abstract: Backyards that feature natural pools trade chlorine for plants, don’t need to be closed for winter and may feature kois with names like Cutie.
lead_paragraph: When Denise Carroll jumps into her pond from its ledge, she swims alongside kois named Cutie, Baby and Jason (names chosen by her two young children).
