lead_paragraph: My family and I have just returned from a weekend in rural Pennsylvania, where we spend every Memorial Day weekend hanging out with good friends, eating enormous platters of grilled meat and veggies, and enjoying the mixed choir of tree frogs and bullfrogs that populate the lake. More reliably than any calendar, that throaty, flirty chorus announces that summer is finally (if unofficially) here.

headline: Memo to Orchestras: Do More Opera
abstract: The Cleveland Orchestra’s staging of Mozart’s “The Magic Flute” was a reminder that ensembles can help fill the gap as opera grows harder to find.
lead_paragraph: It was that rarest of sights when I walked into the Cleveland Orchestra’s hall on Sunday afternoon: a dark curtain drawn across the stage.

headline: North Korean Rocket Carrying Spy Satellite Explodes After Takeoff
abstract: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, has made deploying a fleet of spy satellites one of his country’s latest ​military ambitions.
lead_paragraph: North Korea attempted to put a military reconnaissance satellite into orbit on Monday, the South Korean military said, but the rocket carrying the satellite exploded midair shortly after takeoff, marking the country’s third failed attempt to put a spy satellite into orbit.

headline: Here Comes Manhattanhenge’s 2nd Night: When and Where to Watch
abstract: The annual event brings New Yorkers together to celebrate longer days, warmer weather and epic summer sunsets.
lead_paragraph: A low cap of clouds toyed with New Yorkers on Tuesday as they attempted to take in the first night of the solar spectacle known as Manhattanhenge. On Wednesday evening, many may try to see the event again.

headline: ‘Bluets’ Review: This Maggie Nelson Adaptation Is All About the Vibes
abstract: How do you bring an almost plotless book of elliptical fragments to the stage? The director Katie Mitchell has tried with three actors, four screens and three bottles of whiskey.
lead_paragraph: When the Royal Court Theater in London announced it was staging an adaptation of Maggie Nelson’s prose poem memoir “Bluets,” my first reaction was head-scratching surprise. This largely plotless book, in which elliptical fragments of autobiography are entwined with meditations on the cultural history of the color blue and loosely coalesce around the theme of depression, doesn’t exactly scream theater.

headline: N.J. Officials Briefly Close Popular Boardwalk, Citing ‘Civil Unrest’
abstract: The officials offered few details as to why they declared a state of emergency in Wildwood on one of the busiest weekends of the year.
lead_paragraph: The City of Wildwood, N.J., briefly closed its boardwalk late Sunday, citing “unruly teen crowds” at the bustling beachside attraction during the busy Memorial Day weekend but offering few details about what prompted the decision.

headline: Shooting Near Rafah Border Crossing Kills a Member of Egypt’s Security Forces
abstract: The Israeli military also reported a shooting at the border, where it is fighting Palestinian militants.
lead_paragraph: A member of Egypt’s security forces was killed near the Rafah border crossing with the Gaza Strip and an investigation is underway, an Egyptian army spokesman said on Monday, after the Israeli military reported a shooting on the border.

headline: Trump Elevates a Conservative ‘Warrior’ on Education
abstract: Byron Donalds is best known as a Trump defender and potential vice-presidential pick. But in Florida, the congressman and his wife made a name — and a business — in the charter school movement.
lead_paragraph: In early 2021, Representative Byron Donalds, Republican of Florida, and his wife, Erika, took the stage at an event hosted by the Truth & Liberty Coalition, a group that pushes to inject Christianity into public schools and other institutions and whose leader has described homosexuality as Satan’s work.

headline: The Unlikely Women Fighting for Abortion Rights
abstract: The end of Roe has turned women who terminated pregnancies for medical reasons into a political force.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, many women who had abortions because of catastrophic fetal diagnoses told their stories only privately. Grieving pregnancies they dearly wanted and fearing the stigma of abortion, they sought the closely guarded comfort of online communities identified by the way many doctors had described the procedure — TFMR, or “termination for medical reasons.”

headline: Biden Marks Memorial Day With Message About Freedom as Trump Lashes Out
abstract: An earlier message from Donald J. Trump was more traditional, but it was quickly followed by one wishing a happy Memorial Day to “Human Scum.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden paid tribute to veterans who died in America’s wars at Arlington National Cemetery on Monday, hailing them as “a link in the chain of honor” who deserve recognition for protecting the nation’s democracy.

headline: Gazans Look Through Ashes After Israeli Strike on Rafah
abstract: Displaced Palestinians mourned the dead and sifted through the debris of a tent camp in Rafah, Gaza, that was devastated by an Israeli strike.
lead_paragraph: Displaced Palestinians mourned the dead and sifted through the debris of a tent camp in Rafah, Gaza, that was devastated by an Israeli strike.

headline: Voices Carry at La MaMa, but Only a Few Rise Above the Din
abstract: The La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival 2024 featured a high ratio of talking to dancing.
lead_paragraph: “You’ll hear our voices, and you’ll see us dance,” the choreographer Arthur Avilés said on Thursday. He was introducing “Naked Vanguard,” his half of one of three double bills in the second week of this year’s La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival. But he could have been speaking about most of the other works sharing the week. The ratio of talking to dancing was especially high, as if to make the low-budget avant-garde more welcoming.

headline: Museum Workers Walk Out, Describing Exhibit as Aligned With Zionism
abstract: The Wing Luke Museum in Seattle temporarily closed after employees criticized an exhibition, saying it wrongly conflated anti-Zionism with antisemitism.
lead_paragraph: The Wing Luke Museum in Seattle remained closed on Monday afternoon, nearly a week after employees walked off the job to protest an exhibition that includes language they believe frames “Palestinian liberation and anti-Zionism as antisemitism.”

headline: World Leaders Denounce Deadly Strike in Rafah
abstract: They called for an investigation into the attack, which Gazan authorities say killed 45 people, and intensified the pressure for Israel to end its military campaign in southern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike on the southern Gaza city of Rafah that killed dozens of displaced Palestinians drew widespread international condemnation Monday, with world leaders calling for an investigation into the attack and intensifying the pressure for Israel to end its military campaign in the south.

headline: No, Americans Are Not Completely Stupid About Inflation
abstract: People may not fully understand the economy, but their feelings about it contain some wisdom.
lead_paragraph: Stefanie Stantcheva was 11 years old in 1997 when annual inflation in Bulgaria, the country from which she and her family had emigrated, surpassed 2,000 percent. “The episode helped shape her eventual decision to study economics,” according to a profile in the International Monetary Fund’s Finance & Development magazine.

headline: The Delivery Business Shows Why Unions Are Struggling to Expand
abstract: The Teamsters union has made little headway in organizing workers at Amazon and FedEx despite wage and other gains it secured at UPS last year.
lead_paragraph: Last year, two unions representing workers at three large automakers and UPS negotiated new labor contracts that included big raises and other gains. Leaders of the unions — the United Automobile Workers and the Teamsters — hoped the wins would help them organize workers across their industry.

headline: Severe Storms and Tornadoes Cause Destruction in Several States
abstract: Severe weather hit several parts of the United States over the weekend, killing more than 20 people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power.
lead_paragraph: Severe weather hit several parts of the United States over the weekend, killing more than 20 people and leaving hundreds of thousands without power.

headline: ‘General Hospital’ Actor Killed in Shooting in Los Angeles
abstract: Johnny Wactor was fatally shot when he interrupted a person who was stealing his vehicle’s catalytic converter, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Wactor, an actor best known for his role in “General Hospital,” was shot and killed on Saturday, reports said, amid what his family described as an attempted theft of a catalytic converter in Los Angeles.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Netanyahu Calls Rafah Deaths a ‘Tragic Accident’
abstract: Plus, the toll from the Papua New Guinea landslide
lead_paragraph: The day after an airstrike killed dozens of displaced Palestinians in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, called the deaths a “tragic accident” and accused Hamas of hiding among the general population.

headline: Bill Walton, N.B.A. Hall of Famer and Broadcasting Star, Dies at 71
abstract: He won championships in high school, college (U.C.L.A.) and the pros (Trail Blazers and Celtics) before turning to TV as a talkative game analyst in the college ranks.
lead_paragraph: Bill Walton, a center whose extraordinary passing and rebounding skills helped him win two national college championships with U.C.L.A. and one each with the Portland Trail Blazers and Boston Celtics of the N.B.A., and who overcame a stutter to become a loquacious commentator, died on Monday at his home in San Diego. He was 71.

headline: Stanley Goldstein, Who Helped Make CVS a Pharmacy Giant, Dies at 89
abstract: The small chain that he, a brother and a third partner opened in 1963 had become the nation’s largest by the time he retired as its chief executive three decades later.
lead_paragraph: Stanley P. Goldstein, who in the early 1960s helped start a retail chain named Consumer Value Stores, which, after shortening its name to CVS — because, he said, fewer letters meant cheaper signs — grew into the largest drugstore chain in the United States, died on Tuesday at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 89.

headline: Facing Global Outrage, Netanyahu Calls Civilian Deaths in Rafah Strike ‘Tragic Accident’
abstract: The strike on Sunday, which Israeli officials said targeted two Hamas leaders taking cover near a civilian encampment, ignited a fire that killed 45 people, according to the Gazan authorities.
lead_paragraph: With international condemnation mounting, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Monday that the killing of dozens of people a day earlier at a camp for displaced Palestinians in Rafah was “a tragic accident,” but gave no sign of curbing the Israeli offensive in the southern Gaza city.

headline: Ransomware Group Claims Responsibility for Christie’s Hack
abstract: The hacking group RansomHub is threatening to release “sensitive personal information” about the auction house’s clients.
lead_paragraph: A hacker group called RansomHub said it was behind the cyberattack that hit the Christie’s website just days before its marquee spring sales began, forcing the auction house to resort to alternatives to online bidding.

headline: The Stench of Climate Change Denial
abstract: What overflowing septic tanks tell us about the future.
lead_paragraph: This may sound a bit weird, but when I think about my adolescent years, I sometimes associate them with the faint smell of sewage.

headline: Trump Lawyers Assail Limited Gag Order Request in Documents Case
abstract: The latest battle over what the former president can say about a continuing legal case came after he falsely suggested that F.B.I. agents were authorized to shoot him when they searched Mar-a-Lago.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyers on Monday assailed a request by federal prosecutors to limit what he could say about a new flare-up in a case accusing him of illegally retaining classified documents after leaving office.

headline: ‘I’ve Never Seen Anything Like It.’ Tornado Devastates Arkansas Town.
abstract: Rogers, Ark., was one of many places hit hard by the rash of storms over Memorial Day weekend across the South.
lead_paragraph: Melisa Swearingen woke up early on Sunday morning as a tornado bore down on her home in the northwestern corner of Arkansas. As she raced down the stairs with her toddler, she looked out the window and saw a 40-foot tree falling toward the house.

headline: Call Me Your Darling Angel
abstract: This Tuesday debut puzzle is full of fun facts.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Quote of the Day: Manhattanhenge Is Nigh, So Get the Camera Ready and Watch Out for Traffic
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I think of it as astronomy in your face.”

headline: Leaflet by Leaflet, a Few Aging Activists Fight India’s Tide of Bigotry
abstract: As politicians stoke religious hatred online, these veterans of social causes deliver their messages in person: “Talk to each other. Don’t let anyone divide you.”
lead_paragraph: One recent morning, Roop Rekha Verma, an 80-year-old peace activist and former university leader, walked through a north Indian neighborhood prone to sectarian strife and parked herself near a tea shop.

headline: Business-First Hong Kong Now Comes With a Catch: Beijing Politics
abstract: The city, promised some autonomy by China, is trying to move on from a security law imposed by Beijing. Companies are learning that’s not always possible.
lead_paragraph: Doing business in Hong Kong increasingly comes with a new risk: the political cost of upsetting Beijing.

headline: South Africa’s Young Democracy Leaves Its Young Voters Disillusioned
abstract: We spoke to South Africans who grew up in the three decades since the country overthrew apartheid and held its first free election about their lives and plans to vote — or not — in this week's pivotal election.
lead_paragraph: At the dawn of South Africa’s democracy after the fall of the racist apartheid government, millions lined up before sunrise to cast their ballots in the country’s first free and fair election in 1994.

headline: How the Tree Lobster Escaped Extinction
abstract: The Lord Howe Island stick insect vanished from its home, but an effort at zoos in San Diego and Melbourne highlights the possibilities and challenges of conserving invertebrate animals.
lead_paragraph: The feisty Lord Howe Island stick insect crawling on the gloved hand of Kyle Kassel, a keeper at the San Diego Zoo, had no idea that he shouldn’t exist. The intrepid insect, nicknamed a tree lobster because some grow to eight inches, seemed determined to prevent me from snapping a good picture as he raced about Mr. Kassel’s hands like a dog with the zoomies.

headline: London Moves to Revive Its Reputation as a Financial Hub
abstract: As fears have grown that the city is losing its attractiveness for publicly traded businesses, Britain’s government is making changes to bring them back.
lead_paragraph: Shein, the online retail giant founded in China, had grand ambitions to go public in New York. But as relations between Washington and Beijing soured, the ultrafast fashion company began taking a closer look at a backup plan across the Atlantic.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: We’re covering Israel’s offensive in Rafah and the death toll from the Papua New Guinea landslide.
lead_paragraph: The day after an airstrike killed dozens of displaced Palestinians in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, called the deaths a “tragic accident” and accused Hamas of hiding among the general population.

headline: The Story of South Africa No Longer Makes Sense
abstract: The country is in the midst of another complex transformation.
lead_paragraph: The ceremony went virtually unnoticed. On an overcast April day in South Africa’s administrative capital, Pretoria, President Cyril Ramaphosa delivered a lackluster speech commemorating the end of white-minority rule in South Africa. When Nelson Mandela was inaugurated as the country’s first Black president, the skies were sunny with hope. Thirty years later, Mr. Ramaphosa’s enervated display against a gloomy backdrop was symbolic of decline. The African National Congress, Mr. Ramaphosa’s party, has been politically dominant since the country’s first democratic vote in 1994. In the general elections on Wednesday, it may lose its parliamentary majority for the first time.

headline: Word of the Day: amiable
abstract: This word has appeared in 60 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word amiable has appeared in 60 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 12 in the obituary “Olga Murray, Who Changed the Lives of Children in Nepal, Dies at 98” by Richard Sandomir:

headline: A Deadline Approaches on a Campaign Against Plastic Waste
abstract: The New York State Legislature is reviewing a bill that could reduce the state’s use of plastic packaging by a whopping 50 percent.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll learn more out about a bill that could reduce New York State’s use of plastic packaging by a whopping 50 percent. We’ll also look at why a New Jersey town decided to declare a state of emergency in the middle of the holiday weekend, and we’ll meet a legal team that is suing Elon Musk.

headline: Congestion Pricing Could Bring Cleaner Air. But Maybe Not for Everyone.
abstract: Officials expect New York City’s new tolling system to reduce air pollution, as well as carbon emissions. The impact may be uneven.
lead_paragraph: When congestion pricing takes effect in New York City next month, officials say it will create an array of benefits: The system’s tolls will generate revenue for improving mass transit while prompting some drivers to avoid Manhattan, potentially reducing traffic and air pollution, as well as carbon emissions that contribute to climate change.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: When Reporters Need a Voice, Sometimes They Ask the Crowd
abstract: Reader callouts are like fliers on a digital bulletin board. They help journalists find sources — and discover stories they didn’t know they were looking for.
lead_paragraph: Every day, New York Times reporters knock on doors and make phone calls to find stories. They spend hours, weeks and months on old-fashioned, boots-on-the-ground reporting. But a reader callout — an online form designed to elicit responses from certain people — can do what no other tool in the reporting tool belt can. Like a flier on a bulletin board or an advertisement that asks “Has this happened to you?,” a callout helps reporters reach many more people at once and find just the right source for their story.

headline: Cyclone Remal Uproots Trees, Rips Down Power Lines in Bangladesh
abstract: People braved high winds and heavy rain to clear debris as the storm tore through the region.
lead_paragraph: People braved high winds and heavy rain to clear debris as the storm tore through the region.

headline: Cyclone Remal Tears Through India and Bangladesh, Killing at Least 23
abstract: The storm, the first of the season, hit the South Asian countries after weeks of intense heat. Millions were left without power.
lead_paragraph: At least 23 people were killed and millions were left without power after Cyclone Remal, the first tropical storm of the season, hit Bangladesh and neighboring eastern India on Sunday.

headline: Climate Change Added a Month’s Worth of Extra-Hot Days in Past Year
abstract: Since last May, the average person experienced 26 more days of abnormal warmth than they would have without global warming, a new analysis found.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year of record-shattering warmth, the average person on Earth experienced 26 more days of abnormally high temperatures than they otherwise would have, were it not for human-induced climate change, scientists said Tuesday.

headline: Ellis Island
abstract: In the early 1970s, two high school filmmakers ventured out in a rowboat to make a 16-millimeter film about an abandoned space nearby: Ellis Island.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, two high school filmmakers ventured out in a rowboat to make a 16-millimeter film about an abandoned space nearby: Ellis Island.

headline: In 1974, Two Film Students Rowed to Ellis Island. Here’s What They Captured.
abstract: In the early 1970s, two high school filmmakers ventured out in a rowboat to make a 16 mm film about an abandoned space nearby: Ellis Island.
lead_paragraph: Ellis Island in New York Harbor served as the principal point of entry for immigrants arriving in the United States from 1892 through 1924, and was used for detention and deportation until its closing in 1954. All in all, over 12 million immigrants passed through its halls. But by 1974, when we were students and made the short documentary above, it was in decay.

headline: Want to Succeed as an Artist? Click Here.
abstract: With a rising number of artists vying for a limited number of galleries and grants, arts professionals are pivoting to careers as coaches. But can they help people profit from their talents?
lead_paragraph: From 2005 to 2017, Paddy Johnson ran a respected art-world blog, Art F City. “Fiercely Independent,” began its tagline. But art criticism is a precarious business. She tried teaching as an adjunct, but that wasn’t much better.

headline: The Most Influential Jeans Guy You’ve Never Heard Of
abstract: Benjamin Talley Smith may well have made the jeans in your closet. And your friend’s closet. And your friend’s friends’.
lead_paragraph: One overcast Sunday morning, Benjamin Talley Smith, an apple-cheeked 45-year-old with a thing for a Canadian tuxedo, was at the Rose Bowl flea market in Los Angeles shopping for jeans.

headline: A 20-Minute Intense Workout That’s Easy on Your Joints
abstract: HIIT routines are typically both high intensity and high impact. But you can still get the hard work while being easy on your body.
lead_paragraph: High-intensity workouts are designed to be hard. The whole point of repeatedly going all out for 30 seconds or a minute at a time is to get the maximum cardiovascular exercise in the least amount of time. But that doesn’t mean these workouts need to be punishing for your joints.

headline: Elon Musk Dominates Space Launch. Rivals Are Calling Foul.
abstract: At a time when the U.S. government is concerned about its reliance on a mercurial billionaire for access to space, new competitors say Elon Musk’s SpaceX is using tactics intended to squash them.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk aggressively elbowed his way into the space launch business over the past two decades, combining engineering genius and an entrepreneurial drive with a demand that the U.S. government stop favoring the big, slow-moving contractors that had long dominated the industry.

headline: A Manhattan Apartment Full of Salvaged Finds
abstract: A hands-on renovation during the early part of the pandemic produced a place to call home that doubles as a home office.
lead_paragraph: For years, Elena Colombo loved the live-work studio she shared with her partner, Mark Lavelle, in an industrial section of Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. She had a workshop and office where she could tinker, and was near the artisans and vendors that her company, FireFeatures, needed to make large-scale fire bowls and sculptures.

headline: Divorced, Disheveled and Hiking Toward Love
abstract: In David Nicholls’s “You Are Here,” a boggy trek through the English countryside becomes an unlikely impetus for midlife romance.
lead_paragraph: David Nicholls’s captivating new novel takes place almost entirely during a guided, days-long walk through the English countryside, past perilous crags, moors and villages with names like Buttermere, Honister Pass and Bolton-on-Swale. In lesser hands, “You Are Here” might be a literal slog, but Nicholls has fashioned an ideal structure for an affectingly hard-won romance, a genre he has honed as the author of many best sellers, including the much loved and repeatedly adapted “One Day.”

headline: War-Weary Iraqis Feel for Gaza, but Fear Spread of the Conflict
abstract: Iraqis want to help Palestinians but say they are still recovering from their own wars and fear playing host to a proxy fight between Iran and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Iraqis have known the bitter taste of war so intimately and frequently over the past 40 years that they say they can feel viscerally the suffering of Palestinians in Gaza. They remember the dreaded whistling of a shell before impact, the fear of a knock at the door bringing word of a loved one’s loss, the stench of blood drying on concrete.

headline: We Can Turn a River in Maine Into a Paradise for Salmon
abstract: Currently, the fish are blocked from their most important spawning tributary.
lead_paragraph: In his 1937 book, “Kennebec: Cradle of Americans,” the poet Robert Tristram Coffin called Maine’s sprawling river a “paradise for fish.” But pollution and dams that block spawning runs for Atlantic salmon, sturgeon and shad put an end to that world.

headline: If A.I. Can Do Your Job, Maybe It Can Also Replace Your C.E.O.
abstract: Chief executives are vulnerable to the same forces buffeting their employees. Leadership is important, but so is efficiency — and cost-cutting.
lead_paragraph: As artificial intelligence programs shake up the office, potentially making millions of jobs obsolete, one group of perpetually stressed workers seems especially vulnerable.

headline: Excavating Jerry Garcia’s Crucial Bluegrass Roots
abstract: In 1964, the guitarist took a road trip, hoping to become Bill Monroe’s banjo player. The journey, and his longtime love of the genre, shaped the Grateful Dead.
lead_paragraph: Just off the lobby of the Bluegrass Music Hall of Fame & Museum is the “picking room” — a cozy, glass-enclosed corner where visitors are encouraged to grab any of the guitars, banjos and fiddles hanging on the wood-paneled walls and play. Located on the Ohio River 35 miles northwest of Rosine, the small farming community that produced the bluegrass pioneer Bill Monroe, the museum’s readily available instruments and neighborly spirit are no surprise.

headline: 100 Easy Summer Recipes for Right Now
abstract: Breezy and adaptable, most of these dishes can be on the table in 30 minutes or less.
lead_paragraph: More fun, less drudgery. That’s my goal for the summer — and specifically for my summer cooking. In my dreams, I’m whisking together a vinaigrette in a seaside cottage with a big breezy kitchen and a farm stand down the road (think Diane Keaton’s place in “Something’s Gotta Give”). While that’s not the reality for most of us — myself included — you can still welcome that relaxed sensibility in the recipes you cook and how you cook them (barefoot, good music playing, windows thrown open — or the A.C. on full blast).

headline: The Man Behind the Effortless, Viral Grooves
abstract: Shay Latukolan, who has worked with Jungle and Childish Gambino, creates choreography so infectious that everyone thinks they can dance along.
lead_paragraph: Dancers sometimes talk about finding the pocket — a kind of flow state where rhythm and movement are so perfectly married that the dancing is not just on the music, but in it.

headline: Feeling Lonely? Grouchy? Murderous? There’s a Spell for That.
abstract: In “Cunning Folk,” Tabitha Stanmore takes us back to a time when the use of “service magic” was an everyday — and underground — practice.
lead_paragraph: If Siri, embodied as a real-live woman, had popped up in England a few centuries ago with access to her present range of information, she might have been hanged for her helpfulness. The services the virtual assistant can provide — geolocation, weather forecasts, image capture, finding lost objects and (no small point) revealing the dates of the deaths of kings — strike us today as merely convenient; but, to the pre-modern mind, they would have seemed suspicious, not to mention possibly illegal.

headline: Sun, Sun, Sun. Here It Comes.
abstract: Spring’s warmth is a flirt, but New Yorkers are ready for the season’s unpredictability.
lead_paragraph: The shift to New York City spring follows a familiar pattern: skittishly unpredictable weather leading to uncertain modes of dress. But with the rise in temperature, the style of the city often blooms along with it. It’s marvelous to behold; discarding heavy wools for lighter cottons, short skirts and even shorter sleeves. One of the big standouts is the white maxi skirt, a signal of a lightness of mood and fresh possibilities.

headline: Jaap van Zweden’s Brief, Fraught Time Atop the New York Philharmonic
abstract: He arrived on a mission to reshape the ensemble as its music director. Now, as he departs, he’s still making sense of his pandemic-interrupted tenure.
lead_paragraph: On a balmy spring morning, after a breakfast of coffee and plain yogurt at a luxury Manhattan hotel, Jaap van Zweden grabbed his bag of conducting batons and scores by Mozart and Gubaidulina and set out for Lincoln Center through the wilds of Central Park.

headline: Ted Cruz Has Some Strong Opinions About College Sports
abstract: Money is changing college sports in big and small ways. Jane Coaston interviews Ted Cruz about how some conservatives want to regulate college athletics.
lead_paragraph: College sports bring in billions of dollars in revenue every year, but until very recently virtually none of it went to athletes. In 2021, the Supreme Court ruled in N.C.A.A. v. Alston that student athletes should be able to profit from their names, images or likenesses, known as NIL. As Justice Brett Kavanaugh noted in a concurring opinion, the N.C.A.A.’s policies against permitting athletes to profit from their labor could be considered a violation of antitrust laws, writing, “Nowhere else in America can businesses get away with agreeing not to pay their workers a fair-market rate on the theory that their product is defined by not paying their workers a fair-market rate.” Since then, in practice, NIL has included two common types of compensation: endorsement deals for athletes, but also more direct payments, which usually come from college-affiliated collectives supported by donors in exchange for appearances at events, social media posts or other promotion.

headline: Eyeing Trump, but on the Fence: How Tuned-Out Voters Could Decide 2024
abstract: Politically disengaged Americans are increasingly Trump-curious, but President Biden has a shot at winning some of them back. Reaching them in a changed media environment will be his challenge.
lead_paragraph: Joe Perez is exactly the type of voter President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump are fighting over: A 22-year-old Hispanic man in Las Vegas who grew up leaning Republican, he also supports abortion rights and was turned off by the Capitol rioters on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Will Roy Cohn Save Donald Trump’s Hide One Last Time?
abstract: The wily lawyer taught Mr. Trump how to manipulate people and the law, and it’s all on display in a Lower Manhattan courtroom.
lead_paragraph: Sitting still for hours on end in a chilly, drab courtroom, unable to speak his mind, forced to listen to people say objectionable things about him, Donald Trump at a defense table in Manhattan’s Criminal Court may seem as far from his usual domain — the cheering crowds and the trappings of wealth — as could be imagined.

headline: Melinda French Gates: The Enemies of Progress Play Offense. I Want to Help Even the Match.
abstract: A philanthropist is focusing on gender issues around the world, including abortion access in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago, I received this piece of advice: “Set your own agenda, or someone else will set it for you.” I’ve carried those words with me ever since.

headline: Carbon Offsets, a Much-Criticized Climate Tool, Get Federal Guidelines
abstract: The new principles aim to define ‘high-integrity’ offsets amid concerns that current practices often don’t cut greenhouse gas emissions as claimed.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Tuesday laid out for the first time a set of broad government guidelines around the use of carbon offsets in an attempt to shore up confidence in a method for tackling global warming that has faced growing criticism.

headline: The Untold Story of the Network That Took Down Roe v. Wade
abstract: A conservative Christian coalition’s plan to end the federal right to abortion began just days after Trump’s 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: It happened almost by accident, over cocktails. Exactly the kind of accident that Leonard Leo intended to happen at his Federalist Society’s annual conference — a three-day gathering of the conservative tribe and a strategy session for right-wing lawyers, officials and judges that drew both big names and those who had lower profiles but were no less ambitious.

headline: Storm Kills at Least 1 in Texas, Where Power Could Be Out for Days
abstract: Half a million customers were without power after hail the size of golf balls and strong winds hit Texas, where flood warnings were active early Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: At least one person was killed after another round of powerful storms brought rain, high winds and large hail to Texas on Tuesday, causing widespread damage, knocking out power to half a million customers and halting flights at Dallas Fort Worth International Airport.

headline: Trump Leans Into an Outlaw Image as His Criminal Trial Concludes
abstract: Preparing for a potential verdict in Manhattan, the former president has increasingly aligned himself with fellow defendants and people convicted of crimes.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, Donald J. Trump rallied alongside two rap artists accused of conspiracy to commit murder. He promised to commute the sentence of a notorious internet drug dealer. And he appeared backstage with another rap artist who has pleaded guilty to assault for punching a female fan.

headline: Three European Countries Formally Recognize Palestinian Statehood
abstract: The moves are a rebuke to Israel, who is the face of mounting international anger over the country’s military offensive in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Three European nations formally recognized an independent Palestinian state on Tuesday, drawing the ire of Israel as it continued to press its military offensive in Gaza.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,075, May 29, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Trump Criminal Trial Closing Arguments, and Outcry Over Rafah Strike
abstract: Plus, concerns about the dominance of SpaceX.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: OpenAI Says It Has Begun Training a New Flagship A.I. Model
abstract: The advanced A.I. system would succeed GPT-4, which powers ChatGPT. The company has also created a new safety committee to address A.I.’s risks.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI said on Tuesday that it had begun training a new flagship artificial intelligence model that would succeed the GPT-4 technology that drives its popular online chatbot, ChatGPT.

headline: The Alitos and Their Flags
abstract: The saga of a Supreme Court justice, his wife and two symbols adopted by people campaigning to overturn the result of the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: The discovery that an upside-down American flag — a symbol adopted by the campaign to overturn the 2020 election result — had flown at the home of Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. elicited concerns from politicians, legal scholars and others. And then came news of a second flag.

headline: What We Know About the Papua New Guinea Landslide
abstract: Nearly five days after the disaster hit a remote section of the country, officials have started evacuating residents. But the scale of the death toll remains uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Nearly five days after a landslide devastated a remote section of Papua New Guinea, officials in the Pacific Island nation have begun evacuating residents, because the area remains unsafe.

headline: Why Lawmakers Are Brawling and People Are Protesting in Taiwan
abstract: Supporters of President Lai Ching-te are protesting legislative amendments introduced by the opposition that would limit his authority.
lead_paragraph: Opposition lawmakers in Taiwan pushed through measures on Tuesday that could challenge the powers of the new president, Lai Ching-te, defying tens of thousands of his supporters who poured into the streets in recent days in protest.

headline: China’s Role in Ukraine
abstract: Russia has been able to keep paying for the war, despite sanctions. How? U.S. officials point to Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few weeks, a Russian blitz has claimed more than a dozen villages in northeast Ukraine, near the country’s second-largest city. This summer, Russia will likely continue its offensive push in the country’s east.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 353, May 29, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Calls Mount to Let Ukraine Strike Russia With Western Weapons
abstract: The U.S. and other allies have banned Ukraine from firing Western weapons into Russia. Kyiv says that has handcuffed its ability to prevent cross-border attacks.
lead_paragraph: Western nations are stepping up their calls to allow attacks on Russian territory using weapons that they have sent the Ukrainian military — an issue that is taking on greater urgency as Russia builds up troops on the border in preparation for a possible offensive.

headline: Big Oil’s Winning Streak Forces Activist Investors to Regroup
abstract: Climate-focused shareholders are rethinking their tactics ahead of this week’s annual meetings at Exxon Mobil and Chevron.
lead_paragraph: Months of tensions between oil majors and activist investors could reach a boiling point at the annual meetings of Exxon Mobil and Chevron Wednesday, as the U.S. giants pump record levels of crude and sit on bumper profits.

headline: Do You Know the Manhattan Locations of These Children’s Books?
abstract: This urban island is home to a huge number of popular books for younger readers. Try this short quiz to see how many you recognize.
lead_paragraph: This urban island is home to a huge number of popular books for younger readers. Try this short quiz to see how many you recognize.

headline: Trump’s Trial Has Entered Its Final Stages. Here’s What Comes Next.
abstract: In the seventh week of trial, closing arguments will be made and the jury will start deliberations.
lead_paragraph: Closing arguments start Tuesday in the Manhattan hush-money trial of Donald J. Trump, signaling the final stages of the first criminal trial of an American president. Both prosecutors and defense lawyers will make their final cases for his guilt or innocence before jurors deliberate Mr. Trump’s fate.

headline: More of the Best Books About California
abstract: We’re adding love letters and cautionary tales to our Golden State reading list.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite books about Los Angeles is Eve Babitz’s witty collection of essays “Slow Days, Fast Company.” The first time I read it, a few years ago, while living in L.A., I was struck by how a book published in 1977 — telling bold and sharply observed stories of L.A.’s bohemian artist class — could still ring true so many years later.

headline: A Final Graduation Requirement: Making Sense of Protest
abstract: As students in Columbia’s class of 2024 received their diplomas, many of them were grappling with what intense activism on campus would mean to their futures.
lead_paragraph: Standing on the stage at Radio City Music Hall, Mariame Sissoko began to speak in a voice trembling, ever so slightly. Growing up in Philadelphia, Sissoko was outspoken, a high achiever, captain of the high school debate team. In other words, just the sort of person who would go to Barnard College, run for student government and wind up giving a graduation speech before an audience of 4,700 university officials, classmates and parents.

headline: Closing Arguments Are Coming in Trump’s Trial. Here’s How They Work.
abstract: Each side will have an opportunity to summarize its case before the jury begins to deliberate.
lead_paragraph: After five grueling weeks of testimony, prosecutors and defense lawyers will have one final chance to sway the 12 jurors in the Manhattan criminal trial of Donald J. Trump: closing arguments.

headline: Adam Neumann Gives Up on Buying Back WeWork
abstract: The co-founder of the shared-office company, who stepped down under pressure before the firm went bankrupt, announced an audacious takeover bid this year.
lead_paragraph: Adam Neumann has officially admitted defeat in his quest to buy back WeWork, ending his bid to acquire the co-working company, which he helped found in 2010 and built into a global enterprise valued at $47 billion before it fell into bankruptcy last year.

headline: When Roller-Skating Nuns Came to the Opera House
abstract: The choreographer Florentina Holzinger’s shows feature circus performers and abundant nudity. Now, she’s bringing her experimental approach to opera.
lead_paragraph: In a rehearsal last week at the Mecklenburg State Theater in Schwerin, northeastern Germany, Fleshpiece, a shirtless performer with tattoos and purple hair, strode to the front of the main stage and delivered an impassioned monologue.

headline: Pope Apologizes After Reports That He Used an Anti-Gay Slur
abstract: Francis’ remark came as he spoke against admitting gay men to seminaries during what was supposed to be a closed-door meeting with Italian bishops last week.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican said on Tuesday that Pope Francis “extends his apologies” after reports that he used an offensive slang word referring to gay men at what was intended to be a private meeting with 250 Italian bishops last week.

headline: Lawyers to Plastics Makers: Prepare for ‘Astronomical’ PFAS Lawsuits
abstract: At an industry presentation about dangerous “forever chemicals,” lawyers predicted a wave of lawsuits that could dwarf asbestos litigation, audio from the event revealed.
lead_paragraph: The defense lawyer minced no words as he addressed a room full of plastic-industry executives. Prepare for a wave of lawsuits​ with​ potentially “astronomical” costs​. Speaking at a conference earlier this year, the lawyer, Brian Gross, said the coming litigation could “dwarf anything related to asbestos,” one of the most sprawling corporate-liability battles in United States history.

headline: Two More ‘Succession’ Actors Are Broadway Bound, in ‘Job’
abstract: Peter Friedman and Sydney Lemmon will star in the two-hander, a psychological thriller that previously found success downtown.
lead_paragraph: “Job,” a two-character thriller about a psychological evaluation going awry, started small, with a run last year at SoHo Playhouse. Word-of-mouth was good, the New York Times review was positive and sales were strong, so early this year it transferred for another Off Broadway run at the Connelly Theater in the East Village.

headline: The 15 Most Unforgettable Looks From Cannes
abstract: The festival is over, but the style is here to stay.
lead_paragraph: The Cannes Festival jury led by Greta Gerwig announced its winners this weekend, including the Palme d’Or for “Anora,” a comedy from the American filmmaker Sean Baker about a sex worker who marries the son of a Russian oligarch. The ceremony concluded 10 full days filled with movies and long ovations, news conferences peppered with politics, a filmmaker’s return, women-led films that caused a stir, a president’s origin story and, of course, canine stars.

headline: Say Hello to Our Summer 100
abstract: The 100 recipes (shrimp scampi with tomatoes and corn, watermelon chaat, perfect peach cobbler) to cook on repeat all summer.
lead_paragraph: Summer is the best of time of year to cook and eat, by far, with its hissing grills, saltwater-seasoned beach picnics, stone fruit dripping with juice, vine vegetables brimming with flavor and pastel cones of melting ice cream. I love it.

headline: I.R.S. Failed to Police Puerto Rico Tax Break, Whistle-Blower Says
abstract: An insider accused the agency of failing to scrutinize a lucrative tax break in Puerto Rico designed to lure wealthy Americans to the island.
lead_paragraph: For the past decade, thousands of wealthy Americans have been flocking to Puerto Rico to take advantage of a tax break that can cut their tax bills to zero. For nearly as long, there have been allegations that the benefit enables multimillionaires to avoid paying what they owe when they reap big investment profits.

headline: Robert De Niro, as Biden Surrogate, Says Trump ‘Absolutely’ Should Go to Jail
abstract: Seeking to troll Donald Trump outside his Manhattan trial, the Biden campaign held a news conference with the actor and two former Capitol Police officers. Mr. De Niro veered off script.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s campaign, after more than a year of studiously avoiding direct comments about Donald J. Trump’s legal problems, on Tuesday dispatched the actor Robert De Niro to the Manhattan courthouse where the former president’s first criminal trial is wrapping up.

headline: Georgia’s Ruling Party Secures a Contentious Law on Foreign Influence
abstract: The Parliament, controlled by the Georgian Dream party, overrode a presidential veto of a bill critics say could undermine the country’s efforts to join the European Union.
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s Parliament overrode a presidential veto to give final approval on Tuesday evening to a contentious bill that has plunged the country into a political crisis and threatened to derail the pro-Western aspirations of many Georgians in favor of closer ties with Russia.

headline: 2 Louisiana Inmates Still at Large After Escaping Through 8-Inch Gap
abstract: The two were among four whose escape went undetected for hours over the weekend. Two of the escapees were returned to jail after being found in a dumpster, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Four men were able to escape from Tangipahoa Parish Jail in Louisiana over the weekend because of an eight-inch gap and a lack of oversight at the facility, the authorities said. Two of the men were still at large as of Tuesday night, while the other two had been found hiding in a dumpster, the police said.

headline: Taylor Swift Prevails Over Billie Eilish for a Fifth Week at No. 1
abstract: In a tight battle that had fans hustling to support their favorite star, “The Tortured Poets Department” outsold “Hit Me Hard and Soft.”
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift holds the No. 1 spot on Billboard’s latest album chart for a fifth consecutive week, after an intense contest with Billie Eilish in which both stars released a blizzard of “versions” of their LPs to lure fans.

headline: Throngs Waited Through the Weekend for Courtroom Seats. Few Got Them.
abstract: Most members of the public who tried to see closing arguments in the first trial of an American president walked away disappointed Monday.
lead_paragraph: Erika Del Priore took a short “disco nap” Sunday night and was in line for the Trump trial at 1:30 a.m. Monday.  Joining her at 2 a.m. was Jennifer Weinstein, whom she had befriended earlier this month on another all-night line wait. Behind them was John Lamb, a Montana farmer who traveled all night and arrived at 4:30 a.m.

headline: BuzzFeed Clashes With Vivek Ramaswamy
abstract: The former G.O.P. presidential candidate, who has invested in BuzzFeed, believes the company needs to pivot. He wants to see commentators like Tucker Carlson in its lineup.
lead_paragraph: BuzzFeed’s newest activist investor, the former Republican presidential candidate Vivek Ramaswamy, wants the company to consider moves like hiring the former Fox News host Tucker Carlson and the N.B.A. commentator Charles Barkley.

headline: Is Shrimp Good for You? It’s Complicated.
abstract: Americans love their prawns. So how healthy are they — for us and for the planet?
lead_paragraph: Americans aren’t particularly enthusiastic about seafood. We eat less than half of what a Japanese or Indonesian person does. Less than a third of the average Icelander. But there is one big exception: shrimp.

headline: Need a Refresher on Trump’s Criminal Trial? Catch Up Here.
abstract: Donald J. Trump has been charged with 34 felony counts in the first criminal case against an American president. Defense lawyers and prosecutors are making their closing arguments on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Closing arguments began Tuesday in the weekslong criminal trial of Donald J. Trump, the first president to face prosecution in American history, in a case that stems from a hush-money deal to a porn star who said she had sex with him.

headline: Trump’s ‘Dystopian Deportation Scheme’
abstract: Readers discuss two opinion pieces about Donald Trump’s plans if elected. Also: Gaza’s ruined hospitals; Florida’s climate law; a G.O.P. double standard; pregnancy calories.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Flaco the Owl’s Wings to Be Kept at a Museum in His Neighborhood
abstract: Remains from the Eurasian eagle-owl, whose year on the loose captivated New York City, will become part of collections at the American Museum of Natural History.
lead_paragraph: Partial remains of Flaco, the Eurasian eagle-owl whose escape from the Central Park Zoo and year on the loose enthralled New York City before his death in February, will be kept at a museum near where he spent most of his life, zoo officials said on Tuesday.

headline: If Trump Is Convicted, How Will Biden’s Team Go on the Attack?
abstract: A guilty verdict in New York would be a gift for Democrats — but if it comes, the Biden campaign is unlikely to tear up its 2024 playbook.
lead_paragraph: Normally, seeing your presidential opponent convicted of a felony would be a cause for celebration.

headline: Top FTX Executive Sentenced to 7½ Years in Prison
abstract: Ryan Salame, the head of FTX’s subsidiary in the Bahamas, was the first of Sam Bankman-Fried’s deputies to be sentenced since the crypto exchange collapsed in November 2022.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Salame, a top executive at the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison on Tuesday, making him the first of Sam Bankman-Fried’s circle of advisers at FTX to receive prison time.

headline: Who Plotted to Sell Graceland? An Identity Thief Raises His Hand.
abstract: A person using an email for the company seeking to foreclose on the former home of Elvis Presley says his ring was behind the threat to sell the beloved landmark.
lead_paragraph: The writer said he was an identity thief — a ring leader on the dark web, with a network of “worms” placed throughout the United States.

headline: Harvard Should Say Less. Maybe All Schools Should.
abstract: Let’s spare universities from having to decide which world events deserve official statements.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Harvard University’s leadership found itself at the center of a highly public, highly charged fight about taking an official institutional position in connection with the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel and the war in Gaza.

headline: Forgione Brings Its Rustic Charm to the Former Danube Space
abstract: Little Banchan Shop opens on Pier 57, Asia Shabazz is the new executive chef at Contento and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Gilded cast-iron columns from David Bouley’s Danube still punctuate this space on Duane and Hudson Street, which is now Forgione; a Bouley cookbook sits on a shelf in the late chef’s honor. The transfer of the rustic setting decorated with yard sale memorabilia from Marc Forgione’s former Reade Street location was seamless, and the menu by the famously mohawked chef offers classics like hiramasa tartare and chile lobster. New are grilled Maine eel over broken rice, and baby Pennsylvania rainbow trout planked like fresh sardines. An unlisted burger is exclusive to the rear bar area and the wine list has quadrupled thanks to more storage.

headline: The ‘Home Alone’ House Is for Sale (Booby Traps Not Included)
abstract: The house in Winnetka, Ill., where Kevin McCallister battled two hapless burglars in the 1990 film is on the market for the first time in more than a decade. List price: $5.25 million.
lead_paragraph: One of the most famous movie residences is for sale.

headline: State Senator Opposes Casino Proposal in Queens, Rebuffing Mets Owner
abstract: Jessica Ramos, a state senator from Queens who is considering a run for mayor, moved to stop a proposal from Steven Cohen, the billionaire owner of the New York Mets.
lead_paragraph: A state senator from Queens moved to stop a major casino proposal in her district on Tuesday, rebuffing Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire owner of the New York Mets.

headline: Texas 35th Congressional District Primary Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.

headline: Texas 12th Congressional District Primary Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.

headline: Texas 32nd Congressional District Primary Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.

headline: Texas 23rd Congressional District Primary Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.

abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.

abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.

headline: Texas 31st Congressional District Primary Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.

headline: Texas 7th Congressional District Primary Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff election.

headline: Texas Primary Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Texas primary runoff elections.

headline: Have You Enrolled in Georgia’s Medicaid Work Requirement Program? We’d Like to Hear From You.
abstract: We’re hoping to speak with people who have tried enrolling in or have been covered by Georgia Pathways, the Medicaid work requirement program. We want to know what the experience was like.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Georgia began a program called Pathways to Coverage, which allows lower-income residents to secure Medicaid health insurance if they complete 80 hours each month of professional, academic or community activities. People who are working part- or full-time, have completed community service or are pursuing a college education can qualify, and can mix the different activities to be eligible.

headline: Judge Denies Limited Gag Order Request in Trump Documents Case
abstract: The decision was made on procedural grounds and left open the possibility that federal prosecutors could try again to restrict Donald Trump from making statements that could endanger F.B.I. agents.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday temporarily denied a request by prosecutors to bar former President Donald J. Trump from making statements that might endanger law enforcement agents working on the case in which he stands accused of illegally holding on to classified documents after he left office.

headline: What Donald Trump’s Lawyer Said in His Closing Argument
abstract: The former president was taken advantage of by liars, his lawyer, Todd Blanche, said while arguing that he should be found not guilty of the 34 felonies he is charged with.
lead_paragraph: A defense lawyer for Donald J. Trump said Tuesday in the closing argument of his criminal hush-money trial that the former president was not only innocent, but also a victim of extortion by liars seeking his demise.

headline: The Daily Beast’s New Bosses Plan Buyouts to Cut Losses
abstract: The two leaders have looked for money-saving measures since joining the digital tabloid in April.
lead_paragraph: The Daily Beast’s new leaders will do a round of voluntary buyouts intended to cut costs by $1.5 million, in one of their first major moves to try to revitalize the flagging digital tabloid.

headline: Here’s What Happened in the Texas Runoff Elections
abstract: The Texas House speaker, Dade Phelan, survived a challenge from a Trump-backed activist, and a Republican former Navy officer will face Representative Henry Cuellar this fall.
lead_paragraph: Texans voted in runoff elections on Tuesday for a number of offices, with establishment candidates emerging victorious from two House Republican primaries, and the speaker of the State House narrowly surviving an insurgent challenge from a Trump-backed Republican.

headline: Music’s Most Neglected Day of the Week
abstract: Seven songs for Tuesdays from Stevie Wonder, iLoveMakonnen and more.
lead_paragraph: The day after Memorial Day — or any day that directly follows a beginning-of-the-week holiday — is one of those Tuesdays that feels like a Monday. A certain temporal fog lingers and will continue to confuse you all week: “Wait, what day is it again?” Well, today it is Tuesday. And I am here to offer you a sonic cure for that fog, something to ground you in the present: a playlist of Tuesday songs.

headline: Gazan Officials Say a Strike Killed 21 in Al-Mawasi
abstract: The reports come just two days after dozens of people were killed when a fire tore through a camp for displaced Palestinians in Rafah after an Israeli airstrike.
lead_paragraph: Gazan officials said that at least 21 people were killed and dozens injured on Tuesday in a strike that hit a tent encampment housing displaced people in Al-Mawasi, a coastal area in southern Gaza where Israel has designated a humanitarian safe zone.

headline: Man Who Invaded Nancy Pelosi’s Home Apologizes for Attacking Her Husband
abstract: David DePape’s federal sentencing hearing was reopened to give him a chance to address the court, but his apology did not persuade the judge to change his sentence.
lead_paragraph: David DePape, who was convicted of federal crimes for breaking into the residence of Nancy Pelosi two years ago and beating her husband with a hammer, apologized on Tuesday for the attack and expressed remorse, as a judge briefly considered a more lenient prison sentence.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Also, He’s a Magician’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Trading poodle skirts and blouses for trucker hats and flannels, decades before the term “gender nonconforming” entered the mainstream, Aunt Barbara stopped trying to fit into her Missouri farm town. I innocently called her “Uncle Barbara” as a toddler. She always laughed. For all of her standing out, for the acceptance that she demanded and received, Barb’s inner life is unknowable. Long gone from cancer, she left me two important gifts: a record of her courageous clothing preferences — deeply provocative in her time — captured in family photos, and a blazed path for her family to accept me, her gay nephew. — Dylan Connell

headline: U.S. Officials Say Deadly Rafah Airstrike Did Not Cross Biden’s Red Line
abstract: The deaths were “devastating,” a White House spokesman said, but the scale of the attack was not enough to change U.S. policy.
lead_paragraph: U.S. officials said on Tuesday that the Israeli strike that killed dozens of Palestinians in southern Gaza was a tragedy but that it did not violate President Biden’s red line for withholding weapons shipments to Israel.

headline: Democrats Adopt Nomination Plan to Allow Biden on the Ohio Ballot
abstract: Party leaders said they would nominate the president via a virtual roll call of delegates before the national convention, overcoming a glitch that had threatened to keep him off the November ballot.
lead_paragraph: Democratic Party leaders said Tuesday that they would nominate President Biden for a second term in office via a virtual roll call of delegates to the party’s national convention, bypassing a glitch in Ohio law that had threatened to keep Mr. Biden off the November ballot in the state.

headline: How to Fix Carbon Offsets
abstract: Carbon offsets have been heavily criticized as greenwashing, but they have a hidden benefit: getting crucial climate funds to developing nations.
lead_paragraph: The White House announced guidelines this morning to strengthen the market for carbon offsets, otherwise known as the voluntary carbon market. Offsets allow companies or individuals to buy credits tied to emissions reductions created by projects that remove carbon from the atmosphere, many of which are in the developing world.

headline: Harvard Says It Will No Longer Take Positions on Matters Outside of the University
abstract: The policy could ease pressure on the school to issue statements on current events. Officials were criticized for their handling of the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks.
lead_paragraph: Harvard said on Tuesday that it would now avoid taking positions on matters that are not “relevant to the core function of the university,” accepting the recommendations of a faculty committee that urged the university to dramatically reduce its messages on issues of the day.

headline: Biden Moves to Open U.S. Banks to Cuba’s Private Sector
abstract: The rules will allow Cuban entrepreneurs to open bank accounts in the United States, making it easier for them to expand and encouraging other Cubans to start businesses.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration, in a major move to support Cuba’s expanding private sector, announced on Tuesday new regulations allowing Cuban entrepreneurs on the island to open bank accounts in the United States for the first time and to make remote online transactions.

headline: Marco Rubio Wants to Be Trump’s Vice President. He Doesn’t Want to Audition.
abstract: The last time the Florida senator lived in Donald J. Trump’s orbit he was mocked and defeated. As he returns, he’s trying to do it on his terms.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio, the Republican of Florida, has not visited the courthouse in Manhattan to flaunt his support for Donald J. Trump like other potential running mates. He is not a fixture at the former president’s campaign rallies and has not become part of the furniture at Mar-a-Lago, like other Republicans craving relevancy.

headline: On the Dangers of Inflation Brain
abstract: Is the Fed, among others, focused on the wrong problem?
lead_paragraph: Surging prices in 2021-22, after decades of low inflation, came as a shock to many. So it was in a way understandable that many observers more or less freaked out, seeing a return to the 1970s lurking under every bed and behind every closet door.

headline: Its Future in Doubt, the Freewheeling ‘Inside the NBA’ Is on Edge Instead
abstract: Next season could be the last for TNT’s influential and beloved studio show, and Charles Barkley, for one, will not be going quietly.
lead_paragraph: The future of “Inside the NBA” was already a sensitive topic when Charles Barkley stepped into an elevator in Minneapolis after Game 2 of the Western Conference finals late Friday night. Barkley’s on-air candor as an analyst is a key reason that the studio show has become so influential and beloved among basketball fans and around the league.

headline: Blinken Travels to Eastern Europe as Russia Presses War in Ukraine
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken aims to show support for Moldova, which is under threat from Russia, and plans to attend a NATO meeting in the Czech Republic.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken plans to spend this week showing U.S. support for nations facing a hostile Russia in visits to Moldova and the Czech Republic, where he is scheduled to attend a meeting of NATO foreign ministers that will discuss how to bolster Ukraine.

headline: Gaza’s Historic Heart, Now in Ruins
abstract: The Great Omari Mosque, built on an ancient holy site, is one of the many treasured landmarks damaged in Israel’s military offensive.
lead_paragraph: The Great Omari Mosque, built on an ancient holy site, is one of the many treasured landmarks damaged in Israel’s military offensive.

headline: Rare Wu-Tang Clan Album to Be Played at Exhibit in Tasmania
abstract: The sole known copy of the album “Once Upon a Time in Shaolin” was not to be heard by the public until 2103. Some fans will be able to hear a selection of the 31 tracks at a museum in Hobart, Tasmania.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, the Wu-Tang Clan issued a sole copy of a CD-only album, secured it in an engraved nickel and silver box, locked it away in a vault and said it could not be heard by the public until 2103.

headline: U.S. Pier for Gaza Aid Damaged by Rough Seas
abstract: Army engineers are working to put the pier back together, and Defense Department officials hope it will be operational again in about a week.
lead_paragraph: The temporary pier that the U.S. military constructed and put in place to provide much-needed humanitarian aid for Gaza has broken apart in rough seas, the Pentagon said on Tuesday.

headline: Man Charged With Hate Crimes in New York City Street Attacks
abstract: Skiboky Stora, 40, is accused of targeting people he believed were white, female or Jewish. He was arrested in March after one of his alleged victims shared her story on TikTok.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man was charged on Tuesday with felony assault and stalking as hate crimes and with misdemeanor harassment after a series of attacks on strangers over the past year, the Manhattan district attorney’s office announced.

headline: At Trump Trial’s Closings, Lawyers Weave Facts Into Clashing Accounts
abstract: A defense lawyer painted Donald J. Trump as the victim of unscrupulous people, but a prosecutor said Mr. Trump had directed a scheme to conceal a hush-money payment.
lead_paragraph: For nearly three hours on Tuesday, Donald J. Trump’s lawyer did his level best to persuade the jury to acquit his client, wielding a scalpel to attack nearly every strand of the criminal case against the former president.

headline: Bill Walton’s Long, Special Relationship With the Grateful Dead
abstract: “It wasn’t like he was a fan,” the drummer Mickey Hart said. “He was part of our family.”
lead_paragraph: Bill Walton played 604 basketball games in college and the N.B.A. over the course of his Hall of Fame career. But Walton, who died Monday from cancer at 71, wrote in a 2016 autobiography that he had attended more than 869 concerts by his most beloved musical act, the Grateful Dead.

headline: Strike Kills Displaced Gazans in Al-Mawasi, Officials Say
abstract: More than 20 people were killed and dozens more were injured when a strike hit a tent encampment for displaced Palestinians, Gazan officials said.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 people were killed and dozens more were injured when a strike hit a tent encampment for displaced Palestinians, Gazan officials said.

headline: Five New Hotels and Spas Built for Bathing
abstract: From southern Japan to the English countryside, these properties put the focus on therapeutic waters.
lead_paragraph: In the ever-expanding wellness world, one of the latest trends is actually one of the oldest: soaking in, and sometimes drinking, therapeutic waters. In ancient Greece, physicians, including Hippocrates, prescribed mineral-rich baths to treat everything from skin diseases to insomnia. (According to one theory, the word “spa” is an acronym of the Latin phrase “sanus per aqua,” meaning “health by water.”) The practice has also been employed in Asia since at least the sixth century A.D., when nomadic Buddhists are said to have brought the concept of onsen (inns and bathhouses built around natural geothermal pools) to Japan from the Korean Peninsula. Now, with various forms of hydrotherapy, such as cold plunges and steam saunas, making a comeback, wellness entrepreneurs are debuting properties centered on bathing. Here, five places to take a dip.

headline: Chevron’s $53 Billion Oil Deal Is Backed by Hess Shareholders
abstract: Hurdles remain as Chevron and Exxon Mobil wage a legal battle over Hess’s stake in a lucrative oil project in Guyana.
lead_paragraph: A large oil industry deal advanced on Tuesday after shareholders of Hess approved a proposed sale of the company to Chevron for $53 billion.

headline: Who Is the Prosecutor Delivering the Closing Statement in the Trump Trial?
abstract: Joshua Steinglass is part of the Manhattan district attorney’s team that includes veteran prosecutors and former white-collar criminal defense lawyers.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Steinglass, the prosecutor who is delivering the hourslong closing argument in the criminal trial of Donald J. Trump, is an assistant district attorney who has served in the role in Manhattan since 1998.

headline: Stream These 12 Movies and Shows Before They Leave Netflix in June
abstract: Mark Wahlberg and Reese Witherspoon when they were kids-ish, Clint Eastwood as a drug mule on the other side of life, and Meryl Streep in “Out of Africa.”
lead_paragraph: One of the most durable shows of the modern television era leaves Netflix in the United States this month, along with an equally long-lasting horror franchise, a handful of enjoyable genre flicks and several Oscar winners and nominees. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Closing Arguments in Trump’s Criminal Trial
abstract: Plus, South Africa goes to the polls
lead_paragraph: The prosecution and defense made their closing arguments to the jury yesterday in the first criminal prosecution of an American president. Here are live updates.

headline: Senators See Possible Conflicts of Interest in Health Care Pricing Tools
abstract: A data analytics firm that helps insurers collect big fees while leaving some patients with unpaid bills has been summoned to explain its business model.
lead_paragraph: The chairmen of two Senate committees overseeing health policy, concerned about companies “padding their own profits” at the expense of patients, are looking into the practices of a data analytics firm that works with big insurers to cut payments to medical providers.

headline: Both Sides Delivered Closing Arguments at Trump’s Trial
abstract: Also, Israel pushed on in Rafah. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The prosecutors who charged Donald Trump with 34 felonies and the lawyers defending the former president against the accusations spent all day today delivering their final arguments to the jury of 12 New Yorkers who will soon decide Trump’s fate.

headline: R.F.K. Jr. Denounces the Removal of Confederate Statues
abstract: The independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said on a recent podcast that he had a “visceral reaction” to the removal of statues glorifying Confederate leaders.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. denounced the removal of hundreds of Confederate statues and other monuments across the United States after the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer in 2020.

headline: What Is the ‘Access Hollywood’ Tape, and How Does It Factor Into Trump’s Trial?
abstract: Prosecutors have mentioned the tape at various stages of Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, including during closing arguments on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: About a month before Donald J. Trump was elected president in 2016, a recording surfaced of him speaking in vulgar terms about women, causing a crisis within the Trump campaign and pandemonium across the Republican Party.

headline: The Alitos, the Neighborhood Clash and the Upside-Down Flag
abstract: Inside the escalating conflict on a bucolic suburban street that Justice Alito said prompted a “Stop the Steal” symbol at his home.
lead_paragraph: The police in Fairfax County, Va., received an unusual phone call on Feb. 15, 2021. A young couple claimed they were being harassed by the wife of a Supreme Court justice.

headline: Michigan Trooper Charged With Murder in Death of Fleeing Man
abstract: Detective Sgt. Brian Keely was charged in the death of Samuel Sterling, who was fatally struck by an unmarked police S.U.V. in suburban Grand Rapids last month.
lead_paragraph: The Michigan attorney general charged a state trooper with murder on Tuesday, saying he was “grossly negligent” when he fatally struck a fleeing man, Samuel Sterling, with a vehicle last month in suburban Grand Rapids.

headline: Do We Still Understand How Wars Are Won?
abstract: Israel and Ukraine don’t have the luxury of fighting fecklessly.
lead_paragraph: In the past 50 years, the United States has gotten good at losing wars.

headline: How We’ve Lost Our Moorings as a Society
abstract: Our society is losing sight of qualities that kept America strong, like responsibility and civility but also the capacity to feel shame.
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom is that Donald Trump’s trial over his alleged efforts to buy the silence of a porn star on the eve of the 2016 election is the least important of the cases against him. Politically that may be true. But more than any of the other cases, this one is revealing of a trend ailing America today: how much we’ve lost our moorings as a society.

headline: Sue Johnson, Psychologist Who Took a Scientific View of Love, Dies at 76
abstract: She believed the bond between adults was as sustaining as that between parent and child, and developed a therapy to strengthen and repair broken relationships.
lead_paragraph: Sue Johnson, a British-born Canadian clinical psychologist and best-selling author who developed a novel method of couples therapy based on emotional attachment, challenging what had been the dominant behavioral approach — the idea that behaviors are learned and thus can be changed — died on April 23 in Victoria, British Columbia. She was 76.

headline: Health Officials Tried to Evade Public Records Laws, Lawmakers Say
abstract: N.I.H. officials suggested federal record keepers helped them hide emails. If so, “that’s really damaging to trust in all of government,” one expert said.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans on Tuesday accused officials at the National Institutes of Health of orchestrating “a conspiracy at the highest levels” of the agency to hide public records related to the origins of the Covid pandemic. And the lawmakers promised to expand an investigation that has turned up emails in which senior health officials talked openly about trying to evade federal records laws.

headline: 1 Person Is Killed After Gas Explosion Rips Facade Off Ohio Building
abstract: One person was in critical condition and six other people were also injured after the midafternoon explosion in Youngstown.
lead_paragraph: A natural gas explosion ripped the facade off a building in downtown Youngstown, Ohio, on Tuesday afternoon, killing a 27-year-old man and injuring at least seven others, one critically, officials said.

headline: Israel Pushes Into Rafah as Displaced Palestinians Search for Safety
abstract: The Israeli military said it had deployed additional combat troops to the southern Gaza Strip, even as a growing chorus of voices demand an end to the fighting.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military said it was pressing on with its ground assault in the southern Gaza Strip on Tuesday despite mounting international outrage over its operations there, including an airstrike over the weekend that killed dozens of civilians.

headline: NYU Nurse Is Fired After Calling the Gaza War a ‘Genocide’ in Speech
abstract: NYU Langone Health gave the nurse, Hesen Jabr, an award for her work. She said hospital officials then fired her because she made pro-Palestinian remarks in an acceptance speech.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, NYU Langone Health bestowed an award on a labor and delivery nurse for providing compassionate care to mothers who had lost babies. But shortly after, the nurse said, the hospital fired her over the speech she gave when she accepted the award.

headline: It’s Over to the Jury
abstract: After closing arguments, the Manhattan trial is in the endgame.
lead_paragraph: It could take a day, a week, a month. But the criminal trial of Donald Trump is in the endgame.

headline: Texas State House 21st District Primary Runoff Results
abstract: See full live results from the 2024 Texas primary runoff elections.
lead_paragraph: See full live results from the 2024 Texas primary runoff elections.

headline: Here’s What the Prosecution Said in Its Closing Argument in the Trump Trial
abstract: Donald J. Trump orchestrated a conspiracy that influenced the outcome of the 2016 election, the prosecutor, Joshua Steinglass, said.
lead_paragraph: Over more than five hours on Tuesday, a Manhattan prosecutor made his final case to the jury in Donald J. Trump’s criminal hush-money trial that the former president had orchestrated “a conspiracy and a coverup” to help him win the 2016 presidential election.

headline: Trump’s Case Heads to the Jury: 5 Takeaways From Closing Arguments
abstract: Defense lawyers and prosecutors tried strategy and stagecraft to sway jurors. The panel of 12 New Yorkers will get the case Wednesday morning.
lead_paragraph: As the criminal trial of Donald J. Trump began its seventh week, the prosecution and the defense made their final pitches to jurors, sending the landmark case into deliberations on Wednesday.

headline: Republican Navy Veteran Will Face Henry Cuellar in South Texas
abstract: The congressional district has slightly moved in favor of Republicans after Mr. Cuellar, a centrist Democrat, was indicted on federal charges.
