lead_paragraph: Jay Furman, a retired Navy officer, has won the Republican nomination to challenge embattled Representative Henry Cuellar of South Texas in November, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Billionaire Plans Dive to the Titanic in a Newly Designed Submersible
abstract: Larry Connor, 74, who made his wealth in real estate, said he’s building a new acrylic-hulled submersible that will be certified and rigorously tested to show that deep sea exploration is safe.
lead_paragraph: A real estate billionaire in Ohio is planning an underwater voyage to the site of the Titanic shipwreck, where a submersible imploded on its approach to the sea floor a year ago, killing all five passengers on board.

headline: Haiti Names New Prime Minister to Try to Lead Country Out of Crisis
abstract: Garry Conille is taking on the office just ahead of the arrival of a Kenyan-led international police force charged with helping restore order to the violence-torn nation.
lead_paragraph: An experienced international aid official, Garry Conille, was unanimously appointed prime minister of Haiti by a Presidential Transition Council on Tuesday, which tasked him with leading the country out of its current crisis until elections for a new president can be held.

headline: Catch in the Act
abstract: Jeanne Breen makes her New York Times debut with a puzzle in collaboration with Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: I.M.F. Is Upbeat on China’s Growth but Questions Its Industrial Policy
abstract: Surging exports and factory investment are buoying China’s output, but the housing market faces serious troubles and industrial policies may hurt other countries.
lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund made sizable increases on Wednesday in its forecasts for China’s economic growth, while questioning the scale of the Chinese government’s assistance to export-focused industries.

headline: Menendez Jurors Hear Audio and See Texts From Seized Phones
abstract: Prosecutors introduced private messages between Senator Robert Menendez and his future wife to show what they say was the start of a bribery conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 31, 2018, the day Senator Robert Menendez was formally cleared of bribery charges that had dogged him for nearly three years in New Jersey, he got a text from Nadine Arslanian, a woman he would soon begin to date and later marry.

headline: Texas Storms Topple Power Lines and Trees
abstract: Sparks flew behind one Dallas home as a powerful storm system brought high winds, heavy rain and large hail.
lead_paragraph: Sparks flew behind one Dallas home as a powerful storm system brought high winds, heavy rain and large hail.

headline: Texas House Speaker Survives Challenge From Hard Right
abstract: Dade Phelan, the speaker of the Texas House, defeated a party activist and first-time candidate backed by former President Donald J. Trump in a bitter contest.
lead_paragraph: The speaker of the Texas House, Dade Phelan, won renomination in a runoff on Tuesday, surviving a bruising Republican primary challenge from a party activist and first-time candidate who was backed by former President Donald J. Trump and his Texas supporters.

headline: Briefly Open to a Fair-Looking Election, Venezuela Reverses Course Again
abstract: Officials rescinded an invitation to E.U. observers for the presidential vote in July, in another sign that Nicolás Maduro is unlikely to cede power regardless of the result.
lead_paragraph: Venezuelan officials rescinded an invitation to the European Union to observe the upcoming July 28 presidential elections, another stark sign that President Nicolás Maduro is unlikely to cede power despite allowing an opposition candidate to run against him.

headline: Closing Arguments Finished, Trump’s Case Heads to the Jury
abstract: The prosecution and the defense made their final pitches to jurors. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution and the defense made their final pitches to jurors. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.

headline: Corrections: May 29, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about Richard Grenell’s quest to be secretary of state in a second Donald Trump administration misstated a familial connection of an L.G.B.T.Q. activist, Stuart Milk. He is Harvey Milk’s nephew, not his brother.

headline: Quote of the Day: Small-Town Teams Are Conjuring Fans With Offbeat Brands
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I want the mouth to be John Wayne, and the eyes to be Clint Eastwood.”

headline: Hold the French Fries! Paris Olympics Chart a New Gastronomic Course.
abstract: The environment will come first as France tries to revitalize the global image of its cuisine.
lead_paragraph: There will be no French fries for the 15,000 athletes at the Olympic Games that open in France in July. Yes, you read that right.

headline: Can South Africa’s Opposition Parties Break Through?
abstract: A record 51 parties are competing to unseat the long-ruling African National Congress in the national election on Wednesday. Here’s why it won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: Papi Mazibuko, a 50-year-old library assistant, decided it was time to switch teams and vote for the Democratic Alliance, the leading opposition party in the national elections in South Africa on Wednesday.

headline: South Africa’s Black Elites Sour on the President They Championed
abstract: In pivotal elections on Wednesday, President Cyril Ramaphosa and his African National Congress party are struggling to keep the support of Black middle- and upper-class voters.
lead_paragraph: Cyril Ramaphosa ascended to the presidency of South Africa several years ago carrying the excitement and optimism of the country’s rising Black professionals, who saw themselves in him: a measured businessman with intellectual gravitas. He seemed an antidote to the previous administration, which had blasted Black professionals as elitists complicit in the continued white domination of the economy.

headline: Saudi Arabia Eyes a Future Beyond Oil
abstract: The kingdom is trying to juggle its still-vital petroleum industry with alternative energy sources like wind and solar as it faces pressure to lower carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: At a two-hour drive from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia’s capital, rows of solar panels extend to the horizon like waves on an ocean. Despite having almost limitless reserves of oil, the kingdom is embracing solar and wind power, partly in an effort to retain a leading position in the energy industry, which is vitally important to the country but fast changing.

headline: A Show That Makes Young Japanese Pine for the ‘Inappropriate’ 1980s
abstract: A surprise television hit, now on Netflix, has people talking about what Japan has lost with today’s changed sensibilities.
lead_paragraph: The younger generation has frequently called out Japan’s entrenched elders for their casual sexism, excessive work expectations and unwillingness to give up power.

headline: Ancient Skull With Brain Cancer Preserves Clues to Egyptian Medicine
abstract: Cuts in the cranium, which is more than 4,000 years old, hint that people in the ancient civilization attempted to treat a scourge that persists today.
lead_paragraph: Fluctuating disease rates, innovative treatments and talk of “moonshots” in the White House may make cancer seem like a modern scourge. But a new discovery highlights how humans dealt with the illness and hunted for cures as far back as the time of the ancient Egyptians.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: We’re covering closing arguments in Donald Trump’s trial and Election Day in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution and the defense made their closing arguments to the jury yesterday in the first criminal prosecution of an American president. Here are live updates.

headline: Texas Congressman Wins Runoff, Bolstering G.O.P. Effort to Hold House
abstract: Representative Tony Gonzales’s narrow victory over a far-right challenger came after a divisive race for the party, and most likely strengthened Republicans’ grip on the border district.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tony Gonzales, the Texas Republican who represents a large swath of the southern border, on Tuesday narrowly turned back a right-wing primary challenger who called himself the “AK Guy,” in a victory that could bolster his party’s efforts to hold the House.

headline: Word of the Day: synopsis
abstract: This word has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word synopsis has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 21 in the introduction to the podcast “A Surreal New TV Series About Life, Love and Fruit”:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: In ‘Where to Eat,’ Digesting the Complex New York Dining Scene
abstract: In her weekly newsletter, Nikita Richardson takes readers through New York’s five boroughs and offers suggestions, tips and advice for dining out.
lead_paragraph: New York City is flavored by all kinds of cultures — and their cuisines. That can make going out to eat thrilling but deciding where to go fairly complicated.

headline: Israel Used U.S.-Made Bombs in Strike That Killed Dozens in Rafah
abstract: A Times visual analysis found that munition debris filmed at the scene was remnants of a GBU-39, a bomb designed and manufactured in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The bombs used in the Israeli strike that killed dozens of Palestinians in a camp for displaced people in Rafah on Sunday were made in the United States, according to weapons experts and visual evidence reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Watch: Campaign Ads From Democrats in 6 Close Senate Races
abstract: In each state, a Democrat leads the Senate race while Donald Trump leads the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: In Wednesday’s edition of The Morning newsletter, David Leonhardt noted that Democratic Senate candidates are leading races in six states where President Biden is trailing, according to recent polls. All six candidates emphasize populist themes that criticize big business and China.

headline: How to Escape the Olympics in Paris This Summer
abstract: Even if you’re visiting for the Games, you may want to take a cultural break like a local.
lead_paragraph: Construction chaos, price hikes and now mandatory QR codes to walk some city streets: As the Olympics loom in Paris, many locals are already looking to escape the Games, and come July, will head to quieter parts of France.

headline: So Close to Sicily, So Far From the Crowds
abstract: Pantelleria is a seductive idyll of mud baths, romantic ruins and secluded swimming coves. It’s also rocky and wind-whipped, making it quieter than its big-sister island next door.
lead_paragraph: For years I had been hearing about the island of Pantelleria, the craggy, hard-to-get-to Eden with middle-of-nowhere tranquillity that sits 89 miles southwest of the island of Sicily and about 50 miles east of Tunisia. Luca Guadagnino’s 2015 film “A Bigger Splash” painted a seductive idyll of mud baths, romantic ruins and secluded swimming coves. Celebrities like Madonna, Sting and Julia Roberts visited, drawn to the striking, Africa-meets-Italy ambience, along with Giorgio Armani, a part-time resident since 1980. The fact that nobody was impressed by them added to the allure.

headline: The Ancient Art of Calligraphy Is Having a Revival
abstract: Calligraphy, which means “beautiful writing” in Ancient Greek, is seeing a surge of interest from younger people who say it offers a meditative and creative escape.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in many years, a teacher was correcting my handwriting.

headline: For Some Families of Color, a Painful Fight for a Cystic Fibrosis Diagnosis
abstract: Universal screenings for the inherited disease promised to get babies diagnosed and treated sooner. But they still miss some children of color.
lead_paragraph: By the time Rena Barrow-Wells gave birth to her fourth baby in 2020, she was well-versed in caring for a child with cystic fibrosis. She was also experienced in fighting for a diagnosis of the disease, which runs in families and can severely damage the lungs and digestive system.

headline: Leslye Headland Hopes the Force Is With ‘The Acolyte’
abstract: Her new “Star Wars” show is a dream come true, but she knows it carries enormous expectations. “I would be lying if I said I wasn’t scared,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Leslye Headland has been telling “Star Wars” stories onscreen since she was a teenager. Ostracized at school for being different, she retreated inward, making stop-motion films starring her action figures.

headline: Should You Delay Your Morning Caffeine?
abstract: Some influencers say that doing so can offer benefits. We looked at the evidence.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’ve heard that drinking coffee first thing in the morning can interfere with my ability to feel awake and can lead to an afternoon energy crash. Is that true?

headline: ‘MoviePass, MovieCrash’ Review: When They Take Your Company Away
abstract: An illuminating documentary about the ill-fated (though now-revived) subscription service finds an unexpected story.
lead_paragraph: As a reporter, I spent the better part of 2018 puzzling over the meteoric rise and sensational nosedive of MoviePass, the brief beautiful dream of a subscription service that’s the subject of Muta’Ali’s new documentary “MoviePass, MovieCrash.” Perhaps you remember those halcyon days. For about $10 a month, you could see any movie in any theater on any day. You received a debit card that you’d use to “purchase” the ticket, and then the company would reimburse the theater for the ticket’s full cost. It worked, for a while, and it was amazing. But it made positively zero sense.

headline: How A.I. Made Mark Zuckerberg Popular Again in Silicon Valley
abstract: After some trying years during which Mr. Zuckerberg could do little right, many developers and technologists have embraced the Meta chief as their champion of “open-source” artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: When Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, announced last year that his company would release an artificial intelligence system, Jeffrey Emanuel had reservations.

headline: Logging in Canada’s Most Famous National Park to Save It From Wildfires
abstract: Trees have been cut to create fire guards in Banff, the country’s most popular national park. After its warmest winter in history, Canada braces for another season of wildfires.
lead_paragraph: The loggers’ work was unmistakable.

headline: The Ingredient That Unites My Favorite Salads
abstract: A good salad can transport you, but the truly great ones all have one thing in common: plenty of cheese.
lead_paragraph: The summer after my freshman year of college, I bused tables at a restaurant by the water in St. Augustine, Fla. Parched and sticky with sweat, I watched one particular salad — huge, geometric chunks of watermelon and feta, stacked on a plate with basil — go to nearly every table. I cleared those plates, tempted every time to sneak a rehydrating taste when there were leftovers. On my last day, the managers said I could order anything I wanted: I sat at a table, a diner for the first time, and ordered the salad. It was a revelation. The salty feta cut through the refreshing fruit not like a sword, but like the higher note in a two-part harmony — the Paul McCartney to the John Lennon, the Michelle Branch to the Jessica Harp.

headline: A Celebration of Frank London’s Music Will Be Missing One Thing: Him
abstract: The trumpeter, composer and bandleader who helped revitalize klezmer is battling cancer. But his work hasn’t slowed, and his longtime associates are rallying around him.
lead_paragraph: Frank London is one of those musicians who somehow seems to be everywhere, participating in a bit of everything. At 66, the trumpeter, composer, arranger and bandleader has collaborated with everyone from Mel Tormé to LL Cool J. A founding member of the Klezmatics, a band that helped to revitalize the klezmer style during the late ’80s, London has worked for decades at a fertile crossroads where Jewish music meets downtown jazz. With two new albums involving both styles arriving imminently, he arranged to throw a party, and invited dozens of friends and colleagues to play.

headline: Marymount Manhattan to Merge With Northeastern
abstract: The Upper East Side college’s alumni include Geraldine Ferraro, the first woman to run for vice president.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at merger plans for a small college in Manhattan. We’ll also look at whether congestion pricing will mean cleaner air in places where drivers go to avoid the tolls in Manhattan.

headline: An Unexpected Rebranding of the Democratic Party
abstract: Meet a former Republican trying to convince rural voters that the G.O.P. is no longer the party of freedom.
lead_paragraph: Democrats tend to do well in cities; Republicans tend to do well in rural areas. But winning back at least some rural voters is essential for Democrats to succeed in statewide elections. Farah Stockman, a member of the New York Times editorial board, found one Democrat who is trying out a new message in rural Ohio.

headline: Treat Your Palate and Feast Your Eyes on These Perennials
abstract: The author of “The Heirloom Gardener” offers tips for growing a garden of lush perennials you can put in a soup or add to a salad.
lead_paragraph: Many weeks before tomato seedlings can be safely transplanted outside — or almost any freshly seed-sown vegetables dare break the surface of the slowly warming soil — harvest is underway in John Forti’s Maine garden.

headline: The Long-Overlooked Molecule That Will Define a Generation of Science
abstract: These tiny biological powerhouses can help us cure deadly diseases, and tell us how life itself started.
lead_paragraph: From E=mc² to splitting the atom to the invention of the transistor, the first half of the 20th century was dominated by breakthroughs in physics.

headline: ‘Did You Tase Him in the Face!?’ Inside ‘Goon Squad’ Deputies’ Group Chat
abstract: Years of messages from an encrypted WhatsApp text thread show conversations of sheriff’s deputies, including those who terrorized Mississippi residents.
lead_paragraph: Between vacation photos and cookout invitations posted on their private text thread, a group of Mississippi sheriff’s deputies who called themselves the Goon Squad traded pictures of rotting corpses and joked about rape and shocking people with Tasers.

headline: There’s a Reason Most People Aren’t Following the Trump Trial
abstract: Voters recognize that it’s a misguided attempt to settle the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Hitchens once described participation in the absurd debate over who actually wrote Shakespeare’s plays as “an unfailing sign of advanced intellectual and mental prostration.” It would be unsporting to apply this characterization of literary conspiracy theorists to the enthusiastic followers of Donald Trump’s criminal trial in New York, but only, I think, because the verdict in the latter case is still an open question.

headline: In Florida, Democrats Hope Abortion Will Revive Their Fortunes
abstract: They may not win the state in the Electoral College, but Democrats may improve their chances in the statehouse.
lead_paragraph: On the Miami River recently, a parade of gleaming white pleasure boats cruised through the city. Half-naked revelers basked on their decks, swaying to Taylor Swift anthems and waving bottles of champagne as they floated by.

headline: Ketanji Brown Jackson Points to a Way Forward for the Court
abstract: Can liberal justices reclaim judicial restraint?
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s recent rescue of an important federal agency from the hands of a hostile lower court was an exercise in the evolving definition of originalism.

headline: What to Know About the Open Versus Closed Software Debate
abstract: A.I. companies are divided over whether the technology should be freely available to anyone for modifying and copying, or kept close for safekeeping.
lead_paragraph: Few debates have raged longer and more contentiously in the computing industry than one: Is “open source” better than “closed” when it comes to software development?

headline: A Crowning Achievement in a Neighborhood’s Fight Against Air Pollution
abstract: The artist Jordan Weber’s queenly sculpture in a Detroit park does double duty as an air quality monitor.
lead_paragraph: The East Canfield Village neighborhood of Detroit is not the most likely place to encounter a monumental sculpture of an African crown glittering with gold lowrider paint and soaring high into the trees.

headline: $4 Million Homes in New York, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania
abstract: A 1766 Dutch farmhouse in Claverack, a two-bedroom condominium in a loft building in Boston and a 1912 Colonial Revival home in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: This 18th-century brick house, which includes later stone and post-and-beam additions, is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It was meticulously restored by the seller, Nancy Fuller, a chef who used the property as the main filming location for her Food Network show, “Farmhouse Rules.” The restoration focused on preserving woodwork, fireplaces and outbuildings, including a brick summer kitchen, a barn and an icehouse.

headline: New York Fleet Week, the Movie
abstract: Cue the landmarks, the skyline, the King Kong vistas when some 2,300 members of the Navy, the Marines and the Coast Guard cruise into town.
lead_paragraph: “I feel like I’m in a movie right now,” Petty Officer Third Class Ayanna Crawford said last weekend as she navigated the bow tie of Times Square, with its hordes of panhandlers costumed as Elmo, Minnie Mouse and Spider-Man. “I’m in culture shock.”

headline: The Battle Over College Speech Will Outlive the Encampments
abstract: For the first time since the Vietnam War, university demonstrations have led to a rethinking of who sets the terms for language in academia.
lead_paragraph: Early on the afternoon of Nov. 10, Jameel Jaffer, the director of the Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University, was on his way into a meeting in Low Library, the domed neoclassical building at the center of campus, when an administrator pulled him aside. The school, the administrator said, was about to announce the suspensions of the campus chapters of the organizations Students for Justice in Palestine and Jewish Voice for Peace, an allied anti-Zionist organization — a move that alarmed Jaffer given the fraught politics of the moment.

headline: Emerging Portrait of Judge in Trump Documents Case: Prepared, Prickly and Slow
abstract: Judge Aileen Cannon’s handling of court hearings offers insights into how the case accusing Donald Trump of illegally retaining classified material has become bogged down in unresolved issues.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, a top prosecutor on former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case stood up in court and told Judge Aileen M. Cannon that he was concerned about the pace of the proceeding, gingerly expressing his desire to keep the matter “moving along.”

headline: A Border Runs Through Their Families. Now It’s a Front Line.
abstract: In northeastern Ukraine, and in the part of Russia it touches, the war strains the emotions of people with relatives, and family histories, that span both sides.
lead_paragraph: When Valentina’s small town in Russia came under heavy bombardment in March by Ukrainian forces, her daughter Alla, who lives a short distance across the border near Kharkiv, would text her mother to make sure she was all right.

headline: With Payments to College Athletes, Another Fight Looms for Women
abstract: Despite gains, women still lag far behind men in the little-regulated industry of college sports. A proposed revenue-sharing deal could create new clashes over equality.
lead_paragraph: After decades of striving, the growing popularity of women’s basketball — including a lucrative new television deal — and recent gains in other sports have put women on closer to equal footing with men in college athletics.

headline: The Gender Gap Is Now a Gender Gulf
abstract: The consequences for America’s political future are enormous — and a little unpredictable.
lead_paragraph: Regardless of who wins the presidential election, the coalitions supporting President Biden and Donald Trump on Nov. 5, 2024, will be significantly different from those on Nov. 3, 2020.

headline: Big Money. College Athletes and the N.C.A.A.: A Timeline
abstract: The landmark settlement that would create a revenue-sharing plan is part of a long arc of profits in college sports.
lead_paragraph: The proposed $2.8 billion settlement announced last week between the N.C.A.A. and athletes in a class-action lawsuit would, if approved by a judge, allow schools to pay students directly for playing sports for the first time.

headline: America’s Military Is Not Prepared for War — or Peace
abstract: The armed services are not sized or equipped to deal with new global threats.
lead_paragraph: “To be prepared for war,” George Washington said, “is one of the most effectual means of preserving peace.” President Ronald Reagan agreed with his forebear’s words, and peace through strength became a theme of his administration. In the past four decades, the American arsenal helped secure that peace, but political neglect has led to its atrophy as other nations’ war machines have kicked into high gear. Most Americans do not realize the specter of great power conflict has risen again.

headline: Perhaps Lost in the Polling: The Race for President Is Still Close
abstract: Though he trails in the polls, President Biden has mostly held his support among white voters. Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin probably offer his clearest path to victory.
lead_paragraph: There’s no way around it: The news for President Biden hasn’t been great.

headline: Justice Alito’s Wife Has Managed to Avoid the Spotlight Until Now
abstract: Martha-Ann Alito has built a limited public life since moving to Washington that has mainly centered on apolitical projects and charity work.
lead_paragraph: In the 18 years since her family left their home in New Jersey and stepped into some of the most rarefied circles in Washington, Martha-Ann Alito has never sought or cultivated a particularly public identity.

headline: Latest North Korean Offensive: Dumping Trash on South Korea From the Sky
abstract: The South Korean military said on Wednesday that it found hundreds of balloons carrying garbage from North Korea.
lead_paragraph: North Korea has resumed an unusual operation to show its displeasure with South Korea: dumping trash from the sky across the world’s most heavily armed border.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,076, May 30, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 354, May 30, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Jury to Consider Trump Charges, and U.S.-Made Bombs Were Used in Rafah Strike
abstract: Plus, a plot to sell Graceland.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Closing Arguments in the Trump Trial
abstract: What happened during the last day of arguments at the historic criminal trial in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, lawyers for the prosecution and the defense delivered their final arguments to the jury in the criminal case of The People of the State of New York v. Donald J. Trump.

headline: Biden and Harris Make New Push to Strengthen Support From Black Voters
abstract: In their latest effort to court a crucial group of voters, the two leading Democrats will roll out an initiative called Black Voters for Biden-Harris at a rally in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris are traveling to Philadelphia on Wednesday to announce the rollout of a new coalition aimed at bolstering support from Black voters, who are vital to their re-election but have broadcast frustration with the president in a series of polls.

headline: Democrats Who Are Winning
abstract: We examine if populism is crucial to that appeal.
lead_paragraph: Recent polls contain a surprising combination of results: Democrats appear to be leading in six tough Senate races even as President Biden trails Donald Trump in the same states.

headline: In This English Countryside Race, the Winner Takes the … Cheese
abstract: Every year, thousands gather at a steep hill in southwestern England to watch competitors hurtle themselves after a coveted prize: a wheel of Double Gloucester.
lead_paragraph: “Cheese! Cheese! Cheese!” hundreds of people chanted at the top of their lungs.

headline: ‘I’ll Be Strong for You.’ A Former Hostage Awaits Her Husband’s Release.
abstract: Aviva Siegel was held captive with her husband until late November, when she was one of 105 hostages released as part of a cease-fire deal.
lead_paragraph: When Hamas released video last month of Keith Siegel, an American-Israeli hostage held in Gaza, it was the first sign in months that he was still alive. His wife, Aviva Siegel, couldn’t bring herself to watch it.

headline: ConocoPhillips to Acquire Marathon Oil in $22.5 Billion Deal
abstract: The takeover is the latest in a wave of consolidation sweeping the oil industry, with the biggest players rushing to acquire smaller rivals.
lead_paragraph: ConocoPhillips agreed on Wednesday to acquire its smaller rival, Marathon Oil, the latest deal in a wave of consolidation sweeping the oil industry. The burst of mergers and acquisitions has tracked a robust recovery in commodity prices, with the major players emboldened by record profits and high share prices.

headline: American Airlines Is Accused of Discrimination in Lawsuit
abstract: Three Black men said they and five other Black men were removed from a Phoenix-to-New York flight in January for about an hour because of a complaint about body odor.
lead_paragraph: Three Black men have accused American Airlines of “blatant race discrimination” over its temporary removal of them and five other men from a Jan. 5 flight from Phoenix to New York, in a federal lawsuit filed on Wednesday.

headline: Another Big Oil Deal Despite Regulatory Pushback and Market Volatility
abstract: ConocoPhillips has agreed to buy Marathon Oil for $22.5 billion, as consolidation in the U.S. energy sector shows little sign of slowing down.
lead_paragraph: Bullish predictions for $100 crude oil may not have come to fruition, but that hasn’t stopped the deal frenzy in the fossil fuel sector.

headline: ‘All Eyes on Rafah’ Surges on Social Media After a Deadly Israeli Strike
abstract: The slogan, which has been a touchstone for pro-Palestinian demonstrators for months, ricocheted across social media this week.
lead_paragraph: The slogan “All Eyes on Rafah” has ricocheted across social media this week following an Israeli strike in the Gazan city that killed dozens of civilians and provoked international outrage.

headline: Divisions Set to Deepen in Georgia After Foreign Influence Law Passes
abstract: Many Georgians see restrictions on organizations that receive international funding as a sign their country is moving away from the West and toward a Russia they abhor.
lead_paragraph: The moment the Parliament of Georgia put its final seal of approval Tuesday night on a contentious law aimed at keeping closer tabs on organizations funded from abroad, protesters surrounding the building erupted with screams, boos, and whistles.

headline: An 81-Year-Old ‘Serial Slingshot Shooter’ Is Arrested After Decade of Mischief
abstract: Residents in Azusa, Calif., have been plagued by broken windows for years. The police say they have found the man who did it.
lead_paragraph: It had been happening for a decade. Residents of North Enid Avenue in Azusa, Calif., would find a broken window in their house or car and a telltale ball bearing nearby. Neighbors reported hundreds of dollars of damage.

headline: This Is How Close We Live to Gun Violence
abstract: The New York Times mapped where and how the number of fatal shootings in the United States has grown since 2020.
lead_paragraph: Here are some alarming findings about gun violence in the United States: About one in seven Americans now live on a block near a recent gun homicide, a figure that has grown drastically since before the pandemic.

headline: Why Can’t I Break Into My New Boyfriend’s Friend Group?
abstract: A reader is anxious about the language barrier keeping her from bonding with her partner’s friends. A two-week group vacation has ramped up the urgency.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend and I have been dating for nearly a year. It’s going really well! But his close-knit group of friends is not welcoming to me. They are all bilingual, and when they hang out together, they speak Spanish. I am studying Spanish, but when people speak quickly or use slang, I can’t follow the conversation. Even beyond the language barrier, though, they don’t seem all that interested in getting to know me. My boyfriend has asked what he can do to help, but I’m not sure. I’m afraid his friends may resent me if he asks them to switch to English when I’m around. We’re about to go on a two-week vacation with the whole group, and just thinking about the trip makes my stomach hurt. Help!

headline: Apex, the Largest Stegosaurus Fossil Ever Found, Heads to Auction
abstract: The specimen, found by the paleontologist Jason Cooper, could be auctioned for millions of dollars by Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: In May 2022, Jason Cooper, a commercial paleontologist, went for a walk around his property near the aptly named Colorado town of Dinosaur with a friend and found a bit of femur protruding from some rock.

headline: You Can’t Perform a Good Marriage
abstract: Ashley Madison and the pitfalls of a public relationship.
lead_paragraph: I saw the new Netflix documentary series “Ashley Madison: Sex, Lies & Scandal,” anticipating just some prurient garbage to half-watch before drifting off to sleep. That’s because ashleymadison.com is a website for married people looking to find partners in infidelity — its tagline is “Life is short. Have an affair.” The documentary is about what happened in 2015 when hackers released “members’ names, user names, addresses, phone numbers and birth dates as well as details of credit card transactions,” as The Times’s Daniel Victor reported, a breach that “promises to roil the marital lives of its members.”

headline: The Textbooks Were Wrong About How Your Tongue Works
abstract: The perception of taste is remarkably complex, not only on the tongue but in organs throughout the body.
lead_paragraph: Think for a minute about the little bumps on your tongue. You probably saw a diagram of those taste bud arrangements once in a biology textbook — sweet sensors at the tip, salty on either side, sour behind them, bitter in the back.

headline: What Penalties Does Trump Face Now That He Has Been Convicted?
abstract: Each of the 34 counts carries the possibility of up to four years in prison, but incarceration is not a given: Justice Juan M. Merchan could opt to impose a sentence of probation, with no prison time.
lead_paragraph: Now that a New York jury has convicted Donald J. Trump of all 34 felony counts against him, it will be up to Justice Juan M. Merchan to decide whether his punishment will include prison time.

headline: New Delhi Sweats Through Its Hottest Recorded Day
abstract: For weeks now, temperatures in several states in northern India have been well over 110, and hospitals have been reporting a rise in heatstroke.
lead_paragraph: New Delhi recorded its highest temperature ever measured on Wednesday — 126 degrees Fahrenheit, or 52.3 degrees Celsius — leaving residents of the Indian capital sweltering in a heat wave that has kept temperatures in several Indian states well above 110 degrees for weeks.

headline: Once a Sheriff’s Deputy in Florida, Now a Source of Disinformation From Russia
abstract: In 2016, Russia used an army of trolls to interfere in the U.S. presidential election. This year, an American given asylum in Moscow may be accomplishing much the same thing all by himself.
lead_paragraph: A dozen years ago, John Mark Dougan, a former deputy sheriff in Palm Beach County, Fla., sent voters an email posing as a county commissioner, urging them to oppose the re-election of the county’s sheriff.

headline: Yale Chooses Head of Stony Brook University to Be New President
abstract: Maurie D. McInnis, a cultural historian, will be the first woman to serve as the school’s permanent president.
lead_paragraph: Yale University’s new president will be Maurie D. McInnis, currently the president of Stony Brook University, a New York state public university  where she is known for raising the school’s profile, donations and prestige.

headline: Jury Begins Sifting Evidence as It Weighs Trump’s Fate in Criminal Case
abstract: Justice Juan M. Merchan explained the 34 charges of falsifying business records that Donald J. Trump faces before jurors went behind closed doors to start their deliberations.
lead_paragraph: It’s all up to the jury now.

headline: Which Cannes Films Might Become Oscar Contenders?
abstract: Films backed by the studio Neon have won Cannes and gone on to Oscar nominations regularly in the last few years. That’s one reason to keep an eye on “Anora.”
lead_paragraph: Last year’s Cannes Film Festival was practically a one-stop shop for Oscar voters, premiering three major films — “Anatomy of a Fall,” “The Zone of Interest” and “Killers of the Flower Moon” — that would go on to be nominated for best picture.

headline: The Author Started as a Skeptic. He Came Out a Believer in Pure Evil.
abstract: “The Devil’s Best Trick,” Randall Sullivan’s in-depth occult investigation, is not for the easily frightened.
lead_paragraph: When I was 12 years old, my family went on vacation and, at my request, left me behind. My mother told me that I could sleep in her and my stepdad’s bedroom — normally strictly off limits to kids — and watch their TV. The first night they were away, I made a horrifying mistake: “The Exorcist” was debuting on Canadian television. It came on around sunset. I turned on the TV and climbed into my parents’ bed. You know what happened next.

headline: Teen’s Missing AirPod Leads to Arrest of Driver Accused of Hitting Him
abstract: Lochlan Nicol of Jensen Beach, Fla., was riding his bike when he was struck by an S.U.V. His AirPod landed inside the vehicle, allowing investigators to track down the driver.
lead_paragraph: Lochlan Nicol, 15, of Jensen Beach, Fla., was biking to a gas station and convenience store near his home to buy ice cream last week when a driver heading in the opposite direction suddenly turned into the station and hit him, he said.

headline: ‘Defeat by Truth’: Biden’s Gaza Critics Start an Anti-Trump Campaign
abstract: The effort by Black faith leaders and activists signals that at least some of President Biden’s critics on the left will work to defeat his Republican rival.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Michael McBride was an early backer of a cease-fire in Gaza, publicly breaking with President Biden’s support for the war months before many other Democrats arrived in a similar place.

headline: The 6 Women Who Shaped America’s Most Macho President
abstract: In “The Loves of Theodore Roosevelt,” Edward F. O’Keefe explores the informal kitchen cabinet that helped Roosevelt, the 26th president, speak softly and carry a big stick.
lead_paragraph: We in the United States have yet to be officially led by a woman in the presidency. But in subtle ways, we have come closer than we might think. In certain presidencies, first ladies played vital roles behind the scenes, guiding their husbands with both emotional support and shrewd political advice. Dolley Madison springs to mind; so does Edith Wilson, who wielded near-presidential powers as she restricted access to her husband, Woodrow, after a series of strokes that weakened his body and mind.

headline: At City Ballet, a Once-in-a-Generation Dancer Arrives
abstract: Mira Nadon, the rising New York City Ballet principal, is coming off her best season yet. And it’s only the beginning.
lead_paragraph: Mira Nadon was 5 when she took her first ballet class. It was pre-ballet, which meant running around the studio, maybe getting a shot at fluttering like a butterfly. This was not for her.

headline: This Is the Pizza I Make at Home
abstract: It splits the difference between pizza and focaccia, with an airy, olive-oil-enriched dough that can be adorned with whatever toppings you love (anchovies, of course!).
lead_paragraph: I recently solved a pizza conundrum that had been plaguing my family. Pizza night at our house has always forced us to choose between an excellent but slow-rising dough that takes days to proof, or the instant gratification of a defrosted ball of store-bought. The marshmallow test, but pizza.

headline: Aid Groups in Rafah Say Israel’s Advance Is Pushing Them Out
abstract: Hospitals, clinics and kitchens are shutting down, and transporting the wounded is a challenge on roads choked with debris and fleeing refugees.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s offensive in the southern city of Rafah has strained medical and humanitarian services to the breaking point, aid workers say, with only one hospital still functioning and several aid operations forced to decamp to other parts of the Gaza Strip.

headline: Sleepless in Seattle as a Hellcat Roars Through the Streets
abstract: The modified Dodge Charger roaming Seattle’s downtown by night has infuriated residents. But it seems no one can stop it.
lead_paragraph: As much of Seattle tries to sleep, the Hellcat supercar goes on the prowl, the howls of its engine and the explosive backfires from its tailpipes echoing off the high-rise towers downtown.

headline: Jury Deliberations Have Started in Trump’s Trial. Here’s How They Work.
abstract: The 12 unidentified jurors have retreated behind closed doors and started to debate whether the first president to be criminally prosecuted has committed felony crimes.
lead_paragraph: For more than five weeks, the 12 unidentified jurors in Donald J. Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial have listened to opening statements, witness testimony, closing arguments and the judge’s final instructions.

headline: Can You Guess the Country? A New Geography Photo Quiz for Students
abstract: Test your geography knowledge using photographs from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Test your geography knowledge using photographs from around the world.

headline: The Best True Crime to Stream: Digital Dating and Coercive Control
abstract: Four picks across television, film and podcasting that explore a devastating, yet slippery, type of manipulation.
lead_paragraph: The concept of “coercive control” entered the lexicon about a decade ago and has become an increasingly prevalent theme in the true crime genre. Pioneered by Evan Stark, a researcher and expert on domestic abuse, it refers to a pattern of abusive behavior and manipulation — including isolation, humiliation, financial abuse, stalking and gaslighting — used to dominate a partner. Men are most often, but not always, the abusers.

headline: I’m Worried About Overfishing. Should I Give Up Fish?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the limits of personal responsibility.
lead_paragraph: I think that overfishing is going to result in wild fish’s becoming exceedingly rare — something that our grandchildren won’t get to eat often, if at all. Given this outlook, what do you think about continuing to enjoy fish now while we can? I don’t think that excuses like “everyone is doing it” or “my actions won’t make a difference” apply if an act is inherently immoral. But how about actions that are not inherently wrong but that collectively and cumulatively will lead to harm? — Josh

headline: Nikki Haley Writes ‘Finish Them’ on Artillery Shell in Israel
abstract: Her visit came just days after Israel drew international condemnation for a strike that killed dozens of Gazan civilians in a camp for displaced Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, the former Republican presidential candidate and U.N. ambassador during the Trump administration, wrote “Finish them” on an artillery shell in Israel this week.

headline: Welcome Back, Pandas! Two Furry Diplomats Are Headed to the D.C. Zoo.
abstract: The pandas, Bao Li and Qing Bao, will be flown to the Smithsonian National Zoo from China before the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: It was a long and terrible six months without giant pandas, Washington’s most famous symbol of literal soft diplomacy, but this unbearable (sorry) drought will soon be over.

headline: Amid Orchestral Waves, the Sound of Cultures Conversing
abstract: “Natural History,” performed in Cincinnati, is a collaboration between the composer Michael Gordon and the Native American ensemble Steiger Butte Drum.
lead_paragraph: Eleven members of Steiger Butte Drum sat in a circle around a large elk-hide drum at the front of the stage of Cincinnati’s Music Hall last Thursday. Washes of sound from the orchestra behind them built and receded in grand waves.

headline: Pro-Palestinian Protesters March in Cities Around the World
abstract: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators marched by the thousands and some clashed with police after an Israeli strike killed dozens of people at a tent camp sheltering displaced people in Rafah, Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators marched by the thousands and some clashed with police after an Israeli strike killed dozens of people at a tent camp sheltering displaced people in Rafah, Gaza.

headline: Read the Jury Instructions in the Trump Manhattan Criminal Trial
abstract: The judge in former President Donald J. Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial, Juan M. Merchan, issued instructions to jurors on Wednesday that serve as a guide to applying the law in deliberations.
lead_paragraph: The judge in former President Donald J. Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial, Juan M. Merchan, issued instructions to jurors on Wednesday that serve as a guide to applying the law in deliberations.

headline: Former Intelligence Chief Tapped as Next Dutch Prime Minister
abstract: Dick Schoof is poised to be the country’s first new leader in over 13 years. His selection came as a relative surprise, after more than six months of negotiations to form a governing coalition.
lead_paragraph: The Netherlands will be getting a new prime minister, with the four right-wing parties that are forming a government finally naming their pick, more than six months after the elections.

headline: No Sophomore Slump for ‘We Are Lady Parts’
abstract: The comedy about a Muslim punk band returns for a raucous encore.
lead_paragraph: For the early punks, many of them white British blokes, their music was about declaring themselves outside the larger society. The Sex Pistols dreamed of “anarchy for the U.K.” The Clash howled for “a riot of my own.” To be punk was to give offense, to make one’s self unpalatable, to choose to stand apart.

headline: Home Insurance Is Clobbering Consumers. Yet It’s Barely Counted in Inflation.
abstract: Skyrocketing premiums are hitting homeowners hard, but they barely factor into common price measures.
lead_paragraph: Holly Meyer Lucas estimates that as many as 30 of the 100 houses her real estate team sold in and around Jupiter, Fla., last year were put on the market because their owners could no longer keep up with skyrocketing home insurance.

headline: In the ‘Demandingly Joyful Company’ of Socrates and Plato
abstract: Responses to an essay about the role of liberal arts in higher education. Also: Tim Scott; political violence; saving Marilyn Monroe’s house; FAFSA.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pentagon Opens Ammunition Factory to Keep Arms Flowing to Ukraine
abstract: A plant still under construction in Mesquite, Texas, will soon turn out 30,000 artillery shells each month, roughly doubling current U.S. output.
lead_paragraph: In a warehouse off Lyndon B. Johnson Freeway in an industrial area outside Dallas, the future of American military ammunition production is coming online.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Mr. & Mrs. Smith’ and More
abstract: I just wrapped up a reporting fellowship at The Times, covering space, physics and the intersection of science and society. Here are five things I’ve been indulging in lately.
lead_paragraph: I just wrapped up a reporting fellowship at The Times, covering space, physics and the intersection of science and society. Here are five things I’ve been indulging in lately.

headline: Alito Refuses Calls for Recusal Over Display of Provocative Flags
abstract: “My wife is fond of flying flags,” the justice wrote in a letter to members of Congress who had demanded he step down from two cases related to the Jan. 6 attack. “I am not.”
lead_paragraph: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. declined on Wednesday to recuse himself from two cases arising from the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol after reports that flags displayed outside his houses appeared to support the “Stop the Steal” movement.

headline: Israel declares ‘tactical control’ over a strategic Gaza corridor bordering Egypt.
abstract: Hamas tunnels into Egypt make it essential for Israel to control the corridor, Israel says, but Egypt says there are no such tunnels.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Wednesday night that it had taken “tactical control” over the Philadelphi Corridor — a sensitive strip of Gaza along its border with Egypt — in a move that could further tax Israel’s already strained ties with Cairo.

headline: Jamie Raskin: How to Force Justices Alito and Thomas to Recuse Themselves in the Jan. 6 Cases
abstract: Can they really decide for themselves whether they can be impartial?
lead_paragraph: Many people have gloomily accepted the conventional wisdom that because there is no binding Supreme Court ethics code, there is no way to force Associate Justices Samuel Alito and Clarence Thomas to recuse themselves from the Jan. 6 cases that are before the court.

headline: Blinken Hints U.S. May Accept Ukrainian Strikes in Russia With American Arms
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken made his remarks after some European leaders called on President Biden to lift the restrictions he has imposed on Ukraine’s use of U.S. weapons.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken suggested on Wednesday that the Biden administration could be open to tolerating strikes by the Ukrainian military inside Russia using American-made weapons, saying that the United States would “adapt and adjust” its stance based on changing conditions on the battlefield.

headline: Review: For ‘Molly Sweeney,’ Not Seeing Was Never the Obstacle
abstract: The Irish Rep ends its season-long Brian Friel survey with the story of a blind woman who undergoes an operation to try to restore her sight.
lead_paragraph: Molly Sweeney can identify dozens of plants by touch, catch a lie in a familiar voice and dance ecstatically through a crowd without disturbing a hair. Because she lost much of her eyesight when she was 10 months old — except, crucially, her ability to discern light from dark — Molly has developed keen powers of sensory perception.

headline: South Africans Vote, Many Hoping for Change as Seismic as Mandela’s Rise
abstract: In a high-stakes national election, the African National Congress, which has governed for three decades since the end of apartheid, may lose its outright majority for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Tension, excitement and uncertainty consumed South Africa on Wednesday as millions cast their ballots in an election that could end the monopoly on power of the African National Congress, the party that has governed since leading the defeat of apartheid 30 years ago.

headline: The Tories Will Lose the Election. But What Will Labour Win?
abstract: British voters are fed up with the Tories, and a change election seems inevitable. But Labour does not seem poised to capitalize on the moment.
lead_paragraph: A snap election is a rush to judgment on the state of a nation, and in Britain, the vote coming in less than six weeks appears likely to be a devastating referendum on the governing Conservative Party, which is heading for all but certain humiliation. But perhaps it will also be an indictment of the Labour Party opposition, which seems remarkably uninterested in seizing the moment.

headline: Jury in Trump Case Will Weigh a Monumental Decision in a Utilitarian Space
abstract: Jurors are considering the former president’s fate in a room as unexceptional as the dry ledger entries, checks and invoices at the heart of his trial.
lead_paragraph: The rectangular room is unremarkable.

headline: Volcano Erupts in Iceland, Spewing Lava 150 Feet Into the Air
abstract: Guests staying at the Blue Lagoon spa and surrounding hotels were ordered to evacuate hours before the eruption occurred.
lead_paragraph: A volcano in southwestern Iceland erupted on Wednesday for the fifth time since December, cracking the Sundhnjukar mountain ridge open with spectacular force and sending lava spewing 150 feet into the air.

headline: House Ethics Panel Will Investigate Cuellar on Bribery Charges
abstract: The committee voted unanimously to scrutinize the Texas Democrat’s conduct after his indictment this month on federal bribery and corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: The House Ethics Committee has launched an investigation into Representative Henry Cuellar, Democrat of Texas, over allegations that he accepted bribes and committed misconduct in office, the panel said on Wednesday.

headline: This Easy Party Menu Makes Summer Classics Extra Special
abstract: The former Chez Panisse chef David Tanis puts his spin on a well-known seasonal bill of fare: a salad, burger and a crumble.
lead_paragraph: Summer cooking should be a breeze, more pleasure than chore. So keep it simple. Have a simple salad, something for the grill, a homey fruit dessert. If you can find someone to help with the preparation, so much the better.

headline: Audra McDonald to Star in ‘Gypsy’ Revival on Broadway This Fall
abstract: The six-time Tony-winning actress will play musical theater’s most famous stage mother in a production directed by George C. Wolfe.
lead_paragraph: Audra McDonald has been dreaming of “Gypsy” since she was a 10-year-old in Fresno, Calif., with a small part in a dinner theater production of the musical. She played one of the children in a vaudeville act called “Uncle Jocko’s Kiddie Show,” and ever since, she said, “Gypsy” has remained “very much alive in my brain.”

headline: Americans Raced to Get Their Families Out of Gaza. Then the Border Slammed Shut.
abstract: The closure this month of the Rafah border crossing into Egypt, the only way out for civilians, has thrown an already complicated system into disarray.
lead_paragraph: Ghada Redwan, a 48-year-old pharmacist in Houston, has been trying to get her parents out of Gaza for months. Their bags, packed and ready to go, have been sitting by their door in Rafah, the city where Israel is now conducting a military offensive.

headline: ‘Bad Breath Rapist’ Is Captured After Nearly 17 Years on the Run
abstract: Tuen Kit Lee, 55, who was convicted in 2007 of raping a woman in Massachusetts, had been living with a woman in California who “never knew who he really was,” the police said.
lead_paragraph: A Massachusetts man who fled during his rape trial in 2007, and was convicted in absentia, had been living for more than a decade with a woman in California who had no idea he was a wanted fugitive, the authorities said.

headline: Owner and Manager of Grimaldi’s Pizzeria Plead Guilty to Wage Theft
abstract: The owner, Anthony Piscina, 63, and the manager, Frank Santora, 71, pleaded guilty to stealing more than $32,000 in wages from 18 employees.
lead_paragraph: The owner of Grimaldi’s Pizzeria and the manager of the restaurant’s Manhattan location pleaded guilty to stealing more than $32,000 in wages from 18 employees by bouncing checks and sometimes by not paying workers at all, prosecutors announced on Wednesday.

headline: Biden Asks What Trump Would Have Done if Capitol Rioters Were Black
abstract: “What do you think would have happened if Black Americans had stormed the Capitol?” the president said at a rally in Philadelphia. “I don’t think he’d be talking about pardons.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden made an aggressive push on Wednesday to head off former President Donald J. Trump’s modest gains among Black voters, condemning his Republican opponent as a racist who had lied to Black Americans about what his term in office delivered them.

headline: Two Giant Pandas Will Head to D.C.’s National Zoo From China
abstract: The Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute said that pandas, Bao Li and Qing Bao, will be flown over before the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute said that pandas, Bao Li and Qing Bao, will be flown over before the end of the year.

headline: Richard Ellis, 86, Dies; Artist Whose Works Included a Museum’s Whale
abstract: Once called the “poet laureate” of deep-sea creatures, he melded science with art in paintings, books and a notable life-size installation in New York.
lead_paragraph: Richard Ellis, a polymath of marine life whose paintings, books and museum installations — especially the life-size blue whale at the American Museum of Natural History in New York — revealed the beauty and wonders of the ocean, died on May 21 in Norwood, N.J. He was 86.

headline: Susanne Page, Who Took Rare Photos of the Hopi and Navajo, Dies at 86
abstract: She was the first photographer allowed to document life among the Hopi, in the Southwest, since the early 20th century. Her work appeared in books and magazines.
lead_paragraph: Susanne Page, whose intimate photographs of the Hopi tribe and Navajo nation opened a rare window on the everyday culture of Indigenous people in America’s Southwest, died on May 13 in Alexandria, Va. She was 86.

headline: Man Dies After Climbing Into Jet Engine at Amsterdam Airport
abstract: The Dutch military police identified the man only as “an employee of a company operating at” Schiphol Airport. His death on Wednesday has been ruled a suicide.
lead_paragraph: A man was killed on Wednesday when he climbed into a running jet engine at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam, officials said.

headline: Barry Kemp, Who Unearthed Insights About Ancient Egypt, Dies at 84
abstract: An archaeologist, he wrote widely on everyday life under the pharaohs and did much of his fieldwork at Amarna, considered the Egyptian version of Pompeii.
lead_paragraph: Barry Kemp, an archaeologist whose decades of painstaking digging at the abandoned capital of a mysterious pharaoh helped revolutionize understanding of how everyday ancient Egyptians lived, worked and worshiped, died on May 15 in Cambridge, Britain, one day after his 84th birthday.

headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in June
abstract: This week in Newly Reviewed, Max Lakin covers Alan Saret’s delicately chaotic sculptures, Jamie Nares’s two-venue retrospective and Robert Irwin’s panels of teal and smoky brown acrylic.
lead_paragraph: This week in Newly Reviewed, Max Lakin covers a survey of Alan Saret’s works, Jamie Nares’s two-venue retrospective and Robert Irwin’s stuttering panels of teal and smoky brown acrylic.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Did Dua Lipa Flop? + Miserable Pop Music Films
abstract: Discussing the imperfect rollout of Dua Lipa’s latest album, “Radical Optimism,” and the recent music movies “Back to Black” and “The Idea of You.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes discussion of:

headline: Thursday Briefing: A Hard Choice for the U.S. on Russia Attacks
abstract: Plus, New Delhi’s hottest day
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony Blinken suggested today that the Biden administration could be open to tolerating strikes by the Ukrainian military inside Russia using American-made weapons. He said the U.S., which has so far opposed such attacks, would “adapt and adjust” its stance based on battlefield conditions.

headline: North Korea Sends Balloons Filled with Trash to South Korea
abstract: The South Korean military said that they found 260 balloons from North Korea filled with cigarette butts, plastic water bottles and used paper and shoes.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean military said that they found 260 balloons from North Korea filled with cigarette butts, plastic water bottles and used paper and shoes.

headline: In a Texas G.O.P. at War With Itself, the Hard Right Is Gaining
abstract: The speaker of the State House, Dade Phelan, survived a primary challenge from a Trump-backed activist, but many other Republican incumbents were ousted in bitter primary races.
lead_paragraph: Republican hard-liners in Texas thought this year’s primary elections would be the moment when, after years of trying, they would finally be able to take decisive control of the State Legislature.

headline: The Scene Outside the Trump Trial Mellows as Deliberations Start. Sort of.
abstract: Even a more sedate day outside the trial of Donald J. Trump includes spectacle and confrontation.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush-money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Trump’s Fate Is Now in the Hands of the Jury
abstract: Also, home insurance rates are clobbering consumers. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: For more than five weeks, a jury of 12 New Yorkers, seven men and five women, sat quietly and listened to arguments from lawyers and testimony from witnesses in the first criminal trial of an American president. Now, a decision is in their hands.

headline: Weinstein May Face New Charges as More Accusers Emerge, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Harvey Weinstein, the disgraced producer, is already facing a retrial after his 2020 sex crimes conviction was overturned last month.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors on Wednesday signaled that they might seek to indict Harvey Weinstein on new charges, saying they were vetting allegations from people who have accused him of sexual assault in recent years as they prepared to retry him after his 2020 sex crimes conviction was overturned.

headline: Trump’s Hush-Money Trial Heads Into the Unknown as Jury Deliberations Begin
abstract: The start of jury deliberation in the former president’s criminal trial is a moment of genuine uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Today, at 11:28 a.m., a jury of 12 New Yorkers began deliberating in the criminal trial against former President Donald Trump.

headline: From Allies and Advisers, Pressure Grows on Biden to Allow Attacks on Russian Territory
abstract: President Biden is weighing fears of escalation with a nuclear-armed adversary as he considers whether to let Ukraine shoot American weapons into Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is edging toward what may prove to be one of his most consequential decisions in the Ukraine war: whether to reverse his ban on shooting American weapons into Russian territory.

headline: New Cease-Fire Proposal Circulates at U.N., Driven by Outrage Over Israel’s Strike on a Tent Camp
abstract: Algeria, the only Arab representative in the current makeup of the Security Council, drafted the resolution.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to harness the outrage over an Israeli strike on Sunday that set fire to an encampment and killed at least 45 displaced Palestinians, including children, many diplomats at the United Nations Security Council are backing a new resolution this week that would demand an immediate cease-fire and a halt to Israel’s military operations in the city of Rafah.

headline: Tracking Biden and Trump on the Campaign Trail
abstract: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump’s rematch is testing their ability to make the traditional appearances on the trail that voters have come to expect.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump’s rematch is testing their ability to make the traditional appearances on the trail that voters have come to expect.

headline: Bette Nash, World’s Longest-Serving Flight Attendant, Is Dead at 88
abstract: A Guinness record-holder, she started flying in 1957, and never stopped. Her regular route from Washington to Boston was nicknamed the Nash Dash.
lead_paragraph: Bette Nash, whose nearly seven decades of serving airline passengers aboard the Washington-to-Boston shuttle earned the route the nickname the Nash Dash and won her a spot in Guinness World Records as the longest-serving flight attendant in history, died on May 17. She was 88.

headline: 18 Charged in Gang Violence That Killed Two 16-Year-Old Boys
abstract: The authorities said those charged were as young as 15 when they committed crimes around Brooklyn that included murder.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen teenagers and young men who the authorities said belonged to street gangs were charged on Wednesday with unleashing a wave of gun violence in Brooklyn that killed two 16-year-old boys and injured 10 others over a three-year period.

headline: Less Marriage, Less Sex, Less Agreement
abstract: Bonds between men and women may be eroding when we need them most.
lead_paragraph: I wrote a column recently lamenting the decline in marriage rates, noting that a record half of American adults are now unmarried. As a long-married romantic myself, steeped in statistics suggesting that marriage correlates with happiness, I found that sad.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Worse Than a Spoiler
abstract: Voting for an independent candidate in a presidential contest does not make you principled.
lead_paragraph: Lately, you’ve probably been asking yourself: What does it mean that Nicole Shanahan has been chosen as Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s running mate?

headline: How a Group of Rappers Became Trump Evangelists
abstract: The seemingly transactional relationship between hip-hop artists and a politician with legal troubles.
lead_paragraph: One oddity of Donald Trump’s Bronx rally last week was when the former president invited two rappers — Michael Williams, who performs as Sheff G, and Tegan Chambers, who performs as Sleepy Hallow — to the stage.

headline: Gaza Offensive to Last at Least to Year’s End, Israeli Official Says
abstract: The assessment, at odds with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s assertion that the country is “on the brink of victory,” came as Israel claimed control of a key buffer strip along Egypt’s border.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s national security adviser said Wednesday that he expected military operations in Gaza to continue through at least the end of the year, appearing to dismiss the idea that the war could come to an end after the military offensive against Hamas in Rafah.

headline: Activist Investor Nelson Peltz Is Said to Sell His Disney Stake
abstract: A billionaire who was critical of Disney’s management, Mr. Peltz lost an expensive battle for a place on the company’s board.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two months after losing an epic corporate battle to get on the board of the Walt Disney Company, Nelson Peltz is no longer an investor in the entertainment company.

headline: Hong Kong Convicts Democracy Activists in Largest National Security Trial
abstract: As part of China’s crackdown on even peaceful opposition, a court in Hong Kong convicted 14 people, who now face prison time along with dozens of others.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen democracy activists in Hong Kong were convicted on Thursday on national security charges, adding to the ranks of dozens of others — once the vanguard of the city’s opposition — who may now become a generation of political prisoners.

headline: His License Suspended, a Man Appears in Court From Behind the Wheel
abstract: A defendant charged with driving with a suspended license appeared via Zoom while driving. “I don’t know why he would do that,” a perplexed judge said.
lead_paragraph: If one is facing a charge of driving with a suspended license, there are better ways to make one’s case than from behind the wheel of a moving vehicle.

headline: Walks in the Park
abstract: Shh … Royce Ferguson’s puzzle holds secrets.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Corrections: May 30, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, May 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about criticism of plans to turn a waterfront park in Toronto into a spa misstated the location of a garage planned as part of the development. The garage is proposed for the mainland, not on West Island.

headline: Quote of the Day: It’s Tradition in England: 8-Pound Wheels of Glory
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 30, 2024
lead_paragraph: “I’ve got a gash on the knee, but that is a small price to pay.”

headline: What the I.C.J. Ruling Actually Means for Israel’s Offensive in Rafah
abstract: There is a substantial consensus among legal experts that Israel cannot continue its current Rafah offensive without violating the court’s order.
lead_paragraph: I had two thoughts on Friday as I listened to the chief judge of the International Court of Justice tell Israel to halt its military offensive in Rafah, the city in southern Gaza to which more than a million displaced people fled earlier in the conflict.

headline: How to Watch the Scripps National Spelling Bee
abstract: The finals on Thursday night will determine which of the remaining eight spellers takes home $50,000. The Times will have live coverage.
lead_paragraph: The Scripps National Spelling Bee, the annual competition that challenges erudite children and teenagers to spell some of the most obscure entries in the dictionary, will crown a new champion in its final round on Thursday.

headline: Singapore Releases Initial Report on Deadly Turbulence That Hit Flight
abstract: A man died and more than 70 other people were injured last week when a flight to Singapore from London hit sudden turbulence.
lead_paragraph: The severe turbulence that killed one passenger and injured dozens on a recent Singapore Airlines flight led to sudden changes in altitude and airspeed, Singapore’s Transport Ministry said on Wednesday.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Good morning. We’re covering a push to allow U.S. weapons in strikes within Russia as well as New Delhi’s record heat.

headline: New Scandal Engulfs South Korean Leader in Wake of Marine’s Death
abstract: President Yoon Suk Yeol has been accused of intervening in an inquiry into an accidental death during a peacetime search and rescue operation.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean marines were sent in after monsoon rains flooded a rural section of the country’s heartland last July. They were looking for missing residents in waist-high floodwaters, but they were not wearing life jackets. Nor did they have buoys or safety tubes.

headline: Israel Must Stop Its Campaign Against UNRWA
abstract: The commissioner of UNRWA calls for an end to Israeli attacks, both physical and verbal, against its staff and buildings.
lead_paragraph: The war in Gaza has produced a blatant disregard for the mission of the United Nations, including outrageous attacks on the employees, facilities and operations of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees.

headline: Man Charged After Attempted Attack Outside Jewish School in New York
abstract: A suspect faces hate crime and other charges after police say he yelled antisemitic statements and drove toward pedestrians onto a sidewalk.
lead_paragraph: A man who police say drove onto a sidewalk and tried to strike pedestrians outside an Orthodox Jewish school in New York City was arrested on Wednesday on charges including attempted murder, reckless driving and hate crimes.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Menendez’s Blame-My-Wife Strategy Has Its Risks
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez is accused of a complicated corruption scheme. His lawyers have tried to shift the blame to his wife, Nadine, who is also charged.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors had called their first witness, and Senator Robert Menendez’s blame-my-wife strategy in his federal bribery trial already appeared vulnerable.

headline: Congress Signed the Checks, but Artists Paid the Price
abstract: In “The Playbook,” James Shapiro offers a resonant history of the Federal Theater Project, a Depression-era program that gave work to writers and actors until politics took center stage.
lead_paragraph: A week before Election Day 1936, when a landslide vote would keep Franklin D. Roosevelt in the White House for a second term, the antifascist play “It Can’t Happen Here” opened nationwide: 21 productions in 18 cities, from Los Angeles to New York.

headline: Craig Johnson Wants to Give Longmire Fans the ‘Best 3 Minutes’ He Can
abstract: “Make eye contact, shake their hand, ask them about themselves and then sign their book with a genuine smile,” suggests the author of the Wyoming-set mystery series. The 20th, “First Frost,” is just out.
lead_paragraph: How do you organize your books?

headline: Sarah McLachlan Is Resurfacing
abstract: The Canadian songwriter became a superstar through a series of defiant decisions. After slowing down to be a single mother, she has returned to the stage and studio.
lead_paragraph: Sarah McLachlan was just 30 hours from beginning her first full-band tour in a decade, and she could not sing.

headline: Is Heat Actually Good for Sore Muscles?
abstract: A hot tub or a sauna after a hard workout can be amazing. But is it as healthy as it feels?
lead_paragraph: After a hard workout, soaking in a hot tub or sitting in a steam room can be transcendent. A heating pad pressed on a particularly tight area of your lower back can help it feel looser after a long day of lifting boxes or hunching at your computer.

headline: The Trauma of Testifying in a Sexual Assault Trial
abstract: With a new trial looming for Harvey Weinstein, an advocate discusses what the experience of testifying is like for witnesses in such cases.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today, in light of the steps toward a second trial for the disgraced movie mogul Harvey Weinstein, we’ll look at what the experience of testifying in sexual assault trials is like for witnesses.

headline: 17 New Books Coming in June
abstract: A biography of Joni Mitchell, two hotly anticipated horror novels, a behind-the-scenes exposé about Donald Trump’s years on “The Apprentice” and more.
lead_paragraph: In Talty’s novel, Charles — who was raised on a Penobscot reservation in Maine before being asked to leave because he wasn’t Native — reflects on his life and what he has lost in the years since his expulsion.

headline: ‘Not Everything Was Bad’: Saluting the Mercedes of Eastern Europe and a Communist Past
abstract: A festival of classic cars from the communist era brings out some nostalgia in eastern Germany for pre-unification days, although the abuses that occurred behind the Iron Curtain aren’t forgotten.
lead_paragraph: As the beige car bounced up to the former Soviet barracks, the rattling of its half-century-old motor overpowered the din of people setting up for the day’s festivities at a temporary fairground.

headline: ‘Handling the Undead’ Review: When the Dead Don’t Die
abstract: A zombie movie is wrapped in a gentle tale of mourning and love.
lead_paragraph: The yearning to reverse death is baked into human nature, a longing to defeat evil, to set things right, to conquer mortality. In “Handling the Undead,” that desire is the fruit of great love. Who hasn’t, upon losing someone, wished desperately for just one more chance to see them, hold them, tell them how much they mean?

headline: Millions of Indians Living Abroad Have a Say in the Election, Even if They Can’t Vote
abstract: The number of Indians abroad is small relative to the country’s population. Indian political parties want their support anyway.
lead_paragraph: The dishes at a community center potluck for Indian expatriates near Washington, D.C., ranged from chana masala, a popular northern Indian chickpea curry, to idli, a southern Indian rice cake.

headline: The Very Slow Restart of G.M.’s Cruise Driverless Car Business
abstract: An incident that seriously injured a pedestrian in San Francisco led Cruise to take all of its cars off the road. The question now is when they will return.
lead_paragraph: At a sprawling complex in Warren, Mich., General Motors’ hopes for its driverless car future play out in a virtual reality headset offered to visitors.

headline: Can Billions in New Subsidies Keep Family Farms in Business?
abstract: The Biden administration aims to better support small farmers while still aiding big operations and rewarding climate-friendly practices. It’s a tall order.
lead_paragraph: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack has a line about the state of small-scale agriculture in America these days.

headline: 36 Hours in Porto, Portugal
abstract: Fall in love with the churches, seafood-heavy cuisine and UNESCO-listed streets of Portugal’s second-largest city.
lead_paragraph: Fall in love with the churches, seafood-heavy cuisine and UNESCO-listed streets of Portugal’s second-largest city.

headline: What Kind of Country Do You Want? Start With Taxes.
abstract: The 2024 election is a choice between two fundamentally different visions for our country.
lead_paragraph: To many Americans, the 2024 election is an unwelcome contest between the felonious and the frail. Voters hear democracy is at risk, which is true but is also another potential reason for disillusionment.

headline: ‘Robot Dreams’ Review: A Friendship That Is Far From Mechanical
abstract: This animated film from Pablo Berger is a silent wonder that says everything about love.
lead_paragraph: Decades after Philip K. Dick asked if androids dreamed of electric sheep, we have an answer. This android — one of two nameless leads in the Oscar-nominated charmer “Robot Dreams” — envisions a small, lonely dog in his third-floor walk-up, microwaving a depressing dinner for one.
