Set in 1980s Manhattan, Pablo Berger’s all-ages, wordless wonder of a cartoon kicks into gear when the mutt assembles a self-aware, spaghetti-limbed robot companion ordered from an infomercial. You might be thinking that sentient artificial intelligence didn’t exist 40 years ago, and you’d be right. But dogs don’t rent apartments, either.

headline: Delays and Allegations Cool Off Africa’s Hottest Art Event
abstract: Artists are struggling on with side exhibitions despite the postponement of the official biennale in Dakar, Senegal, and the accusations against its champion, Kehinde Wiley.
lead_paragraph: Artists were putting the final touches to their works. Visitors had bought tickets long in advance. Everyone was counting on a big splash for the 15th edition of the event rapidly becoming Africa’s most prominent cultural gathering — the biennale in Dakar, the capital of Senegal, which had been set to start on May 16.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties on the Upper East Side, in Chelsea and Kew Gardens.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, three-bath, roughly 1,175-square-foot triplex apartment with a bedroom, a den/home office and a washer/dryer on the first level; an open floor plan with an updated kitchen on the second level; a bedroom and a roof terrace on the third level; plus through-the-wall air-conditioning and built-ins, in a five-story prewar co-op with a super, virtual intercom and shared laundry. Victoria Vinokur, Brown Harris Stevens, 917-952-3452; bhsusa.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Glen Cove, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Jersey City, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath house, built in 2002 in a gated waterfront community, with an open dining and living room area, an eat-in kitchen with an island, a den with a gas fireplace, a first-floor en suite primary bedroom, an office with built-in shelving, a finished basement, a rear deck and an attached two-car garage, on 0.42 acres. Debra Quinn Petkanas, Emily Quinn Edelman, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 516-359-3204; danielgale.com

headline: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
abstract: A past look at tough times in New York, and current looks at struggles in North Korea and China.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

headline: More N.Y.C. Rentals Are Available. But Can You Afford One?
abstract: Inventory has grown over the past year, though prices continue to rise as well — just not as fast.
lead_paragraph: The number of available rentals in New York City grew to 30,314 in April, up nearly 5 percent since last April. That’s good news for prospective renters, but it’s still way down from the 41,123 that were available in April 2019 — and not nearly enough to rectify a shortage that has been decades in the making, according to a new report from StreetEasy.

headline: Highly Educated Grads Can’t Find Work. What’s Happening?
abstract: The class of 2024 is struggling to secure interviews, never mind entry level jobs.
lead_paragraph: Recently graduated and struggling to find a job? You are not alone. In this audio essay, the Opinion economics writer Peter Coy explores why the class of 2024 is in a job slump, despite a low unemployment rate. He talks to a recent graduate, John York, about his challenges so far.

headline: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
abstract: John Adams’s opera “Girls of the Golden West,” a recital program by Barbara Hannigan and a collection of Elgar symphonies are among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: You would be hard-pressed to find a fan of John Adams and Peter Sellars’s “Girls of the Golden West” when it premiered at San Francisco Opera in 2017. Critics, who found its libretto aimless and its three-hour score baggy at best, mostly dismissed it.

headline: How a Self-Published Book Broke ‘All the Rules’ and Became a Best Seller
abstract: Keila Shaheen’s “The Shadow Work Journal” shows how radically book sales and marketing have been changed by TikTok.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, a book changed Kohn Glay’s life.

headline: Replacing Prison Uniforms With Custom Suits
abstract: Bindle & Keep, a suit maker in Brooklyn, offers free formal wear to newly exonerated men and women trying to rebuild their lives.
lead_paragraph: Prison limits self-expression. Inmates are usually forced to identify as a number and, for the most part, can only wear a standard-issue uniform.

headline: How Some ‘Wheel of Fortune’ Tips Turned Into $50,000 in Prizes
abstract: The Upshot’s guide helped a New Jersey man, who has some good tips of his own.
lead_paragraph: Last December, the Upshot published a guide to Wheel of Fortune strategies, using data from more than 6,000 bonus-round puzzles. Our guide has influenced the behavior of at least one contestant. Scott Menke, a data analyst from New Jersey, won $52,690 in cash and prizes on an episode last month after creating a strategy based on our article, he said.

headline: Mexicans Are on the Verge of Electing Their First Female President
abstract: Claudia Sheinbaum is the front-runner in Mexico’s presidential race, but she is wrestling with the image that she could be a pawn of the current president.
lead_paragraph: Claudia Sheinbaum’s list of accolades is long: She has a Ph.D. and a shared Nobel Peace Prize and was the first woman elected to lead Mexico City, her nation’s capital and one of the largest cities in the Western Hemisphere.

headline: And Now, a Real-World Lesson for Student Activists
abstract: A generation raised to believe it could change the world learns that the rest of the world may not share its vision.
lead_paragraph: The encampments have been cleared; campuses have emptied; protester and counterprotester alike have moved on to internships, summer gigs and in some cases, the start of their postgraduate careers.

headline: Ernie Barnes Paints What It Feels Like to Move
abstract: The artist, who once played professional football, captured the anatomical and experiential details of bodies in motion in an expansive survey at Ortuzar Projects.
lead_paragraph: The second thing you notice about an Ernie Barnes painting might be its vibrant color scheme. Anchored in earthy reds and browns, it perfectly complements the artist’s virtuosic, almost musical mastery of space and composition. Or it could be the overflowing warmth with which he depicts Black American life that catches your eye. If the painting is “The Sugar Shack,” you might recognize it from an appearance on the 1970s sitcom “Good Times,” where it was shown during the closing credits; from the cover of Marvin Gaye’s 1976 album “I Want You”; or from its dramatic sale for more than $15 million in 2022. You may also have encountered one of the thousands of posters and prints which, throughout his career, he made available at modest prices.

headline: The Unknown Ray Johnson Takes the Spotlight
abstract: The artist you meet in a small, revelatory show is quite different from the one known for mail art and his later gritty samplings of popular culture.
lead_paragraph: In 1949, a young American artist named Ray Johnson left Black Mountain College near Asheville, N.C., moved to New York City and began to explore his prolix talents, both visual and verbal.

headline: What’s a Banksy Museum Without Banksy?
abstract: Work by the anonymous street artist is hard to find. At a museum devoted to him, it’s even harder.
lead_paragraph: To enter the Banksy Museum, which opened this month above a Bank of America on the lower lip of SoHo, a visitor must wade through the thicket of vendors crowding Canal Street with bootleg Apple products and almost-convincing Prada handbags splayed out on blankets.

headline: Catastrophic Floods in Brazil Set Off Another Crisis: Homeless Pets
abstract: Officials in the southern part of the country have rescued more than 12,500 animals in recent weeks since catastrophic floods inundated cities and towns.
lead_paragraph: When the two puppies arrived at a makeshift shelter in the southern Brazilian city of Porto Alegre, their rail-thin legs buckled from exhaustion. They had treaded water for hours, fighting to survive as floods submerged the city, turning streets into rivers.

headline: How A.S.M.R. Took Over the World
abstract: Our internet culture reporter explains why all the videos you’re watching sound so similar.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve spent some time on social media, you’ve probably encountered an A.S.M.R. video. Filled with whispers and crinkles and clicks, A.S.M.R. videos are designed to give viewers a pleasant, tingly sensation. And for years, they have occupied a niche corner of the internet.

headline: How ‘Election Integrity’ Can Change the People Around Trump
abstract: Some people really believe the fraud claims, and people don’t but make it sound as if they did. Both seem likely to be a part of the Trump future.
lead_paragraph: If you go to Republican National Committee headquarters, one thing you’ll notice, Lara Trump said onstage Friday night, “is that the bulk of the staff — the bodies that are actually in the R.N.C. building — are dedicated to one cause: election integrity.”

headline: New Housing Crisis for San Francisco: Where to Put the Sea Lions
abstract: The sea lion population at the city’s Pier 39 reached 2,000 this week, setting a record.
lead_paragraph: The number of visitors to San Francisco has not rebounded to its prepandemic level — not among humans, anyway. Sea lions, on the other hand, are swimming to the city in higher numbers than ever recorded.

headline: Unconventional Sex Let Anglerfish Conquer the Deep Ocean
abstract: During a chaotic period some 50 million years ago, the strange deep-sea creatures left the ocean bottom and thrived by clamping onto their mates.
lead_paragraph: How did the ghoulish creatures known as anglerfish pull off the evolutionary feat that let them essentially take over the ocean’s sunless depths?

headline: A First-Time Buyer at 66, She Tested her $220,000 Budget in Illinois. Which House Did She Buy?
abstract: After years of living in employer-provided housing, a retired pastor decided to put down roots in Peoria, Ill. Could she afford the single-story, three-bedroom house she wanted?
lead_paragraph: After years of living in employer-provided housing, a retired pastor decided to put down roots in Peoria, Ill. Could she afford the single-story, three-bedroom house she wanted?

headline: What Women Voters Really Want
abstract: It’s a political question at the heart of 2024 and the premise of Trump’s criminal trial. We check in with two female pollsters who wrote a book in 2005, claiming to know … one of whom happens to be Kellyanne Conway.
lead_paragraph: While the political world waits for a verdict in Donald Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan, we wanted to take a moment to remember how we got here — especially the broader political context of the fall of 2016.

headline: Pro-McCormick Super PAC Plans $30 Million Ad Blitz in Pennsylvania
abstract: Senator Bob Casey’s re-election campaign and the campaign arm of Senate Democrats have so far spent the most in a race that could determine control of the closely divided chamber.
lead_paragraph: The main super PAC supporting David McCormick, the Republican running for Senate in Pennsylvania, is reserving $30 million worth of television ads in the state, a major escalation in the campaign to unseat Senator Bob Casey, the Democratic incumbent.

headline: After 100 Years of Pizza, the Future of Totonno’s Is in Question
abstract: One family has owned the beloved Coney Island pizzeria through fire, flood and a pandemic. Now the business is up for sale.
lead_paragraph: Since it was founded in 1924 by a baker from Naples, Italy, named Antonio Pero, very little has changed at Totonno’s Pizzeria Napolitana. The restaurant has operated in the same one-story building in Coney Island, burned coal in the same brick oven and followed the same recipe to make pizza that is widely held to be among New York City’s finest.

headline: Experts Question Alito’s Failure to Recuse Himself in Flag Controversy
abstract: Legal ethicists welcomed the fact that the justice gave reasons for staying on two Jan. 6 cases, a break from court tradition. But they said his rationale was open to criticism.
lead_paragraph: Supreme Court justices seldom give reasons for their decisions to recuse themselves. Even rarer are explanations for deciding to participate in a case when they have been accused of conflicts of interest.

headline: A ‘Laundry List’ or a ‘Feel’: Biden and Trump’s Clashing Appeals to Black Voters
abstract: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump both see Black outreach as critical to winning in November. But their approaches differ in fundamental and revealing ways.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden took the stage in Philadelphia on Wednesday to kick off his Black voter outreach program, he methodically ticked through more than a dozen accomplishments, executive orders, appointments, investments and economic statistics.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,077, May 31, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 355, May 31, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Government Takes On Ticketmaster
abstract: Explaining a case that could reshape the multibillion-dollar live entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: Over recent years, few companies have provoked more anger among music fans than Ticketmaster. Last week, the Department of Justice announced it was taking the business to court.

headline: Trump Deliberations Continue, and New Delhi’s Hottest Recorded Day
abstract: Plus, Justice Samuel Alito refuses recusal calls.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Patriotism, Diversity and the Election
abstract: We explore the battle for Senate control.
lead_paragraph: Climate change. Student debt. Diversity, equity and inclusion. The war in Gaza.

headline: John Lennon’s Guitar From ‘Help!’ Is Sold for $2.9 Million at Auction
abstract: After appearing in multiple albums by the Beatles, the instrument was forgotten for more than 50 years before it turned up in the attic of a British countryside home.
lead_paragraph: A recently discovered guitar that John Lennon used to record multiple Beatles songs in the 1960s before it went missing for 50 years has sold at auction for $2.9 million, becoming one of the most valuable pieces of memorabilia from the band.

headline: ‘Backspot’ Review: Cheer Squad Drama
abstract: This queer high school movie, starring Devery Jacobs and Evan Rachel Wood, channels an after-school special without the coming-out trauma.
lead_paragraph: The nonbinary director, D.W. Waterson, wanted to make the kind of film they wished they had seen growing up in a hockey-obsessed household in Canada. Which may explain why an earnest teen spirit seems to be alive and somersaulting in “Backspot,” a cheer squad tale offering plenty of life lessons.

headline: ‘Ezra’ Review: This Father Doesn’t Know Best
abstract: This drama centers on a boy with autism and his divorced dad, with a cast featuring Robert De Niro, Rose Byrne, Whoopi Goldberg and Bobby Cannavale.
lead_paragraph: Success has many fathers, but in the case of Ezra (William A. Fitzgerald), none of them are Max (Bobby Cannavale), his hotheaded divorced dad.

headline: ‘In a Violent Nature’ Review: Killing Them Softly
abstract: Chris Nash’s ultraviolent horror movie is an unexpectedly serene, almost dreamlike meditation on a murderous psyche.
lead_paragraph: There is a calm implacability to “In a Violent Nature” that’s deeply unsettling and particularly unpleasant. Yet I was also transfixed: Chris Nash’s direction is so persuasively bold — brazen, really — and bloodcurdlingly coolheaded that his unusual shocker is impossible to dismiss.

headline: ‘The Great Lillian Hall’ Review: A Star Is Fading
abstract: Jessica Lange is ideally cast as a grande dame of the theater who is facing a reckoning in this well-crafted melodrama by Michael Cristofer.
lead_paragraph: “The Great Lillian Hall” is not afraid to embrace its classicism; had it been made in the 1940s, it would have starred Bette Davis. Like many of the best golden-age melodramas, this HBO film fully commits to both unabashed emotion and a complicated female lead, a role filled by Jessica Lange with a finely tuned mix of showmanship and nuance.

headline: ‘The Young Wife’ Review: Dancing With Cold Feet
abstract: A beleaguered bride spirals on her wedding day in Tayarisha Poe’s stylish but overly familiar comedy-drama.
lead_paragraph: In Tayarisha Poe’s “The Young Wife,” a wedding party plays out like a psychedelic fever dream. The camera keens and swoops, birdlike, around the guests — who are decked out in neon eye shadow and bright pastel-colored outfits — and a synth-heavy score lends the whole affair a hint of the uncanny.

headline: ‘Haikyu!! The Dumpster Battle’ Review: Drama on the Court
abstract: This film extends the story told in an anime series about high school volleyball teams.
lead_paragraph: For someone unfamiliar with “Haikyu!!,” the anime adaptation of a slice-of-life manga about a high school volleyball team, the premise may seem a bit niche. And yet the series, which continues in the form of the film “Haikyu!! The Dumpster Battle,” has always excelled at making its wholesome sports drama accessible to every kind of audience — especially those who may not know anything about volleyball.

headline: Spain Approves Amnesty for Separatists in 2017 Catalan Independence Vote
abstract: The measure has divided Spain in recent months, and opponents vowed to keep trying to block it.
lead_paragraph: Spain’s Parliament approved a landmark law on Thursday that grants amnesty to Catalan separatists involved in the illegal October 2017 independence referendum, a reprieve that could apply to hundreds of people, including Carles Puigdemont, the former Catalan leader who has been living in self-imposed exile for seven years.

headline: What’s Behind Elon Musk’s Bromance with Donald Trump
abstract: The Republican is courting the mogul to bolster his re-election fight, but  the Biden campaign sees a political opportunity to exploit.
lead_paragraph: For much of President Biden’s time in the White House, his relations with Elon Musk have been tense. They may be about to plunge to a new low after Biden’s re-election campaign hit out at reports that Donald Trump could make Musk an adviser if the Republican were to win in November.

headline: Trading Art for Politics, Former Uffizi Chief Runs for Mayor of Florence
abstract: Eike Schmidt, the former director of the Uffizi Galleries, is facing an uphill battle in his bid to become mayor, but he’s counting on his cultural clout to win.
lead_paragraph: It was only midmorning, and Eike Schmidt was already way off schedule.

headline: Ukraine Warns of Deepening Russian Threat in the North
abstract: Analysts say an offensive in the Kharkiv or Sumy regions could stretch Ukrainian troops to the breaking point and allow Moscow to punch through.
lead_paragraph: Top Ukrainian military officials have warned that Russia is building up troops near northeastern Ukraine, raising fears that a new offensive push could be imminent in a region that has become a pressure point on strained Ukrainian forces.

headline: Calvin Klein Names a New Designer and Plans a Runway Return
abstract: Veronica Leoni will be the first woman to run the brand.
lead_paragraph: Calvin Klein, a brand that recently made waves with an ad campaign featuring the actor Jeremy Allen White in nothing but his underwear, is getting a little more buttoned up. On Thursday, it announced it would restart its high-end Collection business under a new creative director, Veronica Leoni, along with a return to the runway — and, perhaps, to its former position as a tentpole of New York Fashion Week.

headline: ‘Young Woman and the Sea’ Review: Fighting Sexism and Rough Waters
abstract: Daisy Ridley plays Gertrude Ederle, who persuades her father to pay for swim lessons, and then goes on to be a pioneer.
lead_paragraph: In a brassy set piece from the 1952 classic “Singin’ in the Rain,” its star, Gene Kelly, impersonates a newbie hoofer seeking fame on the Great White Way. “Gotta dance!” he exclaims to anyone he meets. In “Young Woman and the Sea,” Trudy Ederle is fond of singing the 1921 hit “Ain’t We Got Fun.” First loudly, with a ukulele, to convince her early-20th-century immigrant dad to spring for swimming lessons; later, softly, to herself as she prepares to become the first woman to swim across the English Channel. It’s her way of proclaiming “Gotta swim!”

headline: Will California Have a Summer Covid Surge?
abstract: The answer is probably yes.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new Covid variant in town.

headline: One Designer’s Take on the Perfect Silver Chain
abstract: Plus: a bright boutique hotel in Laos, dance music at MoMA and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Hotels in Luang Prabang, Laos’s temple-dotted former royal capital, have long taken their design cues from the town’s French-colonial past with teakwood floors, louvered windows and creamy stucco walls. Against that backdrop, the new Senglao Boutique Hotel, which opened earlier this month, is a brightly colored standout. Its Laotian owners hired the Bangkok-based designer Saran Yen Panya, who created interiors that channel the nostalgia of the Senglao Movie House, an erstwhile part of the owners’ family business and a fixture in Luang Prabang during the 1980s. “I looked at the quirky and whimsical side of the city’s heritage,” Saran says. For the 31 rooms, some of which open to private terraces, he sourced vintage furniture and commissioned bespoke wallpapers and neon-lit art pieces inspired by traditional textiles and local embroidery. A custom stained-glass window takes center stage in the lobby, as does a work by the British artist David Shrigley, whose tongue-in-cheek work shares similarities with the embroidery commonly found in Laos’s night markets. From $55 a night, senglaoboutiquehotel.com.

headline: U.S. Economic Growth in First Quarter Was Milder Than Initial Reading
abstract: Consumers eased up on spending in the face of rising prices and high interest rates, Commerce Department data shows.
lead_paragraph: Economic growth slowed more sharply early this year than initially estimated, as consumers eased up on spending amid rising prices and high interest rates.

headline: Congestion Pricing’s Latest Challenger: New York City Truckers
abstract: The industry that moves nearly 90 percent of goods within the city is suing to challenge the policy, claiming it unfairly burdens their business.
lead_paragraph: With a month left before drivers start being charged to enter Midtown and downtown Manhattan under New York City’s congestion pricing plan, a new group of challengers is joining a crowded field of critics: truckers.

headline: Does P-22, the Celebrity Big Cat of Los Angeles, Have a Successor?
abstract: More than a year after the death of P-22, the beloved mountain lion who made Griffith Park his home, another has been spotted nearby.
lead_paragraph: For months, Los Angeles residents believed the park had been vacated. Only the memory of P-22, the beloved celebrity mountain lion who had once made it his home, lingered as the city mourned his death.

headline: There’s a Program to Cancel Private Student Debt. Most Don’t Know About It.
abstract: A nonprofit group is publicizing the relief program that Navient, a large lender, created for students who attended for-profit schools that misled them.
lead_paragraph: More than a million borrowers who were defrauded by for-profit schools have had billions of dollars in federal student loans eliminated through a government aid program. But people with private loans have generally been excluded from any relief — until recently.

headline: The Best Move for the Trump Jury: A Split Decision
abstract: A trial-watcher’s prediction.
lead_paragraph: With the jury still deliberating, it’s time for those of us who have heard every minute of this trial to place our bets. My prediction is this: Donald Trump will be convicted on nine of 34 counts of falsifying business records. He’ll go down for the nine fraudulent checks he signed in the White House in 2017 — each a piece of a broader effort to falsify business records and, ultimately, to interfere unlawfully in the 2016 election.

headline: Word of the Day: exhume
abstract: This word has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word exhume has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 14 in the video game review “Hades II’s Eternal Pursuit of a Tantalizing Past” by Yussef Cole:

headline: Why Are People So Down About the Economy? Theories Abound.
abstract: Things look strong on paper, but many Americans remain unconvinced. We asked economic officials, the woman who coined “vibecession” and Charlamagne Tha God what they think is happening.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy has been an enigma over the past few years. The job market is booming, and consumers are still spending, which is usually a sign of optimism. But if you ask Americans, many will tell you that they feel bad about the economy and are unhappy about President Biden’s economic record.

headline: Supreme Court Clears Way for N.R.A. to Pursue First Amendment Challenge
abstract: The unanimous opinion, by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, found that the gun rights group had plausibly claimed a First Amendment violation.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court sided with the National Rifle Association on Thursday, finding that the group could pursue a First Amendment claim against a New York state official who had encouraged companies to stop doing business with it after the 2018 school shooting in Parkland, Fla.

headline: Cleveland Museum of Art to Return a Rare Ancient Icon to Libya
abstract: A 2,200-year-old sculpture of a bearded man carved from basalt, unearthed in the 1930s, is believed to have been stolen in the early 1940s.
lead_paragraph: While excavating an ancient Greek palace in eastern Libya in the 1930s, an archaeologist dug up a large earthen storage jar, looked inside and spotted something unexpected — a 2,200-year-old sculpture of a bearded man carved from basalt, a dark volcanic stone.

headline: Europe Banned Russia’s RT Network. Its Content Is Still Spreading.
abstract: A study found that hundreds of sites, many without obvious Kremlin links, copied Russian propaganda and spread it to unsuspecting audiences ahead of the E.U. election.
lead_paragraph: The website calling itself Man Stuff News caters to a certain sensibility, with categories like “Backyard Grilling,” “TV Shows for Guys” and “Beard Grooming.” A recent article headlined “Tips for Dads During Labor” offered this nugget of advice: “Just remember to spend some time together before deciding whether or not to give birth.”

headline: Grilled Chicken With Tomatoes and Corn, Mango Sticky-Rice Popsicles and the Nicest Niçoise
abstract: And many more hits from our Summer 100.
lead_paragraph: You can make a niçoise salad year-round, and I do: I always have canned tuna in the pantry and olives and anchovies in the fridge, and the grocer closest to me stocks cherry tomatoes and green beans even in the depths of January. It’s not eating with the seasons, but it is eating with my instincts, and when I want punch and tang and heft — with good-for-me greens — it’s the only salad that’ll do.

headline: PTSD Has Surged Among College Students
abstract: The prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder among college students rose to 7.5 percent in 2022, more than double the rate five years earlier, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: Post-traumatic stress disorder diagnoses among college students more than doubled between 2017 and 2022, climbing most sharply as the coronavirus pandemic shut down campuses and upended young adults’ lives, according to new research published on Thursday.

headline: What if the Disabled Characters Were Just Going About Their Day?
abstract: Madison Ferris and Danny J. Gomez star in the meet-cute “All of Me” — proof that depictions of disability onstage don’t have to be “a buzz kill,” as Ferris puts it.
lead_paragraph: A bizarre thing happens when the actors Madison Ferris and Danny J. Gomez are out and about in public together, using mobility aids to get around: she a scooter, he a wheelchair. Inevitably, she said, strangers approach, presuming that the two are somehow in distress.

headline: Girls of Color Are Getting Their Periods Earlier. No One Quite Knows Why.
abstract: Researchers have linked early menstruation to an increased risk of health problems later in life.
lead_paragraph: A new study, published Wednesday, found that girls are starting their menstrual cycles earlier now than in previous decades. The trend is more pronounced for girls from minority groups and those from lower-income backgrounds.

headline: After Hack, Christie’s Gives Details of Compromised Client Data
abstract: Its disclosure came after RansomHub claimed responsibility for the cyberattack and threatened to release client data on the dark web.
lead_paragraph: The auction house Christie’s said Thursday that it had alerted the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the British police about the cyberattack that hobbled its website earlier this month, and began telling clients what types of personal data had been compromised.

headline: The Most Delicious Way to Make Wild Salmon
abstract: Leaner than farmed fish and far more flavorful, wild salmon is in season now. Here’s how to cook and savor it.
lead_paragraph: In Maurice Sendak’s classic children’s book, “Where the Wild Things Are,” the Wild Things are hardly mild. When the main character, a little boy named Max, meets these monsters, he first notices their “terrible” roars, teeth, eyes and claws. A rumpus ensues, and Max comes to learn that these monsters aren’t terrible at all. They’re just Wild Things: unpredictable and exciting. The same is true of wild salmon.

headline: A Look at California Today, and Tomorrow
abstract: Soumya Karlamangla, who writes The Times’s California newsletter, wants to balance uplifting stories and hard news happening in the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: When Soumya Karlamangla, who lives in San Francisco, tells someone she works for The New York Times, the reaction is often the same: a look of confusion.

headline: The World Needs an Action Hero. Enter Twyla Tharp (and Camus).
abstract: Leading off the summer season at Little Island in Manhattan, the choreographer presents “How Long Blues,” with T Bone Burnett and David Mansfield.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Twyla Tharp immersed herself in the work of the French writer and philosopher Albert Camus, namely “The Plague.” World events were on her mind, and his 1947 novel about a pandemic in Algeria struck a chord. In her new full-length work, an outdoor dance-and-musical hybrid, “How Long Blues,” named after a Leroy Carr song, Tharp finds inspiration in that writing and also in American jazz.

headline: ‘The Dead Don’t Hurt’ Review: A Foursquare Western From Viggo Mortensen
abstract: Mortensen gives his film a nested, at times unnecessarily complicated structure, but with performances this good, it’s hard to mind much.
lead_paragraph: In making an honest go at reviving the movie western, Viggo Mortensen — who directed, wrote and stars in “The Dead Don’t Hurt,” in addition to composing its score — delivers a few different westerns in one.

headline: Jury in Trump’s Trial Rehears Testimony and Judge’s Instructions
abstract: The jurors’ requests included specific testimony from David Pecker, the former publisher of The National Enquirer, and Michael D. Cohen, Donald J. Trump’s former fixer.
lead_paragraph: On the second day of deliberations in the criminal trial of Donald J. Trump, the jury revisited words uttered earlier in the courtroom, then retreated again behind closed doors to continue their work.

headline: Why the Trump Trial Jurors Didn’t Get the Judge’s Instructions in Writing
abstract: While common sense suggests a written copy would be helpful for jurors as they deliberate, the law does not allow it.
lead_paragraph: There has been some confusion in recent days about why the jurors in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, who on Wednesday began deliberating over his fate, weren’t allowed to take a copy of the judge’s legal instructions with them into the jury room.

headline: Get Your Sauce Library Card
abstract: Build a sauce library — rich peanut sauce, herby cilantro-mint chutney, lemon-caper dressing — and return to it all week for salads, grain bowls and other easy dinners.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Danielle, a “long-time reader, first-time caller,” reached out with a newsletter prompt too good to refuse: She needs help building a sauce library but is “overwhelmed by all the potential.” (As someone often paralyzed by choice, I get it.)

headline: OpenAI Says Russia and China Used Its A.I. in Covert Campaigns
abstract: Iran and an Israeli company also exploited the tools in online influence efforts, but none gained much traction, an OpenAI report said.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI said on Thursday that it had identified and disrupted five online campaigns that used its generative artificial intelligence technologies to deceptively manipulate public opinion around the world and influence geopolitics.

headline: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, May 28, 2024
abstract: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: 6 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: From punk to poetry to politics, we’ve got you covered this week: Our recommended books include Kathleen Hanna’s memoir of life as a groundbreaking figure in music’s riot grrrl movement, Andrea Cohen’s latest collection of sly and engaging poems, and Isaac Arnsdorf’s deeply reported look at the grass roots loyalists who have sustained MAGA as a political force.

headline: Objections to Alito’s Refusal to Recuse
abstract: Readers discuss the flag controversy involving the justice’s wife. Also: Math for all, not just the few; medical consent; Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and history.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: South Africans Turn Away From Ruling Party, Early Election Results Show
abstract: As votes trickled in, the power and influence of the African National Congress, which has led the country for 30 years, appeared to be waning.
lead_paragraph: South Africans were on edge Thursday as votes trickled in from a tight national election, with early returns showing poor results for the African National Congress, the party that has governed the country for three decades.

headline: Taking the Fight to Russia: The West Weighs Ukraine’s Use of Its Weapons
abstract: More NATO allies are backing Kyiv’s pleas to allow its forces to conduct strikes in Russian territory with Western weapons.
lead_paragraph: With Ukraine’s second-largest city bracing for a new Russian offensive, a growing number of NATO allies are backing Kyiv’s pleas to allow its forces to conduct strikes in Russian territory with Western weapons.

headline: How Republicans in Key Senate Races Are Flip-Flopping on Abortion
abstract: Several G.O.P. Senate candidates used to embrace anti-abortion views. Now they are shifting their positions on an issue that has become an electoral liability for their party.
lead_paragraph: Republican candidates in all eight of the country’s most competitive Senate races have changed their approach on the issue of abortion, softening their rhetoric, shifting their positions and, in at least one case, embracing policies championed by Democrats.

headline: What Is the Philadelphi Corridor, and Why Does It Matter?
abstract: An eight-mile-long strip of land between the Gaza Strip and Egypt is the latest focus of the Israeli assault on Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s announcement on Wednesday that its forces had gained control over a strip of land that runs along the Gaza Strip's southern border suggested that it had fulfilled one of the goals of the country’s war against Hamas, but it portends further isolation for Palestinians in the enclave.

headline: Boeing Gives F.A.A. Plan to Address Systemic Quality-Control Issues
abstract: The action plan is the latest in a series of moves by the F.A.A. to push for safety improvements throughout Boeing during a tumultuous year for the company.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s top executives delivered a plan to improve quality and safety to the Federal Aviation Administration on Thursday, vowing to address systemic issues that have damaged the company’s reputation and put the aircraft manufacturer at the center of several federal investigations.

headline: A ‘Carnival’ of Signs, Spats and Skin Outside the Trump Trial
abstract: The Naked Cowboy appeared, briefly, in the park outside the courthouse where a jury of 12 New Yorkers will decide the criminal case against Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Naked Cowboy usually hangs his hat in Times Square, but he made an exception on Thursday for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Ukrainian Drone Strikes Target Russian Nuclear Radar Stations
abstract: A radar facility more than 1,100 miles into Russia was damaged, satellite imagery showed. The attacks have drawn concern from U.S. officials.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, Ukraine has conducted a series of drone attacks inside Russia, including one of the longest-range strikes of the war, that target radar stations used, at least partly, as early nuclear warning systems by Moscow.

headline: Charles Barkley’s Barbs Infuriate and Fuel Players
abstract: With the future of “Inside the NBA” in flux, athletes say their respect for Barkley means his unsparing evaluations are a rite of passage.
lead_paragraph: When Charles Barkley, the quippy commentator on TNT’s “Inside the NBA” studio show, grew tired of Draymond Green’s aggressive on-court antics several years ago, he made it exceedingly clear that he wanted to punch Green in the face.

headline: Tulsi Gabbard Says She’d ‘Be Honored’ to Be Trump’s Running Mate
abstract: The former Hawaii congresswoman, who became estranged from the Democratic Party, has drawn intrigue from Donald J. Trump but is considered a long shot.
lead_paragraph: Tulsi Gabbard, a former House member who ran for president in 2020 as a Democrat and then left the party, on Wednesday embraced the idea of joining Donald J. Trump as his running mate on the Republican ticket.

headline: The Words That Defined Closing Arguments in Donald Trump’s Trial
abstract: Defense lawyers and prosecutors deployed their best lines to win jurors to their side. The panel of 12 New Yorkers then went behind closed doors.
lead_paragraph: After more than six taxing weeks of Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial on felony charges of falsifying business records, lawyers presented their closing arguments on Tuesday and the case was moved into the hands of 12 jurors the next day.

headline: The Right Kind of Tipping Point
abstract: Global carbon dioxide emissions might have already peaked, according to new estimates, signaling a potentially monumental shift.
lead_paragraph: Amid a deluge of terrifying headlines about destructive tornadoes, blistering heat waves and DVD-sized gorilla hail, here’s a surprising bit of good news: Global carbon dioxide emissions may have peaked last year, according to a new projection.

headline: Departing House Members Ask: ‘Why Am I Here?’
abstract: A wave of retirees from both parties, including committee chairs and rising stars, say that serving in Congress is no longer worth the frustration.
lead_paragraph: At some point during a routine seven-hour trip from his Oregon district to Washington, Representative Earl Blumenauer, 75, a Democrat who has served in Congress for almost three decades, experienced a depressing epiphany.

headline: Bird Flu Has Infected a Third U.S. Farmworker
abstract: The worker had respiratory symptoms, unlike the first two. But the risk to the public remains low, federal health officials said.
lead_paragraph: A third farmworker in the United States has been found to be infected with bird flu, heightening concerns about an outbreak among dairy cattle first identified in March.

headline: Episode 6: Bats
abstract: Sam stares into another hole.
lead_paragraph: The first five episodes of “Animal” featured creatures that are easy to love: Walnut, puffins, manatees, ferrets and the poor extinct Japanese wolf. But the more I thought about this, the more it seemed unfair. We can’t just go around respecting animals because they’re cute. What about all the many millions of beings who are slimy, lumpy, stinky, freaky, ugly, bitey, etc.? Don’t they deserve our attention and respect? Shouldn’t they be seen and encountered?

headline: Episode 5: Wolves
abstract: On a taxi ride, Sam meets a Chihuahua.
lead_paragraph: Episode 5 tracks our pilgrimage to an obscure memorial in rural Japan: the statue of the last Japanese wolf. The “Animal” team debated, for a long time, whether or not to make this trip. The place was hard to get to — from Tokyo, it takes several trains and taxis, and then a long drive into the countryside. But the tragedy of the Japanese wolf had gotten under my skin — this cute little animal (small, by wolf standards) that was once worshiped as a god but was then ruthlessly exterminated in the name of “modernization.” The last known Japanese wolf was killed in 1905. This statue was modeled on its actual body. I needed to see it. Who knows, I thought — maybe we’d meet someone interesting along the way.

headline: Episode 4: Ferrets
abstract: Sam soothes his anxiety by visiting a convention center in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: The best birthday party I’ve ever had was not when I turned 10 or 16 or 21. It was my 44th. Because that was when my friends surprised me by renting ferrets for me to play with in their backyard.

headline: The Outdoor Dining Season Opener
abstract: Rooftop beers and pretzels at Greats of Craft, natural wine and pop-ups at Frog, and more reasons to get outside.
lead_paragraph: We are so back. No matter how long I live here, I will never get over the awesome power of late May and early June in New York City. The temperatures are consistently warm, but not too hot. There’s rain, but not too much. And the worst of the pollen has passed.

headline: Episode 3: Manatees
abstract: Sam makes his underwater dreams a reality.
lead_paragraph: If you ever catch me staring off into space, with maybe a whole ice cream cone melting down my arm, or bath water spilling all over the floor, don’t be alarmed — I’m just imagining myself many miles away, floating in a tropical lagoon, bobbing around with some of my favorite creatures on earth: manatees. This is one of my go-to forms of stress relief. I find it extremely relaxing, a form of meditation. (Manatation?) Because, in my manatee fantasies, I can just float there. There’s nothing to do, nowhere to go, no deadlines, no schedules. I can just be.

headline: ‘Ren Faire’ Is ‘Succession’ With Turkey Legs
abstract: An engrossing documentary debuting Sunday on HBO, it chronicles a Renaissance festival impresario’s effort to find a worthy heir.
lead_paragraph: “Ren Faire,” an engrossing and inventive three-part documentary that debuts on HBO Sunday at 9 p.m., centers on George Coulam, founder of the Texas Renaissance Festival. King George, as everyone calls him, claims he wants to retire; he believes he’ll live for another nine years, and he has a vision for how he wants to spend this remaining time.

headline: Episode 2: Puffins
abstract: As his daughter prepares to leave for college, Sam visits a remote island.
lead_paragraph: In Episode 2, we went to Iceland to rescue baby puffins — which are called, adorably, pufflings. Our guide was Trausti Mar Sigurðarson, a chatty 19-year-old.

headline: Medline Recalls 1.5 Million Adult Bed Rails After 2 Deaths
abstract: Federal regulators said that the portable bed rails posed a serious entrapment hazard and a risk of death by asphyxiation.
lead_paragraph: Medline Industries, a medical supply company, is recalling about 1.5 million portable adult bed rails in the United States and Canada after two reported deaths involving the product, federal safety regulators said.

headline: Episode 1: Walnut
abstract: A hole in Sam’s floor sparks a crisis.
lead_paragraph: We begin with a hamster named Mango.

headline: Chief Justice Rejects Call for Alito’s Recusal in Jan. 6 Cases After Flag Incidents
abstract: In a letter to Democratic senators, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said that individual justices decide when to recuse. He declined to meet with the senators to discuss court ethics.
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. on Thursday declined requests to have Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. recuse himself from cases related to the Jan. 6 Capitol attack after provocative flags flew on the justice’s properties.

headline: Under Pressure, Biden Allows Ukraine to Use U.S. Weapons to Strike Inside Russia
abstract: White House officials said the president’s major policy shift extended only to what they characterized as acts of self-defense so that Ukraine could protect Kharkiv, its second-largest city.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, in a major shift pressed by his advisers and key allies, has authorized Ukraine to conduct limited strikes inside Russia with American-made weapons, opening what could well be a new chapter in the war for Ukraine, U.S. officials said on Thursday.

headline: Idaho Man Is Found Guilty of Murder in ‘Doomsday’ Killings
abstract: Chad Daybell was convicted of first-degree murder in the deaths of his first wife and two of his current wife’s children. His wife, Lori Vallow Daybell, was previously sentenced to life in prison.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Idaho on Thursday found Chad Daybell guilty of first-degree murder in the killings in 2019 of his first wife and two of his current wife’s children in a case that drew widespread attention because of the couple’s “doomsday” religious beliefs.

headline: Trump and His Allies Push False Account of What the Judge Told Jurors
abstract: A tweet from a Fox News anchor falsely said that the jury would not have to settle unanimously on a charge to find the former president guilty.
lead_paragraph: It was a shocking assertion for anyone with even a passing knowledge of American jurisprudence: The judge overseeing the trial of Donald J. Trump had said that jurors could individually choose from a menu of different crimes to find the former president guilty, so long as the total of votes added up to 12.

headline: The Trump Manhattan Criminal Verdict, Count By Count
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump faced 34 felony charges of falsifying business records, related to the reimbursement of hush money paid to the porn star Stormy Daniels in order to cover up a sex scandal around the 2016 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump faced 34 felony charges of falsifying business records, related to the reimbursement of hush money paid to the porn star Stormy Daniels in order to cover up a sex scandal around the 2016 presidential election.

headline: Egypt Faces Hard Choices After Israeli Seizure of Gaza’s Southern Border
abstract: Egypt’s government is weighing its “cornerstone” relationship with Israel against the economic damage the war in Gaza is inflicting and against the domestic outrage over the devastation there.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel announced plans late last year to occupy a sensitive corridor of land in the Gaza Strip, along the border with Egypt, the response from Cairo was public, explicit and ominous.

headline: Ex-Professor Gets More Than 5 Years in Prison for California ‘Arson Spree’
abstract: Gary Stephen Maynard, 49, of San Jose, Calif., admitted to setting four fires in 2021, including one behind firefighters who were already battling a large blaze.
lead_paragraph: A former criminology professor who specialized in social deviancy and “went on an arson spree” was sentenced on Thursday to more than five years in prison after he admitted to setting four fires in California in 2021, prosecutors said.

headline: Donald Trump, Felon
abstract: The former president’s conviction in a New York criminal trial revealed, yet again, why he is unfit for office.
lead_paragraph: In a humble courtroom in Lower Manhattan on Thursday, a former president and current Republican standard-bearer was convicted of 34 felony counts of falsifying business records. The jury’s decision, and the facts presented at the trial, offer yet another reminder — perhaps the starkest to date — of the many reasons Donald Trump is unfit for office.

headline: How Trump’s Team Blew It
abstract: The defense failed to focus on the most important things.
lead_paragraph: The criminal trial of Donald Trump didn’t have to end this way.

headline: Albert S. Ruddy, Producer Who Won Oscar for ‘The Godfather,’ Dies at 94
abstract: A creator of the sitcom “Hogan’s Heroes,” he went on to win a second Academy Award for “Million Dollar Baby,” the boxing film starring Hilary Swank and Clint Eastwood.
lead_paragraph: Albert S. Ruddy, who found early success in television as a creator of “Hogan’s Heroes,” the situation comedy about Allied prisoners outwitting their bumbling Nazi captors in a P.O.W. camp, and then became a movie producer who won Oscars for “The Godfather” and “Million Dollar Baby,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 94.

headline: Trump Has Been Convicted. Here’s What Happens Next.
abstract: Donald J. Trump has promised to appeal, but he may face limits on his ability to travel and to vote as he campaigns for the White House.
lead_paragraph: The conviction of former President Donald J. Trump on Thursday is just the latest step in his legal odyssey in New York’s court system. The judge, Juan M. Merchan, set Mr. Trump’s sentencing for July 11, at which point he could be sentenced to as much as four years behind bars, or to probation.

headline: If Trump’s Conviction Lands Him in Prison, the Secret Service Goes, Too
abstract: The former president could face probation or prison time. Either option would be without precedent.
lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump’s unprecedented felony conviction on Thursday, what has long been a remote and abstract concept could move closer to a stunning reality: a former president of the United States behind bars.

headline: Trump Convicted on All Counts to Become America’s First Felon President
abstract: A Manhattan jury found that he had falsified business records to conceal a sex scandal that could have hindered his 2016 campaign for the White House.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was convicted on Thursday of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign, capping an extraordinary trial that tested the resilience of the American justice system and transformed the former commander in chief into a felon.

headline: Friday Briefing: Trump is found guilty on all counts
abstract: Plus, the U.S. will let Ukraine use American weapons to strike inside Russia
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has been convicted of all 34 felony counts in a criminal case stemming from a hush-money payment to a porn star on the eve of the 2016 election. He is the first American president to be declared a felon, a stain he will carry as he seeks to regain the presidency.

headline: Trump Can Proceed With Lawsuit Against His Niece, Court Rules
abstract: The case concerns Mary L. Trump’s disclosure of financial documents to a team of reporters at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump can proceed with a lawsuit against Mary L. Trump, his estranged niece, over her role as a source for a New York Times investigation into Mr. Trump’s finances, a New York State appeals court said on Thursday.

headline: Trump’s Guilty Verdict May Be a Political Accelerant
abstract: He has spent much of his lifetime and all of his political career preparing for a chapter like this.
lead_paragraph: The first former American president to be put on trial is now the first former American president to be convicted of a felony. Those milestones should be tombstones. A normal mortal doesn’t rise from that political grave.

headline: U.S. Accuses Hyundai and Two Other Companies of Using Child Labor
abstract: The Labor Department filed a lawsuit accusing Hyundai, one of its suppliers and a staffing company of jointly employing a 13-year-old on an auto body parts assembly line in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: The Labor Department on Thursday sued Hyundai over the use of child labor in Alabama, holding the car manufacturer liable for the employment of children in its supply chain, including a 13-year-old girl who worked up to 60 hours per week making car parts.

headline: How A.I. Has Changed Music, and What’s Coming Next
abstract: Artificial intelligence has become the dominant disrupter to music creation and distribution. And it’s only getting started.
lead_paragraph: Whether you know it or not, you’ve likely encountered A.I. — artificial intelligence — in your music consumption over the past year. Maybe it was Ghostwriter releasing a song with a fake “Drake” and “the Weeknd” in collaboration that took over the internet last year. Or maybe it was Drake himself rapping as “Tupac” and “Snoop Dogg” during the recent Kendrick Lamar beef. Or maybe it was a new track by the country superstar Randy Travis, who suffered a stroke in 2013, and hasn’t sung a song since.

headline: Trump Is Guilty on All Counts
abstract: Also, Biden will allow Ukraine to use U.S. weapons in Russia. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump was convicted today of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign. He is the first American president to be declared a felon.

headline: DNA From a Discarded Fork Leads to Arrest in Brutal Cold-Case Murder
abstract: A 41-year-old Florida man has been charged in the 2009 stabbing death of his uncle in Queens.
lead_paragraph: This February, Anthony Scalici discarded a fork in Florida. Detectives from New York and Florida had been watching him for weeks, waiting for a chance to get a sample of his DNA.

headline: Slovak Prime Minister Leaves Hospital 2 Weeks After Assassination Attempt
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Fico had been shot during a meeting with supporters. The hospital’s director told a TV station Mr. Fico could continue treatment at home.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after being shot and seriously wounded in an assassination attempt, Prime Minister Robert Fico of Slovakia was released from the hospital on Thursday and taken to his home in Bratislava, the capital.

headline: Elon Musk’s X to Host Election Town Hall With Donald Trump
abstract: The social media platform will produce video town halls with Mr. Trump and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., extending its push into politics.
lead_paragraph: X, the social media service owned by Elon Musk, will host live video town halls with former President Donald J. Trump and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in the run-up to the U.S. presidential election, a major push into politics, according to a person familiar with the plans.

headline: Trump Cites Litany of Misleading Claims After the Verdict
abstract: Some of Donald J. Trump’s assertions lacked evidence. Others were merely exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after former President Donald J. Trump was convicted on Thursday, he delivered remarks in the courtroom hallway, insisting that the true verdict would come at the polls in November and repeating a number of inaccurate assertions about the case.

headline: Trump’s G.O.P. Allies Assail His Guilty Verdict and Warn It Will Backfire
abstract: Republicans urged the former president to appeal the verdict after a jury found him guilty of all 34 criminal counts.
lead_paragraph: The Republican allies of former President Donald J. Trump wasted no time in blasting the guilty verdict returned by a New York jury on Thursday and in imploring him to appeal, repeatedly turning to words like “travesty” and “injustice” to describe the moment.

headline: After Conviction, Trump Says ‘Real Verdict’ Will Come in November
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump, speaking in the courthouse hallway, repeated his unfounded claims that the case was an attempt to interfere with his White House bid, and insisted he was innocent.
lead_paragraph: Moments after becoming the first former president to be convicted of a felony, Donald J. Trump walked out of the courtroom, strode toward a television camera and declared the legal system that had found him guilty — a system that presidents are sworn to uphold — a sham.

headline: This Is What It Was Like Inside the Courtroom When the Trump Verdict Was Read
abstract: Late on the second day of deliberations, the judge returned to the courtroom with the announcement of a verdict.
lead_paragraph: It happened very quickly.

headline: What if This Is Our Last Real Election?
abstract: The stakes for our democracy should be obvious.
lead_paragraph: Some of the Americans protesting the war in Gaza have turned on President Biden. They assert that the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is killing huge numbers of civilians, which is true, and that Biden can stop it, which is more doubtful. But how do they deal with the reality that in a second term Donald Trump would be far more pro-Netanyahu and anti-Palestinian than our current president?

headline: The Trump Verdict: Americans React
abstract: Initial reactions nationwide to former President Donald J. Trump’s conviction on all 34 counts of falsifying business records.
lead_paragraph: Americans were still digesting the news on Thursday evening that Donald J. Trump, the Republican Party’s presumptive nominee, had just become the first former president to be found guilty of felony. But Mr. Trump’s conviction on 34 counts of falsifying business records to silence a porn star’s account of a sexual liaison with him was reverberating quickly.

headline: ‘Guilty,’ and History Is Made
abstract: A single word rings out in a Manhattan courtroom as Donald Trump becomes the first American president convicted of a crime.
lead_paragraph: “Guilty.”

headline: What Is Your Reaction to Trump’s Conviction on 34 Felony Counts?
abstract: Donald J. Trump is the first American president to be declared a felon, a stain he will carry as he seeks to regain the presidency.
lead_paragraph: Please note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our Student Opinion questions and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on nytimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only forum that explicitly invites the voices of young people.

headline: Trump’s Guilty Verdict Reverberates Through New York City, His Hometown
abstract: In the place where Donald J. Trump first made his name, reactions mirrored the nation’s: exultation and deflation. At Trump Tower, the defendant pumped his fist for a crowd of hundreds.
lead_paragraph: The news that Donald J. Trump had been found guilty on all 34 felony counts in a cover-up of a sex scandal spread in seconds from the Manhattan Criminal Courthouse, where the verdict was read, to the hundreds of people who were gathered outside.

headline: How Prosecutors Made the Case Against Trump
abstract: Over six weeks and the testimony of 20 witnesses, prosecutors wove a sprawling story of election interference and falsified business records.
lead_paragraph: For years, prosecutors debated, fought and even, in at least two cases, resigned over the fate of the Manhattan district attorney’s investigation into Donald J. Trump. Some legal experts predicted it would be the downfall of the district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg.

headline: ‘Ukraine Has Gone Through a Terrible Period’: A Q. and A. With Frederick and Kimberly Kagan
abstract: We’re at a crucial moment in the war.
lead_paragraph: We’re at a crucial moment in the Ukraine war. After Congress’s monthslong delay in approving additional American aid — and the failure of the Ukrainian counteroffensive last year — Ukraine finds itself on the defensive. Russia is advancing at a number of points on the front. I wanted to get an unvarnished evaluation of the military realities of the conflict, and for that I could think of few people better positioned to provide insight than Frederick and Kimberly Kagan.

headline: Read the Verdict Sheet in the Trump Manhattan Criminal Trial
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump was convicted on Thursday on all 34 counts of falsifying business records by a jury of 12 New Yorkers, who deliberated over two days.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump was convicted on Thursday on all 34 counts of falsifying business records by a jury of 12 New Yorkers, who deliberated over two days.

headline: Trump Verdict Gets Little Reaction From the White House
abstract: “We respect the rule of law,” a spokesman for the White House Counsel’s Office said after former President Donald J. Trump’s conviction in the hush-money case.
lead_paragraph: White House officials said little on Thursday after former President Donald J. Trump was convicted of falsifying records to cover up a scandal with a porn actress, becoming America’s first ex-president to be declared a felon.

headline: Trump Reacts to Guilty Verdict
abstract: Donald J. Trump was convicted on Thursday of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was convicted on Thursday of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Trump Had Good Fortune So Far With His Four Cases. Then Came a Verdict.
abstract: Until the jury’s decision on Thursday, the four criminal cases that threatened Donald Trump’s freedom were stumbling along, pleasing his advisers.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s run of luck in his criminal cases has expired.

headline: The Trump Conviction: How an 8-Year Reporting Trail Connected the Dots
abstract: As rumors circulated of Donald J. Trump’s reported infidelity, two accounts of women being paid to stay silent about their encounters became central to his indictment.
lead_paragraph: As the 2016 presidential election approached, reporters around the country chased the stories of a string of women who were speaking about unsavory encounters they said they had with Donald J. Trump. In the middle of this scrum, a different kind of tip came into The Wall Street Journal: a lawyer was arranging payoffs to silence other women from Mr. Trump’s past.

headline: Transcript of Trump Manhattan Trial, May 29, 2024
abstract: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Update on May 30: New York State’s court released transcripts from each day of the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted on 34 counts of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to derail his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Going Behind the Scenes of ‘Popcast (Deluxe)’
abstract: The weekly culture roundup show, hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, celebrates its first anniversary on May 31.
lead_paragraph: When you walk into the “Popcast (Deluxe)” recording studio on the second floor of the New York Times office in Manhattan, the first thing you notice is two colorful chairs in the center of the room with black microphones perched on the seat backs.

headline: Top Minnesota Democrats Call on State Senator Charged With Burglary to Resign
abstract: A Democratic state lawmaker was charged with burglary in April. Her fate could threaten a slim majority Democrats have in the Minnesota Senate.
lead_paragraph: After Minnesota Democrats took control of the State Legislature and the governor’s mansion in 2022, they passed a trove of legislation, including measures legalizing marijuana and expanding abortion rights, with the help of a mere one-seat majority in the Senate.

headline: Trump’s Campaign Donor Website Crashes After Guilty Verdict
abstract: Mr. Trump began soliciting donations off his felony conviction almost immediately after the verdict.
lead_paragraph: WinRed, the payment processor for Republican campaign donations, crashed after former President Donald J. Trump’s felony conviction, a technical issue that his campaign attributed to the number of people trying to donate in the immediate aftermath of the verdict.

headline: Inside the Courthouse Where Trump Was Convicted
abstract: A special report.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from our court reporter Jesse McKinley, who watched as former President Donald J. Trump was found guilty on all 34 felony counts.

headline: A Historic Verdict Made for Riveting TV. Then the Punditry Began.
abstract: Every major TV network broke in to daytime programming to present a rare moment of political and legal suspense.
lead_paragraph: At 5:06 p.m. on Thursday, shortly after NBC News broke in with a special report, Savannah Guthrie and Lester Holt told viewers that a verdict in the first criminal trial against an American president was imminent. After weeks of dramatic testimony that, with no cameras in the courtroom, made little impact on TV, the tension spilled onto the airwaves all at once.

headline: Hopeful Yet Cautious, Biden’s Team Aims to Exploit Trump’s Conviction
abstract: The verdict in Manhattan gave the president and his allies a new way to frame the race: a choice between someone who is a felon and someone who is not.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, President Biden has sought to cast the 2024 election not as a referendum on his four years in office but on whether voters want to return Donald J. Trump to office after a first term in which he undermined abortion rights, democracy and the rule of law.

headline: The Dark Rhetoric After Trump’s Conviction
abstract: The former president sought to weaponize the verdict to undermine trust in the justice system.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon, in a New York courtroom, Donald Trump wore a glum look on his face as a jury pronounced him guilty of 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, sitting slack as he became the first former president to ever be convicted of a crime.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Echoing Trump, Calls Manhattan Case Politically Motivated
abstract: The independent presidential candidate said he believed Mr. Trump’s conviction would only help the former president at the ballot box.
lead_paragraph: The independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. criticized the Manhattan district attorney’s prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump shortly after it ended in a conviction on Thursday, describing it as a politically motivated and “profoundly undemocratic” case that would only strengthen Mr. Trump’s support.

headline: Ex-President, Felon and Candidate: 5 Takeaways From Trump’s Conviction
abstract: Donald J. Trump will live the life of a New York convict until he is sentenced on July 11. He faces as long as four years in prison.
lead_paragraph: It was an end like no other for a trial like no other: a former American president found guilty of 34 felonies.

headline: Will It Matter? Searching for Clues in the Polls About a Trump Conviction.
abstract: He may not lose support at all, but recent backing from young and nonwhite voters might be likelier to fade.
lead_paragraph: For almost a decade, Donald J. Trump has done, said and survived things that would have doomed any other politician.

headline: The Jury That Convicted Donald Trump
abstract: They heard weeks of testimony in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial. Then the 12 New Yorkers who made up the jury stuck to the task at hand.
lead_paragraph: As the 12 jurors entered into the courtroom to deliver the verdict against Donald J. Trump, 11 of them looked ahead. But one looked in the direction of the defendant.

headline: ‘The Jury Has Spoken’: Manhattan D.A. Speaks After Trump Guilty Verdict
abstract: The district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, became the first prosecutor to bring a criminal case against a United States president. On Thursday, he won.
lead_paragraph: In February 2022, two months into his tenure, the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin L. Bragg, made a momentous decision: He would not pursue a criminal case against Donald J. Trump.

headline: Select All Images With Bicycles
abstract: Aidan Deshong captures our hearts with a lively yet accessible Friday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Convicted, Trump Blames Judge, Jury and a Country ‘Gone to Hell’
abstract: Moments after a jury found him guilty, Donald J. Trump worked his conviction into the story of persecution at the center of his presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty.

headline: 3 Killed, Including a Police Officer, in Minneapolis Shooting
abstract: The officer was responding to a call when he was ambushed by a gunman, who was later killed while exchanging gunfire with another officer.
lead_paragraph: A police officer was killed in a series of shootings on Thursday afternoon in Minneapolis that left two other people dead, including the gunman, city officials said. Three people were injured, including another police officer and a firefighter.

headline: Trump Guilty on All Counts in Hush-Money Case
abstract: Donald J. Trump was convicted on 34 felony counts of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened his ascent to the White House in 2016. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was convicted on 34 felony counts of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal that threatened his ascent to the White House in 2016. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives his takeaways.

headline: A fast-paced spell-off capped the night: Takeaways from the spelling bee.
abstract: Bruhat Soma overcame Faizan Zaki, spelling a series of words at lighting speeds, in their tiebreaking round to secure the Scripps Bee trophy.
lead_paragraph: The Scripps National Spelling Bee on Thursday came down to its second-ever spell-off, a fast-and-furious tiebreaking round that rewards speed as much as accuracy. Given 90 seconds to spell as many of the announced words as possible, Bruhat Soma and Faizan Zaki, the two remaining spellers after 14 rounds, stood tense over a blue buzzer as they flew through words difficult to comprehend even at conversational speed.

headline: A 7th Grader’s Electric Tiebreaking Performance Earns Spelling Bee Championship
abstract: Bruhat Soma spelled a stunning 29 words correctly in a 90-second spell-off to win the Scripps National Spelling Bee.
lead_paragraph: It was only the second spell-off in the history of the Scripps National Spelling Bee, and Bruhat Soma rattled off a head-spinning 29 correctly spelled words in 90 seconds, including heautophany, nachschläge and puszta.

headline: Quote of the Day: 14 Convicted of Subversion in Hong Kong
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Almost all of them are seeing their own lives being put on hold — these are some of the best and brightest of Hong Kong, all of whom have seen their careers cut short as they endure month after month behind bars.”

headline: Wall Street Lands on India, Looking for Profits It Can’t Find in China
abstract: Stock markets in Mumbai have surged as big global investors hope India can become a source of growth. It won’t be so easy.
lead_paragraph: Mumbai, India’s financial capital, has seen a lot of new faces over the past year. The heads of global banks have been trooping through, visiting its stock exchanges, buying property and hiring new staff.

headline: A Match Made in Church Sparks a Journey of Self-Discovery
abstract: Jonathan Stewart was dating a woman and grappling with his sexuality when he met Enrico Lagasca. Mr. Lagasca, who developed a crush on him, was surprised to learn that Mr. Stewart felt the same way.
lead_paragraph: On a weekend evening in April 2016, Jonathan Runge Stewart came home to his apartment in Manhattan’s West Village from a first date with Enrico Lagasca, elated, his adrenaline running high.

headline: They Swiped and Immediately ‘Clicked’
abstract: Dolly Meckler said that she and Jordan Cohen got along right away because they “speak the same language.” Both work in social media and connected nearly four years ago on a dating app.
lead_paragraph: The main character at Dolly Lana Meckler’s wedding was probably her dress: a theatrical, reconstructed Pucci gown that was more than two years in the making.

headline: When ‘Girlfriend’ Just Isn’t Enough
abstract: Jen Tullock and Marie Ronn met through a dating app, but didn’t start dating until months later when they saw each other at a film premiere.
lead_paragraph: In November 2022, Jennifer Leigh Tullock was at the film premiere for “Spirited,” which she had a role in, when Marie Lenia Ronn tapped her on the shoulder.

headline: Discovering ‘This Was a Forever Romance’
abstract: Once Timothy Murray landed a date with Michael Bullard, the two were inseparable — except when they were separated by their work as actors.
lead_paragraph: Despite his best efforts, Timothy Raymond Murray could not get Michael Alexander Hoy Bullard to give him the time of day — that is, until a mutual friend intervened.

headline: An Engagement Ring, but No Fiancé
abstract: The origin of the word betrothed is “truth,” but my ring was a lie.
lead_paragraph: I was flying from Boston, where I grew up, back to Michigan, where I had moved five years earlier to live with my boyfriend, Steve. As I reached for a packet of pretzels from the flight attendant, she grabbed my left hand and said, “Oh, your ring is beautiful. Are you engaged?”

headline: Corrections: May 31, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, May 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about Israel’s continued assault on Rafah despite fierce condemnation misstated the population of Rafah before the war. It was between 200,000 and 300,000, not close to one million.

headline: OPEC to Meet Amid Signs of Waning Influence on Oil Prices
abstract: Major producers, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, are set to gather virtually on Sunday. They are expected to maintain production cuts amid signs of a softening market.
lead_paragraph: When officials from many of the world’s biggest oil-producing countries meet on Sunday, their menu of options for managing the market may be limited.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Good morning. We’re covering the verdict in Donald Trump’s criminal trial and U.S. permission for Ukraine to use American weapons inside Russia.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has been convicted of all 34 felony counts in a criminal case stemming from a hush-money payment to a porn star on the eve of the 2016 election. He is the first American president to be declared a felon, a stain he will carry as he seeks to regain the presidency.

headline: The Dizzying Rise and Damp, Deflated End of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak
abstract: “Now is the moment for Britain to choose its future,” Rishi Sunak told an indifferent nation as water soaked into his suit.
lead_paragraph: Last week a visibly cold Rishi Sunak stood in front of No. 10 Downing Street in a downpour to announce the date of the general election — July 4, months earlier than expected — to an indifferent nation. “Now is the moment for Britain to choose its future,” Mr. Sunak said, as water soaked into his suit.

headline: Why I Love the Sydney Opera House
abstract: The art is accessible, the attendees cut across the social spectrum and the architecture beguiles.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, as I stood in line at the Sydney Opera House for an event in the concert hall with Amy Poehler tied to the new movie “Inside Out 2,” I looked around at the large crowd.

headline: Word of the Day: strenuous
abstract: This word has appeared in 79 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word strenuous has appeared in 79 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 22 in “How Do You Paddle a Disappearing River?” by Daniel Modlin:

headline: From 700 A.D., a Pre-Viking Vessel Rises Into View
abstract: On the Norwegian island of Leka, archaeologists have unearthed the earliest known ship burial in Scandinavia.
lead_paragraph: For hundreds of years, Norwegians thought they knew who or what had been interred in an enormous barrow on the island of Leka, which is just off the country’s northern coast, facing the Atlantic Ocean. The grassy hillock is named for King Herlaug, a ninth-century Viking monarch who, if the Norse folklore is to be believed, had himself and 11 companions buried alive rather than face certain defeat by a rival ruler.

headline: U.S. and Chinese Defense Chiefs Hold First In-Person Talks Since 2022
abstract: Lloyd J. Austin III met his Chinese counterpart as both countries try to show they can manage their disputes over Taiwan and the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. secretary of defense, Lloyd J. Austin III, and China’s minister of defense held their first face-to-face talks in 18 months on Friday, exploring tentative steps to manage military tensions despite their opposing positions on Taiwan, the South China Sea and other disputes.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
